Journals.Outcome Statement: Tea Garden workers adopt alternative livelihoods options, preferably, in the formal economy, with access to industry linkages, financial resources, and support systems, thus reducing their dependence on tea-gardens as their only source of income.
Journals.Why is this observation of change notewo: There is a risk that tea gardens may close, leading to potential job losses at any time. Additionally, the low wages in tea gardens make it difficult for workers to manage household expenses.
Journals.What do you think has contributed to thi: Mobilization Efforts:  Conducting various community engagement activities and working with local stakeholders (community leaders, Aanganwadi/ASHA workers, parents) to spread awareness about vocational education Training Activities:  Hybrid skilling program combining digital content, video calls, and hands-on practical training. Level 1 (Awareness): 2-7 days of self-learning courses about the trade. Level 2 (Foundation Skills): 15-25 days of virtual/in-person instructor-led training sessions. Level 3 (Hands-on Skills): 20-30 days of practical training at Pratham centers, industry partners, or community-based Ustaad spaces  Placement Efforts: Mapping trainees to preferred job opportunities Preparing students for job interviews including focused counseling for joining the workforce Building and leveraging relationships with 7000+ industry partners across India  Post-Placement Efforts:  Phone interviews with alumni at every 3-month interval for up to a year post-placement. Addressing employment-related issues and facilitating job retention and multiple placement support for unemployed individuals. Formation of regional alumni chapters and engagement through yearly in-person alumni events Implementation on alumni engagement on Instagram through a dedicated handle Operation of a toll-free helpline for alumni support  (10am-7 pm on working days)

Journals.What did they do different? What was the: Change in Behavior:Proactive Outreach: These youth transitioned from being passive participants to active advocates for the vocational program. Increased Confidence and Leadership: By referring others, these youth displayed increased confidence in their own decisions and abilities. Journals.Outcome Statement: Youth role models emerge within each community, inspiring and motivating others to pursue vocational-led employment pathways, thereby fostering a culture of skill development and sustainable livelihoods.
Journals.Why is this observation of change notewo: Catalyst for Positive Social Change: These role models serve as living proof that vocational-led employment is not only a viable option but also a path to success. Their achievements break down societal stigmas associated with vocational training, encouraging more youth to consider these pathways.  Ripple Effect in the Community: As these role models inspire others, a ripple effect is created. More youth are likely to pursue vocational training, which leads to higher employment rates, reduced poverty, and overall economic upliftment within the community.  Building a Culture of Skill Development: The presence of role models fosters a culture where skill development and lifelong learning are valued. This cultural shift is critical for sustainable development, as it encourages continuous improvement, adaptability, and resilience in the workforce.  Alignment with Sustainable Livelihoods: By promoting vocational-led employment, this change directly supports the goal of sustainable livelihoods. It reduces dependency on unstable or informal employment and helps build a more robust and diverse local economy.  Long-Term Impact on Future Generations: The influence of these youth role models is likely to extend to future generations. Younger children and adolescents in the community will grow up with the mindset that vocational training and employment are respectable and achievable goals, setting a positive precedent for years to come.
Journals.What do you think has contributed to thi: Community Engagement: By actively involving the community in program activities, the program has created a supportive environment that celebrates the success of youth who choose vocational pathways, encouraging others to follow suit.  Visibility of Success Stories: The program has highlighted the achievements of these youth role models through local events, social media, making their success stories widely known and inspirational to others.  Alumni Experience Sharing: Alumni members have had a positive experiece in the program and have widely shared their experience within their friends and family networks.

Journals.Why is this observation of change notewo: A permanent worker, suffered from severe malnutrition after 7 years of closure of the tea garden. Madhu Tea garden was reopened after 7 years of closure on December 27, 2021. The deceased, was unable to work due to frequent seizures even after the garden re-opened. With no source of income, and the Government’s ₹1,500 dole of FAWLOI (Financial Assistance to the Workers of Locked Out Industries) stopping after re-opening, the tea worker and his wife, who is his sole family member, were reduced to begging from their neighbours for food. After death of the tea worker, it was observed that the deceased wife was severely malnourished with a BMI of 12 kg/m2. The team further observed that despite being Antodaya Anna Yojana Card-holders, the deceased and his wife were deprived of basic amenities.
Journals.What do you think has contributed to thi: Through community meetings and discussions, the team understood grievance in accessing ration under the AAY scheme. The team reached out to local Ration Dealer, Food Inspector, Assistant Provident Fund (PF) Commissioner, Tea Garden Manager of Madhu Tea Garden, Assistant Labour Commissioner, Joint BDO and ADM (L&R) and each of such authorities was provided with written representations in this regard. Subsequently, 48 kgs of food grains along with some other General Reliefs were given to the widow and she was taken for admission to the local PHC by the State Government, later on she was released after her condition became stable.

Journals.Outcome Statement: The government strengthens its systems and enables improved access to government schemes and benefits for the tea garden workers.
Journals.Why is this observation of change notewo: Dheklapara Tea Garden is one of the closed tea gardens in North Bengal. It has been in such a comatose condition for a number of years, and since its closure its workers had been getting the benefits under Financial Assistance to Workers of Locked Out Industries scheme of the Government of West Bengal (FAWLOI). But recently the said Tea Garden was reopened illegally, and the benefits under FAWLOI stopped.
Journals.What do you think has contributed to thi: Our grantee made consistent efforts to advocate for the reinstatement of Financial Assistance to the Workers of Locked Out Industries (FAWLOI) benefits in the Dheklapara Tea Garden. Following their written representation against the halting of FAWLOI benefits, the state government reintegrated 288 workers into the scheme. Despite initial delays in disbursal, our grantee is actively engaging with the Assistant Labour Commissioner to expedite benefit distribution. We remain committed to ensuring all eligible workers receive their entitlements promptly, continuing to monitor and support the process closely.
Journals.Include links to any additional document: Receipt of payments in the bank accounts of beneficiaries from the scheme.

Journals.Outcome Statement: Tea garden workers demand their rights and access benefits from public, private and civil society organisations. They register their grievances on non-realisation or non-receipt of rights, benefits and entitlement and raise their voice.
Journals.Why is this observation of change notewo: Despite existing laws and welfare schemes for the benefit of tea workers, workers face challenges in accessing essential services and claiming their entitlements in crucial areas such as maternal and sexual health, food security, sanitation, and access to their basic rights. With a majority of the workers being women, the impact of poor access to socio-economic entitlements on maternal health and nutrition have a far-reaching impact on the welfare of women and families. The historical marginalisation of workers, the remoteness of tea plantations, limited presence of healthcare infrastructure, and a dearth of knowledge amongst workers about protective provisions and entitlements has exacerbated the situation.

Journals.What did they do different? What was the: 17,291 community members repeatedly participated in conversations to understand disaster risk, consequences and interconnection. This led to following change:  (i) Earlier,  according to community people, the loss of land/asset, livelihoods etc. are the major impacts of disaster. They were unable to see how the children are affecting by the recurrent disasters. However, now they could articulate how their coping mechansims (like migration, more involvement of women at work etc.) are affecting children in the form of being out of school, poorly supervised etc.  (ii) Community people are also sharing that the child labour has increased in couple of years to combat with disaster-driven finanical hurdles.  (iii) They can now identify that children being out-of-school or irregular at schools is the early sign which may lead to various serious child harms in later stage.
Journals.Where did it happen? (Eg. Village / blo: 70 GPs across 8 blocks in N24P and 79 GPs across 8 blocks in S24P
Journals.Outcome Statement: The awareness of community on disaster risk, consequences, interconnection between disaster impacts and child harms is increasing
Journals.Why is this observation of change notewo: Nascent
Journals.What do you think has contributed to thi: The observation is noteworthy because the people's view on impact of disasters has started to change. They started to recognize and understand how the child is being pushed towards risk due to recurrent disaster events. This change in articulation will obviously the first step of work towards making child safe.
Journals.Include links to any additional document: Aangan/partner team held series of conversations with the community adults.  The community members have reached multiple times. It has also included briefing using real life examples to increase understanding about the risks of harm.

Journals.What did they do different? What was the: Community women come together in group and engaged in the following activities: (a) Identification of vulnerable (with regrad to child harm) hamlets/tolas within their GP, (b) Identification of children who are dropped out from school or irregular at schools. Based on this identification, they have prepared a list of locations and children. They went to GP to meet Pradhan and other members with this list. The women has shared this data with GP members and requested for action so that these identified children can be enrolled/regularized at school.

Journals.Outcome Statement: Communities started to identify various child risk in the community, shared such information with local govt. and requested for solution to protect children.
Journals.Why is this observation of change notewo: Nascent
Journals.What do you think has contributed to thi: Community has started taking ownership of the issues specific to child protection in their communities and are taking the same to the local government for solutions.

Journals.What did they do different? What was the: Change in Practice-  Cooking rice with appropriate amount of water so that they do not need to strain excess water afterwards.
Journals.When did it happen? (Should be after pr: It was reported in the FGD conducted in the area on 25.06.24 and written feedbacks from the Key community members.
Journals.Where did it happen? (Eg. Village / blo: Lahiripur Panchayat, Gosaba block. The audio recording shared as evidence is from the FGD conducted at  Sadhupur Banikhali village of the Panchayat
Journals.Outcome Statement: The women in the household are using appropriate amount of water while cooking rice so that they do not need to strain the excess water afterwards. This practice maintains the levels micronutrient in the cooked rice and is recommended in "Dietary Guidelines for Indians" published by National Institute of Nutrition (NIN) in 2024.
Journals.Why is this observation of change notewo: The conventional way of cooking led to loss of micronutrient like vitamin B complex and Zinc in rice. These micronutrient helps in maintaining immune system of the body. These families consume rice 2-4 times a day.  Thus, altering the rice rinsing and boiling method allows the family to get more micronutrients that will result in resistance to infections in general.
Journals.What do you think has contributed to thi: Training of paranutritionists.  Household visits and advocacy by the trained paranutritionists on rice preparation. Street plays performed by the community task force members (CTF*) including paranutritionists. Many of the older village members informed that the practice of using less water for boiling rice was present in the community, but got lost in the subsequent generations. Thus it was easier to restore the practice.

Journals.What did they do different? What was the: Change in Practice- storing dietary salt in close-lid bottles.
Journals.When did it happen? (Should be after pr: The first evidence was reported by paranutritionists after their household advocacy in June 2024. Evidence was collected on 25.06 2024.
Journals.Where did it happen? (Eg. Village / blo: Lahiripur Panchayat, Gosaba block. The audio recording shared as evidence is from the FGD conducted at Sadhupur Banikhali village of the Panchayat.
Journals.Outcome Statement: The women in the household are storing their dietary salt in bottles with lids. This ensures that the iodine in their salt is preserved and the family gets regular dose of dietary iodine.
Journals.Why is this observation of change notewo: Lack of Iodine in diet often leads to thyroid malfunction and thyroid related diseases. As thyroid hormones are major metabolic regulators of the body, their imbalance can trigger various non-communicable diseases like cardiac arrhythmea. Maintaining Iodine in diet, through storing the dietaray salt in the lidded bottle as well as adding salt to cooked food after turning the heat off, results in better Iodine availability and reduces chances of thyroid related  lifestyle disease.
Journals.What do you think has contributed to thi: Training of paranutritionists. Household visits and advocacy on optimum Iodine utilization by the trained paranutritionists. Street plays performed by the community task force members (CTF*) including paranutritionists on how to preserve and use dietary salt to ensure Iodine availability in the diet.

Journals.What did they do different? What was the: Change in Practice- reduction in cooking oil use. (This change is not reported from all household interviewed)
Journals.When did it happen? (Should be after pr: It was reported in the FGD conducted in the area on 25.06.24
Journals.Where did it happen? (Eg. Village / blo: Lahiripur Panchayat, Gosaba block. The audio recording shared as evidence is from the FGD conducted at Sadhupur Banikhali village of the Panchayat.
Journals.Outcome Statement: Some households from the village are trying to reduce the daily cooking oil use by 50%. Though the reduction is well above the dietary needs recommended by NIN, the women reported abrupt reduction is not possible, and are focussing on gradual reduction.
Journals.Why is this observation of change notewo: The households used 2-3x the NIN recommended dietary fat/oil for cooking. Decrease in that will lead to balanced diet. Many household reported reduction of cooking oil has led to less incidence of acid reflux and flatulence among them. Moreover high dietary oil (mainly mustard oil) has potential of atherosclerosis, which can lead to serious cardiac issues. Reduction of cooking oil will potentially reduce cardiac problems.
Journals.What do you think has contributed to thi: Training of paranutritionists.  Household visits and advocacy on optimum cooking oil utilization by the trained paranutritionists. Messsaging through "Health Festival" platform and subsequent community meetings where eminent hepatologist called to reduce cooking oil use.

Journals.What did they do different? What was the: Adapting New practice - Preparing ORS at home according to WHO recommended formulation
Journals.When did it happen? (Should be after pr: It was first reported by trained paranutritionists in mid-June meeting. Evidence was collected on 25.06.24.
Journals.Where did it happen? (Eg. Village / blo: Lahiripur Panchayat, Gosaba block.
Journals.Outcome Statement: The community learnt about the composition of ORS, which they easily prepared at home and used for rehydration during the summer .
Journals.Why is this observation of change notewo: This summer the temperature reached 50C in the Sundarban area and there were reports of dehydration and sun stroke. The young generation is tempted to go for cold beverages that often lead to further dehydration. The knowledge that ORS can be prepared simply and without any extra resources, helped the community to maintain their hydration during tough summer months.
Journals.What do you think has contributed to thi: Extreme heat conditions this summer.   Training of paranutritionists.  Street plays performed by the community task force members (CTF*)  that showed how to prepare ORS with requisite amout of salt and sugar. Advocacy by ASHA on ORS preparation to avoid dehydration / attend diarrheal situation.

Journals.What did they do different? What was the: Behavioural change- Hand wash practices during cooking and serving food
Journals.When did it happen? (Should be after pr: It was reported in the FGD conducted in the area on 25.06.24
Journals.Where did it happen? (Eg. Village / blo: Lahiripur Panchayat, Gosaba block. The audio recording shared as evidence is from the FGD conducted at Sadhupur Banikhali village of the Panchayat.
Journals.Outcome Statement: The women in the households are washing hands with soap before food preparation and serving food.
Journals.Why is this observation of change notewo: Though handwash was practiced in the community, our baseline surveys indicated necessity of washing hands with soap before food preparation and serving was not given importance. These practices led to clinical  and subclinical gastro-intestinal infection, especially among children. The new practice will lead to better hygeine.
Journals.What do you think has contributed to thi: Continuous awareness, leaflet distribution, advocacy program by CTF trained by Liver Foundation.

Journals.Outcome Statement: The village community can differentiate between types of burn, and can take action in case of 1st degree and 2nd degree burn cases
Journals.Why is this observation of change notewo: Villagers often encounter 1st/ 2nd degree burns in the community. Traditionally they would have used household remedies, that often led to infection in the burn site. Through trained informal healthcare providers, the villagers learned about the degrees of burn and how to respond to them. This will help in reducing burn related wounds and infection in the vilage community.

Journals.Outcome Statement: The women in the household are using appropriate amount of water while cooking rice so that they do not need to strain the excess water afterwards. This practice maintains the levels micronutrient in the cooked rice and is recommended in "Dietary Guidelines for Indians" published by National Institute of Nutrition (NIN) in 2024.
Journals.Why is this observation of change notewo: The conventional way of cooking led to loss of micronutrient like vitamin B complex and Zinc in rice. These micronutrient helps in maintaining immune system of the body. These families consume rice 2-4 times a day.  Thus, altering the rice rinsing and boiling method allows the family to get more micronutrients that will result in resistance to infections in general.
Journals.What do you think has contributed to thi: Training of paranutritionists.  Household visits and advocacy by the trained paranutritionists on rice preparation. Street plays performed by the community task force members (CTF*) including paranutritionists. Many of the older village members informed that the practice of using less water for boiling rice was present in the community, but got lost in the subsequent generations. Thus it was easier to restore the practice.

Journals.What did they do different? What was the: Change in Practice- storing dietary salt in close-lid bottles.
Journals.When did it happen? (Should be after pr: The first evidence was reported by paranutritionists after their household advocacy in April 2024. Evidence was collected on 24.07.24.
Journals.Where did it happen? (Eg. Village / blo: Rangabelia Panchayat, Gosaba block. The audio recording shared as evidence is from the FGD conducted at Bagbagan village of the Panchayat.
Journals.Outcome Statement: The women in the household are storing their dietary salt in bottles with lids. This ensures that the iodine in their salt is preserved and the family gets regular dose of dietary iodine.
Journals.Why is this observation of change notewo: Lack of Iodine in diet often leads to thyroid malfunction and thyroid related diseases. As thyroid hormones are major metabolic regulators of the body, their imbalance can trigger various non-communicable diseases like cardiac arrhythmea. Maintaining Iodine in diet, through storing the dietaray salt in the lidded bottle as well as adding salt to cooked food after turning the heat off, results in better Iodine availability and reduces chances of thyroid related  lifestyle disease.
Journals.What do you think has contributed to thi: Training of paranutritionists.  Household visits and advocacy on optimum Iodine utilization by the trained paranutritionists. Street plays performed by the community task force members (CTF*) including paranutritionists on how to preserve and use dietary salt to ensure Iodine availability in the diet.

Journals.What did they do different? What was the: Change in Practice- reduction in cooking oil use. (This change is not reported from all household interviewed)
Journals.When did it happen? (Should be after pr: It was reported in the FGD conducted in the area on 24.07.24
Journals.Where did it happen? (Eg. Village / blo: Rangabelia Panchayat, Gosaba block. The audio recording shared as evidence is from the FGD conducted at Bagbagan village of the Panchayat.
Journals.Outcome Statement: Some households from the village are trying to reduce the daily cooking oil use by 50%. Though the reduction is well above the dietary needs recommended by NIN, the women reported abrupt reduction is not possible, and are focussing on gradual reduction.
Journals.Why is this observation of change notewo: The households used 2-3x the NIN recommended dietary fat/oil for cooking. Decrease in that will lead to balanced diet. Many household reported reduction of cooking oil has led to less incidence of acid reflux and flatulence among them. Moreover high dietary oil (mainly mustard oil) has potential of atherosclerosis, which can lead to serious cardiac issues. Reduction of cooking oil will potentially reduce cardiac problems.
Journals.What do you think has contributed to thi: Training of paranutritionists.  Household visits and advocacy on optimum cooking oil utilization by the trained paranutritionists. Messsaging through "Health Festival" platform and subsequent community meetings where eminent hepatologist called to reduce cooking oil use.

Journals.What did they do different? What was the: Adapting New practice - Preparing ORS at home according to WHO recommended formulation
Journals.When did it happen? (Should be after pr: It was first reported by trained paranutritionists after their household advocacy in April, 24. Evidence was collected on 24.07.24.
Journals.Where did it happen? (Eg. Village / blo: Rangabelia Panchayat, Gosaba block.
Journals.Outcome Statement: The community learnt about the composition of ORS, which they easily prepared at home and used for rehydration during the summer .
Journals.Why is this observation of change notewo: This summer the temperature reached 50C in the Sundarban area and there were reports of dehydration and sun stroke. The young generation is tempted to go for cold beverages that often lead to further dehydration. The knowledge that ORS can be prepared simply and without any extra resources, helped the community to maintain their hydration during tough summer months.
Journals.What do you think has contributed to thi: Extreme heat conditions this summer. Training of paranutritionists.   Street plays performed by the community task force members (CTF*)  that showed how to prepare ORS with requisite amout of salt and sugar. Advocacy by ASHA on ORS preparation to avoid dehydration / attend diarrheal situation.

Journals.What did they do different? What was the: Behavioural change- Hand wash practices during cooking and serving food
Journals.When did it happen? (Should be after pr: It was reported in the FGD conducted in the area on 24.07.24
Journals.Where did it happen? (Eg. Village / blo: Rangabelia Panchayat, Gosaba block. The audio recording shared as evidence is from the FGD conducted at Bagbagan village of the Panchayat.
Journals.Outcome Statement: The women in the households are washing hands with soap before food preparation and serving food.
Journals.Why is this observation of change notewo: Though handwash was practiced in the community, our baseline surveys indicated necessity of washing hands with soap before food preparation and serving was not given importance. These practices led to clinical  and subclinical gastro-intestinal infection, especially among children. The new practice will lead to better hygeine.
Journals.What do you think has contributed to thi: Training of paranutritionists. Continuous awareness, advocacy program by CTF trained by Liver Foundation.

Journals.Outcome Statement: The village community can differentiate between types of burn, and can take action in case of 1st degree and 2nd degree burn cases
Journals.Why is this observation of change notewo: Villagers often encounter 1st/ 2nd degree burns in the community. Through trained informal healthcare providers, the villagers learned about the degrees of burn and how to respond to them. This will help in reducing burn related wounds and infection in the vilage community.

Journals.What did they do different? What was the: They collectively identified the most significant issue in their village and started a research to understand the root causes of that issue.   To continue this research they also took collective initiative to engage with relevant stakeholders .          Women members of the group actively participated in the process of evidence geneation and data analysis for the first time. Adolescent members in this group also actively participated in the evidence gereration process . The PAR group has 25 core members where 17women, 4 men and 4 adolescents              ( Mass petition was submitted to the BDO by the PAR members                    After this intervention,  the local Panchayat(from Zilla Parisad fund)  initiated  the river embankment reparing  work from August 2024.  To protect the river embankment,  a natural solution was proposed that is the installation of bamboo wave crasher to the BDO in May-June 2024 ) and between May end to June 1st week, multiple bamboo wave crushers have been installed near "Amirer kheya ghat" by the Block (in front of one of the  vulnerable parts of the embankment near Kuemuri area)

Journals.Why is this observation of change notewo: This kind of community research initiative is entirely a new idea to the community,  The process not only helped the community to understand the issue also it helped to build skill to analyse the collected data , this process also helped them to plan the initiative, approach , how to build strategy to enegage with relevant stakeholders, how the decision can be made based on collective opinion. Sundarbans Journal.Unnamed: 2: A total of 20 farmers' groups from 5 villages are practicing Climate Adaptive Natural Farming (CANF), disaster-resilient agriculture, and diversified farming. They have also adopted improved land-use processes to enhance agricultural sustainability and resilience.
Sundarbans Journal.Unnamed: 4: Purba Sripatinagar, Paschim Sripatinagar villages, Choto and Boro banashyamnagar and Satyadaspur villages
Sundarbans Journal.Unnamed: 5: During the Kharif and Rabi seasons (August 2024 to January 2025), 20 farmer groups from Purba Sripatinagar, Paschim Sripatinagar, Choto Banashyamnagar, Boro Banashyamnagar, and Satyadaspur villages have adopted and implemented climate-smart agricultural practices. They have transitioned to organic and mixed farming approaches on both their own lands and shared lands, demonstrating increased awareness and capacity to practice sustainable farming. This shift indicates a behavioral change towards climate resilience, reducing dependency on chemical inputs, and enhancing soil health and productivity.
Sundarbans Journal.Significance of change: This observation is significant because it reflects a tangible shift in farmers' behaviors and agricultural practices toward climate resilience. The adoption of climate-smart, organic, and mixed farming methods demonstrates: 1. Increased Awareness & Capacity – Farmers are actively applying sustainable farming techniques, showing that they understand the benefits of reducing chemical dependency and improving soil health. 2. Community-Led Adaptation – The shift is not limited to individual farmers but extends across 20 farmer groups, indicating collective action and peer learning. 3. Utilization of Shared Lands – The inclusion of hare (shared) lands suggests an expansion of sustainable farming beyond individual holdings, fostering resource optimization and cooperation. 4. Climate Resilience & Sustainability – By adopting organic and mixed practices, farmers are better prepared to handle climate variability, ensuring long-term food security and livelihood stability. This change aligns with the program’s vision of climate-resilient and sustainable agriculture by: • Strengthening Livelihoods – Encouraging diverse, eco-friendly agricultural practices contributes to income stability and food security. • Enhancing Environmental Sustainability – Reducing chemical use improves soil fertility, biodiversity, and water conservation. • Scaling Sustainable Solutions – The adoption by multiple farmer groups demonstrates the replication potential of climate-smart practices, paving the way for wider policy or practice shifts. • Empowering Local Communities – By equipping farmers with knowledge and skills, the initiative fosters community ownership of sustainable agricultural solutions. This observation signifies progress toward the program's broader goal—enhancing farmers' resilience against climate change while promoting sustainable agro-ecological transitions
Sundarbans Journal.Contributing Factors: Team members from 360 farmers conducted capacity-building programs, Chas Chakro, Kishan Pathshala, transect walks, and exposure visits, where they trained and learned from farmer group leaders on climate-smart practices. These initiatives enhanced farmers' knowledge and skills, encouraging the adoption of organic and mixed farming methods on their own and shared lands.

Sundarbans Journal.Unnamed: 5: In response to water congestion (waterlogging) in the village canal, all members took collective action to remove excess water from agricultural land by engaging with the local panchayat and para village committee. A significant contribution came from 23 women members from Sripatinagar village, demonstrating strong community-led efforts in addressing the issue. Additionally, the Sanjher Bati PAR Group in Purba Sripatinagar and Pather Sathi Women's Group in Paschim Sripatinagar played key roles in mobilizing local stakeholders, ensuring effective problem-solving at the community level within Achintyanagar G.P.. These initiatives highlight an improved collective decision-making process, local governance engagement, and climate resilience practices within the community.
Sundarbans Journal.Significance of change: This change is significant because it demonstrates community-led action and collective problem-solving in response to water congestion. Key reasons include: • Strengthened Local Governance – Engagement with the panchayat and para village committee shows increased community participation in decision-making. • Women's Leadership – The involvement of 23 women members highlights growing women's agency in local environmental management. • Disaster Resilience – Addressing water logging in agricultural land supports climate adaptation and food security by preventing crop damage. This aligns with the program’s vision of community empowerment and climate resilience by: • Promoting Collective Action – Encouraging group-led initiatives fosters long-term sustainability. • Enhancing Climate Adaptation – Water management efforts contribute to disaster preparedness and resilient farming. • Building Local Capacity – Strengthening community structures ensures sustainable solutions for environmental challenges.
Sundarbans Journal.Contributing Factors: The change was driven by community awareness, collective decision-making, and proactive engagement with local governance structures. Women’s participation and farmer group mobilization played a crucial role in taking action against water congestion. • Conducted capacity-building sessions on climate resilience and water management. • Facilitated community meetings, PRA exercises, and transect walks to identify waterlogging issues. • Strengthened women’s leadership through group mobilization and decision-making platforms. • Encouraged collaboration with the panchayat and para village committee, ensuring local governance support. • Organized farmer field schools and exposure visits to learn water management best practices. These efforts empowered the community to take collective action, improve disaster resilience, and strengthen local problem-solving mechanisms.

Fathers and family heads now seek and respect the opinions of women in children’s education-related decisions. Sundarbans Journal.Unnamed: 2: The budget for the GPDP in aspect to addressing on the issues of the child rights has been accepted and is being processed for implementation
Sundarbans Journal.Unnamed: 4: village level
Sundarbans Journal.Unnamed: 5: Outcome Statement:  The budget for the VLAP, focused on addressing child rights issues, has been accepted and is now in the process of implementation. This marks a significant step toward institutional commitment and resource allocation for child protection and welfare. With the approved funding, targeted interventions can be effectively executed, ensuring better safeguards, services, and support systems for children at risk.
Sundarbans Journal.Significance of change: This observation of change is noteworthy because it reflects a concrete commitment to child rights by securing resources for action. The acceptance and processing of the GPDP budget demonstrate institutional recognition of the issues raised, ensuring that child protection measures move from planning to implementation.  This aligns with the program vision of strengthening community-led child protection mechanisms and validates the theory of change that when communities, especially local structures like the Village-Level Child Protection Committee (VLCPC), are empowered with knowledge and resources, they can advocate effectively for children's rights. The VLCPC's role in identifying key child protection concerns, influencing the VLAP, and ensuring accountability has been crucial in this process, reinforcing the importance of grassroots participation in systemic change.
Sundarbans Journal.Contributing Factors: This change has been driven by advocacy efforts, capacity building, and community mobilization led by the program. The program has facilitated training sessions for the VLCPC, enabling them to identify child protection concerns and advocate for resource allocation. Additionally, stakeholder engagement meetings and technical support have strengthened the proposal and negotiation process for the VLAP budget. By equipping local committees with knowledge, tools, and a platform to voice concerns, the program has ensured that child rights issues are prioritized, leading to budget approval and steps toward implementation.

Tea Garden Journal.Unnamed: 2: Youth develop industry-relevant practical, theoretical, and soft skills, improving their employability across various sectors. This comprehensive training equips them with the knowledge and abilities needed to succeed in diverse professional environments and career paths.
Tea Garden Journal.Unnamed: 4: Training conducted in the center and provided placement in different parts of the country.
Tea Garden Journal.Unnamed: 5: Tea garden workers explore alternative livelihood options in the formal economy, supported by industry linkages, financial resources, and support systems, reducing their reliance on tea gardens as their primary source of income.
Tea Garden Journal.Significance of change: Tea gardens face the risk of closure, which could result in significant job losses and economic uncertainty for workers. Additionally, the low wages in tea gardens make it challenging for workers to meet their household expenses and basic needs, increasing their financial vulnerability.
Tea Garden Journal.Contributing Factors: Mobilization: Building awareness about vocational education through community engagement activities. Collaborating with local stakeholders, including community leaders, Aanganwadi/ASHA workers, and parents, to encourage youth participation in skilling programs.  Training:  Awareness: 2-7 days of self-learning courses introducing the trade. Foundation Skills: 15-25 days of virtual or in-person instructor-led training to develop core technical skills. Practical Skills: 20-30 days of hands-on training conducted at Pratham centers, industry partner locations, or community-based Ustaad spaces. This hybrid model combines digital content, video calls, and practical sessions.                                                                                     Placement: Connecting trainees to jobs, offering interview preparation, and leveraging a network of 7000+ industry partners.  Post-Placement: Regular follow-ups, job retention support, alumni networks, social media engagement, and a toll-free helpline (10 am-7 pm, weekdays).
Tea Garden Journal.Evidence: Enrollment Forms, MIS Data, Offer Letter for Placement

Tea Garden Journal.Unnamed: 2: They chose the alternative form of livelihood from traditionally followed livelihood practice i.e. working in Tea Garden as unskilled labour. They retrain in their jobs after placement.
Tea Garden Journal.Unnamed: 4: Family of the people living in tea garden
Tea Garden Journal.Unnamed: 5: The standarded of living improved due to financial stability earning after the placement. Shift from traditionally followed livelihood practice to skill oriented livelihood.
Tea Garden Journal.Significance of change: This observation is crucial as it highlights a positive shift in the socioeconomic status of youth and their families. Employment in the formal economy provides stable incomes, social security, healthcare, and career growth opportunities. This financial stability supports long-term planning, improves family livelihoods, and enhances the overall well-being of the community.
Tea Garden Journal.Contributing Factors: Youth Retention in Jobs

Tea Garden Journal.Description of Change: Youth from Schedule Tribe  and Schedule Caste
Tea Garden Journal.Unnamed: 2: They -changed from traditional way of livelihood working as Tea Garden Labour to skill based livelihood. This has developed the sence of empowerment among ST and SC community.
Tea Garden Journal.Unnamed: 4: Among Schedule Tribe and Schedule Caste
Tea Garden Journal.Unnamed: 5: The SC ST community in the tea garden has emarged with self-confidance and inspiring the youth from SC ST community.
Tea Garden Journal.Significance of change: Empowerment of Tribal Community: The centuries-old practice of bonded labor among the tribal community is gradually eroding as they recognize the importance of stepping out of their comfort zones. With a growing understanding of alternative livelihood opportunities, tribal and marginalized communities are embracing new pathways toward economic independence and social upliftment.
Tea Garden Journal.Contributing Factors: Providing opportunities to the youth belonging to Tribal Community.

Tea Garden Journal.Unnamed: 2: Change in Behavour: Youth shifted from passive participants to active promoters of the vocational program, sharing their experiences and encouraging peers to enroll and benefit from the training.  Improved Confidence & Leadership: By referring others, youth gained confidence in their decisions and emerged as informal leaders, guiding and motivating their peers toward better opportunities.
Tea Garden Journal.Unnamed: 5: Youth role models are emerging within each community, actively inspiring and encouraging others to explore vocational-led employment pathways. Their success stories highlight the value of skill development, motivating peers to pursue similar opportunities. By sharing their experiences, these role models foster a culture of learning, professional growth, and sustainable livelihoods, contributing to long-term community empowerment and economic resilience.
Tea Garden Journal.Significance of change: Catalyst for Social Change: Youth role models demonstrate that vocational-led employment is a viable path to success, breaking societal stigmas and encouraging more youth to pursue skill-based careers.  Community Ripple Effect: Their influence increases vocational training participation, leading to higher employment rates, reduced poverty, and economic growth.  Culture of Skill Development: These role models promote a culture of lifelong learning and skill development, fostering adaptability and workforce resilience.  Supporting Sustainable Livelihoods: Vocational-led employment reduces reliance on unstable jobs, strengthening the local economy and promoting sustainable livelihoods.  Impact on Future Generations: Youth role models inspire future generations to view vocational training as a respectable and achievable career path, shaping long-term community development.
Tea Garden Journal.Contributing Factors: Community Engagement: By actively involving the community in program activities, the program has created a supportive environment that celebrates the success of youth who choose vocational pathways, encouraging others to follow suit.  Visibility of Success Stories: The program has highlighted the achievements of these youth role models through local events, social media, making their success stories widely known and inspirational to others.  Alumni Experience Sharing: Alumni members have had a positive experiece in the program and have widely shared their experience within their friends and family networks.

Indigenous Communities Journal.What did they do different? What was the: Started agroecological practice, crop diversification, water resource development and nutritional security amoung male and female farmers.
Indigenous Communities Journal.Where did it happen? (Eg. Village / blo: 25 Project Village in Ranibandh Block, Bankura District
Indigenous Communities Journal.Outcome Statement: 1.        A total of 925 paddy farmers are adopting the System of Assured Rice Production (SARP) method across 977 bighas (326 acres) of land, with training provided on the use of bio-pesticides and bio-fertilizers. Additionally, 666 bighas of fallow land have been brought under cultivation with maize, black gram, and red gram. 2.        220 acres (662 bighas) of land were cultivated with mustard, benefiting 670 farmers, while 206 acres (619 bighas) of land were used for food crops (cereals and pulses), also benefiting 670 farmers. Furthermore, 69.33 acres (208 bighas) of land were cultivated to vegetable cultivation, benefiting 323 farmers, with crops including cabbage, tomato, and cauliflower. 3.        20 mobile vermicompost units were promoted, which will yield results, and 2 SMC structures were desilted and repaired. 4.        The dietary habits of the community are shifting, with 400 farmers now growing a variety of vegetables in their household yards, thereby enhancing food security at the household level. 5.        The transition to agroecological practices was facilitated through Farmer Field Schools and 51 demo plots, training 2,642 individuals on agroecological practices, crop-specific techniques, and crop diversification. Additionally, 2,462 farmers were trained in the preparation and application of Jeevamrutham, Neemastram, Agniastram, and Ganajeevamrutam, with 342 farmers actively using these methods.
Indigenous Communities Journal.Why is this observation of change notewo: In West Bengal Paddy is the main crop and use huge level of pesticide, farmers are now shifting towards crop diversification and chemical free farming. This is becoming possible because of the Tribal Farmers Service Centre/ CBO getting established and they are adopting and spreading awareness about the agro ecological practices to other farmers.
Indigenous Communities Journal.What do you think has contributed to thi: Input support and handholding support and training to farmers through demo plots and FFS have paved the way for this change. Motivating the communities through shramdan and financial contribution had resulted in communities owing of the project.
Indigenous Communities Journal.Include links to any additional document: Photographs of fields. Maintained crop production data in excel and registered.

MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Thematic Details: FPAI’s strategic priorities include reproductive health services, sexual rights advocacy, and policy engagement, with a focus on tracking service delivery through ECMIS and DHIS2.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Rationale for Maturity/Strength: FPAI has structured monitoring at the branch and HQ level, with MEL integrated into strategic planning. Decision-making is supported by monthly MEL reviews, ensuring data is utilized effectively (Transcript, 00:40:00). However, entitlement-based tracking is not consistently linked to service data, limiting advocacy MEL integration.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Current Challenges (Severity/Likelihood/: The non-standardized data formats across 44 branches make MEL data aggregation difficult, leading to inconsistencies in program impact analysis. Service-level MEL tracking is structured, but advocacy MEL tracking lacks standardized indicators (Transcript, 00:35:00). Government engagement outcomes are not systematically captured, making it difficult to assess policy influence.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Experience in Addressing Challenges: Monthly MEL review meetings are conducted, but lack of uniformity in reporting remains a concern. The branch-level MEL teams require training to improve integration of advocacy and entitlements into MEL reporting (Transcript, 00:40:00). FPAI has attempted advocacy data collection, but without a structured format, it remains difficult to measure long-term change.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Support Required: A structured review mechanism is needed to harmonize MEL data across branches. An improved tracking system for advocacy and policy engagement is required to link MEL data with rights-based programming. Entitlements data should be integrated into existing ECMIS and DHIS2 systems.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Support Possible: CMS can provide standardized review templates, train teams on entitlement tracking, and support the development of an advocacy-focused MEL framework. MEL teams require training on process indicators to track government engagement systematically.
MEL System Maturity and Support Assessme.Key Requirements/Goals: Strengthening data standardization across all 44 branches. Ensuring MEL captures both service delivery and advocacy impacts. Developing a clear framework to integrate advocacy MEL indicators with service-level data.

PR_Association_for_Indias_Development_St.Purpose::
Purpose: To support Indigenous communities from 200 villages across four districts of 
West Bengal to ensure that forest resources are sustainably used, conserved, and 
regenerated. AID promotes sustainable, equitable, and just development. It 
supports grassroots organisations in India working on education, livelihoods, 
natural resources, agriculture, health, gender, and social justice. 
 
 
 
7.
PR_Association_for_Indias_Development_St.Progress Against Objectives:
Progress Against Objectives 
Under each expected project objective, briefly explain your progress in reaching the objective and its 
results, and discuss any changes you propose to the project goals or objectives with the PO. 
 
7.1.a. Objective 1 
Use the Forest Rights Act to claim legal rights for individuals and communities and strengthen grassroots 
democratic institutions in 200 villages across 4 districts of northern West Bengal. 
 
 
7.1.b. Objective 1: Principal accomplishments 
Very good ground mobilis ation despite the pandemic. The following meetings at various levels were 
organised. 
20 community level meetings were organised with 40 participants on an average. Any adult in the village 
can attend this type of open meeting. In some places women participation is less as they go to work in others 
homes for domestic help or they go to forest for foraging. Increasing livelihood options in the village will 
help women’s increase participation. The purpose of these meetings was to provide basic orientation on the 
FRA and talk about the provisions under FRA to start new Gram Sabhas. 
1 district level meeting was organised where Gram Sabha members from 30 villages spread across 3 districts 
had participated. Basically, the district meeting was organised to raise awa reness around FRA so that 
representatives would go back to their respective villages and work with other villagers in order to 
strengthen their Gram Sabhas. Sometimes people don't realise that they got less land while getting the Patta. 
Those who have rece ived less land under IFR are going back to the district officials. Those villages that 
have not been converted to revenue villages have started the process as a result of this meeting. 
3 alliance building meetings with like -minded organisations were organi sed in Nagpur, Kolkata and in 
Purulia. Different groups related to forest issues from different districts have participated in the meetings 
so that the FRA is implemented better across the state. 
Village level leadership committees were formed in 7 villages to drive the community processes through 
Gram Sabhas. 
Capacity building workshop on GPS & satellite mapping is going on for CFR mapping in the operational 
forest villages with the Gram Sabha representatives so that they can authenticate their cust omary forest 
boundary and claim CFR with the map. 
Besides, the regular meetings, interactions with the forest and district administration are being continued 
because the implementation of FRA has to be recognized by the government. FRA guidelines are not being 
followed. The process is not done correctly by the government hence people have to repeatedly go for the 
correction of land records, ensure their representation in the Sub Divisional Level Committee (SDLC) and 
bringing issues back in the village. 
  
 
 
7.1.c. Objective 1: Shortfalls 
The starting of developing the audio-visual materials have been delayed due to Covid pandemic. 
 
 
 
 
7.2.a. Objective 2 
To create livelihood opportunities for the communities living in and around the forest  to  build their 
resilience and encourage conservation of forests and the surrounding landscape. 
 
 
7.2.b. Objective 2: Principal accomplishments 
The outcomes of the livelihood activities have surpassed our own expectations. People were mobilised in 
25 villages to form clusters for community level farming. Around 680 families involved in farming have 
reaped a harvest in jute, mustard and vegetables.  
• 300 families were involved in Jute farming and each family had made an average additional 
income of Rs.27,000 
• 350 families were involved in mustard farming and each family had made an additional income 
of around Rs.10,000 to Rs.12,000. The marketing of mustard oil is in the process. People in these 
clusters have brought 330 acres of land under mustard cultivation. 
• 35 families in Nimati village were involved in vegetable farming and each made an additional 
income of Rs.600 
All of these are additional income for the families because earlier they used to grow rice and then the land 
remained unused for the rest of the year. Rice is mainly grown for sustenance. Most of the villagers in the 
operational area are daily wage earners. On an average they earn around Rs.300 per day as labourers. 
Usually they get 4 months of work in a year which earns around Rs.36,000 annually per family. The clusters 
involved in farming have been able to make some additional income on top of their annual income from 
labour work  because of this livelihood initiative.   
There have been some farmers who grow jute for which they  take a loan of Rs.400 for a bigha (0.33 acre) 
from the money lender. And farmers who were involved in commercial mustard farming used to take a loan 
of Rs.5000 to 600 per  bigha (0.33 acre)  for the initial input costs. This year the situation has changed or 
got better in a way because the cluster got the seed and other input support for farming and also had a good 
income from the harvest.  
Apart from the farming initiatives, 2 nurseries have been raised in different villages with a total of 80,000 
saplings of local indigenous varieties from the forest. The plantation will happen in monsoon season on all 
the degraded lands along the customary boundaries of the forest villages.  
Formal meetings with all the Gram Sabhas in 25 villages happened and resolutions were passed in order to 
initiate the farming and plantation work in the forest villages. Several follow up meetings with the Gram 
Sabha and the clusters had been carried out to start the newly adopted livelihood initiative. Besides, some 
workshops on the technical aspect of organic farming were also organised in 25 villages with the farmers 
involved in clusters. 
  
 
 
7.2.c. Objective 2: Shortfalls 
We are a bit late in terms of plantation effort because the seed collection was delayed  due to the Covid 
induced lockdown. Plantation is a time sensitive work. We missed the first plantation time because of the 
delayed seed collection and we had to wait for the next plantation time. On top of that the first batch of 
saplings got destroyed by the elephants for which we had to change the location of one of the nurseries.  
 
 
 
 
7.3.a. Objective 3 
To develop a new rung of leadership from the youth (12 to 18 years) through an education that is rooted in 
their socio-cultural-ecological context and empowers them to develop self-reliance and live in their 
culture with dignity. 
 
 
7.3.b. Objective 3: Principal accomplishments 
We could not organise any formal workshops in the initial months of the project due to Covid pandemic. 
However,  several rounds of discussion have been done with the adolescents and youth (aged between 12 
to 18 years old) both including men and women in different villages. Based on those interactions we are 
now developing the learning modules which will be completed by April, 2022.  Due to the enthusiasm 
from the community we increased the learning centre from six to seven. Selection of teachers through an 
interview process from the community has been done. We are in the process of buying one desktop for 
each centre. We observed the FRA day on December 18th in which people from different villages 
participated, and community members of different tribes presented their unique cultural performances. 
 
 
7.3.c. Objective 3: Shortfalls 
We could not organise any formal workshops on planned time for developing the learning modules due to 
the Covid pandemic. However, our experts (resource persons) have visited all the targeted villages several 
times in order to interact with the women and youth groups in the process of dev eloping basic learning 
modules.  
No school level competitions could be done because schools were closed due to the Covid-19 induced 
restrictions. 
  
 
 
 
8.
PR_Association_for_Indias_Development_St.What has your team learned during the im:
What has your team learned during the implementation and evaluation of your project? 
1. In the process of nursery development, we have learned that forest villagers want indigenous 
varieties that grow naturally in the forest for their nurseries unlike timber that is always promoted 
for plantation. The forest villagers believe that plantations of more indigenous variety can restore 
the degraded forest patches and eventually reduce the human-animal conflict.  
2. We have found that the youth group in the villages are very enthusiastic about computer 
education.  
3. We also learned that cluster farming can have a huge impact on the income of the families. 
 
 
 
 
9.
PR_Association_for_Indias_Development_St.How will your team use this information:
How will your team use this information to change the way you work? 
1. We are raising only indigenous varieties in our nurseries. There is no plan for timber plantation. 
2. We have incorporated computer learning in all 7 centers. All centers will start with one desktop 
each this year. 
3. The huge production of mustard and jute has made us think of exploring the scope of value 
addition and marketing initiatives. We have already started talking to the clusters on the 
marketing efforts. 
 
 
10.
PR_Association_for_Indias_Development_St.How will you share what you have learned:
How will you share what you have learned inside and outside your organisation? 
We will discuss the processes and outcomes with our other partners. The outcomes have really given us a 
lot of enthusiasm and have driven us to think that we may try to implement some of the successful 
examples in other areas with different partners.

Purpose: To help strengthen the Migrant Resilient Collaborative (MRC) in India, which aims 
to protect migrant workers by regulating placements and work conditions and 
providing them with full access to safety nets and entitlements. Approximately 
240,000 migrant workers will be directly impacted as an initial step. The MRC is a 
grassroots-led collaborative of not-for-profit, philanthropic, and private sector

7.1.a. Objective 1 Objective 
Strengthening social security delivery system and increasing access to benefits and 
entitlements 
 
 
 
7.1.b. Objective 1 Progress. 
What progress has been made toward the above grant objective(s) over the last grant period?  Please focus your response on 
progress against desired outcomes or changes that occurred because of the activities; do not only describe what activities 
occurred or products of these efforts (i.e., Training manuals; policy briefs, etc).  
The Oak Project: As part of our ongoing efforts to create a social registry for migrant workers, our 
Jan Saathis registered 1,30,859 migrant workers across sources and destinations on the Jan Saathi 
mobile application during the project period, out of which 70906 women have been registered on the 
portal. These workers were also provided with pre-departure and post-arrival training sessions. In 
these sessions, the workers are informed about their rights and the mechanisms in place to safeguard 
them. The workers are also informed about the various entitlements that they can access at the 
destination and source they are currently present. 
 
 
Social status of families registered in West Bengal 
  
The team has been successful in facilitating 78,153 scheme applications for various households. Out 
of these, till May 2022, 70,201 applications have converted to benefits of which 36,154 are for 
women-led households. The application-to-benefit conversion ratio is (~89%) which is similar to 
what was envisaged at the start of the program.  
Overall MRC Progress: In the MRC program, running across 13 states, we have currently reached 
out to 28,22,497 households since October 2020, they have been registered with the Migrants 
Resilience Collaborative. Aligned with our strategy to register women as primary respondents for the 
households, 40% of households have a woman as the primary respondent in May 2022. 
Our Jan Saathis uses the mobile application to check eligible schemes for registered migrant workers 
and facilitate applications for such schemes. The Jan Saathis also tracks the delivery of benefits for 
each application they help submit. The major schemes that we focused on in West Bengal were 
Lakshmi Bhandar, Krishak Bandhu, old age pension, widow pension, disability pension, Bina Mulya 
Samajik Suraksha Yojana, BOCW, PMSBY, E-shram, BMSSY and Swasthya Sathi.  Our team was 
able to facilitate and implement all the above-mentioned activities smoothly through the constant 
support of the district labor officials.  

 
Oak Progress Report.    3 
Till May 22, 26.6 lakh scheme applications were facilitated and 22.20 lakh benefits were received in 
the MRC program, working across 13 states The focus in many states was in ensuring the filing of 
applications for the community instead of only registering them. In May 2022, the major schemes 
under which applications were filed include EShram, PMSY , Ayushman Bharat, BoCW cards, PM 
Kisan Saman Nidhi, PM Awas Yojana, MGNREGA and work related to ration. 
  
 
 
 
7.1.c. Objective 1 Challenges and obstacles. 
We expect that the work toward grant objectives may not occur as originally planned due to internal and external factors.  
Please share a candid assessment of areas of challenge and learning and whether any adjustments were made. 
1. Due to the second wave of Covid19, our operations were halted from April 21- June 21. 
2. Political interference at the local level affects operation. Despite securing support from 
Gram Pradhan, the team often faces resistance from other members of the same political 
party. 
3. The MRC during the initial days did not receive support from the community. They 
believed that we had come from NRC and harassed our team members.   
4. Government does not accept offline application forms. The only medium to submit the 
applications is through Duare Sarkar camps. Currently, there are no mechanisms for 
submitting the applications for state-specific schemes online, so the team has to wait for 
duare Sarkar camps to happen in order to submit the application form. This makes availing 
the entitlement lengthy.

Enabling responsible recruitment 
 
 
 
7.2.b. Objective 2 Progress. 
What progress has been made toward the above grant objective(s) over the last grant period?  Please focus your response on 
progress against desired outcomes or changes that occurred because of the activities; do not only describe what activities 
occurred or products of these efforts (i.e., Training manuals; policy briefs, etc).  
The Oak Project: In West Bengal, the team has been getting access to new construction sites under 
Mission BOCW. Mission BOCW has been largely successful and we have further streamlined 
implementation support on sites to ensure workers can access social security support, keeping the 
effect of on-site operations to a minimum. The team in Kolkata engages in 2 sites that come under 
and till now, 1087 applications have been submitted for 355 unique workers and 751 benefits were 
delivered for 348 unique workers at construction sites. 
Overall MRC Progress: In the last year, the team has focused on Mission BOCW which is a 
coordinated effort with the government, private sector, and civil society to help migrant construction 
workers and their family’s tide over the crisis. Through this campaign, we aim to register one million 
construction workers by December'22 in 100 cities and districts of 12 states of India. 
 
Oak Progress Report.    4 
The targeted outcome this year was to get labor responsibly recruited to Industries but as we 
proceeded, we understood that to responsibly recruit labor we need to first initiate partnerships with 
the industry to gain access to sites. Hence, we started to focus on Mission BOCW as a stepping stone 
towards the larger goal of responsible recruitment which will be an eventual outcome of the same.  
We are currently engaging with 11 industry partners (employers) across the textile and construction 
sectors. These include names Such as BCI, CREDAI, BCI, HDFC, Godrej and Tata Realty. In 
Partnership with HDFC capital, we are in the process of launching an initiative aimed at recognizing 
and rewarding the industry’s best practices, which in turn will ensure proactive engagement of real 
estate companies in providing social security for the construction worker’s compliance at the sites 
under HDFC capital. An LOI has been signed with the CREDAI National (The prime industry body 
of construction developers), through which they will help with onboarding developers onto the 
Mission BOCW-where social security entitlements will be facilitated on-site at all MRC destination 
cities. 
  
 
 
 
7.2.c. Objective 2 Challenges and obstacles. 
We expect that the work toward grant objectives may not occur as originally planned due to internal and external factors.  
Please share a candid assessment of areas of challenge and learning and whether any adjustments were made. 
1. Gaining access to sites has been a major challenge.  
2. Even after receiving permission for the sites, the onsite managers create hindrance in 
registering the workers for BOCW. 
3. Lack of proper documents (Aadhaar card, bank details etc.)  with the workers at 
construction sites limits our ability to facilitate social security entitlements. 
4. Besides, the presence of promoters of real estate companies/ site managers often hinders 
interaction of Jan Saathis with the workers and the ability of the workers to share their 
problems freely. 
5. The onsite managers expect that the scheme's benefits should be given immediately to the 
laborers, which is not possible as the delivery is determined by the processes at the Labor 
and other relevant departments. 
6. BOCW and many major schemes are not applicable for inter-state migrant workers in West 
Bengal. A number of workers in Kolkata, especially in the construction sector, are inter-
state migrants which could not be benefited due to the limitations.

The team has received 4 cases of accidents at the workplace, 1 case of minimum wages, 1 case of

team is continuously working on promoting helpline services in the communities and labor nakas

We have held awareness sessions for 39,822 workers in the workplace about their rights and

received on the helpline since October 2020, in which 6035 cases have been registered. 1127 cases 
were received from the field team and 4,908 were received through Helpline till May 22. Out of the 
total cases received till October,3,256 cases have been closed after adequate interventions. Different 
strategies have been adopted to popularize the helpline. Besides IEC materials, wall paintings have 
been used an innovative strategy so that the workers get to know about the helpline. The helpline 
has received calls from over 425 districts across the country. 
We have hired lawyers who are helping our team and stakeholders in implementing and imbibe SOPs, 
enabling and capacitating the system towards transformation- Exposure to labour departments, 
community volunteer building relationships and sensitization of field and central teams. We have a 
dedicated lawyer in each state.

identification of their challenges, their empowerment and dissemination of knowledge gained with

7.b. Progress. 
 
What progress has been made toward the above grant objective(s) over the last grant period?  Please focus your response on 
progress against desired outcomes or changes that occurred because of the activities; do not only describe what activities 
occurred or products of these efforts (i.e., Training manuals; policy briefs, etc).  
In Output 1, significant progress has been achieved. Various studies, including an Ethnographic 
Survey of 800 households, PVCA, and Action research, have completed the needs assessment. 
Findings indicate that nearly 50 % of tribal households lack tribal identity cards, hindering their 
access to government policies. The project aided 300 beneficiaries in obtaining caste certificates 
and supported 144 beneficiaries in accessing government schemes. PVCA using PRA tools was 
accomplished in 8 villages, offering insights into resources, hazard exposure, vulnerability, and 
coping capacity. The Action research guided the project timeline and methods, including multi-
hazard mapping, website creation, and PVCA framework. Land Use and Land Cover mapping 
using Remote Sensing and GIS analysis and communication of weather forecasts and crop 
advisories through Information Hubs are in progress to assist the farmers. Knowledge was shared 
via the new project website (https://soundofsilencesundarban.com/). 
Output 2 involves forming 69 WSHGs and 16 Youths' Groups, involving 800 households and 215 
young individuals. Capacity training was completed in all 8 villages for 380 participants. Initiatives 
include Information Hubs for education, employment, and NRM-based vocations. Ongoing efforts 
ensure weather forecasts and hazard warnings in Bengali. 
Output 3 showcases accomplishments. LRRM held health camps for 71 women in Kultali, with 
more planned by DRCSC in other areas. Both organizations have also appealed to the respective 
Block Development Offices (BDOs) for organizing vaccination drives. Football equipment was 
distributed to 8 youths’ groups, along with plans for exercise and training under sought trainers.

We expect that the work toward grant objectives may not occur as originally planned due to internal and external factors.

obtained: 
• Setting up field offices in the blocks of Kakdwip, Sandeshkhali I and Kultali, where none 
existed, was an ordeal owing to the lack of availability of suitable office spaces with basic 
amenities such as washrooms, drinking water and electricity. 
• Delays in obtaining the necessary permission from local government offices for the 
implementation of project activities in the selected villages and blocks.

• Interference and obstruction by local political leaders in the recruitment of community 
mobilizers. Negotiating with these political functionaries and ensuring no such barriers in

decided against an aggressive approach, giving the communities adequate time and 
information about project objectives to help them decide if they would participate in the

During the grant period 27 nos. of Farmer’s Groups including 405 members (mainly women) have 
formed through PRA/PVCA exercises. Representation is there from poor and vulnerable section of 
society and farmers from various caste, religion, age and disability. Group members are regularly 
attending meetings, identifying issues, maintaining group registers, make savings, discuss various 
issues etc. Participation from each group members (mainly women) is ensured and they are very 
much interested to give time and share their learning to dissolve issue among the members. 
Orientation meetings are arranged to generate awareness among the poor and vulnerable people for 
accessing various developmental provisions prescribed in different government schemes. Through 
this initiative almost every member are availing at least one scheme from state govt. 
It is very helpful for the farmers to get training (cultivation of different crops like potato, paddy, 
sesame, pulses etc.) & inputs (paddy seeds, neem oil etc.) from ADA which boosts their interest and 
they are cultivating those crops in the kharif season with sustainable agriculture practices. The 
farmers are using Climate resilient agricultural practices (sorjan technique, integrated farming 
system, vermi-pit, fish rearing, small livestock rearing (hen, duck, goat etc.) to cope up with vagaries 
and challenges of climate change. Community Seed Banks are established in the project area towards 
conservation of salt-tolerant seeds for future. They are getting diversified organic nutritious vegetable 
through Nutrition garden regularly which assured nutrition to the small and marginal farming families 
in the targeted villages. They protect vulnerable coast line through plantation of 10000 saplings of 
mangroves in the river bank sites (3 ha) as identified by respective persons including GP members, 
community members etc. Mangrove nursery is also established with 20000 seeds. Protection groups 
are formed with the community people to monitor and protect the mangrove saplings. 
After getting training community members are hervesting rain water in the pond and cultivating 
mixed cops in dry season and developed pond bank management model including plantation in 
embankment, small livestock rearing over the pond etc.  
Selected farmers have Small livestock rearing (chicks, duck & goat) along with their shelter 
management is becoming a promising alternative livelihood option among the community people in 
the project areas. Crab culture on pond is also becoming an excellent way of earning money apart

7.1.a. Objective 1

7.1.b. Objective 1: Principal accomplishments 
The experience of SEWA and similar organizations demonstrate that workers in the informal economy, 
especially women, benefit from organising themselves to identify their status as workers and demand 
better working conditions and fair wages. Organizing enables an otherwise scattered labour force to 
negotiate with employers and decision-makers from the government. It is to this end that SEWA works 
with women in the informal economy to improve women and girls’ agency and visibility, autonomy and 
secure their socio-economic rights. The programme across two states of Jharkhand and West Bengal 
works to address the systematic issues affecting women and girls and to advance the rights of these 
women as informal women workers under the gamut of the unorganised sector. 
Throughout the past fifteen months, the perils of COVID-19 continued to present multiple challenges to 
our members, through the second lockdown imposed in the months of April-May 2021, followed by the 
third wave of COVID inflicted field restrictions in January-February 2022. For West Bengal, this situation 
was also politically charged in the state with the Legislative Assembly election throughout March and 
April 2021, which led to a fairly slow start to programme activities as per the Workplan. In Bengal, the 
situation was aggravated by another challenge: the floods in Malda. Almost 15000 community members 
in Malda faced flooding during the rainy season. Meanwhile, in Jharkhand, the situation was aggravated 
due to a lack of proper channels of communication, which got lost due to the sufficient infrastructure 
available for our members. 
Throughout the year, the grassroots leaders and organisers in both states have worked dedicatedly towards 
increasing engagements resulting in outreach:

Through the experience of engaging with informal women workers, grassroots leadership has emerged at 
the CORE for any programme development or strengthening of the SEWA movement for SEWA Bharat. 
 
 
Aagewans (SEWA grassroots women leaders) are the elected leaders in the SEWA movement. They are 
the face of SEWA. The Program aims to increase the bargaining power of these grassroots leaders by 
developing their capacities to provide leadership in their communities and understand issues surrounding 
the women in the informal economy be it in trade, occupation, rights and access. Due to their local 
presence, Agewans are often approached by SEWA members and the larger community to help them 
register for government schemes or benefits, as well as to negotiate wages and issues with employers. 
Aagewans play a vital role in the SEWA movement as they are the bridge between the Government, 
contractors of work and all the women working in the informal economy to ensure the last-mile delivery 
of services and support to them. Therefore,  facilitating their capacity building and knowledge 
enhancement around SEWA ’s work is our foremost priority.  
The team in West Bengal focused the interventions on activating aagevans towards an action-oriented 
approach and emphasised the need to reach out to more women workers. Whilst in Jharkhand, which is 
relatively a newer intervention area, the focus is to further strengthen the collectivisation process led by 
the aagevans so that they can lead the trade-specific advocacy and government liaisoning. 
  
Capacity Building of Agewans through Agewan Vikas Training 
Throughout the year from March 2021 onwards, the Agewan received various training and knowledge 
building sessions. In Jharkhand, two batches covering  40 Agewan completed their Agewan Vikas 
Program training course which focused on the following modules (1) SEWA Ideology (2) Importance of 
Union & Trade organising (3) Identifying issues and taking community issues (4) Trade committee.  
Across West Bengal, the training(s) was conducted to equip 106 agewans with the knowledge and skills 
required to become efficient leaders at the community level.  
For the Bengal team, post the training the agewans from every block prepared a three-month plan in which 
they included linkages with government schemes like Swasthya Sathi, Ration Adhaar link, preparing a rate 
chart for domestic workers etc. This made the process of evaluating the growth of aagevans across the year 
more thorough.  
Various inputs given to the aagevans throughout the year, in the form of training(s), sessions or 
discussions have led to not only increased awareness of aagevans among the community members but 
resulted in several actions being taken by aagevans that manifested their leadership qualities.
