7.1.c. Objective 1: Shortfalls 
Following the announcement of the second lockdown, the team shifted quickly to online modes of 
communication, meetings, and other activities. Although the staff was acclimated to online sessions, the 
uptake was accompanied by the time required to adjust. 
SEWA believes that a key component in the work aimed at aagevan development is the component of 
exposure visits, which could not be undertaken in both states due to lockdown restrictions, and this added 
to aagevans taking time in owning the entire process of becoming change agents for the community, and 
fully transforming into their leadership roles. 
Overall, we noted a slowdown in activities, which we believe is related to mental fatigue among the staff 
as a result of stagnant work and delayed processes, which has resulted in a lack of enthusiasm and interest 
in the work, particularly with field-level operations, which are becoming more difficult due to continued 
COVID restrictions and are exposing the underlying vulnerabilities among our members. This disrupts a 
grassroots people-based organisation, slowing down the program's progress. 
 
 
As a result, such situations are handled with a thorough engagement with the desired outcome and 
reflection sessions, which allow teams to revisit the objectives of engaging in activities that could become 
monotonous. 
For Bengal, the shortfall is due to the ongoing deterioration of beedi workers' conditions, the adoption of 
the labour code, and other factors that have demotivated beedi workers and aagevans. As this appears to 
be a setback for years of advocacy and interaction with our members, who are now suffering as a result of 
policy changes and a decline in beedi work in the country. 
Jharkhand observed that, despite having digital tools offered to Aagevan, frequent monitoring of tool use 
becomes difficult, and its maintenance has become an additional duty, aggravated due to a lack of 
infrastructure and public resources.

7.2.b. Objective 2: Principal accomplishments 
SEWA operates empowerment centres known as SEW A Shakti Kendras in all districts across the two 
states. SEWA's presence and operations in communities are anchored on the SSKs. They connect 
community people with government programmes and schemes related to microfinance, health, job, and 
skill development opportunities, and they provide resources, support, and information to women for their 
economic and social growth. The SSK is also important as a last-mile delivery mechanism for social 
security and welfare systems, supporting women and their families in accessing them. These centres, 
which are staffed by a woman from the local community, give assurance and assistance to help women 
negotiate the application processes and receive public welfare benefits. 
SEWA Shakti Kendra acts as a bridge between the government and the community members. Through the 
SSK community members became aware not only of their rights but also of the way to access them. 
At present, through the programme, the states have developed around 8 SSKs under the OAK programme, 
overall 9 SSKs at present supported through various programmes. The inputs given have bolstered the 
SSK in ensuring 
• An increased outreach, covering wider schemes and ensuring maximum benefits are received 
through the Kendras, while also including the expansion of services by catering to the community 
needs through camps, aagevan mobilisation, and door-to-door visits 
• Inputs towards the development of staff capacity on handling multiple aspects attached to the 
SSK, along with developing the SSK In-charge by identifying young leaders in the community. 
• Working towards stronger connections with stakeholders, and relevant government departments. 
• Regularised and centralised database management system. 
The major accomplishment has been to nudge the SEWA Shakti Kendras towards sustainability and 
ensuring by the end of the grant Year 1, 60-65% growth across all aspects mentioned above.

were facilitated in filling out online & Offline forms. The agriculture workers with several 297 were linked 
with Block/ATMA/PACS for seed linkage during Kharif & Rabbi season.  
By the end of 2021 from November to December, in both the districts again a registration campaign was 
conducted on E-Shram Portal registration and more than 1000 from both the districts.  
  
Impact  
The SSKs not only bridge the gap between the grassroots and governance centres but also encourages the 
community members to participate in the governance. The centres  also hold continuous community 
meetings where the members come together and discuss their issues and explore ways to solve them. Along 
with these meetings, there are various kinds of training to happen at these centres. There are financial 
literacy training, entrepreneurship development training, digital literacy training, empowerment training 
and workshops educating the members about health, healthy lifestyle and hygiene. It is because of the SSKs 
 
 
that the centres of governance are accountable and the com munity members are voicing their needs. The 
training, workshop, and awareness campaigns by the SSK centres have empowered the women with the 
knowledge of various governance schemes, and skills and boosted confidence throughout the whole 
process. 
  
Teleconsultation - COVID relief support 
During the wake of the second wave of COVID-19, healthcare access became difficult due to the 
overburdened healthcare infrastructure. A teleconsultation model was implemented which aimed to 
connect women in the field with trained medical experts. In this model, the role of aagevan was seen as 
essential as it is only because of her presence that the community members trusted unknown doctors with 
personal, medical information, especially given the current socio-political climate. Through this 
model,  across the two states, 59 aagevans were strengthened as Master Trainers for dissemination of 
information in their respective communities, resulting in 13,723 awareness calls being made by 
community members, to a team of 7 active doctors available.   
A dashboard which was updated on daily basis was monitored by a central health team created, led by 
Susan ben (National Health Coordinator, SEWA) 
  
Working in collaboration with Right to Food Network to secure the fundamental rights of life-food 
and work 
SEWA in West Bengal collaborated with the Right to  Food Network to advocate the aspects of Right to 
Food and other government schemes that are directly or indirectly related to ensuring food security. One 
Organiser from Murshidabad is now being given the responsibility to work with the network activity to  
ensure food security is ensured to the most vulnerable group. As a part of the campaign, help desks were 
also being set up from where community members can get information related to schemes and services 
provided by the government. They have also surveyed  to analyse the impact of COVID -19 on the most 
vulnerable section, the findings of which will be used for advocacy at the state and national levels. Through 
the network activities, members' access to food security is being ensured. 
  
VLCPC Strengthening  
The role of VLCPC is fundamental in making duty bearers accountable for the protection of child rights 
and addressing issues of child rights violations. As the VLCPC meetings could not be held regularly due to 
the pandemic, the other hand, the child rights  violation cases were also rising. At this point, agewans and 
organisers in West Bengal intervened and approached the committee to regularize VLCPC meetings to 
sensitize the community members to prevent/ reduce the early marriage because during the pandemic early 
marriage rate was high in West Bengal. 15 meetings were held where discussions centred around early 
marriage, increasing dropout rate among girls and action plans were formulated to address the issues. 
  
Capacity Building towards inclusive centres 
The most important strengths of these SSKs are the human resources personnel that are responsible for 
the functioning of the SSKs. Every SSK consists of a team of SSK in-charge, Field Mobilizer, Supervisor 
and Aagewans. The SSKs which are close to each other share their supervisor. With a strong monthly 
reporting system which helps the SSK to track their linkages in place, SSKs can function smoothly. The 
SSKs have a grievance redressal mechanism through which the members can solve their grievances if 
any. A continuously developing and evolving database of all the local, state and central government 
programmes through which the community members could be linked helps the SSK teams to support the 
community members better. This developing database gives information about the programme, eligibility, 
required documents, and the application process too. This keeps the SSKs informed about the 
 
 
developments in government policies and programmes through which they could link the community 
members. 
Developing Youth champions through SSKs 
The SSK has also evolved as space and medium for nurturing local communities. A recent initiative by 
the SSK team has been on building the capacity of the daughters of SEWA's members. They have been 
trained to expand the development work in their communities, and have played the role of building trust 
among their community members towards the services offered by SSKs.

adaptation needed towards centring activities in sync with the Health priority.  
This is accompanied by challenges faced by the SSK setup due to external factors, such as:

Along with internal challenges, like:

for understanding the needs and operations for the SSK and the larger social security ambit in 
India 
• Data entry and monitoring are hindered by infrastructure challenges, and a lack of availability of 
resources, which led to many delays in real-time data generation. 
For West Bengal, 
• Social security schemes like SSY could not be accessed for a specific period as the portal was

7.3.a. Objective 3 
To collectivise women workers [beedi workers, domestic workers, construction workers, street 
vendors, agricultural workers] to enable them to better engage with stakeholders in the value chain 
for full employment and have better access to markets and resources 
 
 
7.3.b. Objective 3: Principal accomplishments 
Women workers in the informal sector suffer from a multitude of challenges, one of which is that their 
work and their contribution to the labour force is rather unreported, and hence not valued appropriately. 
One of the ways SEWA has brought recognition to the issues and rights of these women is by the dual 
action of organising and collectivism. This type of mobilisation is guided by two realms that are close to 
the informal women worker i.e. community based and trade-based.  
  
Trade Committee meetings:  
  
SEWA Bengal has also formed trade committees for beedi rollers and weavers  and the committees hold 
meetings and discuss trade-specific issues and jointly formulate action plans to address the issues. A total 
of 5 Trade committee meetings were organised in Murshidabad with  106 members where the discussion 
centred around trade-related issues including low wages, limited access to healthcare, and social security 
and the formulation of an action plan to address the issues through advocacy at the Block and District level. 
Similar activities have been conducted in Jharkhand, where Trade committee Groups/Members have taken 
the issues ahead and an equal amount of time has also been dedicated to creating an understanding of their 
responsibilities and functions by the committee members to ensure positive impact. The  SEWA National 
Council has also guided to make the trade committee members functional by participating in their regular 
meetings.  
  
Multi-Stakeholder Consultations: 
  
A series of important stakeholder meetings were organised by SEWA in West Bengal with government 
representatives. In Berhampore, a meeting was conducted to discuss trade-related issues of beedi rollers 
where the Assistant Labor Commissioner, members of the different trade unions, Mahajan and aagewans 
were present. A joint action plan was formulated to address the issues faced by beedi rollers. It has been 
decided that the Unions along with SEWA Bharat in West Bengal will draft a letter and submit it to the 
Labour Minister.  
 
 
In Malda, another meeting was organised in  Manikchak, Malda in the presence of Block Level 
representatives from various government departments including NRLM, MGNREGA, and CITU as well 
as the private sector including representatives of Pataka beedi company and Mahajan. This meeting gave 
a platform for our sisters to directly share their trade-related issues with a variety of important stakeholders. 
The stakeholders addressed the issues raised by our sisters and also discussed various skill -based training 
which can provide an alternate means of livelihood. 
On the 23rd of March SEWA Bharat in Jharkhand along with other two organisations, Gharelu Kamgar 
Sangathan & Nirmana, stood for the rights of domestic workers to be considered and performed a 
demonstration in front of Raj Bhavan in Ranchi with the demands.  More than 30 domestic workers 
participated in the demonstration and a few SEWA members also spoke for their rights. A demand letter 
(mentioning, the rectification of ILO convention 189 by the Central government and bringing law for the 
domestic workers in India, decent wage to be provided by employers, social security schemes to be 
introduced more for the domestic workers and to be treated well with dignity in their workplace) was 
submitted to the MPs of Jharkhand. ILO convention points were highlighted.  
The National Platform for Domestic Workers (NPDW) provided an opportunity for the domestic worker 
representatives to participate and learn to mobilise and organise domestic workers to stand for their 
rights in Jharkhand . Through the platform, the domestic workers also learnt about their part of the 
responsibilities to achieve a conducive workplace. In 2021, two domestic workers from Jharkhand, Pinki 
Minj & Swarnlata Devi (Swarnlata Ben is also a state domestic worker representative), along with Anisha 
Ben (SEWA Sathi, a domestic worker Mobiliser) participated. The NPDW conducted a two-day workshop 
for the SEWA domestic worker and facilitated conversation on minimum wage, rate chart and social security 
aspects. A few highlights of the workshop: 
• The domestic worker representative had to present their work done in the state and it was decided 
to mobilise in new areas/basis through which 300 new domestic workers will be organised in 
2022.  
• Through the NPDW, SEWA Jharkhand is now able to connect with other organisations working 
for the domestic workers and raising voices in front of the government for the domestic workers.  
  
Promoting Alternative Livelihoods: 
West Bengal 
Orientation on short term training courses under Gramdyog Vikas Yojna, KVIC  
Agewans and community members were oriented on various short term training courses under Gramodyog 
Vikas Yojana. Khadi and Village Industries Commission (KVIC) is a statutory body under the Ministry of 
MSME, Govt. of India that works towards providing employment, producing saleable articles and creating 
self-reliance amongst the poor and building up a strong rural community spirit. The meeting was attended 
by agewans and community women as well as youth group members from all blocks of Murshidabad and 
Malda. 
Skill-based Training 
SEWA Bharat in West Bengal has been running SEWA Youth Resource Centres in Murshidabad focusing 
on providing alternative livelihood training (mainly tailoring) to get young girls out of beedi rolling. In both 
SYRCs, one special class has been added for advanced training. In the 2021 -22 financial year, 198 girls 
received tailoring training. A total of 51 girls have moved completely out of beedi rolling and into garment 
making.  
Encouraging Social Entrepreneurship  
To promote sustainable livelihood, SEWA Bharat in Raghunathganj block with the sup port of a locally 
placed SBI fellow initiated a project on small scale production and marketing of a snack item locally known 
as Nimki, currently, 3 women are being supported in running this project and scaling it up to a sustainable 
social enterprise owned by the community women. 
 
 
Jharkhand 
A discussion on alternative livelihoods with agriculture workers cum forest worker members, aagewans and 
adolescent girls yielded a few opportunities - such as producing leaf plates, engaging in animal husbandry, 
and organising skill training for adolescent girls.  
Biodegradable leaf plates and bowls 
In the Daru Block, a 10 group of agriculture worker-members developed a team to work on leaf plates and 
bowl stitching during leaf season and the local SEWA team will explore market linkages with local vendors 
in Jhumra. A demo with ten women was conducted in September-October, 2021, right before Dusherra Puja. 
This was the first opportunity for those 10 women to make a living using locally available resources. This 
was a big motivation for the local team as well - setting an example of nurturing the local economy. This 
opportunity will be explored further to check for viability and scale.  
Animal Husbandry 
Exploring further livelihood opportunities within the agriculture secto r is one way to go - in Hazaribagh, 
Animal husbandry work is of equal importance as the women struggle with good practices when it comes 
to cattle rearing (cow, goat, buffalo, hen). There is substantial scope for augmenting the existing incomes 
of women engaged in animal husbandry if such practices are adopted. Currently, bringing their animals to 
the veterinary doctors is a challenge and has caused animal deaths in many cases. In late 2021, SEWA 
Bharat started a program to develop 10 Pashu Sakhis in Hazari bagh. These Pashu Sakhis from different 
villages can then cater to SEWA members in keeping their goats healthy by providing first aid and guiding 
them and in preparing good quality fodder (Pashu Aahar) for them. SEWA Bharat also called in an expert 
team from Bihar that visited Hazaribagh in December 2021 and February 2022 and a 10 -day session was 
conducted consisting of both a classroom session and field exposure. Today,  the 10 Pashu Sakhi are actively 
working in their local and neighbouring villages. Incr ease of monthly income in the range of INR 900 to 
INR 1500 has been reported by the Pashu Sakhis.  
Skill Training for Adolescent Girls 
The team in Hazaribagh has recently begun to work on the skill development of Adolescent girls to prepare 
them for connecting with income sources while they are pursuing their education. 9 adolescent girls have 
been trained in Sohrai painting (the famous Jharkhand art) through one of the renowned organisations called 
“ Sohrai Kala Mahila Vikas Sahyog Samittee '' in Hazaribagh. These girls have completed their training in 
March 2022 and continue to practice. Once their skill is developed, SEWA Bharat will support these girls 
to market their paintings through “Anubandh” which is an online SEWA e -marketplace. Other interested 
SEWA members too can join this training.  
Entering the Digital World 
In SEWA Jharkhand, adolescent girls are today given a platform for understanding digital tools as a means 
of livelihood. 5 girls from Hazaribagh & Ranchi have been trained in conducting online surveys and have 
been able to make an earning of more than INR 5000 each. The purpose of providing them with this training 
is to meet the growing need of collecting primary data, through digital means as has been deemed necessary 
during the pandemic. Many CSOs and government organisations seek such data. 
  
 
 
7.3.c. Objective 3: Shortfalls 
The continuous waves of COVID- 19 pandemic and everlasting restrictions and safety guidelines, along 
with the lack of market and livelihood opportunities have affected the income cycle of the unorganised 
sectors. The situation continued to deteriorate with each passing Day making revenues of livelihood 
scarce and resources limited. 
 
 
The situation is further aggravated by the ongoing debate around labour codes in India whereby there is 
no concrete support for the workers under the various labour codes at present. Specifically, the facilities 
of the beedi workers have been cut down through the code. They are the victims of the double burden. 
Although the state government every six months reviews the minimum wages for the beedi workers. 
However, in West Bengal, the minimum wages are fixed through the tripartite meeting and these 
minimum wages are much lower than the government’s fixed minimum wages.  
On the other hand in Jharkhand, the major challenge witnessed is the lack of interest of members to invest 
in full-day trainings, as it results in loss of livelihoods,  therefore they do not seem to understand the 
larger objective behind providing those training, thereby defeating the purpose of capacity building

What has your team learned during the implementation and evaluation of your project? 
Though the pandemic has challenged every aspect of our daily lives, and especially that of informal women 
workers, it has helped us rethink and restrategize design and implementation at the community level.  
• The agewans played the role of SEWA’s front line workers, taking on the risk to reach each 
member to ensure they have access to food and health services during the pandemic. They 
conducted door to door visits while there were mobility restrictions and supported relief work by 
identifying ultra vulnerable families from their communities. SEWA in West Bengal worked 
collaboratively with Right to Food Network to advocate for food security of the marginalised. 
• The shift to the digital modes of work necessitated by the lockdown spurred a change to adopt 
digital literacy for the local teams and agewans. Online training was organised with agewans, 
youth members as well as the local SEWA teams to make sure the work doesn't stop. The use of 
virtual means of meeting such as Zoom and Google Meets was adopted. The agewans also led the 
teleconsultation service provided by SEWA for virtual help and treatment. While the pandemic 
threatened the necessities including ‘food, clothing and shelter’, it also made it certain that 
providing financial literacy to women is paramount if they want to acquire financial management 
skills to help them to cope with economic shocks. 
• The pandemic exacerbated poverty and hunger pushing people into the vicious cycle of economic 
stagnation. To meet the challenges posed by the pandemic SEWA in West Bengal tried to explore 
opportunities for income generation by collaborating with Khadi Village Industries. This will 
allow the team to increase their focus on the skill development of members and pivot to 
alternative livelihoods if needed.  
• With an increase in cases of early and forced child marriages owing to the pandemic, the youth 
group members have been vigilant within their communities to prevent child marriages and raise 
awareness among their peers.  
• The project enabled the local teams to focus on record keeping and maintaining member 
databases. The team has understood the importance of capturing outcomes and not just 
outreach, which is important to constantly question our key assumptions, and use program 
learnings to inform program design.  
• Both states have acknowledged extending handholding support to the agewans and adolescent 
girls. For instance, this cadre will form the second generation of SEWA Jharkhand which is 
crucial to ensure the sustainability of development programmes in the state. The team has learnt 
that it is equally important to collaborate with other local actors - be it government bodies or 
representatives such as ASHA workers, or Elected Women Representatives (EWRs) to create a 
conducive ecosystem.  
 
 
• NITI Consultancy, an external organisation was introduced to SEWA Bharat by OAK Foundation, 
to improve internal data systems and monitoring practices.

 Summary: 
In 2022, Pratham expanded into North Bengal with a focus on providing vocational training to 
youth from tea garden communities in Darjeeling, Kalimpong, Cooch Behar, Jalpaiguri, and 
Alipurduar districts. The strategic location of the project also ties well with Pratham’s intention to 
expand its presence in the East and North-Eastern parts of India. 
Key Outcomes: 
The program significantly impacted the lives of tea garden youth, offering them stable employment 
with salaries ranging from Rs. 9,500 to Rs. 14,264 per month, along with accommodation and food. 
Community engagement initiatives, including tool-kit exhibitions and camps, fostered trust and 
enhanced foundational skills in reading, math, and English among children and youth in tea garden 
communities. Collaborations with organizations like Transform Trade, Swaniti Initiatives, FPA, 
Nazdeeq, and KABIL enhanced community mobilization and resource-sharing efforts. Pratham's 
funding efforts from CSR initiatives, HNIs, and foundations are poised to further strengthen this 
intervention, ensuring sustainability. 
In summary, Pratham's expansion into North Bengal in its first year of the multi-year grant has 
made substantial progress towards its objectives of providing vocational training, securing formal 
employment, and fostering community engagement in tea garden communities. The program has 
transformed individual lives but also laid the foundation for lasting positive impacts on the region's 
youth and their families in the coming years of the intervention. 
The communities residing in North Bengal face precarious living conditions, largely reliant on 
employment opportunities presented by tea plantation owners. Challenges such as meager wages, 
seasonal employment fluctuations, constraints imposed by plantation owners, and a dearth of 
alternative income avenues have long been endemic. Pratham's proactive approach seeks to address 
these issues directly by engaging with the youth of tea garden areas. Keeping in mind the niche 
challenges of human trafficking faced by the tea-garden communities, the program embeds special 
counseling sessions and end-to-end migration support for youth who get placed out of their district. 
This in-turns is geared towards tackling the issue of unsafe migration and trafficking. 
Pratham's commitment extends beyond North Bengal, as we aim to expand our endeavors 
throughout West Bengal, informed by our ongoing programs and a deep understanding of industry

Community Level Insights 
A team of 8 mobilization mentors conducted various community engagement activities - meetings 
and discussions with ICDS, Self-Help Groups, Parents and youth on a daily basis across the tea 
garden communities of the 5 districts to spread awareness about vocational education led 
employment pathways. Such mobilization formats have been used by Pratham across 26 states in 
India and have been positively received by different communities. Given the historically difficult 
issues of human trafficking and livelihood related challenges, the community initially has 
inhibitions on trusting the organization and the program being offered. However, consistent efforts 
from the team by conducting different awareness activities eventually built trust among community 
members. Videos of the center, alumni members who have completed the course and have now 
been placed in a formal job went a long way in providing evidence about the program and its 
benefits. Community members were invited to visit the center, see the program and interact with the 
students to help bring in more transparency. Certificate & offer letter distribution ceremony was 
conducted within community spaces where everyone gathered to felicitate youth who have 
graduated in vocational courses from those communities. These youth became role models inspiring 
others to take the vocational education pathway and get access to alternate livelihood opportunities. 
A gradual transition from hesitancy and uncertainty to trust and potentially positive pathway was 
observed in the perception of community members. 
 In addition to meetings and discussions, community engagement was driven through the following 
different formats: 
Tool-kit exhibitions: The main intent behind organizing toolkit exhibitions is to take the toolkits of 
various programs to the youth far and wide and expose them to the opportunities available in 
vocational skilling. By taking the tools to the heart of the community, the idea is to encourage the 
youth to interact with the tools and know more about this discipline. The goal behind these 
exhibitions is to forge a connection with the local communities and create a presence. These have 
been conducted in high-schools, colleges and market spaces within the communities. Community 
volunteers were engaged in offering support with exhibition displays and spreading the word about 
this event. The tools were put on display on different tables in a circular structure along with 
information pamphlets and Pratham staff available to explain about the tools and their usage. Such 
a display format sparked much curiosity among students and community members to know more 
about vocational training and livelihood pathways available after training. The team received a 
positive response from all visitors leading to many youth enrolling into the program. 10 tool kit 
exhibitions of Automotive 4W and Hospitality F&B trades were conducted across Nagrakata, 
Banarhat, Madarihat-Birpara, Kalchini, Alipurduar, Kumargram blocks in the past 5 months.

Placement Insights: 
Pratham has a robust placement and post-placement support system to help youth have a smooth 
transition for the formal workforce after completing their training. It has partnered with 7000+ 
industry organizations across India to offer entry-level jobs to its trainees. The industry demand 
data is fed into Pratham’s database every month to map potential trainees based on their location 
preference. Pre-placement counseling includes an exclusive session on matching expectations from 
the industry and challenges that a new workplace and migration may bring forth. Trainees are then 
mapped to their preferred jobs and they are hand-held to prepare for interview and final joining 
formalities. Virtual calls are conducted with Pratham alumni already working in the mapped 
industry properties to offer a real-time experience of the food, culture and living conditions in that 
location. This helps bridge the information gap and build trust among trainees who are about to join 
the same workplace. It also gives them assurance that they have a group of people to support them 
if needed. Placement associates then accompany trainees to their destination location in case they 
are migrating, others are checked upon through phone calls for any support needed during 
joining.  Post-placement support includes a monthly support call from Pratham team to understand 
youth’s current employment status, challenges at the workplace and requirement of another 
placement. The data is collected & maintained in the central M&E system. This helps us gauge 
movement within industries, job changes and overall retention rates. 
Pratham understands that our alumni may need support and guidance even after they complete our 
programs. To this end, we also have set up a toll-free number (1800-12-000-4007) that is active 
from 10 am to 6 pm every day. Our program teams actively circulate these numbers among our 
alumni groups to ensure that our graduates are aware of this valuable resource. Whether our alumni 
need assistance with job placement or any other kind of support, they can reach out to us on these

Our placement coordinators and center teams believe in building a strong community among our

Need Assessment Study: A quantitative baseline survey was conducted in 73 villages across 
Darjeeling, Kalimpong, Alipurduar, Coochbehar, and Jalpaiguri districts from 23rd- 27th 
November 2022. The overarching goal of the survey was to establish the current scenario in the tea-
garden region in terms of the need for skill development & alternate safe employment opportunities 
for youth. In addition to the community survey, an industry survey was conducted to gauge the 
industry demand for the skilled workforce in Hospitality and Automotive sectors in North Bengal. 
Additionally, qualitative interviews were conducted with 27 Households across 3 districts- 
Jalpaiguri, Darjeeling and Alipurduar exploring the themes like- Employment types & pathways in 
tea-garden communities, Challenges pertaining to current employment, Perception of the 
community on different employment types- formal jobs, labor, self-employment, gig opportunities, 
Perception/opinion of the community regarding aspiration of employment for the current 
generation. 
The above study brought to the forefront the following insights: 
1.Lack of formal employment opportunities in the region, no industry other than tea-garden 
factories. Tea-factories offer very few job opportunities , most of which are unskilled, semi-
skilled labor jobs. 
 2.Youth engage/give into alcohol and drugs being depressed about not getting a job. Lack 
of direction and support is leading youth into delusion and often creating suicidal 
tendencies. Skilling will offer a direction/guidance for youth eventually leading to better 
mental and overall health.

3.Breaking generations of low-income trap for tea-garden families, formal job opportunities 
will bring in more income and subsequently improve standards of living. 
 4.Lack of career guidance - Youth have a strong understanding of completing high school 
education (Class 12th) but lack the necessary guidance to make informed decisions about 
higher education and career path. This has resulted in a significant gap in knowledge 
regarding the wide array of career opportunities that are available. 
 5.Government jobs seem the most aspired option for college graduates - Many young 
people who manage to complete their graduation in any field have their sights set on 
securing a government job. They spend significant time preparing for such competitive 
exams, often spending years. This trend highlights the enduring appeal of government jobs 
which is synonymous with stability and security of job. 
 6.Employment Challenges in Tea Garden - Tea Gardens were once a reliable source of 
employment for families across generations. However, there are now concerns about change 
in ownership which may bring modification in terms and conditions or even the permanent 
closure of tea gardens. In this context, it is important to explore alternative employment 
opportunities that can provide a more sustainable livelihood. 
 7.Migration among youth has emerged as a prevalent trend in this area where the younger 
generation is willing to take the risk of moving out to different regions across the country in 
search of better job opportunities. An increasing number of young people from the area are 
migrating to other regions and finding employment in the hospitality or O&M (electrical, 
plumbing) sectors. Many of them do not have any prior training or relevant skills and learn 
on the job. These opportunities are often obtained through personal networks, with someone 
from their area having worked there previously

7.c. Challenges and obstacles. 
 
We expect that the work toward grant objectives may not occur as originally planned due to internal and external factors.  
Please share a candid assessment of areas of challenge and learning and whether any adjustments were made. 
Objective 1 - Industry-Relevant Skills: Implementing this program in the tea garden region came 
with unique challenges. The susceptibility to human trafficking created a trust deficit, demanding 
comprehensive counselling for students and families. Sensitizing them to potential risks and 
safeguards was essential to ensure their safety and well-being while acquiring industry-relevant 
skills. 
Objective 2 - Employment Linkage: Building trust and credibility was crucial due to past negative 
experiences with NGOs. Establishing commitment, transparency, and tangible positive impact was 
necessary to overcome this hurdle. Engaging the community in open dialogue and decision-making 
processes played a vital role in rebuilding trust and linking youth to formal job opportunities. 
Objective 3 - Support Network: The lack of a physical presence initially affected enrollment rates, 
as potential participants questioned the program's legitimacy. To provide a support network for 
youth, Pratham responded by creating awareness through alternative means like toolkit exhibitions 
and community engagement activities. As Pratham's presence became more established, skepticism 
around legitimacy diminished, and the support network for youth in terms of career guidance, 
migration, and placement support began to take shape. 
In summary, addressing the challenges in the tea garden region required strategic solutions aligned 
with Pratham's objectives. Building trust, providing industry-relevant skills, and linking youth to 
employment opportunities were all part of the journey to empower the community and help youth 
grow in their professional journeys.

7.a. Objectives 
 
To enable identified groups of vulnerable people in the Sundarbans to come together, diagnose 
their vulnerabilities, articulate aspirations and avenues of change, and produce a plan for acting

7.b. Progress. 
 
What progress has been made toward the above grant objective(s) over the last grant period?  Please focus your response on 
progress against desired outcomes or changes that occurred because of the activities; do not only describe what activities 
occurred or products of these efforts (i.e., Training manuals; policy briefs, etc).  
Physical activities started in the first quarter of 2022 and before that activities were limited to 
online platforms due to Covid induced global pandemic. However, five physical advocacy 
workshops have been conducted with each hub partner comprising on an average 40 participants 
from the respective partner and community members identified during the process. 
NCAS participated in regular meetings for planning review and coordination with hub partners 
along with annual review of the project. Each workshop was dedicated to explore the community 
issues and how the community can address it themselves based on strength and weakness. 
Vulnerable groups such as farmers, women, children, and migrants were identified along with their 
vulnerabilities such as repairing of river embankment, domestic violence, child marriages, gender 
discriminations, drinking water, forced migration due to lack of local opportunities, prevalence of 
anemia in adolescent girls, etc. Sundarban is delta region where river Ganga flows into Bay of 
Bengal sea. Islands surrounded by saline sea water are the primary characteristics of local 
geography. Every year during monsoon or cyclone saline water breaks the weakening river 
embankment and enters into agricultural fields and fish ponds destroying not only current crops but 
the farm itself. This makes the farm unproductive for the next six or more years subject to intensity 
of salinity. This causes huge loss to the local farmers hence; they want to repair and strengthen the 
river embankment. Farmers are also struggling to access the fair market price of their farm produce 
such as fish, vegetables etc. These issues are interlinked and need to be looked at holistically and 
ecologically sustainable manner. One group has already started the river embankment repairing 
work as an alternative model rooted in traditional knowledge and practices by planting local trees 
and shrubs tolerant to saline water.  State agencies are concretizing the river embankment and 
making the fluid ecological interface between water and land very hard and impenetrable. As an 
alternative to concretization of river embankment we organized "Rethinking River Embankment", a 
field exposure visit for community members and staffs, so that community members can take local 
and ecologically sustainable initiative in their respective villages to protect their life and livelihood. 
We conducted NCAS's Resource Person's meet for ideation to pursue in the next phase of the 
project.

better. The platform of the steering committee falling short to include community representative

towards this approach was very challenging and particularly to assimilate it. This also raises many

Progress Against Objectives 
Under each expected project objective, briefly explain your progress in reaching the objective and its 
results, and discuss any changes you propose to the project goals or objectives with the PO. 
 
7.1.a. Objective 1 
Institutionalized practices in partner organizations contribute to strengthened systems to prevent and 
protect Children and Young People at risk of or affected by unsafe migration and assist sustainable 
reintegration of survivors of trafficking and exploitation. 
 
 
7.1.b. Objective 1: Principal accomplishments 
The project emphasized importance of gender responsive approach to child protection issues and services 
at the system level to reduce stigma against transgender children and survivors of trafficking and sexual 
exploitation. Partners are collectivized to act as a network advocating for the survivors’ right to accessible 
support services and creation of local safety nets for prevention of unsafe migration. The project built 
capacities of CSOs to use tools for a child centred reintegration process and increased acceptance by 
government duty bearers and service providers.  411 frontline workers demonstrated skills on child 
handling and dealing with difficult behaviour of survivors following child safeguarding principles through 
use of tools and learnings from project trainings. 165 children reported their views are sought for and 
incorporated into decision making and care planning. Anecdotes from the children indicate how the tool is 
supporting them to reflect and share their emotions. 
383 government duty bearers shared positive feedback towards the tools and guidelines developed under 
this project. Decentralised resource pools at district level are established, providing assistance to victims 
of unsafe migration. 45 inter-agency meetings conducted  and 391 cases were supported through this 
collaboration, which ensured that the voices of the children are heard and the stakeholders in the 
ecosystem are involved to ensure that Children and Young People (CYPs) recieve quality services. 
Safeguarding Community of Practice has been established with 54 members to promote safety in the 
process of reintegration. 379 child care professionals increased knowledge of Child Safeguarding. CSOs 
were capacitated to support Mental Health, functioning and Psychosocial Wellbeing of survivors of 
trafficking. 243 frontline workers increased their knowledge on Psychosocial Resilience Framework and 
220 front line workers are now able to monitor Psychosocial Wellbeing of CYPs including survivors by 
using tools developed by Tdh, UNICEF and a checklist developed by the partners. 
 
 
7.1.c. Objective 1: Shortfalls 
Multiple challenges were faced during the implementation of the BECOME Tool by the frontline workers. 
The main challenges and feedback given on the use of the tool was that it is  too time consuming and many 
times Children and Youth in Migration (CYiM) with whom the tool is applied loose concentration or are 
unwilling to tell his/her story to be able to complete the process. 
The partner organisations are working at various stages of the entire spectrum of the anti-trafficking space, 
and come with different levels of capacity and skill sets. For this reason it was challenging to build content 
around trainings that accommodated the needs of all. 
For conducting the online training sessions with the frontline workers, one of the challenge was consistent 
internet  connectivity while the level of understanding among all the frontline workers were not found at 
the same level. 
 
 
There could have been a more robust and s ystematic follow up on support for the trained social workers 
within the partner organisations by Tdh, however   Tdh faced challenges with high staff turnover of the 
tained social workers within the partner organisations. 
Inter-agency resource pool formatio n is yet to be done by 6 partner organisations who are comparatively 
small and have a lack of funding and inadequate information on district level resources. It was also found 
that these organizations faced challenges in finding trained personnel who can develop the resource pool. 
In Year 1 the overall challenge was the impact of COVID-19 second and third wave in the implementation 
and changes in the FCRA Rules which caused a 6 month delay to starting the field level implementation, 
which only started from July 2021 onwards. Hence, most of the partners were not able to complete the 
target within the 2022 annual plan. 
 
 
7.2.a. Objective 2 
Community level safety nets are established and functional to protect Children and Youth in Migration 
(CYiM) and support reintegration of the victims of unsafe migration/exploitation/ trafficking in 70 Gram 
Panchayats of 12 districts. 
 
 
7.2.b. Objective 2: Principal accomplishments 
103 multi-sectorial coordination meetings and 76 liasons completed with various formal and informal child 
protection duty bearers at district and block level. Through these, stakeholders in the ecosystem are now 
involved to ensure CYP recieve quality, responsive and stigma-free services. 551 formal and informal child 
protection duty bearers can identify child protection concerns and are aware of their responsibilities and 
referral pathway. 290 child protection concerns were raised and referred by the formal and informal child 
protection duty bearers within this reporting period. 
3544 CYiM participated in leadership training, among whom 1850 children were identified by the partner 
to be supported to join local Child Protection Committees (CPCs) 408 children participated in local child 
protection committee meetings. 231 child prot ection concerns raised and reported by CYP leaders to 
appropriate authorities. For inclusion of the CYiM in the CPCs, 49 advocacy initiatives were completed by 
partner organisations with District Level Child Protection Society for making the CPC’s function al in the 
areas where they are not functional at all or partially functioning and regarding inclusion of CYiM leaders 
in the CPCs and ensuring child participation. 
Partner organisations met with formal and informal district, ward and village level child protection duty 
bearesand organized consultations at the district level for establishment of CPCs. The CYiM prepared and 
placed a draft during the VLCPC/WLCPC formation meetings to the Panchayat Pradhan as well for 
formation and inclusion of CYP’s in the CPC meetings. 20 CPCs at village and ward level and 1 CPC at 
block level have been formed in West Bengal and Jharkhand through initiatives taken by the partner 
organisations. The inclusion of the CYP’s in the CPC meetings helped raise the voices of the children on 
the issues affecting their lives and to advocate for changes. 
 
 
7.2.c. Objective 2: Shortfalls 
 
 
The overall challenge was the impact of COVID-19 and changes in the FCRA Rules which led to a 6 month 
delay in implementing field level activities.   
Due to the West Bengal State elections,   the State Commission for Protection of Child Rights and other 
institutional structures like Child Welfare Committee and the District Child Protection Unit were not 
function for a period of time which m ade the advocacy work very challenging. Advocating for the 
mainstreaming of the tools to be incorporated within the Juvenile Justice (JJ) system in Jharkhand was not 
possible, and  collaboration with the State government of Jharkhand is still ongoing for steering the district 
level and media advocacies. The project was able to initiate organisational level advocacy and cluster level 
advocacy work at the district level; however, the planned state level work could not be achieved. 
The Empowerplus Application and Livelihood Pre-conditioning could not be dessiminated by the partner 
organisations in 2022as the application is under upgradation for additional features based on user feedback. 
Addirionally once of the core consultants working on this passed away from  COVID and retrieving and 
getting another person to take the work forward caused further delays. 
As mentioned above in the principal accomplishment of objective 2, the partner organisations have taken 
up various initiatives at district and local level for making the CPC’s functional in West Bengal and 
Jharkhand. Despite the initiatives taken, some CPC’s are still not functional in some of the intervention 
areas for which the inclusion of CYiM leaders in the CPCs and ensuring child participation was not 100% 
achieved as targeted.   
 
 
7.3.a. Objective 3 
Children and Young People at risk of or affected by unsafe migration are resilient to challenge harmful 
social norms that perpetuate violence and stigma against the survivors of trafficking and exploitation. 
 
 
7.3.b. Objective 3: Principal accomplishments 
Community safe spaces were created in 70 locations for fostering discussions and reflection on gender, 
sexuality and norms. The project engaged 2,054 CYP to increase their knowledge on Gender and 
Sexuality, risks and support services. 991 CYiM realized appropriate information related to coping with 
internal reactions, 334 CYiM reported a sense of calm and decreased negative emotions. 1,415 CYiM 
were able to identify risks they could face, 1,458 CYiM identified the institutions that can respond to their 
safety concerns and they know how to approach them, 2,941 CYiM demonstrated critical 
thinking/problem solving skills and 264 survivors and CYiM reported increased connectedness with 
peers, family, and kinship network. The above outputs were achieved as a result of 421 trainings on 
Gender and Sexuality, 310 trainings on Continuum of Care Approach, Socio Ecological Approachn of 
MHPSS, and 2464 workshops and reflection sessions with girls and 1811 workshops and reflection 
sessions with boys. 
Increased collective actions were observed at the community level through theatre, sports, arts by girls, 
boys, parents and survivors of trafficking to challenge harmful practices. 227 community based social  
actions were organised by CYiM on gender based harmful practices and stigma associated with trafficking. 
3,032 influential leaders and communicators participated in social action events, among them 398 
influential leaders and communicators made public declarations against gender based harmful practices and 
have shown support to survivors. 
669 community male members are able to recognise negative gender norms behind revictimization of 
survivors and harmful practices; like forced marriage and 564 male family members showed support to 
 
 
girls by preventing early marriage and byapproaching survivors and encouraging them to live a stigma 
free life. 
 
 
7.3.c. Objective 3: Shortfalls 
Development of  Social Behaviour Change guideline based on global guidelines with techniques and tips 
followed is ongoing in collaboration with WINDCHANGERS, after the completion of the same, partners 
will be provided training on how to use the materials. Contextualisation of the stories based on the feedback 
from the partners and children has taken longer than anticipated, however we strongly feel that this process 
is critical, and therefore have not taken shortcuts to speed the process up. 
The understanding on gender and sexuality is varied among the project partner organisations, where a was 
observed among the frontline workers when they initiated discussions on gender and sexuality. For many, 
they felt comfortable to talk about sexuality, menstrual health, safe and unsafe touch. 
In conducting reflection sessions with boys, the partner organisations shared a challenge relating to the drop 
out. This drop out rates of boys are much higher among the boys in the age group 15 -18 years and above 
upto 24 years since the boys are mostly migrating out from the villages with their  families for seasonal 
works. 
In conducting reflection sessions with the girls also related to drop out, Girls who are in the age group 18- 
24 years are getting married or migrating with families for work, or going out for educational purpose since 
there is no proper infrastructure for higher studies in most of the intervention areas. 
One of the challenge faced by the partners at field level is getting in touch with the male members and 
bringing all the male members in one place to initiate discussions. The male members are the main 
breadwinners of the family and most of them migrate out of the village in search of work and are therefor 
unavailable.

How will your team use this information to change the way you work? 
Based on the learnings of Year 1 of OAK Phase-3, in Year 2 the plan is as followed: 
1. Partner organisations have been provided with handholding support on BECOME Tool, MHPSS, 
Gender and Sexuality, Safeguarding etc. since the understanding of the tools and other relevant 
topics under this intervention required more support. 
2. 1 state level consultation in West Bengal, 103 multi-sectorial coordination meetings and 76 liasons 
have been done with various formal and informal child protection duty bearers to make the 
community level safety net functional with a focus on sustainability, advocating on prevention of 
trafficking at all levels of government and engaging with relevant agencies of the state to address 
the rehabilitation and reintegration needs of the survivors. 
3. Considering the power dynamics, participation of men seems crucial as typically men are the 
decision makers within the family, hence in Year 1, 669 male members can recognise negative 
gender norms behind revictimization of survivors and harmful practices; like forced marriage and 
564 male family members show support to girls by preventing early marriage and to survivors by 
encouraging them to live a stigma free life. 
4. Through development of the module on gender and sexuality, training sessions were organized with 
the frontline wo rkers on Gender and Sexuality, and the project engaged  with 3032 influential 
leaders and communicators in various social events to conduct discussions on the issues of gender 
and sexuality as well as engaging with community beliefs towards addressing stereotypes. 
5. Community safe spaces have been created in all the 70 locations to ensure safe spaces for the CYP 
to engage in dialogue. 
6. Online training programmes are created on Child Protection, Gender and Sexuality, MHPSS, 
Safeguarding for the service providers associated with district level child protection institutions. 
7. The inter-agency collaborations were strengthened to envisage new avenues of skill building and 
livelihood opportunities for women through linkage with varios government schemes, scholarships 
and vocational trainings. 
 
 
8. Training has been provided to the organisation level and field level focal points on the 5 modules 
of safeguarding  to ensure that the organizations ensure suitable ways to ‘respond’ to the harms that 
have happened beyond reporting or identify measures to address the immediate needs of the victim. 
9. Pandemic induced victims were taken into considerations where the children who have lost one or 
both parents during the pandemic were linked with various schemes of the gover nment like 
sponsorship scheme, and the education system through admission in Kasturba Gandi Vidyalayas, 
and dry ration support through linkage with CHILDLINE etc. 
Through the   following initiatives based on the feedback received from children during the ba seline 
evaluatuion, the voices of the children raised have been considered at all levels of intervention. 
In Year 2, the aim is to achieve results that could not be achieved in Year 1, and to respond to the 
recommendations from the evaluation, such as implementation of the child protection policy of Ministry of 
Women and Child development in every school in the intervention areas, leveraging learnings to inspire 
similar initiatives in the sector, create models to demonstrate results by strengthening organiz ations with 
certain strengths in the strategic direction, leveraging organization’s capacity on psychosocial interventions, 
registration system at Panchayat level for tracking and monitoring, Influencing Gram Panchayats to 
prioritize vulnerable families un der the list of potential beneficiaries of different welfare and poverty 
reduction programmes and engaging with relevant agencies of the state to adequately address the 
rehabilitation and reintegration needs of survivors. Based on this, the following actibivities for the 2nd year 
are planned: 
1. Capacity building support to  grass root level workers who are continuously engaging in all the 
activities at field level. The capacity building workshops have been planned to be done primarily 
on Gender and Sexuality and MHPSS through face to face discussions and activity oriented sessions 
which the frontline workers can use during field level implementation. 
2. Based on feedbacks received from the frontline workers during the review meetings and partners 
meet, handholding support in Empowerplus upgraded version and the Livelihood Preconditioning 
Tool will be provided.   
3. Training of Trainers (TOT) on Problem Management Plus (PM+) a WHO transdiagnostic 
psychological intervention for common mental health problems for the fro nt line workers for 
psychological intervention program, that can be delivered by non-specialist counsellors. 
4. The Core Committee Group which has been formed in West Bengal and Jharkhand will be 
restructured again since the group is of revolving nature to fo ster the principles of partnership, 
participation and collaboration in the project more effectively. 
5. The Technical Advisory Group (TAG) will be revived in West Bengal and Jharkhand in Year-2 The 
members of the TAG will support in providing technical inputs for revising the tools, align the tools 
developed with Juvenile Justice (Care and Protection) Act, 2015 and will provide support in 
strategic advocacy with government. 
6. E-learning materials will be developed on the 5 basic child protection laws of India in  local 
languages (Hindi and Bengali) which will promote understanding among the frontline workers on 
the legal framework. 
7. The plan in Year 2 is to conduct a series of state and district level consultations in West Bengal and 
Jharkhand on Gender Responsive Prevention and Response to Child Protection with Child 
Protection Duty Bearers and with Media on Ethical Reporting to focus more on the engagements 
with government bodies and media and boost up the advocacy initiatives. 
8. Tdh staffs will be more available to the partners (specially Jharkhand) to support Gender and Norm 
intervention, MHPSS Intervention through sports and art methodologies due to the low  level of 
understanding among partners. 
9. Tdh will create more space for knowledge and information sharing among the partners as exchange 
of ideas, actions and good practices play an important role in design and plan for advocacy.  
 
 
Longitudinal study will be conducted to understand “diffusion in social norms change around gender 
among adolescent and young people and its outcome on stigma against the survivors of exploitation, their 
social cohesion and psychosocial resilience. The objective of the longitudinal study is to understand how 
structured CYiM led social behaviour change communication interventions contribute to organised 
diffusion in social norms change and supporting social cohesion, psychosocial resilience and then 
effectively reduced stigma against survivors of exploitation. This study will further help us to understand 
the conditions that help or hinder changes in gender norms.

How will you share what you have learned inside and outside your organisation? 
The learning that is being generated within the Project have been disseminated in various ways. 
• Tdh’s Social Media Platform: Good practices and learnings are shared through Tdh’s Facebook, 
Instagram and LinkdIn page with readers, like minded organisations, academics, mental health 
practitioners and members. 
• Partners meet: Project updates, good practices and experiences are shared thr ough the partners 
meet. Partners have planned to share the learnings from this project beyond the 30 organisations. 
• Joining Forces: Tdh is a member of Joining Forces – a national level network of six INGOs. 
Current country and state level focus of the network is ending violence against children. The 
learnings from this project is shared among the network partners and adopted in the programmatic 
framework. 
• Monthly Steering Meetings:  Monthly meetings were conducted with all the 30 partner 
organisations to share new learnings and project updates. The meetings were also a platform to 
discuss any challenges and come with solutions collectively and steer the activities towards their 
completion within the time frame. 
• Core Committee: Core committee formation has  been done in West Bengal and Jharkhand to 
strategize and track activities related to the the outcomes, to establish sharing of information 
through partnership dialogue, to enable handholding support and supervision to all partner 
organizations (30 partner s), for identification of need for technical support and resources for 
enabling the same and leading forward advocacy action at district and state level. Strenghtning the 
core committee will be planned for better implementation. 
• Technical Advisory Group: The TAG that was formed in the earlier Oak grant phase will be 
restructured in West Bengal and Jharkhand . The members of the TAG will support in providing 
technical inputs for revising the tools, align the tools developed with Juvenile Justice (Care and 
Protection) Act, 2015 and will provide support in strategic advocacy with government. 
• Collaboration with University:  In collaboration with Rabindra Bharati University (RBU), the 
handbook on Gender and Social Norms has been developed for the frontline workers of the piloting 
partners who are focusing on outcome 3. 
• IEC Materials on Safeguarding and SBCC:  The IEC materials developed by Tdh on 
safeguarding has been disseminated among the partner organisations. The Social Behavious 
Change Communication Materials de velopment are under process in collaboration with 
WINDCHANGERS where comic strips and videos will be developed in vernacular languages and 
disseminated, which can be tailored by the partners to their local context. 
• E-Learning Modules on Child Protection La ws: E-learning materials will be developed on the 
5 basic child protection laws of India in local languages (Hindi and Bengali) which will promote 
understanding among the frontline workers on the legal framework. 
 
 
• SPHERE India: Tdh is member of SPHERE India, a National Coalition of Humanitarian Agencies 
in India. The members include key nodal agencies from Govt. of India, UN Agencies, INGOs, NGO 
Networks and National NGOs. Sphere India facilitates Inter Agency Coordination, Training and 
Capacity Building, Co llaborative Advocacy and Information Knowledge and Learning 
Management through a collaborative process for Quality & Accountability. The learnings from this 
project is shared among the network partners and adopted in the programmatic framework. 
• RACHSA Nework: Tdh is also the member of an advocacy group, RACSHA (Rise Against Child

Progress Report for the period of 1/07/2021 to 31/10/22 
  
  
During Second wave of Covid-19, we started working in the field to form community groups. As 
many issues were discussed during Micro level planning, the groups started forming based on 
various issues associated with different communities like farmers groups for agriculture related 
issues, women groups for livelihood related issues, adolescent groups for child marriage or 
migration related issues. Through general issue discussion and introducing the objective of this 
project, several women and adolescents girls related issues like negligence to menstruation health, 
early child marriage, school drop out, early pregnancy, random child birth at home, gender based 
violence(especially domestic violence)  etc. Considering these issues a few mixed adult women and 
adolescent groups were formed and Mukti field ACV staff started organizing several workshops on 
gender discriminations with the help of various participatory tools supported by Rupantaran and 
Prajaak. 8 Adolescent girls boys and 5 women groups( total 320 groups members) got support to 
build their perspective on gender related issues and gradually started identifying gender 
discrimination in their personal life. The basic sensitization workshops also conducted among adult 
men groups. As a result, women started taking active role in the collective discussions making 
process and the woman man ratio in every meetings are nearly became 1:1 as other men are also 
started taking positive initiative to create a safe and non judging space for women. Adolescent 
groups have also started identifying their issues and through root cause analysis, they are getting 
a clear understanding on gender discrimination and how it impacts their lives( issues came during 
discussion like - restriction in higher education for girls, mobility restrictions, gender role etc)  
As an outcome, Heramba Gopalpur women group joined in a community led event organized on 
15th Aug 2022. For Heramba Gopalpur women group, it was the first time for them when they 
participated in a rally and slogan writing. In the main part of the program they also gave a speech 
on Independence day.  
 
 
 
7.1.c. Objective 1 Challenges and obstacles. 
We expect that the work toward grant objectives may not occur as originally planned due to internal and external factors.  
Please share a candid assessment of areas of challenge and learning and whether any adjustments were made. 
 
Oak Progress Report.    3 
  
During the community groups formation, we initially faced a huge political challenges as most of 
the group members were belong to  different vulnerable groups, the ruling party members started 
giving objections to conduct any meetings regarding their issues. For these political pressure, a 
large number of members started dropping out from the groups and refuse to take part into any 
discussions. At that time, the whole ACV working team started approaching to the panchayat 
members to join the meetings to understand the objective of this project. But due to the presence of 
the Panchayat members, some kind of pseudo domination in each discussion started taking places 
and these discussions spaces turned into a space for ruling and opponent party members and the 
real issues left undiscussed. In such situations a few perspective building workshops conducted by 
the facilitation of  ACV team among all the groups to develop the capacity of the community 
members as well as the Panchayat members to understand the concept of right based and 
community led approach and to develop the relationship between community members , ACV team 
members and Panchayat or other powerful stakeholders( teachers, doctors, health workers). With 
several set of meeting and discussion or activities ( perspective building support and 
module provided  by Praxis, Rupantaran, DRCSC, NCAS and Prajaak) , the groups became stable 
and the power influence tends to decrease over time.    
In the beginning of 2nd year ( 1/07/2021),  new field staff and program coordinator were recruited 
who were not completely aligned with the project goal. Hence, it became a bit challenging to the 
ACV staff to be the facilitators and as a result, most of the proposed solutions started 
become partially influenced by the project staff itself such as the decisions taken by collective 
discussion on training topics, scheduling the meetings, issue identification etc. This challenge 
gradually solved with the continue handholding support of other ACV resource partners and 
internal staff meeting and orientation program.            
           
 
 
 
7.2.a. Objective 2 Objective 
Women, Youths and adolescent groups will act as change makers in the community 
 
 
 
7.2.b. Objective 2 Progress. 
What progress has been made toward the above grant objective(s) over the last grant period?  Please focus your response on

Oak Progress Report.    4 
  
Through several gender sensitization workshops, women started identifying gender discrimination 
in their personal and social spaces. The issues mostly addressed by the women groups are - 1. 
Limited scope for sharing personal opinion in the group meetings,2.Lack of confidence to talk 
about the violation of their basic rights(mobility, earning options, decision making, domestic 
violence, health related issues). The sensitization program performed by Mukti ACV field staff 
helped those women to understand the reason of these issues through but it takes a lot more time to 
develop their confidence to talk about those issues freely in front of other community members. In 
order to achieve the safe environment for all the women members from different 
communities(Farmers, daily labour, Migrant workers etc) many orientation program conducted and 
as a result, women started taking initiatives to raise voice against discrimination. Initiative taken 
by the Women collective - 1. Rally to raise awareness on gender based discrimination, slogan 
writing 2. Motivational speech on woman's empowerment by women members, 3. Awareness 
program on Menstruation Health, 4. Developing business and marketing idea for sanitary pad 
production 5. Started taking action on community led advocacy to avail free ambulance 
service(which was provided earlier and recently has been stopped by the local Govt) for the 
pregnant women.  
Initiative taken by the Adolescents groups -  1.Both boys and girls equally participated in rally to 
raise awareness on  menstruation health related taboo and developing a street play group to raise 
awareness on early child marriage and Child labour (Adolescent boys are forced to start working to 
support their family from early ages and this situation increases the possibility of unsafe migration) 
. 2. Active role has been taken by the adolescent groups in community led advocacy on river 
embankment related issues to collect the required evidence.3. Adolescent groups are also 
planning to take initiative to reduce the negative impact of unnecessary usage of social media and 
extreme addiction of online gaming in the youth community.       
 
 
 
7.2.c. Objective 2 Challenges and obstacles. 
We expect that the work toward grant objectives may not occur as originally planned due to internal and external factors.  
Please share a candid assessment of areas of challenge and learning and whether any adjustments were made. 
 
Oak Progress Report.    5 
  
  
Initially we faced several challenge to mobilize the women and develop their confidence to take any 
initiative to raise voice against the violation of their rights and various gender based 
discriminations. During the 15th Aug program planning, all the woman's collective(5groups - 120 
women) refused to participate actively in awareness program as they were concerned about the 
comments they might have received for stepping out from their home to participate in  such 
community events and as a result they ended up suggesting the Adolescent groups(8 groups - 100 
boys and 120 girls) to attend this event to fulfill the purpose. To overcome such challenges, we 
requested these women groups to arrange a few meetings to talk about this issue. To resolve 
this,  Mukti ACV team facilitated the risk assessment process and orientation programs to develop a 
clear perspective about the consequences of their initiative and who and how the others will be 
impacted through these. With several approach, a few women from each groups convinced to take 
lead to mobilize other women and they successfully completed the event.  
In community led advocacy group which is working on river embankment issue, several challenges 
were experienced by the vulnerable community representatives during the larger village level 
committee formation. As river embankment issue is one of the major issues in Heramba gopalpur 
area which is untreated by local Govt for past few years, people from most effected 
communities refused to talk about their issues to find a possible solution through collective 
discussion as they were more concern about their approach might get wrong and they will become 
more vulnerable. Hence a conflict created in this village level committee and they started deforming 
it. To resolve such issues, the objective of community led advocacy again properly defined among 
these committee members by the ACV facilitators and by the support of NCAS member, the 
committee started becoming united     
 
 
 
7.3.a. Objective 3 Objective 
Creating livelihood opportunities in the community 
 
 
 
7.3.b. Objective 3 Progress. 
What progress has been made toward the above grant objective(s) over the last grant period?  Please focus your response on 
progress against desired outcomes or changes that occurred because of the activities; do not only describe what activities 
occurred or products of these efforts (i.e., Training manuals; policy briefs, etc).  
 
Oak Progress Report.    6 
  
  
The communities which are relatively vulnerable based on their livelihood have been included 
in this initiative. The process started with several focus group discussion to understand the  current 
livelihood status of several communities  and the challenges they are facing right now. 
Through  multiple meetings,  women groups turned into the most vulnerable groups as they all are 
directly or indirectly involve in several livelihoods(especially farming, fishing) but don't have 
minimum agency over the earnings and the second most vulnerable community in Heramba 
Gopalpur area is the farmers community. Earning through farming became one of the unstable 
options as in past 4 years, people of Heramba Gopalpur experienced four disasters(Amphan, 
Phaani, Bulbul and Yaash) which created flooding situations in their area. This situation mostly 
forced the farmers community (specially male farmers with limited land) to become 
seasonal migrant workers to run their families. On other hand, the degree of vulnerability of this 
farmers community is also high due to the lack of knowledge about cropping as most of the lands 
are only used for monocropping so the net worth of annual produce become low as respect to the 
need of a farmer's family. This situation also leads most of the farmers to become a migrant 
workers for most of the period of time in a year. In such situation, to revive the soil condition, 
organic farming training has been provided to almost 300 farmers where around 30% farmers 
(including women and men) started making organic fertilizer and pesticides to reduce farming 
expenses.   
And among the women and mixed groups, these groups started exploring suitable options according 
to their resource and abilities. Through several participatory approach, few livelihood options came 
up from these groups such as chicken rearing (especially native breed) indigenous seed collection 
and selling, crab culture , sanitary pad production, paper plate making, scented stick and candle 
making etc. Along with skill development training, several orientation program and marketing skill 
development process also going on among these groups. The training needs came up through local 
demand and supply chain analysis. Presently farmers groups(Women and men) and other interested 
members from different communities received chicken rearing training and started chicken farming 
in a small scale.    
 
 
 
7.3.c. Objective 3 Challenges and obstacles. 
We expect that the work toward grant objectives may not occur as originally planned due to internal and external factors.  
Please share a candid assessment of areas of challenge and learning and whether any adjustments were made. 
 
Oak Progress Report.    7 
  
The concept of having an additional livelihood option in their own locality is largely ignored in 
various communities in Sundarbans. As farming is the primary livelihood for ~85% of population 
in Heramba Gopalpur GP and most of the lands are used for mono cropping, for the additional 
income purpose, most of the people (especially male members of the family) became engage in 
seasonal fishing or became migrant worker for a long period of time in the year. These issues were 
observed during the FGD with the farmers, fisherman and daily labour groups. Through meetings 
and  discussion, as different additional livelihood options were introduced to these groups, mostly 
male members were refused to take interest for further discussion or initiatives. In such situation, 
the additional livelihood implementation initiative started with the women groups who are involved 
with different livelihood ( farming, daily labour, fishing). Through new FGH(Focus Group 
Discussion) , several needs emerged but also a clear demand came from the communities regarding 
financial and marketing support for any production related business ideas such as Pickle, Scented 
Sticks, Soft toys etc. Then the ACV team started taking different approach to build capacity of the 
communities to understand the local market demands and supply chain for developing own ideas 
according to the needs of the local market. To develop such capacity, several tools were given to 
help them understand the current market demands. Parallelly, a few orientation programs were 
conducted to help them understand their role to sustain their livelihood.  These all initiatives are 
gradually helping to eliminate the concept of dependency to third parties for raw material 
collection, product manufacturing and marketing.   
Presently , the woman groups mapped and analyzed the basic local market demands and according 
to that, they have selected two livelihood options - 1. Sanitary pad manufacturing and marketing 2. 
Chicken rearing(native breed). Hence to establish their business, the woman groups are making 
strategies to overcome these challenges.
