modifications in line with the project’s vision. We pivoted our communication strategy to focus on 
the deeper aspects of SRH, modified our outreach methodology to incorporate behavior change 
principles, and focused on better understanding the attitudinal barriers of health staff that hamper 
service provision. While on one hand, these changes represent a significant strategic shift aligning 
with the project's intent, they also provided immense organizational learning. As we began 
implementing this revised approach, we saw better engagement with the community and our 
improved ability to elicit more meaningful responses from our audience that will be helpful in 
driving the desired behavior change. 
Summary of progress on project outcomes: 
1. Trained 12 youth leaders on new communication strategy 
• Re-designed our communication strategy to focus on rights, barriers and gender using a 
behavioral change approach (details in 7.1.c). 
• Conducted four-day residential training followed by three-day practice for youth leaders and 
their supervisor. 
• Youth leaders initiated community outreach using participatory interactions to make young 
people more active participants in their own behavior change. 
2. Oriented 9,410 young women and 7,640 young men on life skills, rights, and gender 
Young women 
• Engaged with young women with focus on SRH rights, barriers faced in exercising these 
rights and their aspirations for change. 
• The sessions sparked interest among young women and led to provoking questions – on 
curbs on movement or clothing choices unlike male counterparts, on restrictions during 
menstruation, and around other practices that make them uncomfortable. The discussions set 
the foundation for subsequent rounds that will build their skills to communicate these issues 
with adults and partners. 
• Promoted our AI-powered chatbot (Disha Didi) and conducted SRH sessions in schools 
reaching 1,800 girls. 
Young men 
• Conducted sessions with men on relevant SRH information, particularly contraception, and 
emphasized their role in supporting women's SRH.

finances. This encouraged discussions on the importance of family planning giving segway

7.1.c. Objective 1 Challenges and obstacles. 
We expect that the work toward grant objectives may not occur as originally planned due to internal and external factors.  
Please share a candid assessment of areas of challenge and learning and whether any adjustments were made. 
Key learnings and insights: 
• Communication strategy – Developed in collaboration with a social and behavior change 
communication consultant, the revised communication strategy emphasizes on key 
principles – rights, power, space, participation and inclusion – and works to address key 
factors that influence behavior, including social norms, beliefs and values. The youth 
leaders are on a learning curve implementing these newer concepts in the community, and 
 
Oak Progress Report.    4 
we are continuously adapting and refining the strategy (including combining modules) 
based on their experience and learnings. 
• Working with the SRH framework – The revised strategy meant a major shift in the 
community engagement approach of youth leaders, with focus on understanding the target 
audience's attitudes, beliefs, and motivators, and working on changing SRH-related 
behaviors keeping these in mind. This approach brought forth unanticipated responses from 
the communities, including seeking solutions for structural barriers (such as movement 
restrictions) and other allied issues (like child marriage). This in turn has meant more 
intense mentorship by IDF to equip youth leaders to manage such conversations. Keeping 
this in view, we have planned periodic capacity building of youth leaders to enable them to 
effectively moderate such conversations and offer support/referrals. 
• Prevailing attitudinal barriers among providers – We introduced a tool – an adaptation of 
Ipas’s Stigmatizing Attitudes, Beliefs and Actions Scale (SABAS) – to measure health 
staffs’ attitudes, perceptions and stigma related to abortion and contraception. The tool 
comprises of 25 statements that the respondent rates on a Likert scale which is used to 
measure three important dimensions, negative stereotyping, exclusion and discrimination, 
and fear of contagion from those who associate with abortion and contraception. The tool 
helped us discover prevailing negative beliefs and attitudes that hinder service provision – 
such as women who use birth spacing may become promiscuous or having an abortion may 
become a habit for women – that we will work on addressing. 
• Safe spaces – Youth leaders created six safe spaces in anganwadi centres and schools to 
provide young girls an environment where they could have confidential and non-judgmental 
conversations about SRH; these were visited by over 560 young women and girls. While we 
received a positive response, we recognized the limitation of this approach with dependence 
on youth leaders and the spaces themselves not being accessible by young girls 
independently. We are re-visiting this and will test an approach where the safe space 
facilitates unrestricted access – for example, creating online forums to facilitate these 
conversations, encouraging leadership by the yuva saathis who can work with their peers to 
identify other such spaces and facilitate these conversations.

In Year 1, we laid the foundation for our intervention by conducting a community survey and 
facility-level assessment to identify gaps and better understand the needs of our target audience. We 
strengthened the capacity of healthcare providers and community intermediaries to provide youth-
responsive services and streamlined SRH services, especially at health and wellness centers for 
improved access. With this strong foundation and our outcome indicators in place, we are now 
prepared to focus our community-based efforts to improve SRH behaviors and practices. 
1. Selected intervention areas for community interventions: 
Working in consultation with district and block health officials, we selected six gram 
panchayats covering 23 villages in the three intervention blocks for community outreach 
activities prioritizing panchayats that were further from health facilities and had poor service 
access. We also selected three facilities – RH Rudranagar, RH Dwariknagar and RH 
Madhabnagar – for facility-level interventions. 
2. Conducted community-based assessment: 
To assess knowledge, behavior, practices and access barriers that young women and adolescents 
face, we conducted a cross-sectional community survey with 767 respondents (including 
adolescent girls, young women and men) in the three intervention blocks. Some key findings: 
• Young women and girls have high level of stigma, myths, and misconceptions related to 
SRH issues – most of them around menstruation (69%) and abortion (54%) 
• Agency is low – irrespective of marital status, young women and girls majorly rely on 
others to take decisions on education, marriage, healthcare, and pregnancy. 
• They have poor negotiating ability – more than one fourth adolescents reported poor ability 
to negotiate with parents regarding continuing education or time of marriage. 
• About one third of male respondents reported having a positive outlook towards women’s 
SRH. 
3. Developed outcome indicators: 
Based on the community assessment and our understanding of the current challenges, we 
determined outcome indicators and the expected level of change we anticipate by the project 
end. Please refer Annexure 2 for the indicator list.

adolescent/youth-friendly SRH services:

Madhabnagar.

leaflets in the Anwesha clinics for distribution and reference aids for counselors. 
5. Strengthened six HWCs to offer adolescent/youth-friendly SRH services and referrals: 
a. Needs assessment: Conducted needs assessment in six HWCs, key observations: 
• Except one, all HWCs had a community health officer (CHO) in place 
• Facility staff reported/demonstrated gaps in technical knowledge on contraception, and had

• While most HWCs followed waste management protocol, there were major gaps in infection

• Sub-optimal SRH service provision 
b. Capacity building:

(telemedicine) 
• Conducted centralized training for ANMs from all six HWCs with sessions on modern 
contraceptives, including model and hands-on practice on IUCD insertion; amendments to

pregnancy urging participants to focus on newly married young couples for delaying

Praajak’s work focuses on strengthening CBOs working in Sunderbans, to enable them integrate 
working on gender & child protection issues within their existing works. 
Over the last year the CBOs have been have been equipped with the knowledge and perspectives to 
identify and address issues of gender-based violence and violations of child rights within the 
communities they are working with through trainings. The CBOs have initiated outreach activities 
within women & children in the communities which is helping them understand the different 
gender & child protection issues in the communities that needs to be addressed. The CBOs, limited 
to working with men of the communities on livelihood issues are now expanding their works with 
women & children in the communities. Women, children & adolescents from the communities are 
also coming out for the first time as they find a platform to speak about themselves, share their 
concerns. 
Incidents of gender-based violence, violence against children are being reported with increased 
interactions of CBOs with women & children. This generated a need within CBOs to equip 
themselves to deal with such situations of violence and accordingly training plans were made with 
Praajak. Since dealing with cases require different systems and mechanisms to be in place, 
discussions on setting up organizational policies & systems were initiated. Thus, the management of 
the organizations have been part of discussions and planning on the development of child protection 
policies so as to ensure proper reporting mechanisms & handling of cases. 
The outreach activities are leading to formation of women and adolescent groups and there is a 
move towards collectivisation and working with the collectives, identifying leaders & developing 
leadership skills.

To advocate for health system strengthening for improving access to rights-based SRH services 
including comprehensive abortion care in Kalchini and Kolkata districts.  
FPA India has been providing SRH information and services in the aforementioned operational 
areas of Kalchini and Kolkata. Based on the steady increase in footfalls to the clinics of FPA 
India, or the number of beneficiaries reached through community-based interventions, there is a 
sustained need for SRH interventions. The public health infrastructure within the operational areas 
is also reliant upon the FPAI teams for last-mile service delivery (Kalchini), or to conduct male 
sterilization procedures (Kolkata). Ever since the onset of the pandemic, FPAI has received 
requests to increase the range of services provided (especially in Kalchini) and expand services to 
newer geographies (particularly in Kolkata). Through this objective, it is proposed to increase 
resource allocation, optimize the utilization of available resources and improve the capacities of 
health care providers for improving access.

An expansion of SRH Programme for Indigent Populations' Rights and Empowerment. 
The Project ASPIRE supported by Oak Foundation is being implemented in West Bengal through 
FPA India’s Kalchini and Kolkata Branches. It aims to expand access to sexual and reproductive 
health and empower individuals and communities to exercise their sexual and reproductive rights 
with gender equality, economic empowerment and thus poverty alleviation. 
The project has been implemented in West Bengal through FPA India’s Kalchini branch located in 
north of Bengal and FPA India Kolkata branch which is catering to the population of south Bengal. 
Under the project, FPA India Kalchini branch has expanded the geographical reach with SRH care in 
Madarihat block of Alipurduar District. The Satellite clinic established by FPA India in Madarihat 
under one of the specially funded projects for comprehensive abortion care was closed down after 
the funding was stopped, with Oak Foundation’s partial grant support, this clinic has been revamped 
with the staff, commodities, and maintenance. It is now being accessed by the people in and around 
Madarihat block. This block is divided into a diverse culture of different communities like Bengali, 
Nepali, Muslim, Adivasi, Rava, Mech, Garo & Toto, having their origin back to different places in 
India. The services provided at the Satellite clinic are being accessed by these communities and 
referral for SRH care has been done with FPA India’s Kalchini RHFPC.  With an expansion under 
ASPIRE project, Kalchini branch has taken up 17 new tea gardens in Madarihat and also covering 9 
new tea gardens in Kalchini block which were not regularly covered due to accessibility issues. The 
expansion is estimated to cover an additional 2,50,000 population together. 
FPA India Kolkata branch has been working in urban, peri-urban areas covering slum population in 
and around Kolkata including Howrah, Hooghly as well as parts of Sunderbans closer to the satellite 
clinics of FPA India Kolkata branch near Lake garden, Topsia and Rajarhat. Under ASPIRE project, 
it intervenes in south Bengal through to 5 selected blocks of Sunderbans, i.e. Basanti, Canning, 
Gosaba, Kultoli in 24 south Parganas and Hingalganj block in north 24 Parganas. With an expansion 
in 24 Parganas, Kolkata would be reaching out to approximately 8,00,000 new population over the 
period of project. 
Expansion includes working with women, men, transgender population, female and male sex 
workers  in selected areas of key population such as Sonagachi.

Understanding the health needs and capacities. 
Kalchini: 
To understand the communities’ health needs, social heath determinants and current capacities of the 
existing healthcare system, Kalchini conducted 7 FGDs with ASHAs, ANMs, AWWs, PRI members, 
Tea garden health service providers and tea garden community members. The findings indicated the 
need of clinical training to the current service providers for sexual and reproductive health. There is 
no apprehension amongst the community members for accessing services at the public health facility 
however, public health facilities and tea garden hospitals are not equipped with the staff and 
commodities.  It is resulting in either people ignoring the health needs or availing health services at 
the private health facilities. Most of the tea garden hospitals in the selected intervention areas are 
non-functional and some tea gardens in Kalchini are accessed by the community but these hospitals 
are largely dependent on external sources like FPA India for commodities and services. 
Kolkata (Sunderbans): 
In Sunderbans however, in depth interviews were conducted with local women along with 26 FGDs 
with local women and men’s groups, frontline workers, PRI members because it was completely new 
intervention area taken by FPA India for SRH care. The healthcare infrastructure in Sunderbans in 
selected 5 blocks was found to be fragmented largely because of its locale which poses difficulty in 
accessing the islands. Institutionalized health care is either non-existent or inadequate. This leaves 
healthcare choices for the people of these areas limited to indigenous healthcare providers using 
herbal medicinal supplements from forest resources and private healthcare providers which demand 
out of pocket expenses. There is a question on the qualifications of the private health care providers 
as well. Both the branches have started their interventions in the selected areas, however building 
rapport and increasing accessibility may take time for focused SRH intervention especially to avail 
safe abortion care and services related to gender based violence.

7.1.c. Objective 1 Challenges and obstacles. 
We expect that the work toward grant objectives may not occur as originally planned due to internal and external factors.  
Please share a candid assessment of areas of challenge and learning and whether any adjustments were made. 
• The local district authorities rely on the FPAI team in Kalchini to deliver last mile 
contraceptive supplies and immunization services to needy populations in hilly terrains where 
there are no motorable roads or government health facilities. While the intervention by FPA 
India helps to build partnership with Government, it consumes lot of resources in order to 
make health care available and accessible to the most needy population. 
• It is challenging to get cooperation of BDOs for capacity building and interventions in 
Sunderbans with health facilities as they expect approval from dept of Sunderbans affairs or 
state government to implement activities. However, local administration like panchayat 
members are cooperative and provide support to the team. 
• The selected intervention areas of Sunderbans are financial and human resource consuming. 
The meetings in regard to advocacy and partnership with government officials for capacity 
building, trainings of grassroot level staff, doctors, and strengthening the hospital systems 
etc.  require participation of experienced and senior staff at the initial stage. These areas are 
geographically hard to reach and in order to return to the cities after intervention, teams need 
to adhere to timings of transports available. Hence, simultaneously meetings and service 
delivery become difficult to cover both service delivery and advocacy aspects hence it also 
results in delay/ slow progress.   
• Currently there is no programme implementation plan being directly implemented as per the 
budget at district level. District health administration has been collecting information through 
the meetings conducted with public health officials and other partners where the issues of 
implementation and special project budgets are being discussed. However, as the PIP of 2022-
2024 is already done and revision will be done in 2023, there is no action, directive suggested 
so far. The 1st scope to put forward the suggestions would come in the mid- review meeting.  
• While most of the Tea garden hospitals are defunct, the staff is present in the hospital and 
many of them have not undergone any clinical training for a long time. This training will be 
conducted at the later stage when funds for commodities are strengthened at the tea garden 
level to ensure that the staff undergone training have sufficient commodities and resources to 
provide these services.

The intervention areas selected from Sunderbans are susceptible to natural calamities like cyclones 
that can throw planned interventions out of gear, stretch health systems and exacerbate 
vulnerabilities. Therefore, under the project, disaster preparedness trainings are considered for the 
capacity building of the community members and stakeholders. The intervention for disaster 
preparedness under ASPIRE project is anticipated in phase 2. FPA India has received a special grant

through MISP (Minimum Initial Service Package) training.  During the reporting period, 1 MISP

principles of providing survivor centered care and communication skills.

• How does the CSE module integrate aspects related to gender and diversity? 
FPA India has a comprehensive sexuality education module, designed to equip adolescents with 
knowledge, skills, attitudes and values related to sexuality and relationships. The aim of this CSE 
module is to encourage young adolescents to enjoy the growing up phase safely, responsibly and 
healthily. As one of the components, ‘Gender and Diversity’ is introduced in the module. The 
sessions based on Gender and Diversity cover difference between gender and sex; exploring 
gender roles and attributes; understanding perceptions of masculinity and femininity within the 
family and across the life cycle; society’s changing norms and values; manifestations and 
consequences of gender bias, myths; and inequality, recognizing and understanding the range of 
diversity in our lives (e.g., faith, culture, ethnicity, socio-economic status, ability/disability, HIV 
status and sexual orientation); recognizing discrimination, its damaging effects and being able to 
deal with it; developing a belief in equality etc.

7.1.b. Objective 1 Progress. 
What progress has been made toward the above grant objective(s) over the last grant period?  Please focus your response on

Swaniti Initiative conducted a baseline study to determine the accessibility of Government ‘Social 
Protection’ schemes by tea garden workers, across gardens in four districts of West Bengal i.e 
Darjeeling, Alipurduar, Kochbihar, and Jalpaiguri.  
The study included a sample of 7488 respondents from these four districts of West Bengal. The 
study was conducted using three methods: Household surveys, semi-structured interviews, and 
focused group discussions. The data was collected by Swaniti team and volunteers through digital 
intervention of Surveyman–a survey management tool.  
  
Using this report as a backbone, Swaniti designed interventions across all the 4 districts mentioned 
above.

Based on our findings some of which are: complete lack of grievance redressal mechanisms as 
reported by 100% of the respondents and 1 out of every 4 respondents had incorrect information 
printed on their Aadhaar Card, the following challenges were faced:  
Challenges: 
• The study faced challenges during data collection, with respondents initially reluctant to 
share information. However, our swaniti team  and volunteers were able to explain the 
purpose of the study and its potential benefits to the tea workers.  
 
Oak Progress Report.    3 
• Access to information was another challenge, with most respondents needing to be made 
aware of important social protection schemes. The surveyors had to explain these schemes 
and how the tea workers could benefit from them. 
Key Learning 
Overall, the study highlights the need for greater awareness and accessibility of  Government 
‘Social Protection’ schemes for tea garden workers in West Bengal. There is a need for robust 
mechanisms to be placed to ensure that all the tea garden workers receive benefits from these 
schemes.

Challenges: 
Over the course of one year, a number of attempts were made through various channels in order to 
establish convergence and acquire the necessary permissions for conducting Aadhaar camps. These 
efforts were made in the face of significant opposition from various stakeholders (like private 
associations, local leaders, etc.) who stood to benefit from maintaining the existing status quo, 
rather than facilitating social and financial inclusion for the dependents of tea gardens. The 
opposition that the team encountered was multifaceted and ranged from vitriolic political 
interference sometime creating a major bottleneck in service delivery. Despite these challenges, the 
team was able to organize Aadhaar Enrollment/ correction camps that enabled more than 1300 
dependents to become eligible for a range of social welfare schemes.  
Learnings: 
As a learning strategy, Swaniti plans to onboard the district administrations of all four districts 
when organizing the Aadhaar camps and other interventions for a smooth flow of work processes. 
Swaniti also plans to onboard and work with the  forms of government and private ( Team 
associations) stakeholders to reach the maximum number of garden workers through the 
intervention plan in place.

7.3.b. Objective 3 Progress. 
What progress has been made toward the above grant objective(s) over the last grant period?  Please focus your response on 
progress against desired outcomes or changes that occurred because of the activities; do not only describe what activities 
occurred or products of these efforts (i.e., Training manuals; policy briefs, etc).  
Swaniti is working across a  range of stakeholders ranging from the communities into the district 
and state administration at large. We are in the process of creating pockets of evidence that can 
work as proof of concepts for scale up and adoption by the key decision makers. To achieve this we 
have designed the following strategy : 
Needs assessment: 
A thorough needs assessment was conducted to identify the specific challenges faced by tea garden 
workers in accessing social protection schemes. That includes issues related to documentation, 
access to information, and barriers related to caste or gender. 
Stakeholder mapping and engagement: 
Tea garden workers themselves, as well as community leaders, civil society organizations, and 
other Government stakeholders, were mapped to be engaged in the policy development process, 
ensuring that the needs and perspectives of the aforementioned groups are considered. 
Capacity building: 
The policy framework includes provisions for building the capacity of tea garden workers to access 
and utilize social protection schemes. This includes training on documentation and application 
procedures, as well as outreach and awareness raising efforts to ensure that workers are aware of 
their rights and entitlements. 
Interdepartmental coordination: 
Coordination between different government departments and agencies being crucial for ensuring

7.1.a. Objective 1 Objective 
To promote understanding and responsibility of employers, monitoring & regulatory bodies for 
creation of safe workplaces that are free of sexual harassment for institutionally employed women 
especially from resource poor background. 
 
 
 
7.1.b. Objective 1 Progress. 
What progress has been made toward the above grant objective(s) over the last grant period?  Please focus your response on 
progress against desired outcomes or changes that occurred because of the activities; do not only describe what activities 
occurred or products of these efforts (i.e., Training manuals; policy briefs, etc).  
Sanhita, in its effort to reach out to the most marginalised women workers within the organised sector, 
chose to engage with the women of the two most important industries in the state’s economy, viz, 
Jute & Tea. The Jute Mills in the state employs around 25000 women workers and the number is 
constantly increasing over the past two years. Historically, tea plantations have always been a 
traditional employer of large number of women. Almost 61% of the 3.2 lakh workers employed in 
the tea plantations of West Bengal are women. However, information on the safety of women workers 
(ie. sexual harassment as an aspect of working condition and welfare) is lacking in both the industries. 
In order to create a body of evidence which would help in advocacy for safe workspaces, Sanhita 
conducted Situation Analysis in both the industries to understand the safety of women workers (in 
the context of sexual harassment at workplace). The studies investigated the perceptions and 
prevalence of sexual harassment, the accountability of key stakeholders towards promoting safe 
workplace for women and the implementation of 2013 Act. These reports will serve as an important 
document on the safety of women workers in the jute mills and tea plantations. 
The Situation Analysis in Jute Industry was conducted in 2019 among women workers of 6 Jute Mills 
and leadership of 7 Jute Federations and 6 Jute Unions in Hooghly and North 24 Parganas districts. 
The Situation Analysis in Tea Plantations was conducted in 2022 and covered government and non-
government stakeholders like the district administration, the Labour Department of GoWB, the tea 
garden management, trade unions, tea associations; besides the women workers themselves from 24 
tea gardens in two (Dooars and Terai) of the three tea growing regions. 
Some of the key findings common to both industries that have emerged from the two independent 
studies are: 
• Lack of awareness regarding safe workplaces (including sexual harassment of women at 
workplace (SHW), the POSH Act, 2013 and its provisions) of almost all respondents in the 
jute mills & the tea gardens. 
• Compliance with the Act is marginal. 
• The issue of safe workplaces, in the context of sexual harassment, has not even been 
considered to be an integral component of working conditions or labour rights of women 
workers. 
The very large numbers of women employed in the two industries studied are vulnerable due to their 
position at the bottom of the hierarchy, casualisation of employment, overall isolated and dependent 
work conditions which are further compounded by poverty, low wages, migration status, domestic 
violence and low literacy levels. 
The government departments like the district administration (District Officer) who is responsible for 
overall implementation of 2013 Act in the respective districts or the labour department who is 
responsible for overall welfare and rights of workers have not adopted any appropriate measures 
towards ensuring safe workplaces for marginal women workers. 
 
Oak Progress Report.    3 
Sanhita has utilised the Situation Analysis findings as a tool for advocacy and intervention with 
multiple stakeholders. The outreach to women workers has been channelled through intense and 
consistent engagement with the Trade Unions who are directly working with them. Parallelly Sanhita 
conducted evidence-based advocacy with the employers, employers’ association, Labour Department 
and District Administration for creating safe workplaces for its women workers through 
implementation and monitoring of the 2013 Act. 
Overall Outcomes in both Industries 
• Knowledge Creation on status of safe workplaces for marginalised women workers: The 
2 Situation Analysis studies have created thus far unavailable information and evidence on 
the safety of women workers in the jute mills and tea plantations in West Bengal. 
• Voices of Women Workers were documented and shared with relevant stakeholders: 
The hitherto unheard voices of the underrepresented women workers in the jute mills and tea

intervention programmes. The voices served as evidence for Sanhita’s dialogue and advocacy 
with the key stakeholders like the monitoring bodies, the employers and the trade unions.

Sanhita organised 2 centralised meetings with the Jute Mill Unions and Tea Plantation Unions 
respectively. These events and the study findings got very well covered in the media articles. 
Following this different groups working with marginal/unorganised workers have reached out 
to Sanhita seeking further information. The Situation Analysis report soft and hard copies 
have been widely disseminated among these different groups and organisations. 
Major Outcomes in Jute Industry

Changemakers Program in Assam: 
The Changemakers Program was launched in Assam in April 2022 by Nazdeek’s grantee partner, 
PAJHRA. The purpose was to support 14 Adivasi youth to build knowledge and capacity towards 
holistic leadership skills. They were provided 6 in-person residential trainings, 2.5 days long each, 
covering sessions on (1) culture, history and society, (2) civic education, and (3) skills such as 
research, writing and reporting. Each training was followed by supervised field work in communities, 
wherein the participants conducted Focus Group Discussions, Individual structured interviews and 
submitted 4 reports per participant in the duration of the Program. Each of the reports were a part of 
their homework, which involved field work on a selected issue (such as the Public Distribution 
System or Anganwadi) and then preparing a report to document the activity and analyse the results. 
To culminate the program, 08 of the fellows were taken on an Exposure Visit where they visited 
historical monuments and interacted with organisations such as DISHA, Durbar, and Jana Sanghati 
Kendra. The idea behind the visit was to provide a chance to these Adivasi youths hailing from remote 
plantations and with limited opportunities for travel and urban exposure to learn about metropolitan 
lifestyles, Indian art and history, and to gain a wider understanding of socio-economic issues and 
CSO based interventions outside the plantations space and with demographies other than Adivasis. 
Of the 14 participants, 09 were women and 05 were men; most hailing from a social work and legal 
education background. The syllabus, pedagogy, design and monitoring, and selection process was 
developed under the guidance of subject matter experts such as Prof. Virginius Xaxa. For each 
session, training modules (15 in total) were created. 
In terms of the progress in achieving Objective 1, as the first in a three-year process, this Program 
was successful. Based on the skills mapping and expectation analysis conducted with the cohort, it is 
evident that they increased, and in certain subjects acquired first time knowledge, on matters of Indian 
governance structure, entitlements on health, food, labour, grievance redressal systems, information 
applications, issues-stakeholder-risk analysis, desk and field research and writing. Significantly, as is 
also reflected in the Most Significant Change stories attached herewith, they developed and 
strengthened critical thinking, public speaking, networking and outreach skills and grew 
demonstrably in confidence and self-respect. Motivated by the learnings, participants from the 
program have gone on to work as Accredited Social Healthcare Activists in tea plantations, gender 
committee President of tea worker women’s collectives, while some are conducting independent 
research on Deposit Linked Insurance Scheme for tea workers, have enrolled in graduate level Labour 
Economic courses, and have become more active as members of workers’ collectives. In various 
feedback sessions, the participants have shown a keenness to work within their community and on 
issues concerning tea workers at large in their professional or individual capacity, as feasible. 
Other Capacity Building Activities, Community Consultations, Meeting with line departments:

Approximately 34 capacity building, trainings of trainers, and community consultations were carried 
out by PAJHRA, with technical support from Nazdeek. Out of these, 04 offline and 03 online 
consultations were held to study the new labour regime and state rules, and formal comments thereto 
were submitted to the Labour Welfare Department, Assam. To commensurate the efforts, 07 meetings 
were held with government line departments (E.g. District offices of National Health Mission, 
Department of Health & Family Welfare, Social Welfare, Gaon Panchayat and local Police Units; 
State level Directorate of Social Welfare and NHM Headquarters) on issues connected with maternal 
health and maternity benefits, ration, sexual harassment at workplace, tea garden hospitals by 
community members and women collective’s representatives. 
The participants of the listed exercises included PAJHRA staff and volunteers, women and student 
collective’s leaders and women community members. Through this process of knowledge sharing 
on entitlements, recording ongoing issues and grievances, identifying redressal strategies, and 
sharing the same with communities, PAJHRA staff, volunteers, and women collective leaders were 
not only able to enhance their 
own understanding of entitlements and grievance redressal mechanisms (helpline numbers, postal 
complaints and in-person complaints submission directed primarily towards ration services, 
healthcare including maternal and child, Anganwadi system), they were also alongside able to 
strengthen and expand their rapport with communities. For the communities, at this stage of the 
project, it led to an increased awareness of their entitlements, approaches and processes to access 
them and filing grievances, and learning through direct demonstration by guided visits/helpline calls 
to authorities for filing complaints, advocacy, and seeking information from the authorities.  In 
Dibrugarh for instance, PAJHRA’s field educators organised community meetings with Aanganwadi 
Workers (AWWs) and ASHA workers for pregnant and lactating women, where the latter filed their 
grievances before the AWCs, shared their mutual challenges—especially those related to 
documentation and form filling. As a follow up, they persuaded the ASHA to accompany them to 
their sub-center to review the status of their maternity cash entitlement applications as per official 
records, submit additional documents, and file complaints over non-payment of cash installments. 
Following this, of the 10 partcipants, 3 received partial instalments, 2 full instalments, and the 
remaining were able to submit necessary documents. Some of the other key impacts observed 
included formation of unit committees of the women’s collective in Dibrugarh, Nagaon, and Golaghat 
Districts, and initiatives taken by women community members and collective’s leaders to address 
their grievances, especially those related to pregnant and lactating women, through meetings with 
government representatives. For instance, in a community meeting held in Duliajan (Dibrugarh), 28 
women community members identified inadequate food, nutrition, clothing and shelter, expensive 
and inadequate medical services, poor and inaccessible education as main issues plaguing the tea 
plantation workers. They were aided in the issue identification process by PAJHRA’s field educator 
and by the local ASHA, AWWs, AWW helpers, and Auxiliary Nursing Midwife (ANM) who had 
especially been invited as government representatives to this meeting for information exchange, 
advocacy, and grievance resolution purposes. The community members discussed best options for 
their advocacy on the identified issues and decided to tackle them by way of collectives. The 
collectives’ leaders (who were also present in the meeting) explanation of the purpose, process, and 
impact of women’s collectives played an important role in this decision. They observed that 
collectives’ strength and resources were necessary to support them in elevating their grievances to 
the government office bearers. Thus, they collectively decided to form a unit committee of the 
collective at Duliajan Gaon Panchayat and a regional committee at Duliajan.

The overall objective of the Project in West Bengal is to improve the livelihoods of tribals, resource poor and other vulnerable communities through promoting sustainable natural resource management and enhancing access to entitlements by building linkages with the Government institutions in 25 forest fringe villages of Ranibandh Block of Bankura District and 12 villages in Sandeshkhali-I block of North 24 Parganas. 
In this report, briefly we highlight the progress of the project based on the objectives as follows.
One Year Progress Report - UPDATED VERSI.Project Objective 1: Formation and Stren:
. 

Graph: Formation and Strengthening of Village Institutions in Ranibandh & Sandheskhali – I 



Tribal Farmer Service Centres (TFSCs) are formed to provide service and handholding support to the tribal farmers, disseminate information on government schemes, providing agricultural implements to farmers and establish demo-plots on agro-ecological practices and share information to small group farmers. Village Coordination Groups (VCGs) are formed with the existing Government committee (PRI, SHG, Mothers committee, ASHA workers, school management committee etc.) members to make the institutions effective and avail government schemes and entitlements. There’s no overlap of members between TFSCs and VCGs. Though, it was proposed to establish 25 TFSCs in each village but in some villages the habitations were too far from the main village (more than 3 kms.) and it was decided to have additional TFSCs. So, 28 TFSCs were formed. Total 123 monthly TFSC meetings have been conducted as on August 2023 to discuss about the issues pertaining to agriculture and livelihoods in their respective habitations. 
Similarly, to avail government schemes and entitlements, Village Coordination Groups (VCGs) are formed in 37 habitations spread across Bankura and North 24 Parganas. Out of 89 VCG members in Sandheshkhali – 1, 68 members are female and in Ranibandh, 76 members are female out of 250 total VCG members. 
Through VCGs, awareness meetings and orientations were organized on various existing government schemes like Kanyashree, Rupashree, Swasthya Sathi and Krishak Bandhu, among others. During these meetings, VCG members/community members are also trained on how to file petitions for both individual as well as community needs.  
The efforts of our VCG members and field staff have resulted in sanctioning of 15 individual entitlements (ST certificate) out of total 266 petitions submitted to Boyarmari – I Gram Panchayat under Sandeshkhali – I Block, North 24 Parganas. In Ranibandh, 118 (individual as well as community) petitions are submitted to Duare Sarkar and the petitions are yet to be sanctioned.
One Year Progress Report - UPDATED VERSI.Project Objective 2: Promoting agro-ecol:
.
Establishment of Demo-Plots
To promote agro-ecological practices amongst the farmers of Ranibandh block, 33 demo-plots are established out of which 24 are in Barikul GP and the rest are in Ranibandh GP. Out of 33 demo plots, 24 demo plots are established to promote vegetable crops such as cauliflower, pumpkin, cabbage, radish, tomato, bitter gourd, ridge gourd, bean etc. by following agro-ecological practices. Demo plots are owned by the farmers and are in the range of 1 – 1.5 bighas of land. The demo plots are our farmer field schools (FFS) where the progressive/interested farmers are brought for exposure and training on the agro-ecological practices. 9 plots were established to demonstrate the System of Rice Intensification (SRI) method.
Table: Details of Farmer Field Schools (FFS) conducted 

Total 45 FFS are conducted in our project location under Ranibandh block, out of which 13 FFS were conducted under Ranibandh GP and 32 FFS under Barikul GP. Total 518 farmers including 53 women farmers have attended the FFS where the farmers are trained on different package of practices (POPs) for crops. 
Through FFS, the farmers are also trained on preparing organic pesticides and fertilisers, land preparation, seed treatment, seed sowing techniques, weed control and pest management. FFS is an avenue to learn new knowledge related to agriculture that involves participatory process where farmers learn by doing under the able guidance of our field staff and experts. Liaising with PRIs and other line departments are done through regular sharing of information and meetings. The team members sought the advice of ADA on pest management in pumpkin and also on availing seeds. As the department is distributing only high yielding seeds and not indigenous, they were procured from outside. 
Agriculture Implements
Table: Agriculture Implement Given to TFSCs in Ranibandh

Farmers to ease the burden and reduce the time spent on threshing wanted to procure paddle paddy thresher, weeder and battery sprayer to increase the productivity. TFSCs procured Paddle Paddy Thresher (28), Cono Weeder (28), Battery Sprayer (6 and the remaining TFSCs will be provided soon) and Drums (56).  
Promotion of Pulses, Oilseeds and Vegetables 
During the Kharif season, 619 farmers received vegetable seed (cabbage, pumpkin, okra, horse gram, tomato etc.) support as part of promoting vegetables amongst the tribal farmers
Similarly, during the Rabi season, 26 farmers received mustard seeds of 1 kg on an average out of which the total mustard seed production was 597 kgs. Further, 59 farmers received support to promote kitchen garden. 
The farmers use high yielding variety of seeds in paddy and indigenous seeds for other crops. The shift to natural farming is a gradual process and so the gradation of change process is followed in CPF. In the initial phase, with few agro-ecological practices are promoted. Farmers are trained and encouraged to apply organic fertilizers (Ghanjeevamritam and Jeevamritam) and organic pesticides (Neemastram and Agniastram). The farmers treat the seeds before sowing by following the process of Beejamritam. 
Capacitating Maintenance of Watershed Structures 
Though the area receives good rainfall, the water is not being retained as the watershed structures constructed by government are not functional. So, the farmers are being given trainings on the maintenance of watershed structures. 
13 watershed structures were identified for repair and maintenance. 1 water tank was desilted in Parashiya village (Barikul GP) with the project cost of Rs.1.38 lakh and farmers contribution were Rs. 12,000. Around, 180 farmers did Shramdan for 5 days. CPFs intervention had a ripple effect and the communities desilted another tank on their own. Further, they also repaired a check dam by contributing Rs.12000/-. 
Soil Test 
To introduce the scientific method of understanding the soil, the farmers were trained on undertaking soil tests. Soil samples were sent for testing to KVK Sonamukhi, Bankura. In the first batch, soil samples of 121 farmers were sent and the result indicated that most of the soil contains high acidic content. The results and recommendations are shared with the farmers to improve the soil health. For instance, if the NPK (Nitrogen, Phosphorous and Potassium) content is low, the farmers are advised to increase the NPK by applying vermicompost, farm yard manure and green manure.  
Another batch of 107 Soil samples have been collected from the farmers and sent for testing. The results are yet to come.

.
As majority of the communities (70%) are dependent upon Non-Timber Forest Produces (NTFPs) for additional incomes, it is imperative that the communities are made aware about the importance of forest and their conservation. Towards this end, CPF has conducted 5 trainings on sustainable harvesting of NTFPs and value addition. 

Local experts and forest department officials were involved as resource persons to provide awareness to the NTFP collectors of our project villages. NTFP collectors were informed about the negative impacts of over harvesting of NTFPs and the need for value addition (leaf plate making, pickles etc.) to fetch more incomes. As far as marketing of the NTFPs are concerned, the project staff has explored different options by speaking and consulting number of persons/organizations such as the DFO of Bankura South Division, Ranibandh Range Officer, PRADAN, traders and NTFP collectors themselves. Two of our community field facilitators (CFFs) were trained on leaflet making and are aware of markets linkages. So, CPF is exploring to reestablish the market linkages through them and Self-Help Groups (SHGs) in each GP under Ranibandh Block for the marketing of NTFPs. As suggested, TRIFED option also will be explored. 
To enhance the income of landless, resource poor and single headed households, backyard poultry farming has been promoted. 42 community members from Ranibandh and Barikul were provided with poultry of local breed (3 each). 
Awareness meetings on Forest Rights Act (FRA-2006) are being conducted at the village level to make them aware about the Community Forest Rights (CFR) and the claim process. CPF has built rapport and collaborated with the Forest Department in plantation and value addition of NTFPs. The SDLC through Block Land Records Office (BLRO)/BDO has distributed IFR titles few years ago but in our operational areas no CFR titles have been submitted. The West Bengal Tribal Development Portal mentions that in Bankura district 210 CFRs have been distributed (https://adibasikalyan.gov.in/forest-right-act ) and we are trying to know where these titles are given. In the next year, we are planning to submit CFR claims in our villages after the formation of Forest Rights Committees (FRCs).

6a. Describe the organisation (include information on leadership,

There is much discrimination in our society based on economic condition, gender, 
caste, age, educational qualification etc. We believe that being treated equally 
with dignity is the basic thing one should expect from the society. With a vision of 
a transformed society built on equity, dignity and peace Rupantaran Foundation 
was formed in 2009 as not for profit, non-political organization. The word 
‘Rupantaran’ literally means ‘the process of positive transformation’. As our name 
suggests we are facilitating an empowering process of transformation towards 
equality, dignity and peace with the disadvantaged people to shape a just, 
equitable and nonviolent world. 
Presently we are directly operating in 4 blocks of Sunderbans in South 24 
Parganas district and Kolkata in West Bengal on the issues of child protection, 
gender equity, education, and livelihoods. Our aim is to build leadership, enable 
social justice and promote responsive citizenship among communities through 
engaging young people, women and marginalized people. Rupantaran also works 
as a resource and capacity building organisation for social partners and institutes.
 
Rupantaran Foundation is registered as a Society under West Bengal Societies 
Registration Act XII of 1860, bearing Registration Number S/1L/60699 of 2009 – 
10. The Society is governed by a Governing Body comprising 8 members: Ms 
Shruti Kundu (President), Mr Himangshu Das (Vice President)  Mr Abhishek 
(Secretary), Ms Debjani Barman (Assistant Secretary), Mr Snehasish Sarkar 
(Treasurer), Mr Gajendra Kumar (Member), Ms Jayati Mal (Member) and Ms 
Urmita Ghosh (Member). 
 
Director Ms Smita Sen is currently leading Rupantaran. The organization has 
Program Coordinator, Supervisor, Field Worker along with a considerable number 
of paid volunteers.

The financial situation of Rupantaran Foundation has been on a growing curve 
with every passing year, especially after receiving the FCRA registration.  In 
previous year, the annual operating costs of the organization was around 67 lakhs 
and this financial year its expected to reach 1 crore.
 
Rupantaran Foundation is grassroots implementing organisation as well as it 
serves as resource organisation. One of Rupantaran’s modes of raising funds for 
its programme initiatives are to provide knowledge services to likeminded 
organizations operating in the development sector.
Along with that Rupantaran Foundation has good individual donors base which 
serves as a backbone and cope with shock in any sudden change in funding 
context e.g. recent FCRA amendment. Also, Rupantaran is supported by few 
individuals who have provided us with Corpus Fund which will act as a reserve for

6c. Describe the history and past achievements of the organisation. 
(maximum 300 words):
Despite representing a large proportion of the population, adolescent and youth are 
widely excluded from the decision making process, as they have limited access to 
information, space and opportunity to acquire and share knowledge, and limited 
participation. In this light, Rupantaran Foundation has started its journey in 2009 
aims to create a safe space, where marginalization cease to exist, and adolescent 
and youth can build their own agency and voice their opinion. We started our 
journey from a single village in Sundarbans. Through participatory vulnerability and 
capacities analysis and micro plan with the youth, the need for working on 
education, prevention of early marriage and child labour etc. were pointed out as 
the menace to be fought against. In that time, our team along with those youth 
designed and shaped the initial programmes of Rupantaran. Gradually, along with 
young people we started engaging with women and other marginalized communities 
and activating government delivery mechanisms and bodies.
 
Past Achievements:
•Two of our youth collective members from remote villages from South 24 
Parganas received the Bravery Award, 2020 from West Bengal Commission 
for Protection of Child Rights for their extraordinary community 
development work during pandemic.
Grant Application Form, July 1 20136
 
•In one of the panchayat where we did our pilot work with VLCPCs, the 
VLCPCs over the period of 3 years addressed 11 cases of trafficking, 200 
cases of child marriage, 97 cases of dropout prevention and 70 cases of 
gender based violence (including eve teasing).
 
A sample of 220 adolescents and youth with whom we worked reached out to 11818 
peers, 3652 family members and 3527 community members on awareness on Child 
Marriage, Trafficking, Reproductive Health Rights, Gender equity, Education and 
Online Safety.
6d. Describe the current strategy of the organisation. (maximum 300 
words):
Rupantaran’s key strategies are:
1) Collectivisation and creating safe spaces for the marginalised
2) Strengthening the local governance  
 
We believe that collectivizing or bringing together the marginalized people in a 
safe space enable them to articulate their oppression and strategize for individual 
and social change. In rural areas, especially in Sundarbans there is a crunch of 
space to engage the marginalised people in the social development processes as 
the politics of spaces significantly plays its role in allowing and rejecting dialogues 
and discussions. For us at Rupantaran, creation of safe space was not about 
creating a physical space rather, creating a socio-cultural and psychological space 
where marginalization would cease to exist, celebrates a bond of trust, encourages 
building their own agency and facilitating a platform for a transformative journey 
from self to society.
6e. What problems are you addressing? What are the opportunities and 
challenges in addressing these problems? (maximum 600 words):
The development landscape of backward areas such as the Sundarbans points at a 
glaring dearth of people-centred processes and sustainable initiatives of change. 
While a number of development interventions are being implemented in the 
Sundarbans, the relative degrees of participation and leadership of local 
communities, especially those hailing from vulnerable sections, appears to be low. 
There seems a significant scope for assimilation of an agenda for nurturance of 
people-centred agencies of change, for greater sustainability of interventions and 
empowerment of people’s agencies.
 
The proposed intervention aims at addressing the non-availability of a facilitative 
Grant Application Form, July 1 20137
platform for vulnerable people in the Sundarbans to come together, diagnose their 
vulnerabilities and act upon the same. Such a platform has been elusive on 
account of high opportunity cost of participation of vulnerable groups in processes 
of development, lack of any favourable prior experiences, and increasing alienation 
from their core habitat and livelihoods.
 
The proposed thrust of the intervention, i.e. creating enabling conditions for 
specific groups of vulnerable people in the Sundarbans to assess and act upon 
their vulnerabilities, is likely to pose multiple challenges to facilitating agencies. 
The challenges were identified through the participatory vulnerabilities and 
capacities analysis along with micro plan. This includes related to mobilisation of 
vulnerable groups amidst their day-to-day struggles, finding acceptance within the 
community for a slow process of change, and potential resistance on the part of 
powerful vested interests. Internally, these include the challenge of restraint 
needed on the part of facilitating agencies, especially at the frontline level, in 
order that they do not pre-determine the directions of the process and allow the 
same to emerge naturally from the community level processes and perspectives of 
vulnerable groups. Other challenges relate to probable gaps in understanding and 
commitment needed to a rights-based community-led approach to development, or 
probable non-availability of necessary skills of facilitation at the frontline level, 
among others. 
 
The proposed intervention offers a great opportunity for strategic leveraging of 
available strengths of other identified organizations, towards creation of pathways 
for emergence of people’s agency for sustainable change.

6a. Describe the organisation (include information on leadership, 
governance, structure and staff) and expected changes. (maximum 300

Terre des hommes Foundation, based in Lausanne, is a member of the Terre des 
Hommes International Federation, which includes sister organisations worldwide. 
Its Executive Board's role is to oversee the organisation of the Foundation and to 
monitor ongoing activities, administration, use of the Foundation's resources, risk 
management and regulation. 2019 was marked by a major financial crisis 
requiring a reduction in the volume of expenditure in order to guarantee the 
sustainability of the organization while ensuring the continuity of operations. 
Measures were taken to adjust priorities at the level of each programme, leading 
to the restructuring of the operational procedures of the Children in Humanitarian 
Crisis programme, which is now managed by a single Operations Department in 
order to promote coordination between emergency, rehabilitation and 
development activities; and to the termination of certain programmes (Child 
Labour Exploitation, Advocacy in Switzerland). The HQ Operations department has 
been restructured into 4 portfolios: Africa, MENA, Asia-South America-Europe and 
FAST (dedicated to humanitarian crisis). This new organization supports project 
implementation in a more efficient way, without changing roles and 
responsibilities at country level. Tdh started its work in India in 1976; the India 
Delegation Office was established in 2008 as a Liaison Office which implements its 
programmes and projects through local partner organisations. The office is led by 
the Country Representative with a Team consisting of Programme Managers of the 
main thematic areas, supported by Programme Officers and other programme and 
office assistance staff. Strengthened by its resilience and commitment of its 2’059 
national and expatriates’ employees and volunteers worldwide, Tdh has been able 
to cope with the challenges in this exceptional context in order to maintain its 
commitment to vulnerable children.

6c. Describe the history and past achievements of the organisation. 
(maximum 300 words):
Tdh, founded in 1960 by Edmund Kaiser in Lausanne, is a leading Swiss child 
rights organisation that was born during the Algerian conflict to provide direct 
help to children in need. Tdh is active in over 40 countries worldwide. In India, 
Tdh has been working since 2008 in the areas of Child Protection, Mother and 
Grant Application Form, July 1 20136
Child Health, WASH and Emergency Response. Tdh co-manages a Global 
Safeguarding and Support Hub, supported by UK Aid and has been awarded 
“Level 1 certification” from Keeping Children Safe.
1.PM+: In 2019, Tdh successfully rolled-out the PM+ approach, a brief 
psychological intervention for adolescents and adults (16+) in Bangladesh. 
In keeping with WHO Mental Health Global Action Program, PM+ was 
developed to manualize a brief counseling approach for mild to moderate 
mental health disorders. The approach focuses on addressing common 
psychological problems – like stress, anxiety, depression symptoms and 
where possible, practical problems like livelihood difficulties, family 
discords etc.
2.Art-based methodology (YouCreate toolkit) for youth participation and 
social cohesion: The toolkit (Art-kit) has been developed by the International 
Institute for Child Rights and Development to train youth champions and 
their adult allies to use various kinds of arts to support children and young 
people’s psychosocial wellbeing. Lessons learnt from this project in Egypt 
and Iraq can be adapted and applied to support young people’s participation 
and build their self-confidence, resilience and empowerment in various 
contexts.
3.Sport for Protection Toolkit: Programming with Young People in Forced 
Displacement Settings” is the result of a multi-agency collaboration between 
the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, the International 
Olympic Committee and Tdh. The toolkit focuses on three key protection 
outcomes: Social inclusion; Social cohesion; and Psychosocial well-being. 
The methodology has been successfully used in Iran, Colombia, Sri Lanka, 
Palestine, Egypt, Georgia, Eastern Europe and India. 
6d. Describe the current strategy of the organisation. (maximum 300

6e. What problems are you addressing? What are the opportunities and 
challenges in addressing these problems? (maximum 600 words):
India has 450 million internal migrants (2011 census), an increase of 45% since 
2001. Of this, 68% are women. A study[1] conducted by Association for 
Stimulating Know-how showed that West Bengal and Jharkhand are among the 
states from where women migrate for work in high numbers. Children migrate 
either alone or with their family to work. While migration does not necessarily lead 
to trafficking, it creates conditions which make migrating women and children 
more vulnerable to being traf?cked for sexual exploitation/labour.
The COVID-19 pandemic has exacerbated these vulnerabilities, putting children 
and young people at increased risk of trafficking and exploitation.
Arriving at a new place, the survivors are cut off from the outside world and forced 
Grant Application Form, July 1 20137
to live in prison-like conditions by their captors. Documents of identification and 
money are immediately seized, and their movements restricted and continuously 
monitored. Repeated violence triggers suicidal tendencies and trauma in many 
survivors. Rescue typically occurs through police raids, help from clients, or 
captors releasing the survivors due to age, health conditions, etc. However, their 
trauma does not end with withdrawal.
What follows is a chaotic and unprepared journey, into an extremely challenging 
process of reintegration. Survivors suffer constant terror, guilt, shame and 
hopelessness. Unaware of service providers and bereft of a social support system, 
survivors lack adequate occupational skills to begin anew, feel too weak to voice 
their concerns and consequently, find it impossible to reintegrate into their own 
society.
The study conducted by Tdh highlights survivors’ experiences of stigma and the 
hardships they face upon return to their communities, that are major barriers to 
their successful reintegration.  Continued stigma, denial, rejection in their own 
communities and lack of preparedness of family members to handle the social 
stigma leave them feeling crippled and isolated.
Tdh has been successfully implementing the Learning Grant supported by Oak 
Foundation since 2013 and is currently in Phase II of the grant that concludes in 
October 2020. The grant has supported 35 partners to strengthen their existing 
practices of working with survivors and support their mental health and wellbeing. 
It has also supported development of child centric participatory tools (BECOME, 
EMpowerPLus, Livelihood Precondition) and Counselling Handbook to support 
frontline workers carrying out the reintegration process.
44 social workers have been trained on mental health and counselling that has 
increased their self-confidence and helped them build a trust-based relationship 
with children.  In 2019, 1124 children were cared for individually, 445 children 
were supported to receive services and 6508 family members were counselled and 
assisted. 1,933 stakeholders were reached through meetings, workshops and 
consultation including village and block level child protection committees (VL/BL 
CPCs), Panchayats and Self-Help Groups. The project has engaged with 91 
VLCPCs for providing support to children and young people.
Partners have been supported to take up joint advocacy initiatives on the gaps in 
services.
Using the seed grant from Tdh, JLKP was able to support 30 young girls and 45 
women vulnerable to trafficking earn livelihood through making and selling sal 
leaf plates, in an initiative supported by the Pradhan and other villagers. This has 
immensely enhanced the confidence and self-esteem of the girls whose average 
monthly family income is now between Rs. 6000-7500. With the money earned 
from selling the plates, some women have also initiated poultry farming and 
piggeries.  Villagers have also been connected to government schemes such as the 
Jharkhand Tribal Agency.
Using the BECOME and Livelihoods pre-condition tools, GGBK staff are now able 
to help survivors identify livelihood options and in the last two years, 46 out of 52 
girls receiving livelihood support are earning an income and slowly increasing 
profits.

5c. What is the problem you want to address and what is your approach? 
How will you use Oak's funding? How did you identify the problem and 
decide your approach? If you have undertaken a theory of change exercise, or if 
you are influenced by research, policy or your own organisation’s experience, please 
tell us about this.  Have you consulted with relevant stakeholders, including your 
communities and others experiencing the problem? Is there an intention to address 
equity, diversity and inclusion? (600 words):
The project aims to promote inclusive social change by amplifying the voices 
of tribal households in 8 villages in the SBR region of the North and South 
24 Parganas and representing them in research, governance and development 
interventions. In 4 phases, it aims to (1) enable communities in identifying 
their vulnerabilities and development needs and aspirations, and assess their 
Oak Application Form     8
vulnerabilities and climate risks, (2) develop community-led interventions to 
address those needs and aspirations and reduce vulnerabilities to climate 
change, and (3) implement these interventions through women-led processes, 
facilitated by like-minded organizations, (4) assess the effectiveness of the 
interventions and disseminate the knowledge gained with relevant actors.
Core Problem: Tribal communities are specifically vulnerable to the effects 
of climate change and have limited assistance to adapt to climate change.
According to researchers from Jadavpur University, the majority of the over 
200,000 tribal people in the SBR remain the most resource-poor and 
vulnerable, inhabiting forest fringe areas characterized by high hazard risks. 
Predominantly landless and ecosystem-dependent, the tribal households have 
low adaptive capacity. Efforts to uplift tribal communities in the SBR are 
underwhelming, with limited research on their situation and needs and few to 
no interventions support them adapt to climate change.
 
Underlying Problem 1: Needs of tribal communities are unknown and 
unaddressed as they are not represented in research, policy, governance and 
leadership.
Despite the existence of several pro-tribal policies in India, tribal communities 
remain largely socioeconomically marginalized and poorly represented in 
research, policy and governance. Several lacunae in policymaking, such as the 
mandate that the tribal population of a location/region must be at least 50,000 
or 50% of the total population to qualify for pro-tribal schemes and 
interventions, exclude and further disempower these communities in the SBR, 
where the tribal population is non-dominant and dispersed. With low levels of 
participation and leadership, their development needs remain largely 
unknown and unaddressed.
 
Underlying Problem 2: Tribal communities have limited or no access to 
interventions and initiatives to reduce their vulnerability to climate change. 
Due to the lack of alternatives they often rely on indiscriminate exploitation of 
natural resources and lack sustainable resource management.
Being predominantly ecosystem-dependent and non-agrarian, with little to no 
landholding, makes a significant contribution to the disempowerment of tribal 
communities, exposing them to man-animal conflict, denial of forest access, 
and forced migration to urban areas for contractual labour. The loss of 
livelihood due to natural disasters and lack of sustainable management of 
natural resources are the main drivers of negative coping strategies adopted 
by the tribal communities. The consequences of these are emissions from 
deforested mangrove forests and blue carbon loss, decline of fish, crabs and 
shrimps, food insecurity and increase of human-animal conflicts. Though the 
SBR has been globally identified as a key climate change and biodiversity, 
climate change adaptation for the local communities have been slow and 
unsustainable, owing primarily to the absence of community-centred 
approaches and failure to develop sustainable initiatives which are both locally 
relevant and accessible. From their previous experience of working for the 
development and protection of vulnerable rural communities in the SBR, both 
DRCSC and LRRM have noted a dearth of development programs and 
interventions with a special focus on tribal communities.
Oak Application Form     9
 
Underlying Problem 3: Tribal women are specifically marginalized, experience 
gender inequality and often face domestic abuse, neglect and deprivation, with 
no access to mental health care.
The disproportionate burden on tribal women remains unaddressed as they 
are severely marginalized by the existing vulnerabilities, climate-related 
stresses and gender inequality. They often assume the role of de facto 
household head in the absence of migrant men, carry overwhelming 
proportions of care work, while also experiencing domestic abuse, neglect 
and deprivation. Women and children in the SBR have no recourse to formal 
mental health support.

7. OBJECTIVES
This is the most important part of your application, as it is your opportunity to explain 
what you want to achieve and what will be different because of your work. We 
understand that social and environmental change is complex and there are a 
multitude of factors that contribute to change. We want to understand how you define 
your role in the overall change you hope to make. You may find it helpful to discuss 
this with your Oak Programme Officer, and others in your own organisation.   
7.a. Objectives
List here up to 3 main objectives for this grant (one sentence per objective). Think of objectives as goals 
that can be achieved within the lifetime of the grant.  We encourage you to think of objective(s) that are 
ambitious but also achievable.  
Objective: Resilience to climate change among tribal communities is 
increased through identification of their challenges, their empowerment to 
active participation in finding solutions for the same and consecutive 
dissemination of the knowledge gained with relevant actors. Interventions to 
improve the resilience and living conditions of tribal communities, that are 
tested, adjusted to the context and identified as effective, are scaled up in 
terms of geographical and target group outreach through a follow-up project 
for which funding from private and public institutions is secured.
The activities will be undertaken by DRCSC and LRRM as local partners, 
research consultants and SoH as German re-granting organisation, facilitator 
and supporter of capacity building workshops in India and knowledge 
dissemination and advocacy events/workshops in India and Germany. DRCSC 
will be responsible for the direct implementation of research and interventions 
in Hingalganj, Sandeshkhali I Block and Kakdwip Block. LRRM will be 
responsible for direct implementation of research and interventions in Kultali 
Block. A project Management board fitted with staff members from both 
organizations will ensure the appliance of equal standards, approaches and 
Oak Application Form     10
methodologies during research and interventions and support cooperation 
between the organizations.
The project shall lay the foundation for a planned follow-up project to 
strengthen the resilience against climate risks of tribal communities in the 
Sundarbans and to improve their living conditions. The Objective of the 
present project (knowledge gained on needs & challenges; development of 
effective and context specific interventions; establishment of networks and 
knowledge sharing between local and international practitioners and donors) 
will serve as a basis for this purpose. The follow-up project shall be timely 
overlapping with the present project (planned start in 2024/25 – depending 
on the evolvement of the present project) and shall have a budget of between 
800,000 – 1,200,000 EUR. Public and private funding will be secured, inter 
alia, through networking activities under Outcome 1.
7.b. Expected Outcomes (bullet points):
What do you expect will change because of this grant? What does success look like? List here 
the main outcomes you hope to achieve or make significant contributions towards with this 
grant, and for whom.  If you have concrete targets, please also list them here. Outcomes 
describe significant changes for people, communities, organisations or systems. Some 
examples are changes in policies and legislation; changes in knowledge, awareness, 
attitudes, beliefs, behaviours or social norms; changes in capacities, level of influence, 
agency or access to services. Please refer to the guidance for additional examples.
Outcome 1: Needs and challenges of tribal communities are identified through 
an ethnographic research and different Participatory Rural Appraisal (PRA) 
tools. Interventions adapted to the local context and target group (Outcome 2) 
are assessed and best practices are identified. The knowledge gained on 
challenges and effective interventions is shared with relevant stakeholders 
and decision makers.
Given the currently scant ethnographic engagement with tribal communities 
in the SBR, research consultants in cooperation with DRCSC/LRRM will 
conduct an in-depth ethnographic study to understand the sociocultural 
context, practices, development needs and aspirations of vulnerable tribal 
communities, assess their vulnerabilities and climate risks in order to promote 
awareness of, and protection for, their cultures, customs, rights and interests 
and to adapt effective interventions for their needs. To avoid further alienating 
the marginalized communities and to ensure that development initiatives are 
sustainable in the long term, intervention design must be just, fair, inclusive, 
locally relevant, and developed and implemented through a people-centred 
approach. Insights from the ethnographic survey, vulnerability and risk 
assessment study and relationship-building exercise will enable the project 
organisers to both assess the needs and aspirations of the communities and 
facilitate their participation and stewardship in intervention design and 
activity implementation.
 
Outcome 2: Community-led development interventions aligned to the needs of 
tribal communities have been designed, piloted, evaluated and improved. 
Oak Application Form     11
Climate risk reduction is increased and the socioeconomic resilience of the 
target group is strengthened.
The planned activities under this Outcome will be based on the findings of the 
preceding research and assessments (Outcome 1). They are designed 
participatory together with the target group in a form that indigenous 
knowledge systems are upheld and combined with scientific methods. The 
process is community-led, meaning that the collaborating organizations and 
researchers’ primary moderate the process, contributing their knowledge and 
capacities rather than taking the direct lead. The interventions are 
continuously monitored, evaluated and improved. The interventions focus on 
group formation and empowerment, climate adaptive and diversified 
livelihoods, organic agriculture, shore protection and dissemination of critical 
information to the target group. As the process unfolds over time, the 
capacities of the community representatives are enhanced to emerge as 
competent trainers who can achieve self-reliance and continue the community-
led work after the completion of the project. Local stewardship will not only 
enable the project team to successfully overcome the communities’ hesitation 
or reluctance in adopting the initiatives but also promote leadership, cohesion 
and decision-making agency.
 
Outcome 3: Physical and mental health challenges of the tribal communities 
are addressed. Good health is promoted and access to government health 
programs is established.
The absence of adequate healthcare facilities is accompanied with a lack of 
awareness of locally prevalent healthcare issues and health-seeking behaviour 
among the communities. While there is scant literature on the condition of 
physical and mental health in the SBR, there is an absolute absence of tribal 
communities in health and well-being-related research, policy and governance 
in the region. In addition to hypertension, pulmonary and gastrointestinal 
issues associated with certain environmental hazards like soil and water 
salinity, mental health disorders like depression, suicide and deliberate self-
harm, often linked with experiences of man-animal conflict, frequent disaster-
related losses and morbidities, are also widely prevalent. Mental health 
support is limited to non-existent in the region, with health camps and 
awareness-building workshops seldom mainstreaming mental healthcare. In 
the event of the dual crisis of pandemic-induced reverse migration and 
cyclone-induced rural-urban migration, the lack of infrastructural support and 
safety nets for migrants and their families became glaringly obvious, and 
communities relied only on psychosocial support from their friends and 
relatives.
While there is no disaggregated data on the health conditions and needs of 
tribal communities, the collaborating organizations are aware that inter-
generational poverty, neglect and exclusion leads to poor physical and mental 
health outcomes within these communities. However, knowledge of the 
specific drivers of poor health and well-being can only emerge from the 
proposed ethnographic survey. The present objective will synthesize relevant 
insights from the survey to design interventions to reduce the physical and 
mental health challenges of the tribal communities and promote good health 
and overall well-being through the following activities.
Oak Application Form     12
