Activities to achieve Outcome 1.
i. Ethnographic survey of 800 tribal households across 8 villages, 
conducted 3 times (= 2,400 households) during the project period to 
identify and understand the socio-historical context, tribal practices and 
the local dynamics of power, gender and exclusion, drivers of 
vulnerability. The methodology (ethnographic methods, participatory 
research, semi-structured and unstructured interviews and discussions 
with community members and other relevant stakeholders, photography 
and videography, photo voice method) will focus on the lived 
experiences of the communities and foster meaningful relationships 
between them and the project team.
ii. A Participatory Vulnerability Capacity Assessments (PVCA) to assess the 
vulnerability and climate risks of the communities based on climate data 
and accounts of experiencing environmental hazards and climate 
change impacts and to explore the potential for leadership among the 
most vulnerable sections of the communities (namely women, youth and 
marginalized occupational groups) for participation and stewardship in 
the design and implementation of appropriate interventions to promote 
inclusive development, resilience und climate risk reduction.
iii. Action research comprising monitoring and evaluation at regular 
intervals to repeatedly assess the efficacy and outcomes of the 
interventions, and introduce necessary modifications to the intervention 
strategies and design.
iv. Empowerment of the target group through collaboration with 
community representatives in reviving tribal customs and practices, 
observing tribal holidays, celebrating tribal festivals, organizing tribal 
food festivals, etc. to promote awareness of tribal cultures, knowledges 
and languages, prevent their erosion and loss, and encourage social 
cohesion.
v. Workshops with regional actors for advocacy and sensitization. Sharing 
the knowledge gained and the results of the action-interventions (under 
Outcome 2) with stakeholders, and advocating tribal needs and interests 
to the relevant governmental authorities for appropriately streamlining 
the implementation of government policies and schemes. This will 
include the publication of research papers, policy briefs, survey reports,

level and practitioners Workshops with local organizations. The activity 
will target specialised and non-specialised audiences and address the

in the media and scholarship, to ensure that relevant government

vi. Empowerment of the target group to express their thoughts, needs and

vii. Dissemination of knowledge gained (identified needs & tested solutions)

GAF_A_Sign_of_Hope_StrenTribaVoiceInSund.10. RISKS AND CHALLENGES:
10.  RISKS AND CHALLENGES
What are the risks or barriers that might prevent you from achieving your 
outcomes and how will you address these?  What are your opportunities?
We understand that achieving long-lasting and meaningful change is hard and we 
expect that the work you want to do will mean taking risks.  We encourage you to be 
open to telling us these, as well as how you will address these risks.  If some of your 
outcomes are risky, are there any incremental achievements that you could identify? 
(300 words):
The project’s approach and proposed thrust of interventions i.e., 
encouraging vulnerable tribal communities in the SBR to articulate their 
vulnerabilities and unique development needs, and piloting suitable 
interventions to address these through WSHGs and local youths’ groups, is 
likely to pose multiple challenges and risks. Some of these anticipated 
challenges relate to mobilization of disempowered groups like tribal women 
and youth amidst their regular duties and struggles, and finding acceptance 
within the community for the implementation of innovative and modern 
initiatives which demand significant behaviour change and inform a slow 
process of transformation. The anticipated risks include potential resistance 
on the part of powerful vested interests and political lobbies, which poses a 
threat to community-led work at the frontline. The collaborating 
organizations can reduce these risks by facilitating regular and transparent 
communication between the community representatives, state and local 
governments and the project team. Another challenge would be in promoting 
sustainable livelihood options among some of the tribes, like the Shabars, 
who are traditionally hunter-gatherers, predominantly non-agrarian and 
dependent on forest and ecosystem services. The research team shall 
address this challenge through knowledge-sharing efforts, learning from 
indigenous in similar conditions from other parts of the country/ world as 
well as by negotiating with the Department of Forest for sustainable use of 
forest resources. Other challenges relate to knowledge gaps about tribal 
concerns and interests, and gaps in understanding of, and commitment to, an 
inclusive approach to sustainable development, and probable non-availability 
of necessary skills and local resources for facilitation at the frontline level. 
These knowledge gaps and capacity deficits will be addressed through 
research to gain relevant ethnographic insights and training and information 
materials for the staff, facilitators, researchers and community 
representatives, to enhance their understanding and capabilities vis-à-vis 
rights-based, gender-responsive, culturally-sensitive and locally-relevant 
community-led approaches to tribal development.

Sundarbans is an ecologically fragile zone spread across two countries. There 
is a space for learning from interventions across both. In Phase 1, 114 groups 
of vulnerable people in five Gram Panchayats of Patharpratima (Digambarpur, 
Gopalnagar, Herambagopalpur, Achintyanagar and Banashyamnagar), South 
24 Parganas, West Bengal, were identified and brought together to diagnose 
their vulnerabilities, articulate aspirations and avenues of change, and work 
together. The project covers 20 villages with a population estimate of 
1,06,650.
After Phase 1, field staff assessed that 29% groups were active and functional 
– meeting frequently, discussing issues of relevance, taking part in activities, 
taking ownership of issues and expressing a need for continued engagement. 
Group members found value in learning new information, finding confidence 
and exercising collective bargaining power.  
They identified issues for action in Phase 2:
Effects of climate change (life and livestock threatened by eroding 
embankments and frequent flooding; livelihoods impacted by 
increasing soil salinity, limited water resources, poor market linkages);
Gender-based discrimination and violence (early marriage; domestic 
violence; limited opportunities for girls in education /livelihoods; lower 
wages for women workers; menstrual taboos);
Limited access to rights and entitlements (poor healthcare; limited 
awareness about government schemes);
Unsafe migration (dropouts, especially among boys;)
Lack of sustainable livelihood options (unsafe migration, dropout)
Phase 2 aims to continue the work done while bridging some gaps:

Target-driven activity-focus of implementation that overshadowed 
process-oriented actions
Limited coordination amongst resource agencies affected holistic 
perspective for staff and communities
Community leadership devoid of perspectives / stands
Focus of what should change rested with organisations rather than with 
communities
Hesitation / reluctance to PRI engagement
To meet these gaps, the consortium framed a theory of change which is 
presented below:
1. How is change within community visualised?
After forming their own micro-level plans, the dynamics between community 
and organisation changed to dependence because of the nature of 
interventions and expectations of communities. The transformation being 
visualised in the community is
•From formulating plan to owning the plan by periodic revisiting / 
evolving their change journey driven by their unique needs (and 
perspectives)
•From individual actions / actions that benefit individuals to collective 
actions
•From receiving organisation’s strategies and directions to community-
led actions that are more organic, impactful, and sustainable 
transformation
•From implementing organisation’s agenda to informing organisation’s 
agenda through careful assessment of their strengths, weaknesses, 
risks and opportunities
2. How is change within organization visualised?
As community groups assume leadership roles, the organisation’s role 
transforms
•From direct control to providing facilitative support
•From providing trainings to mentoring community resource persons
•From leading networking initiatives to strategic advice on stakeholder 
engagement
•From a culture of learning (one-way) to a culture of reflection (analytical 
process)
•From becoming visible in Patharpratima to networking and 
collaboration that visibilises ACV beyond Patharpratima

sidelined because of identity / the work they do / their inaccessibility / their 
inability to give time etc. and what further actions are warranted. For this to 
Oak Application Form     8
happen within the people-centred, community-led model, it is important for 
communities to form their own perspectives around marginalization.
Praxis UK sees Phase 2 as an opportunity to showcase ACV as a model of 
cross-learning and introspection in other geographies, contexts and funding 
scenarios. ACV’s learnings can be offset with similar experiences of 
community development in Bangladesh and other countries. Praxis UK will

What are the risks or barriers that might prevent you from achieving your

Through Phase 1, the following risks have been identified
•Uncontrollable factors such as the Covid-19 pandemic
•Repeated incidents of natural disasters (two cyclones in the three-year 
project cycle)
•Challenges imposed by adverse local governance systems and 
individuals within the panchayat

6e. What problems are you addressing? What are the opportunities and 
challenges in addressing these problems? (maximum 600 words):
As of 2018, both the states feature very low on the Human Development Index 
[HDI] (0.641 and 0.599[1]), and their HDI score is below the national average 
(0.647). With 19.98% and 36.96%[2] of the population of West Bengal and 
Jharkhand living in poverty and 71.16% and 56.21%[3] female literacy rates, the 
problems of poverty, the gender divide in educational attainment, income and 
access to resources is widespread. Women are often the primary breadwinners 
and caregivers of a household in these states as men tend to migrate out for better 
work opportunities, yet, women remain at the fringes of work and income, eking 
out a livelihood under extremely exploitative conditions. This gets reflected in the 
falling Female Labor Force Participation Rate [FLPR] in both states. The female 
labour force participation in West Bengal has increased from 18.08 in 2011 to 23.3 
in 2018, the same has reduced from 29.10 in 2011 to 18.08 in 2018 in 
Jharkhand[4]. 
If we see in terms of trades, research shows that most agricultural workers are 
women in these states, but their landholding is minimal and productivity has been 
constantly decreasing due to climate change, migration of males and limited 
access to government benefits. Beedi workers are struggling to continue with their 
livelihood and domestic workers are denied leaves and fair wages. SEWA has done 
an exploratory study in Jharkhand, (SEWA Exploratory Study Jharkhand, 2016) 
which shows that 63% of women have no awareness of the welfare boards and 
very few workers have identity cards. We have seen that women take up seasonal 
work and remain unemployed for a large part of the year. They rely on contractors 
and middlemen to broker their salary and conditions and often entangle 
themselves in large amounts of debt. Not being able to go up the supply chain, 
upskill themselves or gain income mobility are predominant issues as well. Their 
working conditions are equally precarious owing to their lack of bargaining power. 
Early pregnancy[5] is reportedly common, women and girls face restrictions on 
their mobility and traditional caregiving roles are encouraged for women while 
taking up non-traditional work is frowned upon.
In the past 3 years in Jharkhand and 16 years in West Bengal, SEWA has unionised 
and collectivised more than 20,000 women in the informal economy. SEWA has 
worked towards increasing collective bargaining strength, empowering 
communities to access information and entitlements through SSKs, enhancing skill 
and creating opportunities for access to markets. The effort is being led by a cadre 
of 129 agewans (grassroots leaders). Following are the preliminary findings from 
the end-project impact assessment (phone-based) study conducted in both states in 
July-August 2020.[6]
•A majority of the respondents, that is 65.60%, women attend unit 
meetings organised by SEWA at least once a month. While the remaining 
members attend meetings once in two or three months.

•50% of all members have received at least one type of training offered

Going forward, we would strengthen the existing cadre of agewans so they can 
lead community efforts and SSKs and create new agewans and SSKs. We would 
also address women’s trade-specific needs, explore alternate livelihoods so women 
can diversify or pivot their income sources and simultaneously, look to build our 
grassroots advocacy. The next generation of young leaders will also be created to 
ensure continuity of the movement and relationships with the local administration 
and government officials will be nurtured to ensure strong private-public 
partnership. The above feeds into SEWA Bharat’s commitment to ensuring full 
employment and self-reliance for women in the informal economy. SEWA Bharat 
has been building the capacity of its member organisations and advancing the 
rights of women workers through its twin goals of organising and struggle. We 
have different streams of work focused on unionising women; advancing gender 
equality and rights; trying out innovative and different models of organising 
women such as union, federation, cooperatives, collective social enterprises, 
producer companies; and fostering women’s economic empowerment by 
increasing women’s access to market and finance.
Though the registration process for a state union has been facing bureaucratic

you are influenced by research, policy or your own organisation’s experience, please 
tell us about this.  Have you consulted with relevant stakeholders, including your 
communities and others experiencing the problem? Is there an intention to address 
equity, diversity and inclusion? (600 words):
Sundarbans is a part of the tidally active delta where the land building 
process is still incomplete with Ganges-Brahmaputra River system carries 
suspended sediment load through numerous interlacing channels, 
intervening islands with the elevation of less than 3 meters above msl. 
Agriculture forms the backbone of the economy of Sundarban, where the 
entire area is dependent on a single crop, the rain-fed (mostly high yielding 
varieties) paddy. Sundarbans, is threatened by various biophysical and social 
barriers, emerges as a unique case where the most vulnerable population 
lives in an extremely vulnerable situation with high risk of hazards which is 
characterized by a low level of development and lack of infrastructure, 
prevalence of extreme poverty and lack of health facilities. It is also under 
the threat of severe coastal erosion due to relative sea level rise, increase in 
surface air temperatures and increased intensity of cyclone. All these results 
into the following negative impacting factor for livelihood systems of 
Sundarbans - a) increased anthropogenic pressure for livelihood on natural 
resources b) increased seasonal and permanent outmigration c) lack of 
stability in livelihood operations d) landlessness and poor resource profile 
triggered by land loss/degradation and debt trap.
Oak Application Form     7
There is a pressing need of a strategy to create examples of sustainable 
livelihood options which can transform the local economy. Such 
transformational strategy needs to be built on:
•Value chain-based approach where various business opportunities 
(including products and services) can be created along the value chain 
with backward and forward linkages.  This aims to boost up the entire 
economy around a product line.
•Cluster based approach where value chain actors come together in 
homogeneous or heterogeneous groups depending on the product and 
associated services. This will create scope of inclusion of members who 
do not possess resources/means of primary production.
•Inclusion of vulnerable communities like traffic survivors, landless, 
forest dependents etc. with special focus on youth and women. 
•Gradual shifting from livelihood approach to microenterprises.  
•Organizing farmers into Farmer Producer Companies for achieve 
economies of scale and long-term sustainability.
•Networking with knowledge and financial institute/agencies to 
leverage funding/technical support. Already established Green College 
can be a strategic institute to support training and capacity building.
•Developing a team with local CSO partners who can own and continue 
the initiative.
The approach is developed on the basis of a) Welthungehilfe’s experience of 
last two decades in the region where we have been active with the 
transformative approaches of multisectoral approach to nutrition, rural skill 
building through green colleges, microplanning involving local community to 
support government planning program of GPDP and ecological agriculture b) 
Scoping study commissioned by Oak Foundation c) FGD with CSOs of 
Sundarbans.

6e. What problems are you addressing? What are the opportunities and 
challenges in addressing these problems? (maximum 600 words):
The premise of the project is to work on the issue of creating safe workplaces for 
women.
Sexual harassment is a manifestation of sex discrimination and violence against 
women at the workplace that thrives in an atmosphere of threat, terror and reprisal. 
Sexual harassment at workplace adversely affects the safety, dignity, mental and 
physical well-being of women resulting in loss of life, job and livelihood opportunities 
Grant Application Form, July 1 201312
among others. It is a manifestation of power relations as women are much more 
likely to be victims of sexual harassment because of their status at work, 
vulnerability, insecurity, and social conditioning.
Challenges
24 years post the Vishaka Judgement and 8 years post the enactment of the SHWW 
Act, implementation of the Act in the true spirit is yet to happen. There is however, 
no comprehensive data on the complaints of SHW is available. Based on Sanhita’s 
experience, the number of recent court judgments and the narratives available post 
the #MeToo Movement it emerges that many workplaces still believe that SHW is a 
rare or trivial issue and that the women are responsible for their harassments.  
Evidence shows that the complaints are not dealt with sensitively.  When the woman 
attempts to speak out the pattern is to subvert her credibility to prove that the 
complaint is motivated, if not false. 
Lack of employer accountability towards effective prevention and redress of SHW 
and the gaps in the Act to define the role of monitoring and regulatory bodies, have 
created several loopholes and cracks in the redress process.
Due to the absence or limited access to redress mechanisms, the women workers 
from resource poor backgrounds and the precariously positioned ones among the 
institutionally employed remain particularly vulnerable. 
The SHWW Act 2013 is geared towards safety of women workforce and as such may 
be read as gender specific, applicable to only cisgender women. However, in a 
changing world order where notions around gender identity and expression are 
important markers of personhood, the Act might have to be extended in order to 
make it inclusive of transgender persons.
 
Opportunities
The legal framework for employer responsibility towards safe working environment 
is enshrined in the Constitution of India which provides the basic opportunity for 
working on the SHW issue.
The landmark Vishaka Guidelines and the SHWW Act provide a comprehensive 
definition of SHW and include all kinds of women at workplaces under its ambit. The 
Act places the onus for safe workplaces on the employer and provides the aggrieved 
woman recourse to civil proceeding alongside existing criminal proceeding.
The scope for addressing and working on the SHW issue expanded manifold when 
the issue took centre stage in 2018 because of the # Me too movement and brought 
renewed focus to the prevalent cultures within organizations that perpetuate SHW 
and victimize women.
With regard to the issue of SHW, the legal landscape in India has been a constantly 
evolving one and has led to progressive judgements of Hon’ble Supreme Court and 
High Court leading to organisations across sectors reviewing their compliance to 
the Act. The scope for work increased by inclusion of SHW in the various service 
rules and in the Section 29 (d) of Code on Wages, 2019 and Section 134 of 
Companies Act, 2013 which mandated compliances through service rules among 
others.

The largest cohort of employees, tea garden workers, in West Bengal continues 
to be deprived of the most basic rights of water, sanitation, electricity, and 
housing amongst others. While the government has introduced flagship welfare 
schemes through the tea board and introduced bills such as Plantation Labor 
Act (1951), poor implementation hasn’t improved conditions. In this context, 
Swaniti aims to work closely with the network of civil society organizations, 
district administration, and state government to operationalize core welfare 
programs for tea garden workers. For example, all tea garden workers should 
have access to adequate housing. However, most local administration does not 
adhere to even the basic standards of housing. Lack of governance overview has 
led to the deprivation of this key group. In this context, Swaniti and it's partners 
proposes to embed teams into each affected district and state government to 
work with the local ecosystem and ensure the delivery of programs. The team 
will be expected to come up with joint solutions and implement them with the 
support of the local administration. By the end of the program, tea garden 
workers will be expected to have access to public programs.

Key to Swaniti’s strategy in the next five years is to work in a collaborative model. 
Specifically, Swaniti plans on building on its current cross-sectoral model of 
working with multiple stakeholders to ensure policy and implementation change in 
governance. Swaniti sees the role of the government as being catalytic in serving 
the community. However, to be sustainable and scalable, programs need to engage 
with communities and bring together local partners for successful execution. 
Accordingly, Swaniti pursues a triangular model of collaboration in overall service 
delivery. The three key stakeholders who maintain a symbiotic relationship are as 
follows:   The community is our primary stakeholder. To make a program 
sustainable it is important to ensure that the program is deeply rooted within the 
requirements and expectations of the community. Therefore, the field teams begin 
all engagements by holding community-level meetings with key stakeholders like 
village council members, women’s self-help groups, small landholding farmers, etc. 
Only with key input from community members does the program design move 
forward. The field teams invest several months to build trust within the 
communities and understand gaps and opportunities in public service delivery.  As 
highlighted above, the government is a key collaborator. Swaniti embeds itself in 
the office of the local administration to ensure the requisite support systems for 
service delivery exists and complements it with counterparts in state offices to 
ensure scalability. Swaniti sees government as a critical level in ensuring the 
delivery of key social safety programs that can lift people out of poverty and 
provide them with an opportunity for better quality of life. Our government 
counterparts are a critical part of Swaniti's work. Finally, partnerships of local 
NGO partners who can help in program implementation are a key part of the 
program. NGOs bring in critical insights on how to operationalize local solutions 
within the communities and our seen as the "local solution providers". In this 
particular program, we hope to partner with the Digital Empowerment Foundation 
who would be bringing in their "Soochnaprenuers", community members who have

scaled by DEF. The local entreprenuers, known as Soochnaprenuers, will bring in

6e. What problems are you addressing? What are the opportunities and 
challenges in addressing these problems? (maximum 600 words):
India’s local governance systems are broken. This makes it difficult for the most 
vulnerable to have access to basic public services that are critical to growth. 78 
million people are eligible for government-funded programs. The Indian 
government spends over 58 billion USD on ensuring food security 42 billion on 
creating economic opportunities, and over 126 billion on social protection 
programs. Yet India is home to 20 percent of the world’s poor who are living in 
abject poverty. Despite the government’s will to lift people out of poverty, many 
fall through the cracks because local administrations often don’t have the tools for 
last-mile delivery.
 Local governments lack the three Ps...
Grant Application Form, July 1 20138
                     ...skilled people at a local level who have the knowledge, expertise, 
and drive to effectively execute and reach most marginalized
              ….meaningful civil society partnerships to complement the government 
efforts and create checks and balances for robust long term program delivery
                ….strong processes which include continuous monitoring and 
evaluation.  
Most governance-centric efforts are concentrated at a national level. The weakest 
states, districts, and villages often have little or no tools to improve local 
governance. Yet local governments are the touch points for public services. To 
correct this imbalance, it is critical to work with government administrators at a 
local level in weak and laggard districts and states. This proposal focuses on 
working with local governance to be able to solve issues around social protection 
for tea garden workers.
 
Based on the consultations with grassroots organizations, we learned that there is 
no role of middlemen/contractors in the hiring of the tea workers. The hiring 
happens through heredity. For instance, the original person who was hired 
provides replacement through some family member and the cycle goes on. Office 
staff are interviewed by the DBITA (Dooars Branch Indian Tea Association). Tea 
workers lack the required documentation for most schemes and programs. 
Workers don't have aadhar cards or bank accounts. However, even with an 
alternate id proof (if any), the process is very cumbersome in accessing programs 
like maternity benefit scheme. Even RTE is defunct for the tea workers. Paralegals 
are trained how to acquire the relevant forms etc but implementation hurdles limit 
possible impact levels. 
The impact of access to scheme is ultimately seen in developmental outcomes. 
These include multilayered challenges in the form of health, sanitation etc. 
Following aare some of the outcome challenges within the state:
1. Severely compromised health infrastructure included limited doctors and 
medicines. 
2. Tea workers do not have access to entitled ration
3. Sanitation, housing and drinking water are big challenges.
4. Separate electricity meters in the living quarters and the electricity bill is borne 
by the workers.
 
Thus with these outcomes and broken governance systems, it is important to help 
strengthen the process of public service delivery of tea garden workers. Through 
this proposal, Swaniti hopes to address this issue.

Water For People began working in India in 1996 in North 24 Parganas in

with local governments and communities, has resulted in significant progress 
towards the completion and rehabilitation of improved water and sanitation 
systems, strengthened by municipal and local structures. This transformative 
WASH program in India is helping Everyone – every community, household, 
school, and clinic – gain access to these critical resources across 10 
districts/blocks in West Bengal in South 24 Parganas (Sagar Island,

Patharpratima, Namkhana) and Birbhum (Rajnagar), in Bihar, Sheohar

(Governments of West Bengal and Bihar) have signed Memorandum of 
Understandings in which Water For People formed a Technical Support Unit 
with embedded staff to assist government flagship programs such as Jal

community engagement, program management, capacity building and 
training of state, district, and local level officials. This support aims to assist 
these states to achieve the ambitious goals of the Jal Jeevan Mission (a

models to manage their water resources.  
Water resources in the areas where we work in India are severely affected 
by climate change. There are more frequent tropical storms, sea levels are 
rising, and drought persists. Erratic rainfall, changes in timing, intensity and 
duration of precipitation has adversely affected surface water, putting 
additional pressure on ground water resources. Water For People India 
aligns its water resources management (WRM) activities with the Indian 
government’s water conservation initiative, Jal Shakti Abhiyan—Catch the 
rain when it falls where it falls. We provide training to master trainers, 
guiding them to work closely with communities and villages to develop 
climate resilient Village Water Safety and Security Plans (VWSSPs). These 
plans include budgets for conducting water quality testing, measuring water 
sources, and planning availability. Under these plans, Water for People 
supports the installation of aquifer storage units, ridge and furrow models, 
and creation of recharge pits for surface water management. VWSSPs are 
incorporated into Gram Panchayat Development Plans. We also work with 
farmers to reduce pumping needs for irrigation. In addition, in schools, we 
install roof top rainwater harvesting systems to serve as an 
alternative/supplemental water source.

Water For People is very familiar with the Sundarbans’ challenges, having 
working in Parganas, West Bengal since 1996. This area has a population of 
2.79 million living in about 1,100 villages. Most people, including many from 
scheduled tribes and castes, live in acute poverty and depend on agriculture 
for their livelihoods. This region is very vulnerable to climate change’s 
frequent cyclones, floods, and sea-level rise. These events have led to saline 
soil, seawater intrusion, aquifer contamination, brackish aquaculture ponds, 
and increased incidence of waterborne diseases. Progressive salinization of 
rivers and groundwater has resulted in the decline of available fresh 
drinking water. The demand for groundwater has increased to meet 
increasing demand for crops, which, combined with limited rainfall, is 
resulting in the over-extraction of groundwater and a severe crisis during the 
summer.  
Based on our experience, all activities that Water For People India carries 
out in communities related to water security aim to build resilience as part of 
the overarching goal of communities surviving climate change. A community 
cannot survive climate change if water sources are not secure, namely 
accessible and of sufficient quantity and quality. The people contributing the 
least to climate change are suffering the most. We cannot continue to wait 
for mitigation efforts to reduce global greenhouse gas emissions to correct 
the injustice.?It is time for the people directly facing threats to their water 
sources to have resources necessary to adapt.? 
We plan to use Oak Foundation’s funding to strengthen integrated water 
resources management (IWRM) in Patharpratima and Gosaba, two blocks 
with ecosystems highly vulnerable to cyclones. In Patharpratima block, 23% 
of the population is Schedule Caste, 0.8% is Schedule Tribe. In Gosaba block, 
62.7% is Schedule Caste, 9.5% is Schedule Tribe. We will work closely with 
community leaders and members, particularly those from marginalized 
groups such as Schedule Castes and Tribes, and women.  
This work will empower those community leaders to lead efforts to adapt to 
climate change by ensuring water security.?IWRM acknowledges the pivotal 
role of water as a finite resource and advocates for its judicious allocation 
using a comprehensive approach to address the multifaceted challenges 
posed by climate change, particularly for tribal communities. These 
communities are often reliant on local water sources for sustenance with 
IWRM offering enhanced water security. By implementing sustainable 
practices such as rainwater harvesting, groundwater recharge, and efficient 
irrigation methods, women who traditionally bear the responsibility of water 
collection, can experience reduced physical burden and increased access to 
clean water.  
IWRM can also serve as an educational tool, enhancing tribal communities' 
understanding of hydrological processes, water conservation strategies, and 
climate change impacts. This knowledge empowers everyone, especially 
women, to make informed decisions regarding water use and management, 
producing a culture of environmental stewardship and adaptive learning. 
Also as women are primary users of water, they are interested in learning 
Oak Application Form     8
the scientific and social context of ground water depletion as it greatly 
impacts their daily lives, and how to put into practice newly acquired 
knowledge for the community's benefit. 
IWRM also enhances public health through improved water quality due to 
IWRM's emphasis on monitoring water quality, pollution control, and 
watershed management. By mitigating waterborne diseases and 
contamination, tribal communities experience improved overall well-being 
and reduced healthcare burdens, particularly benefitting women in tribal 
communities through improved maternal and child health. 
For women's empowerment, IWRM and the approaches proposed are 
inherently transformative as it involves women in decision-making processes 
related to water management, challenging traditional gender roles and 
amplifying women's voices. Participation in water committees, resource 
planning, and advocacy initiatives elevates their status and influence within 
the community, nurturing a more gender-equitable society. 
In addition, IWRM can catalyze diversification of livelihoods by integrating 
water-sensitive agricultural practices and aquaculture. This not only 
mitigates climate risks but also stimulates economic growth within tribal 
communities, reducing their vulnerability to external shocks. By enhancing 
water security, supporting education, promoting health, elevating women's 
empowerment, and augmenting livelihoods, IWRM becomes a catalyst for 
inclusive and sustainable development. 
To strengthen IWRM, Water For People, PRASARI, and Akvo propose to build 
on the tested approach of participatory groundwater management (PGWM) 
for select villages in the Sundarbans. This approach incorporates a deep 
understanding of surface and groundwater interactions and values and 
incorporates community knowledge to solve complex water problems. 
Successful implementation of PGWM requires an understanding of 
groundwater science from the perspective of the local population too.  
Firstly, within the Participatory Groundwater Management (PGWM) process, 
the community will engage in the mapping of IWRM activities and models 
currently in place. It is necessary to validate the traditional IWRM models 
using scientific methods. Subsequently, this knowledge will be disseminated 
to the community through various platforms, leading to the development of a 
comprehensive community plan focused on ensuring the sustainability of 
water sources. As a result, the PGWM process will involve the identification 
of different categories of traditional IWRM models, with particular attention 
given to identifying models that have been damaged or reduced in 
effectiveness. During the execution phase, appropriate modifications will be 
made to ineffective traditional IWRM models either with direct support or 
with convergence from government departments.? 
We will nurture local leaders and community-based institutions, particularly 
among women-led Self-Help Groups, supporting them to map the aquifers, 
delineate resources, facilitate water budgeting, and scenario building for 
managing water. In addition, we will combine outcomes of community-based 
water quality mapping with predictive analysis models leveraging available 
and relevant historical data for community and local institutions to make 
informed decisions regarding the sustainability of their water sources. We 
intend to act as enablers, with local communities and their institutions 
Oak Application Form     9
driving the process. Since PRASARI and Water For People have built trust in 
communities in these blocks for years, interventions will begin quickly.  
Participatory approaches and IWRM require investments of time and 
resources before fully realizing benefits. We will use Oak Foundation’s 
funding to design the program and activities together with the government, 
traditional leaders from schedule castes and tribes, and local communities. 
We will facilitate discussions between local government and communities to 
ensure sustainability by creating an advisory committee that includes senior 
government officials from state and district governments, local elected 
bodies, and Panchayati Raj Institution members. We will involve traditional 
leaders, developing a cadre of communities to build their capacity to plan, 
budget, and develop demonstration of freshwater harvesting and aquifer 
recharging models for three years. After the close of the initial project, we 
will build on investments and link communities to government campaigns/ 
resources to fund water security plans and infrastructure solutions. As Water 
For People is embedded in the West Bengal state government, we will foster 
incorporating water security plans into Gram Panchayat Development Plans 
(GPDPs).  
In addition to incorporating these plans in GPDPs, locally elected bodies and 
Panchayati Raj Institution members will play an important role in decision 
making to leverage government resources. From project inception to 
capacity building exercises and workshops to develop community-led water 
security plans and solutions, vulnerable community members, traditional 
leaders, and locally elected bodies will participate in every stage. We will 
ensure regular communication among all stakeholders and jointly celebrate 
successes. By aligning water security plans with existing government 
schemes (Jal Jeevan Mission) and programs, we will also facilitate efforts to 
ensure that community institutions and their representatives receive 
government acknowledgement to access water security financing. 
Within communities, we will apply Elinor Ostrom’s principles to strengthen 
community-based institutions. We recognize that based on data collected and 
analyzed, these principles may be modified to fit the Sundarbans’ challenges 
such as cyclones. We will embed possibilities for modifications. Participatory 
planning along with building capacity of local communities will result in the 
development of evidence-based water security plans with local community 
leaders conducting water budgeting, identifying potential recharge areas, 
and/or expanding traditional water harvesting practices. In addition to these 
activities, demonstration models complete with freshwater harvesting or 
aquifer recharge solutions will be completed in select villages of 
Patharpratima and Gosaba blocks. Informed by data and depending on 
community consensus, solutions could include land shaping for furrow and 
high ridge cultivation, “Five Square’ water harvesting structures that 
PRASARI has implemented in Gosaba, aquifer storage and recovery systems, 
and/or rooftop rainwater harvesting systems with tanks. 
In general, PGWM may seem like a niche topic. But at its core, PGWM builds 
capacities of communities to map and manage their own resources, 
generates local employment (e.g., barefoot hydrogeologists), and empowers 
local communities to make data-driven decisions. Our initial projections 
suggest that about 200 barefoot hydrogeologists and the corresponding 
1,000 water and sanitation committees will participate. It's important to note 
that this is a preliminary estimation, and the final figures may vary. 
Oak Application Form     10
Oak Foundation's investment in PGWM will show the multi-faceted 
successful outputs of this approach to strengthen IWRM, allowing other 
large funders to leverage this water-focused method to achieve their 
outcomes related to job creation, community development, and climate 
change adaptation. The three organizations (Water For People, PRASARI, 
and Akvo) work with several donors that are interested in climate-water-food 
nexus and/or livelihood development, such as Caterpillar Foundation, 
Welthungerhilfe (WHH), Axis Bank Foundation (ABF), and Ajim Premji 
Philanthropic Foundation. We also work closely with global knowledge 
platforms like World Water Quality Alliance and Water Point Data Exchange, 
which have a keen interest in the Sundarbans, SDGs and specifically water 
quality. There are also talks with donors that are showing interest in citizen 
engagement, data-based decision making and collective action. We will 
leverage Water For People’s Technical Support Unit and embedded staff in 
West Bengal’s state government and agreement with the Public Health and 
Engineering Department (in Birbhum and South 24 Parganas District) to 
ensure government convergence in this program.  
We also propose to establish a multi-stakeholder platform that includes local 
Civil Society Organizations (CSOs), such as Oak Partners, in collaboration 
with Water For People, PRASARI, and Akvo. The objective of this platform 
would be to facilitate learning, sharing, implementation, and scaling up of 
the interventions within and beyond the project locations. We propose to 
conduct an annual sharing workshop with our partners to provide a more 
detailed update on the results and the processes followed to arrive at those 
results. In this workshop, we will encourage feedback from the partners and 
use this as an opportunity for cross learning.

Water For People India has been working in West Bengal/ the Sundarbans 
for 20+ years. PRASARI, our partner in this region for 10+ years, works 
closely with local communities. PRASARI is currently working with Water 
For People in four blocks in West Bengal, with communities on improving 
water services, integrating water resources management, rainwater 
Oak Application Form     14
harvesting and building recharge structures. Akvo Foundation and Water For 
People have a decade-old partnership across the globe generating evidence 
for program decision making. As program lead, Water For People India will 
lead project design, establish learning processes, liaise with Oak Foundation 
and relevant government departments, communicate regularly to all 
stakeholders, create policy and public facing communications, and submit 
required reports. We will also leverage our relationship with West Bengal’s 
state government to link these communities to government resources.  
PRASARI will support on-ground implementation. PRASARI will focus on 
strengthening social capital, building community capacity while 
incorporating traditional knowledge, facilitating aquifer mapping, water 
budgeting, and water security planning. It will apply Ostrom’s principles for 
management of commons1, modifying as necessary and developing 
processes that can sustain momentum after the project has ended. In early 
stages of community interactions with local administration, PRASARI will act 
as a facilitator. Akvo is our technology and data partner, using appropriate 
technology to help us to report and build evidence. Local communities will 
use Akvo’s tools to collect data and information. Akvo will analyze data, 
summarize findings, indicate trends, and develop data visualizations that 
Water For People and PRASARI will use for community engagement and to 
promote policy and model scale up. Akvo will work closely with Water For 
People to develop documentation useful for replicating and scaling up this 
program in similar contexts.  
Additionally, Water For People and Prasari will leverage their other donors 
working in West Bengal that are interested in the climate-water-food nexus 
and/or livelihood development, such as Caterpillar Foundation and Ajim 
Premji Philanthropic Foundation.  
We will also establish a multi-stakeholder platform that includes local CSOs, 
such as Oak Foundation Partners, in collaboration with Water For People, 
PRASARI, and Akvo. The objective of this platform would be to facilitate 
learning, sharing, implementation, and scaling up of the interventions within 
and beyond the project locations. 
We will work with these stakeholders (Oak partners and non-Oak partners) 
from the very beginning to identify the operational villages and ensure 
integration with other issues from the outset. The operational villages will be 
selected based on the vulnerability mapping of the Gram Panchayats (an 
administrative unit that represents a cluster of villages). To conduct 
vulnerability mapping, a participatory tool will be used to assess 15 
indicators distributed across four categories: Social, Climatic, Institutional 
and Economic.  
Social:  
i. Ratio of Schedule Caste, Schedule Tribal & Other Backward Caste(s) ration 
to total population, 
ii. Literacy Rate, 
iii. Rate of migration to total no of families, 
iv. Ratio of total number of toilet blocks to total number of households. 
Climate: 
i. Ratio of vulnerable river embankment to total embankment, 
ii. Climatic disaster impact ratio (Ratio of number of disaster(s) in a 
Oak Application Form     15
particular year with average number of climate disaster in last 10 years, 
iii. Ratio of total submergent area to total area. 
Institutional: 
i. Rate of migration to total number of families, 
ii. Child mortality rate, 
iii. Participation of women to the labor force, 
iv. Average number of families dependent on drinking water from tube 
wells, 
v. Ratio of average distance from school, Panchayat and hospital to national 
average. 
Economic:  
i. Ratio of mono-cropped and double cropped area, 
ii. Ratio of waterborne diseases to non-communicable diseases, 
iii. UN Household Dietary Diversity Score,  
iv. Average income from farm-based livelihoods and manufacturing + service 
sector.
These indications have been carefully outlined, agreed upon in public 
forums, and weighed uniformly. In addition, it is evaluated using a 5-point 
Likert scale, with the combined scores for each metric serving as the final 
evaluation. Gram Panchayats (GP) with a score of less than 2.5 are at risk of 
vulnerability. If a vulnerable GP is identified, all its corresponding revenue 
villages will be included for implementation. As GPs are clusters of villages 
without further assessment, we incorporate all the revenue villages of a 
vulnerable GP for action.??

effective project monitoring. At project inception, the team will outline data

4g. Summarise the project’s ultimate goal(s) (maximum 200 words):
( NOT REQUIRED FOR CORE SUPPORT GRANTS)
The project’s ultimate goal to enable identified groups of people in Sunderban to 
come together to diagnose their vulnerabilities , articulate aspiration  and avenue 
of change and produce a plan for acting upon vulnerabilities as well as achieving 
highest standard of cooperation among collaborating organisations, leading to 
deep institutionalisation of values of partnership and commitment for the 
community-led approaches to development.  
In India, Sunderbans lies in the vast delta on the Bay of Bengal formed by the super 
confluence of the Ganges, Brahmaputra and the Meghna rivers. The place has always 
earned a special interest in the world map because of its uniqueness of the Mangrove 
forests and the lifestyle of the local inhabitants. People have been mostly dependent 
on agriculture and fishing. Owing to recent climatic changes, there is evidence of 
livelihood dearth adding to increasing vulnerability amongst all sections of the 
inhabitants. Interventions and support from the various local level organizations, 
government schemes have remained detrimental to the development of this area. 
Day-by-day, people are becoming increasingly dependent on immediate support 
rather than making themselves more reliant and capacitated by participating in 
sustainable processes of growth and development.
Among the 15 Blocks in the South 24 Parganas district of West Bengal, Pathar 
Pratima is one of the largest blocks and known as one of the critical blocks in terms 
of adverse social issues. The various publications and researches have pointed 
towards the increasing adversities related to human trafficking, increasing 
migration, insufficient alternatives to livelihood, frequent disasters in this block 
leading to severe adverse consequences on all section of inhabitants.
Herambagopalpur Gram Panchayat is located in the northern side of the 
Patharpratima Block. The size of the area is about 868.3 hectares. It comprises 4 
main villages, namely, Heramba Gopalpur, Dakshin Kashinagar, Kuemuri and Purba 
Surendranagar. Kuemuri in the Dakshin Kashinagar in the South-East surrounds 
Heramba Gopalpur along the Matla river. A total of 17 Sansads are included in these 
4 villages.
Due to its deltaic location, the river network forms the major transport system of 
this area and people are dependent on the river both for transportation and 
livelihood. Being located in the deltaic region, the rivers here are tidal in nature. The 
area remains flooded mostly during the rainy season and the situation worsens at 
times of natural calamities. Breaching of river embankments, river bank erosion are 
thus very common phenomena here. All these natural calamities have an adverse 
effect on the people residing there. Remoteness and undeveloped infrastructural 
facilities add to irreparable damages of life and property.   MUKTI has been working 
for the underprivileged people in the Sundarban area since 2003. Interventions at 
Patharpratima Block by Mukti started almost 5-6 years back. More than 70 students 
in the Herambagopalpur GP are being benefited through the Mukti Support School 
Centres. The women empowerment programme focussing on developing 
entrepreneurship skills through the MCDF project includes almost 1200 women 
from the GP. Mukti aims to continue ongoing such initiatives to achieve sustainable 
development for these people.

6a. Describe the organisation (include information on leadership, 
governance, structure and staff) and expected changes. (maximum 300 
words):
MUKTI, is a non-profit socio-economic organization, working for the Sundarban 
people in the Delta region of South 24 Parganas, West Bengal, India since 2003. It 
is registered with the Government of India Trust Act 64 in the year 2005, Ministry 
of Corporate Affairs under CSR form 1, 12AA, 80G, TISS, FCRA (Foreign 
Contribution Regulation Act 1976) and ISO certifications in 2005 and is also 
supported by almost 74 enterprises. The organisation was started by a group of 
local youths who had gradually decided to develop the vision and lay the 
foundation for a sustainable development.Today, the organisation is spread across 
54 Gram Panchayats in the whole of North and South 24 Parganas. The 
organisation has been working intensively with almost 50,000 households, 30,000 
SHG women, 3500 children who are mostly in penury, social exclusion and myriad 
discrimination and are extremely vulnerable to climate hazards like strong storms, 
cyclic cyclone and frequent dreadful disasters adding to resource dearth, penury, 
vulnerability and violence. In addition to this, Mukti has provided scholarships to 
more than 2000 students for higher studies, planted 2.5 lac mangrove, created and 
provided livelihood opportunities to the local people. Mukti is governed by the 
Board of Trustees comprising of the Founder-President, Secretary, Assistant 
Secretary, Treasurer and other members. Each trustee in their roles, function with 
specific assigned responsibilities. Mukti has almost 35 Consultants directly 
working in different areas and capacities and more than 200 volunteers who are 
involved with the day-to-day functioning of the organisation. Each project team 
reports to the Programme Officer, President and Secretary for project 
implementation and planning. All activities are aimed towards community 
development and focusing on the most marginalized sections. Mukti’s works on the 
community led approach and beliefs that it is the best way to create sustainability.

6c. Describe the history and past achievements of the organisation. 
(maximum 300 words):
Though a young institution of more than 17 years, MUKTI, a non-profit socio-
economic organization, working for Sundarban people in the Delta region of South 
24 Parganas, West Bengal, India, has accumulated a lot of accolades.
It was in the year 2003 when a few enthusiastic young minds of Sunderban 
became determined to redress some of the most intrinsic problems involving 
education and health. They decided to involve the educated and energetic local 
youth in the various community development projects. These youths gradually 
started developing the vision and finally laid the foundation of MUKTI. The local 
people supported them in this quench and the services continued and grew every 
year paving its way for a sustainable development for these marginalised 
people.  The commendable job by the team has been broadcasted by ‘BBC 
Worldwide service’ and the ‘Dadagiri’ show. The organization has received various 
accolades like Vivek Samman award, Star of Asia award, Bharat Excellence award, 
Krishi Ratna, APJ Abdul Kalam award, True legend award by Telegraph, AmiCare 
award on livelihood. The work of the organisation is visible in various national and 
international platforms and in state newspapers.  Today, MUKTI has been able to 
spread its wings in almost every state and country. Hundreds of volunteers have 
become associated with us and are supporting our noble cause. Our volunteers are 
involved with providing expertise knowledge to fund raising and also to work with 
the people directly in the field. Educational institutions have reached out to Mukti 
for placements and internships for building a strong foundation among their 
students entitled with social commitment and values.

6d. Describe the current strategy of the organisation. (maximum 300 
words):
Mukti is already developing strategy to explore new geographical areas and 
exploring feasibility of new initiatives as per community requirement. The 
organization will be expanding to other districts in West Bengal in the next few 
months. With this, our organization is also focusing on reaching out to the maximum 
population who are very deserving and need support. Mukti believes in maximizing 
quality initiatives which will directly impact the beneficiaries. And to learn from 
them how projects may be implemented as all the communities are dynamic in 
nature and have their own individualities. It is important for us to develop strategy 
accordingly. The current strategy also involves capacitating the team for better 
understanding of the realities and efficient outcome. In order to get timely outputs, 
responsibilities are well decentralized amongst the team members and regular 
meetings and field visits are a continuous process of the strategy. This is not only at 
the ground level but also at the Board level where each Trustee has definite function 
to do in their own roles. Mukti invites volunteers and interns and respects their 
interest in social work. They are involved and assigned with specific tasks as per 
their expertise, interest and convenience which helps in the development of strong 
values among the youngsters. Regular information sharing through newsletters, 
press releases are an important part of the work to reach out to more and more 
people. Already many associations, national and international have joined hands 
with Mukti for the commendable initiatives. It has been our strategy to upkeep these 
and share all updates about the organisation from time to time.
6e. What problems are you addressing? What are the opportunities and 
challenges in addressing these problems? (maximum 600 words):
Mukti is working towards an enabling environment for the community people so that 
these people are capacitated in such a way that they are able to identify their 
vulnerabilities and address them to reduce their vulnerability. In the process of 
doing that, Mukti has helped the community people to identify their own problems 
and people have been able to come up with solutions related to livelihood, dearth in 
resources, disaster preparedness, gender equality, education, health, adolescent 
problems and at the same time have also been able to identify ways to mitigate them 
from their own levels. These problems are related to agriculture, fishing and honey 
collection and how improvement can be brought into them. Community people have 
discussed about gender discrimination, evidence of drop out among school children, 
absence of basic health facilities in the communities, especially for women, impact 
of frequent disasters and how important is disaster preparedness essential in the 
community along with problems of deforestation and was to address them. As 
observed by Mukti, it is crucial to develop the insight among the community people 
to identify these as problems and strengthen their capacities to help them address 
them.
For  fulfilling the objectives of the project, Mukti has also identified lots of 
opportunities. Firstly, there is ample scope to involve youths and volunteers from 
the communities having understanding of the dynamics of the  community and 
Grant Application Form, July 1 20138
making them learn and develop skills to lead the community development 
initiatives.  Secondly, this project creates opportunities for networking 
partnerships among other grass root organizations and resource organizations 
which has a great scope for learning and understanding issues better.  Thirdly, the 
project has a good scope of adapting to the community needs rather than creating 
any unnecessary imposition on the community people. This is a great opportunity 
to understand the socio-economic-cultural contexts of the community and 
accordingly plan with them the future steps.
While working in the community, Mukti has observed certain challenges as well. 
Firstly, it has been noticed that the community people are very much influenced by 
the local politicians in each and every step. All schemes, provisions are very much 
influenced by the politicians and the community is divided into – privileged and the 
underprivileged. Secondly, frequent disasters have hampered the functioning of 
the community severely. Everytime, such disasters have been havoc and people 
have lost everything. It is very difficult for the community people to re-start, even 
though that becomes difficult because of the severe financial crunch. Thirdly, the 
current pandemic situation has not improved overall in the rural areas. People 
restrain outsiders from coming inside, many have lost jobs, demoralized and 
uncertain when the situation will improve and if there will be any scope to get 
back to work. The pandemic has jeopardized the families leading to precipitating 
other adverse social issues. Fourthly, the capacity of the community people in 
terms of motivation and willingness has severely been hit by the various calamities 
and other factors in the community. Hence, the outcomes expected are long term 
and have to undergo continuous process

Kamonohashi Project was founded in 2002 in Japan, aiming at combatting 
human trafficking of children for commercial sexual exploitation in the world. 
It started the projects in Cambodia where the child trafficking for commercial 
sexual exploitation was rampant, and it focused (1) to build community-based 
factory for the most vulnerable populations in rural Cambodia not to take the 
risk of unsafe migration, and (2) to support police training to strengthen the 
prosecution against traffickers. With the gradual shift of the issue, Kamo 
embarked on the global field study and concluded to support India in 2012. 
Kamo’s support in India aims to strengthen access to justice by the survivors 
of human trafficking through systems strengthening approach. Kamo 
facilitates breaking polarization in development debates through dialogue and 
deep listening. Kamo also strongly believes in leadership development in 
survivors and among organizational founders and second line leaders to 
strengthen the ecosystem of the civil society. In 2022, after three-year internal 
dialogue, Kamo decided to shift from mission-driven to the principle-based 
organization, and the new principle, “Dignity for All”, was approved by its 
General Assembly. Key achievements are;
1. Kamo handed over the Cambodia Programme to build further social 
leadership programme using the community-based factory. This process 
was handled professionally with financial transaction, and this type of 
business succession was of a rare case in the Japanese social sector;
2. Kamo built, nurtured and supported Tafteesh Programme since 2013, 
and Tafteesh received the Stop Slavery Collaboration Award from the 
Thomson Reuters Foundation in 2022;
Kamo is supported by 14,999 subscribed supporters as of May 2023. The 
fundraising model of Kamo is recognized as successful and unique in 
Japanese civil societies. The donations from those individual supporters have 
been enabling Kamo to design and support strategic programmes based on 
the contextual needs in India.

equity, diversity and inclusion? (600 words):
Secondary Research on Global Prevention of Human Trafficking (Balu et al, 
2021) under the last phase of Tafteesh revealed that (1) prevention of human 
trafficking is defined in a highly varied manner, depending upon the approach 
to human trafficking, (2) vulnerability to trafficking may show a stronger 
correlation with relative poverty rather than absolute poverty, (3) 
communities and systems sustain vulnerability through permissive 
Oak Application Form     7
environment that prevent quick identification of victims, and (4) the research 
calls for ecological, holistic and multidisciplinary approaches, reiterating that 
single-focused interventions will not impact the overall vulnerability of 
populations that are at risk of trafficking (Attachment 3).
“Preventing Trafficking: Sustainable developmental solutions to combat 
trafficking (Change Mantras, 2021)” under the last phase of Tafteesh also 
clarified that (1) there is no cogent policy on prevention of trafficking either 
in India or other parts of the world, (2) most anti trafficking programmes focus 
on responses to trafficking, rather than pre-emptively seeking to mitigate or 
prevent exploitations or violations that lead to trafficking, and (3) 
interventions are largely community based and making parents more 
responsible to prevent their children from being trafficked, and they lack the 
clarity of responsibility of duty-bearers such as district administration, 
panchayat and police in prevention (Attachment 4).
West Bengal is reportedly one of the most affected states by human trafficking 
and has been a high prevalence state according to the National Crime Records 
(Attachment C). Existing anti trafficking policies, laws or programmes, by the 
government or NGOs do not seem to have created any dent on the prevalence. 
Anti trafficking interventions have long focused on responsive initiatives - 
rehabilitation of survivors, reparation and penalisation of offenders. Even 
though all instruments on human trafficking to address prevention, there are, 
in fact, very few policies, laws or programmes that are focused on prevention, 
not only in West Bengal, but across India.
Tafteesh is one of the largest and most significant civil society led anti 
trafficking initiative in India today, that has mobilised and organised survivors 
of sex trafficking in North and South 24 Parganas in West Bengal and have 
succeeded in establishing survivor led initiatives in claiming rehabilitation and 
protection services from local governments, administration and health service 
providers, claiming compensation and assert rights to accountability from law 
enforcement agencies, legal services authorities and the judicial system in 
prosecution of traffickers. This led to the question - now that community based 
organisations and survivor collectives in these two districts that have become 
empowered to design and take action, how would it address the gap in absence 
of any preventative measures on human trafficking?
The Preventing Trafficking research indicated distinguishable patterns and 
differences in opinion on effective prevention between youth and adults, state 
duty bearers and common people. The research also identified information 
gaps in areas of labour trafficking, trafficking in men and boys, trafficking in 
transgender persons as well as underlying factors that explain higher 
vulnerability amongst people from scheduled caste and Muslims[1].
The opportunities emerged through the last two phases to build on this 
prevention piece is the survivor collectives, people who are victims of labour 
trafficking seeking support services, the enhanced capacities of the NGOs, the 
wide network of Tafteesh which include established connections with the 
legal, law enforcement and other relevant departments. This request from Oak 
Foundation is to enable Tafteesh to build on and implement diverse and unique 
prevention approaches relevant to local contexts based on rights-based and 
community-based initiatives in West Bengal.

by social workers, activists and survivors who participated in the research, 
based on their own experiences, data and observations.

Based on the risk assessment studies done by four legal and consulting firms 
in India in 2018 and 2019, Kamo’s Board decided to hire all team members as 
full-time consultants through third party payroll service. This has been 
practiced by multiple international foundations as well as UN agencies for

Services Ltd. (https://www.sams.co.in/) is the contract holder of all Kamo India 
team members, and Kamo and SAMS are in this arrangement since 2020.
 
4. About Tafteesh Organizational Mission and History
Tafteesh was formed in a response to its action research conducted in 2013, 
and it is the platform of 6 social impact organisations, 2 legal teams, 12 
member survivor collectives, Change Mantras (CM) for programme 
directorship and Kamonohashi Project (Kamo) as fund manager.  The platform 
has grown from 3 organisations and Kamonohashi to the current size with the 
annual budget increased from USD 45,680 to USD 447,335. Survivors are at 
the centre of the programme, and 246 survivors of trafficking as of May 2023 
plays the role of collaborator, feedback provider, monitor and advisor to the 
Tafteesh Management Committee, as well as co-implementor and co-planner 
with grassroots NGOs and legal teams.
Tafteesh is a Justice Programme for and with survivors of human trafficking, 
including children (girls and boys) and adults (women and men), for sexual 
exploitation and forced labour that aims to provoke state and national 
governments of India to develop policies, laws and systems and to allocate 
resources for rights of survivors and to protect rights of communities 
vulnerable to trafficking and exploitation in migration. For this mission, 
followings are the key achievements of Tafteesh;
•Development of Tafteesh’s prevention strategy, theory of change 
(Attachment B) and objectives, based on the community-based research 
conducted by survivors and social activists;
•Stigma reduction in survivors, survivors have organised themselves into 
organisations and have formed India’s first survivors’ exclusive 
leadership forum called Indian Leadership Forum Against Trafficking 
(ILFAT) in 2019;
•Empowerment of CBOs in anti-trafficking programming. CBOs are 
skilled with case-management based practice, which enables CBOs to 
hold district administrations accountable. CBOs are also skilled to 
provide legal services to survivors both for victim compensation and 
prosecution of traffickers, making legal services available from DLSA 
and private lawyers, escalating dereliction of duties or faulty 
investigations in cases to High Court using protest petitions or appeal.
Oak Application Form     15
 
5. Please state the factors behind prevalence of trafficking.
India’s policy on rehabilitation is ineffective, with poor rates of trauma-
recovery, economic security or social assimilation or protection from stigma. 
This systemic neglect alienates survivors from the State. Because India does 
not have a rehabilitation policy nationally or in any state, the role and 
accountability of duty bearers - Panchayats, administration, health 
departments remains fuzzy. This leaves survivors vulnerable to further 
violence in families and communities, and results in domestic violence and re-
trafficking. Investigations of cases of human trafficking are handled by the 
general police stations with limited resources and structural support for 
interstate investigations. The chain of crime is not investigated or established 
leading to poor case for prosecution. The non functioning of Anti Human 
Trafficking Units leads to poor conviction rates to deter trafficking crimes 
across states over years. Poor rate of access of compensations by survivors is 
a result of lack of the implementation of victim compensation scheme by Legal 
Services Authorities across states. Due to the lack of prevention policy 
throughout the country, the roles and responsibilities of government duty-
bearers to prevent human trafficking remains unclear to all. Lack of 
investment in survivors leadership in the sector lead to lack of inclusion of 
survivors as active agents in designing, implementing and monitoring 
interventions contributes to the fragmentation and also results in lack of 
ownership, sustainability and alignment of anti trafficking approaches with 
needs of communities vulnerable to trafficking.

5c. What is the problem you want to address and what is your approach? 
How will you use Oak's funding? How did you identify the problem and 
decide your approach? If you have undertaken a theory of change exercise, or if

Problem statement: Our work in South Asia over the past 10 years has shown 
us that despite sustained efforts by both government and civil society, access 
to justice in the current economic, social and political scenario in India 
remains extremely unequal. A two-tiered justice system allows only a 
privileged minority to understand the law and access justice. While state-led 
legal aid provisions and other legal recourse mechanisms do exist, not every 
marginalised community/individual (women, children, survivors of abuse, 
religious minorities, migrant workers and the disabled to name a few) has easy 
access to these mechanisms. Poor legal literacy and/or the lack of awareness 
of one’s rights under the law further hinders any meaningful engagement with 
the justice system. As a result, legal representation remains beyond the reach 
of poor and vulnerable communities. We also note that grassroots 
organisations representing the interests of these vulnerable communities 
similarly suffer from a lack of quality and affordable legal advice. And finally, 
primary stakeholders within the justice system (for example, public 
prosecutors, the police, lawyers, and so on) often lack nuanced knowledge of 
the laws that serve to protect the rights of these communities.
Theory of Change: iProbono’s pathway to real change is based in a law and 
development paradigm that ensures the most vulnerable communities in our 
society have access to and a voice within the legal system. Our model of 
holistic counsel engages and combines a series of tools including litigation, 
direct legal advice, professional development, outreach and community 
education, research advocacy and policy, and capacity building. Storytelling 
Oak Application Form     7
to change hearts and minds cross cuts across our tools and the concept of 
‘comprehensive care’ provides us with an additional tool to go one step 
beyond the legal. Alongside our capacity building and litigation support, we 
have also provided our partner organisations across India with emergency 
hunger relief funding during the Covid pandemic, or psychosocial support 
our clients who are survivors of sexual abuse in India or the ability to 
evacuate and support of 120 at risk women from Afghanistan when the 
Taliban seized power in 2021.
This holistic justice model thus aims to both prevent rights violations, seek 
solutions when violations have occurred, and catalyse deeper systemic 
change. With the Oak Foundation’s support, we intend to deepen our 
engagement in each of these areas with selected sub-grantees in West 
Bengal: 2 carefully selected partner organisations to deliver holistic access 
to justice to vulnerable communities in West Bengal.
We have held an initial consultation with a core group of 8 organisations 
currently supported by the Oak Foundation to gain insight in to the type of 
access justice issues faced by communities. As part of the proposal, we have 
included an initial scoping period to allow our internal team to apply the 
stated theory of change in the selection of sub-grantee organisations as well 
as in the process of supporting these organisations to plan delivery.
Diversity, equity and inclusion underpin our theory of change and an active 
internal Equality Law team advises on how we inform each of our programs 
from choice of delivery partner to thematic issues covered in our work. 
iProbono intends to monitor implementation in this area during the grant 
period.

4g. Summarise the project’s ultimate goal(s) (maximum 200 words):
( NOT REQUIRED FOR CORE SUPPORT GRANTS)
The project’s ultimate goal is to highlight child agency as one of the critical 
components that need to be kept in mind while amplifying community voices. The 
adult-child axis of power is a difficult power gradient to engage with by both adults 
and children. This becomes even more complicated in case of adolescents where 
issues about choice and consent assume very different nuances.
Agency in children and adolescents is also strongly related to gender identity and 
expression and is shaped by gender norms and expectations. The project hopes to 
capacitate implementing organisations to acknowledge  agency of children and 
adolescents and appreciate the role that gender plays in hindering and facilitating 
participation of children and women so that their opinions and choices are reflected 
adequately within community voices and action.

Pratham was established in 1995 to provide pre-school education to the 
children in the slums of Mumbai. Since then, the organization has grown both 
in scope & geographical coverage and has expanded to most parts of India 
reaching millions of children in both rural and urban areas across 20 states 
and 3 union territories. Pratham has grown to address a gamut of educational 
problems – pre-school education, learning support to both in-school and out of 
school children and youth, mainstreaming of out-of-school  children, computer 
literacy, vocational training for youth and special programs for vulnerable and 
working children. Pratham Skilling is the vocational training arm of Pratham, 
established  in 2005 with the aim of empowering youth (age 18-35 years) from 
economically disadvantaged backgrounds by creating avenues for them to 
attain employability and/or entrepreneurship. Since 2005, we have trained 
1,76,000+ youth in industry specific trades and placed 75-80% youth in jobs 
in automotive, hospitality, healthcare, electrical, beauty & construction trades 
among our 2000+ industry partners at our 130+ centers spread across 16 
states. We also run entrepreneurship development projects and have 
supported 5,300+ entrepreneurs.
The following are some of Pratham’s key achievements:
1.Blended learning approach: Effective blended learning project in 
1000 communities since 2016. 8000 tablets and 1000 Raspberry Pis 
distributed, impacting 60,000 children and 6000 youth, including 2000 
drop-outs.
2.Hybrid Skilling Innovation: Pratham pivoted to a remote-contact self-
learning and virtual-training model in 20,000+ villages during the 
lockdown leading to employment for 32,000+ youth from Oct 2020-
March 2022.
3.Post-Placement Tracking: To ensure continued retention in 
employment, Pratham reaches out to each trainee every 3 months, for a 
period of 1 year, collecting 110+ data points tracking their employment 
status and need for further placement assistance. Pratham is the only 
organization in the ecosystem to conduct such a tracking.
