The communities of North Bengal live in precarious conditions, highly 
dependent on employment provided by tea-plantation owners. Low wages, 
seasonal employment cycle, plantation owners’ restrictions and lack of 
alternative income-earning opportunities are some of the key challenges 
faced by these communities. To understand the region in more detail, a 
team of 4 Pratham members, including program leadership visited 
Soongachi, Naxalbari, Kakarvita & Cooch Behar tea estates in March 
2022. The team interacted with the sarpanch & gram-panchayat members 
and conducted 3 focused group discussions with the youth & their parents 
on their current employment situation, aspirations and challenges. Most 
of the youth majorly belonged to SC/ST sections with someone from their 
family working in a tea garden. Some key insights from their discussions:
1. Current Employment Status: While some youth were still studying, 
majority of them had completed their 12th and graduation and were 
not engaged in any employment activity. 
2. Aspiration: The youth showed disinterest towards working in tea-
gardens and were looking for other job opportunities. However, they 
lacked exposure about jobs available in different sectors, how to access 
them and industry requirements. There was a clear need for guidance 
and mentorship for these youth. 
3. Willingness to migrate for training & job: Majority of these youth 
showed willingness to join a vocational training course near their 
communities and migrate for a job opportunity within Bengal. 
Hospitality, Automotive 4W, Healthcare and electrical trades were 
some of the most chosen preferences of these youth. 
4. Workforce demand: The tea-gardens being a tourist attraction, there is 
massive demand for hospitality staff. Interaction with a couple of 
automotive showrooms and service dealerships and resorts reflected 
the need for skilled staff within this region. Year 2 onwards electrical 
trade will also be introduced based on a need assessment study 
conducted with industry partners. 
 
Another interaction with Adivasi Vikas Parishad and SPAN NGO further 
emphasized livelihood related challenges, trafficking issues, mobility and 
connectivity problems, education and healthcare related issues within the 
region. While these interactions clearly indicate lack of awareness on 
vocational training led employment pathways, Pratham will conduct a 
detailed need assessment survey both in the community and with industry 
partners in North Bengal to understand aspirations and needs in greater 
depth. The survey will also capture potential job opportunities within tea 
manufacturing units. Insights from this detailed survey will feed into the 
program design.

Based on Pratham’s experience of 17 years training over 1,75,000 rural 
youth across India, we propose  a  community-focused youth training 
initiative in Hospitality and Automotive 4W trades in Year 1 and Electrical

 Following are the key components of the programs:
 
Building Awareness : Mentors will interact with youth, panchayat and 
community leaders spreading awareness on career pathways through 
vocational training focusing primarily on communities working in the tea 
garden areas of Darjeeling, Kalimpong, Alipurduar, Jalpaiguri, Coochbehar, 
Uttar Dinajpur and Dakshin Dinajpur districts of North Bengal region. 
Group meetings, skill-melas, video testimonials of Pratham’s alumni will be 
leveraged to build awareness. At this stage, youth will be enrolled in Level 
1 -7-day long self-placed digital courses giving exposure to 7 different 
industry trades and potential job opportunities within them. 
Training – Conducted in a hybrid approach, the core training includes two 
components namely, Level 2 (virtual sessions) and Level 3 (in-person 
practical sessions). The entire training spans roughly 45-60 days. 
Job Placements- Trained youth will be oriented with available job 
opportunities within Hospitality and Automotive sectors. Pratham 
negotiates with its placement partners for salaries and additional benefits- 
food, accommodation and transportation allowance for its trainees. Youth 
will be guided throughout the interview and joining process. 
Post-Placement Tracking: To ensure continued retention in employment,

(300 words):
Measurement is an integral part of all Pratham programs. Be it internal 
measurement, or external evaluations such as by government assessment 
agencies and industry sector bodies, Pratham has established a strong culture 
of capturing and using data rigorously to demonstrate impact over the past 
several years.
In 2013, Pratham set up a separate Measurement, Monitoring and Evaluation 
(MME) Unit to be able to systematically carry out a set of planned evaluations 
to measure and track progress and impact.  This evidence is now internally 
analyzed to understand the strengths and shortcomings of Pratham’s 
programs, and to assist in developing solutions to improve the effectiveness of 
the programs.
A key measure of our impact is the number of youth trained that retain jobs 
beyond 6 months – this is a measure we have adopted above and beyond the 
standard metrics of training and placement that are the norms for the sector. 
We are also trying to use the insights from our measurement of impact to get 
a similar measurement adopted by the entire ecosystem.
Currently, Pratham gathers both quantitative and qualitative information 
about all students enrolled at the training center. At each of the centers, 
Oak Application Form     15
concerned staff will gather extensive background details such as family 
income, educational qualifications and fee status of each student which will 
then be compiled in the ‘Salesforce’ Management Information System 
(MIS). The reports generated will include both Quantitative Metrics (such as 
the number of students enrolled, trained, certified, and supported as 
entrepreneurs, as well as retention and dropout rates) and Qualitative Data 
about the social and economic impact of our programs (e.g. through student 
case studies). Entrepreneurs are also tracked on a monthly basis once 
supported, for the period of a year, to better understand their progress and 
any challenges faced. The Central Team provides them with ongoing support 
and mentorship during this period.

audit team responsible for planned and impromptu audits at the center level.

checklist and feedback mechanism. Supporters are also encouraged to visit 
the Centers they sponsor and assess the impact their investment is having 
through this transformative educational and vocational training program.

occurring at the center. Through this we aim to collect data that represents

All programs will be tracked throughout the year and an annual report will be

Given that this will be our first project in the far north-east part of the country,

marginalised communities across South Asia. Since 2012, working closely with 
Adivasi worker communities, we have conducted numerous trainings to expand 
workers’ knowledge of socio-economic, labour, and maternal health rights. 
•Our training aided activists in their fight for a higher minimum wage for tea 
plantation workers, securing a historic 77% increase in daily wages for 
800,000 tea plantation workers in Assam. Following our efforts providing 
training, conducting community meetings, and advocating for workers, the 
Assam government’s Minimum Wage Advisory Committee recommended 
another wage increase of 110% (from Rs. 167 to Rs. 351) in 2018.
•Evidence from our human rights fact-finding investigations and monitoring, 
such as EndMMNow, supported successful filing of complaints by workers 
to secure their rightful food, health, housing, and labour benefits. 
•Nazdeek also amplified community voices nationally and globally through 
published reports: “No Time to Lose: Fighting Maternal and Infant Mortality 
through Community Reporting” (2015), “A Matter of Life and Death: 
Surviving Childbirth on Assam’s Tea Plantations” (2018), “Hidden Traumas: 
Uncovering Experiences of Obstetric Violence” (2020), and “Rising 
Stronger: Security Strategies for Women Defenders” (2020). 
•Our research in Assam and greater South Asia was also critical in our 
founding of the FRTW in 2019, a first of its kind forum for advancing the 
rights of tea plantation workers. 
•In Delhi, working with 6 socio-economically marginalised communities, 
Nazdeek’s 35 presently-active paralegal volunteers have ensured basic 
entitlements such as community clinics and Anganwadi Centers, and 
housing, water and sanitation rights for over 15,000 residents. 
•Since 2020, Nazdeek and partners have provided COVID-19 humanitarian 
relief to over 25,000 individuals in Assam, Delhi, and Tamil Nadu. 
•Nazdeek’s work was recognised with the Namati Grassroots Justice Prize in 
2015 and World Justice Prize in 2019.
6d. Describe the current strategy of the organisation. (maximum 300 
words):
Nazdeek’s legal empowerment model places the communities we work with at 
the center of our work. We aspire to build leadership among women for greater 
participation in decision-making at the community, state, and policy-making 
levels. Nazdeek’s sustainability strategy creates an advocacy and outreach model 
owned by the community, which thrives without our presence. 
Strategy:
1. Identifying communities after detailed scoping, assessment, and needs-
Grant Application Form, July 1 20138
mapping. Through community meetings and partnerships with 
local organizations, we explain our model and invite participants for 
trainings. We prioritize outreach in communities marginalised on the basis 
of social identities like caste, class, religion, migration, and work status. 
2. Training participants, predominantly women, to be community paralegals 
and equipping them with administrative and judicial tools for addressing 
rights violations. Using participatory methods, we ensure inclusive and 
safe training spaces for participants. 
3. Assisting paralegals in using grievance redressal, policy advocacy, and 
strategic litigation tools. 
4. At every stage, paralegals and communities decide their priorities and 
initiatives. We assess risks and identify mitigation strategies collectively, 
prioritising their safety and security. 
5. Eventually, paralegals undertake community meetings independently, 
strengthening their human rights documentation and advocacy skills. 
Nazdeek then moves to an advisory role. 
6. To support the long-term work of paralegals and connect community action 
to regional initiatives, we facilitate formation of coalitions. 
7. Paralegals work on a voluntary basis and are not paid an honorarium. This 
aligns with Nazdeek’s objective of building community leadership, 
agency,  and ownership of initiatives. Nazdeek does provide them 
certificates and supports them by sharing opportunities, relevant 
government schemes, and needs-based communications reimbursements.
Since early 2020, due to the pandemic, we have employed several tools to 
continue engagement remotely. While we prioritise in-person visits, we have 
now developed novel modes of outreach and maintained our strategy despite 
the crisis.
 
6e. What problems are you addressing? What are the opportunities and 
challenges in addressing these problems? (maximum 600 words):
Tea plantation workers across South Asia experience dismal living and working 
conditions, earn meagre wages, and face ineffectual labour law protections. In 
India, where tea plantation workers are predominantly Adivasi (indigenous) and 
women, these conditions have led to an intergenerational cycle of oppression and 
poverty. 
Key issues faced: 
•Currently, corporations function in the roles previously held by colonial 
powers, and are primarily responsible for the poor housing, wages, health 
care, food, water, and sanitation experienced by tea plantation workers. 
•Workers are not paid a legal minimum wage, sufficient to ensure basic 
necessities for themselves and their families. 
•Women do not receive sufficient medical care, especially pre- and post-natal 
maternal healthcare, leading to extremely high rates of anaemia, and high 
Grant Application Form, July 1 20139
maternal and infant mortality on tea plantations.
Nazdeek, with its partner organizations, has aided workers in addressing these 
problems and issues. However, recent circumstances have worsened this 
situation. 
Challenges: 
•Due to the current political situation in India, organisations and individuals 
doing cutting edge rights work face a higher risk of coercive actions. 
Plantations have become inaccessible due to greater surveillance by their 
management. 
•While the pandemic has opened up new ways of communicating for the rest 
of the world, our project communities have very limited access to electricity, 
gadgets, and the internet. 
•The Central government has repealed and replaced 29 previous national 
labour laws with just 4 labour codes. While the previous laws did not 
provide robust worker protections, certain laws such as the Plantations 
Labour Act, did ensure specific protections for workers on tea plantations. 
•Employers have taken advantage of the current legal ambiguities, wherein 
old laws have been repealed, but the new laws are not yet in force, further 
limiting the rights of workers on tea plantations. 
•Additionally, the COVID-19 pandemic has resulted in an even more dire 
situation for tea workers, as the pandemic-induced lockdown has created 
food scarcity as government-run ration shops and health centers remain 
closed or under-operational. Conversely, tea workers continue to be forced 
to work despite the pandemic and minimal safeguards on plantations. 
Opportunities: 
Addressing both the long-standing issues experienced by tea plantation workers 
and the new issues created by the pandemic is a struggle in the current legal and 
policy climate. However, this also makes it an increasingly important time to 
mobilize workers and assist them in their advocacy, as workers have the 
opportunity to comment on proposed laws and shape local policy in an effort to 
strengthen their legal rights. 
•To overcome communication challenges, Nazdeek, its paralegals, and 
communities are adopting innovative methods. For example, we recently 
conducted 12 intensive online training sessions on labour laws with tea 
workers in Assam. 
•With Central and State governments currently drafting rules to the labour 
laws, an opportunity has arisen for tea workers to engage in this process 
and to effect policy and legislative change. Nazdeek has therefore been 
facilitating their participation through trainings, consultations, and FRTW, 
resulting in submission of 5 comments to draft rules. This has allowed wider 
stakeholder representation, and workers have gained confidence to engage 
in similar processes in the future. 
•Due to the aforementioned threats, now is a critical time for tea plantation 
workers’ advocacy. Enhancing their advocacy skills will not only address the 
immediate needs, but will also shape the future of tea workers’ rights. 
Legislative and policy changes now will combat negative effects of India’s 
new labour laws, as workers will have stronger legal protections and better 
avenues for demanding adequate wages, maternal health benefits, and 
improved living and working conditions.

11. Future Plans
How will the grant influence the organisation and future plans? (maximum 
300 words):
For over a decade, Nazdeek has been a key partner to workers’ collectives and 
CSOs in the rights movements of tea plantation workers in India. The four new 
labour codes, and related rules and policies, will have long-lasting effects on the 
rights of tea plantation workers. Nazdeek intends to continue working with 
organizations in Assam and replicate its legal empowerment model in West 
Bengal, and across India through FRTW. This grant opportunity will enable 
Nazdeek and our partners to affect the drafting and implementation of these new 
laws across states. This will have a positive impact on workers’ rights in the 
future. This grant will ensure that the communities Nazdeek works with will be in 
the best position to defend their rights, as they will have developed the skill sets 
necessary to advocate for themselves and will have strong legal protections on 
which to rely. Aside from Nazdeek’s significant advocacy work in India, we have 
also conducted scoping assessments of the rights of tea plantation workers in 
Bangladesh, Nepal, and Sri Lanka. Nazdeek is dedicated to supporting tea 
plantation workers in their advocacy, and it is critical that workers are organized 
at the national, regional, and international levels to ensure that the industry does 
not move from one state or country with stronger labour policies to another state 
or country with weaker ones. A regional or international coalition and movement 
focused on protecting the socio-economic and labour rights of tea workers is 
necessary to accomplish this. Nazdeek plans to continue our work in strengthening 
and expanding the FRTW, to conduct national, regional and international 
advocacy. This grant would allow Nazdeek to make significant progress in 
developing this Forum, and further, will bring Nazdeek closer to our goal of 
ultimately supporting a strong, international FRTW.

Additionally, as Nazdeek scales up its legal empowerment model, we are also keen 
to further build our consultant's capacity and professional training on international 
complaints mechanisms, cross-country/regional learnings on grassroots 
empowerment models, subject area expertise, workflow management, 
psychosocial issues and stress management. We hope that the proposed grant will 
assist in achieving this goal as well.

through awareness and capacity building, encouraging local planning and

5c. What is the problem you want to address and what is your approach? 
How will you use Oak's funding? How did you identify the problem and 
decide your approach? If you have undertaken a theory of change exercise, or if 
you are influenced by research, policy or your own organisation’s experience, please 
tell us about this.  Have you consulted with relevant stakeholders, including your 
communities and others experiencing the problem? Is there an intention to address 
equity, diversity and inclusion? (600 words):
There is intense research on the pressing challenge of access to water and 
sanitation for tea estate workers and their families in Darjeeling and 
Kurseong. The situation is also aggravated due to climate change. Climate 
impacts of decreased rainfall and increased temperatures in the northern 
part of West Bengal are well recorded in the Indian Network for Climate 
Change Assessment (INCCA), 2010 and the West Bengal State Action Plan on 
Climate Change (SAPCC), 2017. Both reports suggest a decrease in overall 
rainy days and an increase of minimum and maximum temperatures for the 
region. Such changes are not conducive for tea cultivation, and has resulted 
in increased dependency on local water reserves, natural streams and 
reservoirs. A Central Ground Water Board report from 2014 and a study by 
Rai et al., 2016 suggest natural springs and their watersheds are inefficiently 
managed and facing degradation. Excessive extraction, coupled with limited 
recharge or rejuvenation of natural reserves is leading to scarcity of water. 
The scarce resource is also subject to degradation through extensive use of 
Oak Application Form     7
fertilizer, pesticides, and agrochemicals by the tea gardens and 
indiscriminate disposal of waste along the mountain slopes and often into the 
streams. Since some sources of water are available seasonally, there is 
greater likelihood of them being degraded during the dry spells. Apart from 
quality and quantity, reliable access to water is challenging as well, with tea 
estates, hotels promoting tea tourism, the managerial staff of tea estates, tea 
estate workers and local indigenous communities outside the tea estates all 
competing for the same scarce resource.  Even though it is evident that the 
tea estates play a pivotal role as major stakeholders in the water resources 
of the region, there appears to be a noticeable lack of engagement between 
the tea estates and the ongoing initiatives of the government. This 
discrepancy underscores the critical importance of collaboration among 
different stakeholders. 
There are a number of schemes of the West Bengal government that are 
looking at access to water, such as the Jal Dharo, Jal Bharo scheme, the 
Jaltirtho schemes that are supporting micro-irrigation technologies, as well 
as water harvesting or storage structures. Some development schemes such 
as the Kanyashree, Lakshmi Bhandar or Chai Sundari schemes look at 
housing, education or general social development. The current budget has 
allocated INR 823 crores for North Bengal development and more than INR 
1500 crores for water resources development for the fiscal year 2023-24. In 
addition, more than INR 1300 crores have been allocated to technical 
training and skill development.
More often than not, access to water is subject to an unwritten hierarchy 
wherein the indigenous community and the tea estate workers are at the 
bottom rung. Time and labour-intensive practice of fetching water from 
faraway places, impacts women in particular from these communities. There 
are reports indicating that consumption of poor quality water or inadequate 
water has impacted overall health and adaptive capacity of the workers and 
marginalised local communities. 
ICLEI’s experience in the region also reflects these findings. Previous work 
in the region, including in Kurseong, has shown that local communities are 
rarely involved in the critical aspect of water resource management by local 
governments. This results in lack of ownership of water related projects and 
subsequent lack of support by local communities. This means that eventually 
projects may fall into disrepair, if local communities do not use them 
properly and carefully. More importantly, the linkages of water resource 
conservation and solid waste management needs to be highlighted and dealt 
with effectively to keep water resources clean and safe. Gender aspects of 
water use and management is also not considered in the planning and 
implementation of water projects.  
This project intends to tackle the water crisis faced by the local communities 
by using traditional knowledge and community led practices for rainwater 
harvesting, spring revival, reuse and upcycling of wastewater through 
coordinated and collaborative efforts of the communities, the local 
governments and the private sector involving the tea estates and hotels. The 
project envisages the crucial involvement of local communities, particularly 
women, right from the development of action plans, their implementation 
and monitoring as well as replication and scale up. A cadre of barefoot 
hydrogeologists will be trained from among the local communities, focusing 
on local women and youth, giving them the necessary wherewithal to 
Oak Application Form     8
prepare basic water conservation plans and manage their resources in 
collaboration with other stakeholders.

7. OBJECTIVES
This is the most important part of your application, as it is your opportunity to explain 
what you want to achieve and what will be different because of your work. We 
understand that social and environmental change is complex and there are a 
multitude of factors that contribute to change. We want to understand how you define

7.a. Objectives
List here up to 3 main objectives for this grant (one sentence per objective). Think of objectives as goals 
that can be achieved within the lifetime of the grant.  We encourage you to think of objective(s) that are 
ambitious but also achievable.  
The project aims to create and institutionalize a replicable model for 
community-led Integrated Water Resource Management (IWRM), to develop 
and implement Water Security Plans for tea estates that will help to improve 
the quality, quantity, access and reliability of water for local communities. 
The specific objectives of the project include: 
- To mobilise and build capacity of local indigenous community and migrant 
tea estate workers as barefoot hydrogeologists, who are able to assess water 
issues as well as design and implement locally-owned interventions that 
promote water conservation and rejuvenation, in collaboration with local 
governments and tea estate management. 
- To improve overall water availability and equitable access to water, thereby 
enhancing the adaptive capacity and resilience of local communities.
- To create an institutional platform consisting of local governments, 
community representatives, and tea estate management, for overall 
management and robust monitoring of the implementation of water security 
plans, and ensure potential scale up and sustainability.
 
7.b. Expected Outcomes (bullet points):
What do you expect will change because of this grant? What does success look like? List here 
the main outcomes you hope to achieve or make significant contributions towards with this 
grant, and for whom.  If you have concrete targets, please also list them here. Outcomes 
describe significant changes for people, communities, organisations or systems. Some 
Oak Application Form     9
examples are changes in policies and legislation; changes in knowledge, awareness, 
attitudes, beliefs, behaviours or social norms; changes in capacities, level of influence, 
agency or access to services. Please refer to the guidance for additional examples.
The expected outcomes of the project are: 
- community led and managed water security plans institutionalized in at 
least 4 tea estates, and adopted by the local governments in the region. 
- a cohort of barefoot hydrogeologists including women, formed and 
institutionalized in the region who can eventually not only identify local 
water issues, but also design and implement interventions to address such 
issues and act as local ambassadors for water resource management. At least 
seven to ten  barefoot hydrogeologists in each tea-estate  to be trained and 
capacitated. It is also envisaged that at least 50 percent of these barefoot 
hydrogeologists will be women.
- locally responsive water conservation measures implemented 
collaboratively by local communities, local governments and tea estate 
management.
- creation of a societal platform for local communities and tea estate 
management to engage and influence the local governments for safe and 
sustainable water resources.
It is well acknowledged that enhancing water security positively influences 
various socio-economic and environmental aspects. In the project region, 
women typically are responsible for collection of water and enhanced water 
security will reduce the workload for women, providing them with more time 
for education, income-generating activities and community participation. 
Therefore, it is envisaged that the larger impact of the project will 
extend  beyond access to water, and will lead to improved health of women 
in particular but also their families, better access to sanitation, improved 
solid waste management to clean up water resources, enhanced livelihoods, 
and, in general, lead to resilient communities.

The project activities and their timelines are outlined below: 
1. Regional scoping and selection of target area of work (M1 - M4)- Selection 
of 4 target tea estates where the project will be implemented. This will be 
based on several factors such as:
-    Water resources: availability of basic information about water resources 
and associated issues, watershed area covered by the tea estates, 
perenniality etc.
-    Tea estate: whether owned by the government or private; size of the tea 
estate; commitment and support from the tea estate management; support 
from the tea estate unions, proximity and connectivity among others.
Oak Application Form     10
-    Local communities: size and type of the population, socio-economic 
conditions, marginalized and disadvantaged population especially women 
(e.g., migrant laborer, indigenous population), cultural and traditional 
practices among others
-    Presence of Oak/non-Oak partners: opportunity to enhance the synergies 
between the existing organizations in the tea-estate to ensure maximum 
impact
A list of tea estates will be prepared and analyzed considering the above-
mentioned parameters, and will be shared with the Oak Foundation for their 
review and final selection. 
2. Baseline assessment (M2 - M8) - A baseline data assessment of water 
resource related data, hydro-geological mapping, demography, water use, 
will be conducted to get ground level information through secondary data 
collectionThe project team will conduct focused group discussions (FGDs) to 
verify the secondary information collected from different resources. 
3. Gap identification and vulnerability assessment (M6 - M15) - Identification 
of local issues and climate vulnerability of the regional water resources as 
well as vulnerability of the local population will be studied. Through FGDs 
and stakeholder consultations, interventions will be identified to address the 
water related issues of local communities, with emphasis on traditional 
practices to address issues on water conservation and management in the 
region.  
4. Training and capacity building of barefoot hydrogeologists (M10 - M30) - 
Selection of interested community members, including women and youth will 
be conducted based on the interest of the local communities shown in the 
FGDs or other consultations. They will be trained as barefoot 
hydrogeologists and hand holding support will be provided to help them 
institutionalise the process of local water management.
5. Development and government ratification of water security plans (M12 - 
M22) - Community led and managed water security plans will be prepared by 
involving all stakeholders including local communities, tea estate 
management and local governments to identify possible interventions. 
Opportunities of funding the plans through government or private fund 
sources will be identified to facilitate its implementation.
6. Identification and on ground implementation of pilots (M20 - M30) - Based 
on local needs assessment, pilot projects will be selected by the local 
communities and barefoot hydrogeologists from the region for 
implementation. The selected pilot will be determined from a range of 
options identified in the water security plans developed. The local 
communities and barefoot hydrogeologists will identify traditional methods 
of water conservation and use, through FGDs that can be adapted and 
replicated as pilot projects. The project team will facilitate the selection by 
providing technical inputs.
7. Institutionalisation and monitoring (M25 - M32) - A framework will be 
developed for monitoring and used to monitor the implementation of the 
pilots and the water security plans developed by the barefoot 
hydrogeologists and societal platform of different stakeholders 
8. Dissemination (M32 - M35) - Dissemination of the work and identification 
of replication opportunities will begin from the training phase, and continue 
through the project, but will be strengthened at the later stage of the 
project.
9. Reporting and publication (M35-M36) - Some publications are planned 
during the project, particularly for recording the training process of the

barefoot hydrogeologists and the community level interventions 
implemented; final reporting of project activities will be carried out at the 
end of the project.

8. COOPERATION  
How will you involve others in your approach to achieving change? If you are

Why are these the right partners to engage with?  Is there anything new about how you are 
choosing to work - for example, new partnerships or an approach that is different to how you 
usually work? (300 words):
The project proposes to develop a collaborative platform to bring together 
different stakeholders from government, private sector, NGOs and local 
communities (particularly women from indigenous and migrant communities) 
to develop, implement and monitor locally led and managed water security 
plans. The platform will facilitate interaction between the stakeholders to 
implement and monitor actions on ground that promote water security that 
can be scaled up regionally.
The information from the gap analysis in the water and sanitation systems 
and climate vulnerability assessment of the indigenous community, migrant 
workers and existing water resources will be analysed to develop a climate 
resilient and equitable Community Led Water Security Plans (WaSP) through 
this platform with full involvement of the local communities, particularly the 
cadre of trained barefoot hydrogeologists. ICLEI SA will consult with the 
local communities (particularly women), migrant workers, tea estate owners 
and local authorities through workshops and focused group discussions to 
develop a list of possible interventions, both infrastructural and non-
infrastructural. The plans will be ratified by the local governments through 
their councils to ensure government support, both through supportive 
policies and possible funding programmes.
The Water Security Plans will be developed with particular focus on women, 
who are largely responsible for household level management of water, but 
not often engaged in the planning or management of the resources. In 
addition, tea estate management, being responsible for all actions within 
their estates, will be involved in the process for greater transparency and 
engagement. Local governments, responsible for water supply,will be 
engaged to collaborate and partner with the communities so that all actions 
are legitimate and acceptable to all parties. 
ICLEI South Asia regularly works with different stakeholders, governments, 
communities and private sector to prepare and implement plans. Usually, 
most of the focus is on engaging local governments, but in this case, the 
focus will be on the local communities and enabling them to take 
responsibility of their resources in collaboration with the government.

9. MONITORING, EVALUATION & LEARNING 
This section is twofold. Please tell us:

If you have a formal monitoring and evaluation system and if you plan to collect indicator data or 
conduct an external evaluation, please provide details here.

(300 words):
A design and monitoring framework will be formulated to monitor the project 
progress and success, clearly articulating the links between issues, 
interventions, outputs, outcomes and ultimate impact in the context of 
ensuring water security. The framework will have clearly specified, 
measurable, achievable targets such as number of households with improved 
access to water/sanitation, amount/quality of water harvested, number of 
community engagement events, number of barefoot hydrogeologists 
(especially women) trained, etc. The framework will articulate the ultimate 
impact of the project on a larger scale such as improved public health, 
increased environmental sustainability, and overall well-being of 
communities. The progress against each indicator will be monitored 
depending on its objective, either monthly, bi-annually or annually.  
The framework will include elements to assess the gender and social 
inclusivity throughout the project cycle. A stakeholder group, composed of 
key representatives from marginalized and indigenous populations, especially 
women, will be formed to act as a voice for the larger population. 
The  stakeholders group will be involved throughout the planning and 
implementation of the project. They will provide inputs to the formulation of 
WaSP, identifying potential interventions to enhance access to water as well 
as during the implementation and finally operation and maintenance. Open 
dialogues will be conducted with the targeted population to build trust and 
ensure that selected interventions are responsive to the needs and 
aspirations of the community.The process will include quantitative and 
qualitative information gathered from the beneficiaries through participatory 
methods. Such qualitative information from the beneficiaries and 
communities can provide valuable insights and contribute to a more 
comprehensive assessment of the project success.
In addition, a methodology will be identified that can be used periodically by 
the platform of stakeholders to assess the implementation of the water 
security plan and monitor it over time. The barefoot hydrogeologists will also 
be trained on relevant and high-quality data collection for better monitoring. 
The project will introduce and institutionalize a feedback loop mechanism 
where community feedback will be incorporated into ongoing MEL 
processes. Participatory workshops or Focus Group Discussions will be 
Oak Application Form     13
organized semi-annually to get their inputs. By integrating a monitoring 
framework into Water security plans, stakeholders can make informed 
decisions, allocate resources effectively, and continuously improve strategies 
to ensure water availability and access for all while safeguarding the 
environment.
The project will embrace adaptive management principles to ensure that the 
plan remains relevant and effective in a dynamic environment. Regular 
review meetings are planned with Oak Foundation to monitor progress and 
outputs and based on the findings, the team will make necessary adjustments 
to the project plan by modifying strategies, reallocating resources, or 
revising targets.
GAF_A_ICLEI_South_Asia_CommuLedClimaResi.10. RISKS AND CHALLENGES:
10.  RISKS AND CHALLENGES
What are the risks or barriers that might prevent you from achieving your 
outcomes and how will you address these?  What are your opportunities?
We understand that achieving long-lasting and meaningful change is hard and we 
expect that the work you want to do will mean taking risks.  We encourage you to be 
open to telling us these, as well as how you will address these risks.  If some of your 
outcomes are risky, are there any incremental achievements that you could identify? 
(300 words):
The major risks identified for the project include: 
1. Non-cooperation by the tea estates: Lack of awareness, common interest, 
competing priorities or simply no interest towards the larger cause of 
enhancing water resilience can lead to non-cooperation by the tea estates. 
Since the project interventions are planned within the boundaries of selected 
tea estates, it is imperative to bring them on board. The project team will 
select tea estates that are open minded and interested to improve the water 
resource situation during the initial assessment. Continuous engagement 
from the beginning throughout the project  will build their trust and sensitize 
them toward the issue. 
2. Non-cooperation by the local communities: Building trust in external 
people coming in to resolve local issues is not easy. The project team plans to 
extensively engage with the communities, including having local staff around 
for continuous communication, so that trust can be built over time. 
3. Political changes: Changes in political leadership, lack of political will or 
competing priorities can impact the project implementation. Local 
governments will be engaged right from the beginning and a nodal official 
will be identified for continuous communication. ICLEI’s presence in the 
region and previous connections will also be useful in this matter.
4. Data and information gaps: Insufficient or unreliable data on water 
resources, usage, and quality can impact informed decision-making and 
planning. In such a case, state or regional level data will be extrapolated.
5. Financial constraints: Lack of funding or budgetary constraints can hinder 
the implementation of necessary infrastructure and interventions for 
improving water security. ICLEI is already making plans of applying for 
Oak Application Form     14
funding from other sources and will also explore local government budgets, 
or state government schemes such as Jal Dharo, Jal Bharo or Jalatirtho will 
be explored for possible funding. It is to be noted that most of the centrally-
sponsored schemes and programmes are not well-supported and 
implemented in the state of West Bengal, so stress will be on state schemes.

Context
Informal workers form the mainstay of the Indian economy. They constitute a 
significant portion of the Indian workforce, estimated to be around 90% of 
the total workforce.[1] Yet they face a lack of job security, low wages, and 
poor working conditions. They are also not eligible for benefits such as 
pension, insurance, and paid leave, which are available to formal sector 
workers. The live-work conditions of informal workers, especially in cities are 
an ignored reality wherein the formal state-led (exclusionary) urban vision 
has neglected the settlements that house the informal workers. Whilst there 
are initiatives taken by the state to bring the workers’ rights under a broad 
umbrella of reformed legislations to provide social security to informal 
workers, the coverage is still limited and restricted, and not holistic.[2]
The COVID pandemic has ruptured the status quo and lifted the veil on the 
fault lines in our society. The crisis uncovered the sheer lack of security – 
social and economic – and the mere reach that the state extended on its 
vulnerable people. The pandemic began in the cities in India. The hardest hit 
is the most ‘invisible’ poor – informal workers, migrant workers and marginal 
groups living in slums and other makeshift dwellings, across urban 
geographies.  As the economy is gradually returning to normalcy, in the post-
pandemic era, numerous initiatives with a climate resilience perspective are 
being undertaken at a national level including dovetailing existing 
Oak Application Form     8
development–infrastructure programs into climate change discourse. 
Unfortunately, very less of this is concerned with urban informal workers' 
livelihoods and life in the city.
Situation Analysis: Assessing the situation of workers in the Kolkata 
Metropolitan Area
The Kolkata Metropolitan Area is a metropolitan area in the Indian state of 
West Bengal, centred around the city of Kolkata (also known as Calcutta). It 
is the largest urban agglomeration in the eastern part of India and the third 
largest in the country, housing over 14.85 million people, as of the 2011 
census. The Kolkata Metropolitan Area is comprised of the city of Kolkata, its 
suburbs, several neighbouring towns (including 4 municipal corporations, 
and 27 municipalities) and adjoining rural areas. It is the economic, cultural, 
and educational hub of eastern India and hosts several major commercial 
and industrial centres, making it one of the most important economic zones 
in India.[3]
Informal workers like street vendors, domestic workers, construction 
workers and waste pickers are expected to be around 20 - 25 lakh (over 2 
million) in a similar situation as other parts of the country, without much 
social security and living in the margins of the current developmental 
discourse. The KMA also has a large informal sector that employs a 
significant number of migrant workers, particularly in construction, domestic 
work, and small-scale industries. These workers face compounded challenges 
such as low wages, long working hours, and poor working conditions. Many 
of them live in makeshift housing and lack access to basic amenities like 
clean water, sanitation, and health care. Migrant workers face social 
challenges, such as discrimination, isolation, and limited access to education 
and health services. It is estimated that around 50% of the informal workers 
(1 million) are migrants, with an equal percentage from other districts of 
Bengal and migrants from other states like Bihar, Odisha, Jharkhand, and 
Assam. An equal or similar share of outmigration is reported as well.[4]
The Kolkata Metropolitan Area is also located precariously. Like many other 
coastal cities in the world, is facing a range of impacts from climate change 
and is listed in the top eight megacities to be first impacted by climate 
change. The city is in the deltaic region of eastern India, which makes it 
vulnerable to sea level rise and increased frequency and intensity of extreme 
weather events such as tropical cyclones, heavy rainfall, and heat waves.[5] 
The changing climate is leading to an increased risk of coastal flooding and 
erosion, as well as water scarcity, particularly during the dry season. The 
city's infrastructure and public services, including transportation, energy, 
and water systems, are also vulnerable to the impacts of climate change, 
which can strain these systems and result in economic losses. In addition to 
the physical impacts, the changing climate also has social and economic 
impacts on the people of the Kolkata Metropolitan Area. The most impacted 
areas overlapping directly with the informal worker settlements in the region 
are vulnerable to displacement, loss of livelihoods, and increased poverty 
because of climate change.
To address these challenges, the government in the Kolkata Metropolitan 
Area, led by the Kolkata Municipal Corporation are taking steps to increase 
the region's resilience to climate change. This includes implementing flood 
control measures, improving disaster preparedness and response, investing 
in climate-resilient infrastructure, and preparing climate action plans for 
Oak Application Form     9
their cities.[6][7] The major concern in the slew of positively directed actions 
is that informal workers, their live-work settlements and their livelihoods as 
of now are not a major focus area of the climate resilience actions pushed by 
the state and authorities. Thereby ignoring the most vulnerable, impacted 
informal workers from the climate resilience action plans for the region. Also 
straight-jacketed approaches of focusing on the urban ‘infrastructure’ 
building, without focusing on capacities and linkages ignoring migration 
from climate-impacted rural regions is another gap amongst many in the 
climate resilience actions. This approach requires a ‘change’: in perspective 
and in action.  That is what PARIVARTAN intervention sets to achieve – 
CHANGE that is for and led by the empowerment of the most vulnerable 
informal worker communities.
The situation analysis and approach have been developed in discussion with 
experts on climate actions and informal workers, existing secondary sources, 
IGSSS urban teams' experience and previous consultations organized by 
IGSSS. The project aims to keep inclusion, equity and diversity of informal 
workers along with gender concerns at the core of project interventions.

building. This differential level intervention has worked well in the 
previous IGSSS actions and suits well for an informal worker climate 
resilience project, and we hope to improve the same in the coming 
interventions.
4.Gradual/strategic development of project actions led by worker 
collectives starting from micro to macro:  Since the focus of the 
project is community mobilization leading to resilience building, the 
focus initially (year 1) will be on building capacities of the collectives, 
starting with initial low hanging fruits like entitlements and identity 
documents, then going on to engage on meso level issues of developing 
the worker settlements, then with support from CSO network groups 
could influence and reach out to government and private players’ 
accountability. As we move towards year 2 and year 3, the focus will 
shift from collectivization to collective action on objective2 (community 
level) and 3 (city/state federations). Objective 1 actions will be led by 
worker leaders themselves in the long run and are imagined to be 
sustainable in a span of two project cycles.
5.People (worker) led development in the micro, meso, and IGSSS-
led action in the macro level: The worker and community collectives 
in the local are expected to take complete ownership of the actions at 
the local and community level. Training and mobilization of worker 
collectives will be the prerogative of IGSSS local staff. The state staff 
will focus on networking// federation at the city/ state level for 
collaborative actions. The IGSSS Thematic will steer networking at a 
national level and contribute to the policy discourse on climate change, 
informal workers and urbanization in India and Global South from a 
resilience lens.
6.Developing people’s institutions and organizations: The proposed 
program envisages that community collectives/ people’s organizations 
do not just remain as community-based initiatives in the project period 
but sustain and continue to work as bulwarks of local democracy and 
urban resilience for worker communities. This will be attempted 
through a host of capacity building and handholding of the worker 
collectives. Alongside this, the key strategy will be to work at their 
personal level on life skills, building resilience and developing a 
mechanism for reporting violations and abuses to key points for 
address and preservation of dignity in their lives, also by supporting

the community collectives to adopt sustainable and resilience building 
initiatives in their local and community level.
7.Building networks and sustaining established ones – The terrain 
from the national level policy engagement has shifted to the state and 
ULB levels. It is in this context that the premise of community 
federations into a larger critical mass is foundational to having larger-
level policy engagement. Community collectives, extremely successful 
locals, need spaces and opportunities to collaborate and learn from 
each other to raise bigger demands for more inclusive city spaces and 
participatory decision-making. This underlying theme forms the other 
fundamental assumption in the project design. Consequently, such 
spaces for forming city-level and state-level federations are provided 
for in the project intervention that will go a long way in engaging with 
the state and mainstreaming the informal workers and climate justice 
discourse in policy circles. It is also expected that these networks that 
develop will be composed of middle-class groups, and private agencies/ 
bodies as well, with a common consensus developed with the informal 
workers to demand climate resilience and sustainable cities for all.
8.Policy engagement, as well as collaboration with the different 
levels of the government – Engagement and working with the state, 
is put forth as the only way to better the development of communities 
and cities. Especially for informal workers in the context of climate 
resilience building. The reason why the different levels of state and 
bureaucracy fail to function as expected is because of the lack of 
engagement, access and proximity to the urban poor issues, it is this 
gap that the project wishes to address between the communities and 
the state, through multifarious engagements from the local community 
development plans to the state - national policy level discussions. The 
state, especially the ULBs are looking for collaborative opportunities 
with organizations for climate action and that space needs to be

9.Thematic Hub of Urban Poverty Reduction contributes to 
national-level policy discourse: The last phase has initiated the 
development of the Urban Poverty Thematic Hub in IGSSS, it is in now

urbanization, wrt to informal workers and their inclusion in urban

Monitoring plan of IGSSS
All projects implemented by IGSSS begin with the bassline and sets the targets 
to be achieved. Both the project implementation and financial accounting are 
investigated at the time of the monitoring visit by the teams. PME unit and 
Programme Management teams also visit the field and provide support to 
ensure that implementation/operations are on track. Half-yearly review 
meeting with teams is also conducted regionally for result tracking and cross-
learning.
Management Information System (MIS)
The project level MIS begins with - 1. Analysis and benchmarking of a baseline 
study of any project before its inception at the project level. Thereafter 2. 
refinement of the project indicators based on RBM and IGSSS strategic plans 
may be carried out. In discussions with funding partners and organizations. 3. 
Setting up performance tracking tables at the project level with targets and 
baseline figures to be finalized. 4. Setting project-level tools for recording 
results. We use e-tools like the Kobo collects app to collect and record data at 
the field level. Then, 5. periodic data collection and compilation are executed. 
Usually, this is in sync with the reporting cycles and data is assessed every 
quarter. Afterwhich 6. Analysis of data generated and reporting is shared with 
funding partners and within IGSSS as well.  At the organizational level, where 
project level MIS feeds into. The monitoring and evaluation unit of IGSSS helps 
the project level actions with 1. setting up of indicators based on IGSSS 
strategic plan and objectives. 2. pooling out the information from individual 
projects. 3. periodic data collection and compilation and 4. aid the respective 
thematic team with reporting as well. 
Internal Reporting:
Within IGSSS, reporting is on a project-to-project basis. IGSSS state units 
submit their progress reports to the thematic leads. The state coordinators 
verify the reports and forward them to the thematic with their 
recommendations and observations. This is vetted and supported by the Urban 
Poverty Reduction Team. Regular program-related and financial feedback is 
provided by the grants team, based in Delhi. Technical inputs are also provided 
on MIS by the M&E working under the grants team. Thematic and financial 
management support is actively provided to each state to smoothen 
coordination processes. The yearly audit is carried out on the completion of 
the Grant period. 
The state teams prepare timely reports, based on the work done in 
communities, taking stock of the activities that have been undertaken during 
that time. The quarterly activity updates and six-monthly reports are submitted 
to the respective thematic offices of IGSSS. The thematic offices submit a six-
Oak Application Form     23
monthly report to the Programme Management & Grants team based at IGSSS 
Delhi. The team reviews the report and verifies the information from other 
sources and reporting tools. Appropriate feedback is provided to the state 
offices, where course correction or supportive inputs are required. The urban 
thematic unit drafts the report, which is then finalized and shared with funding 
partners.

(300 words):
Risks, Outlook, Prospects and Sustainability of Actions
There is an increasing amount of distrust of the authorities towards NGOs and 
the changed legal rules that discourage networking is one such perfect 
example. Going forward in the coming years it will be increasingly tough to 
work on policy engagement and recommendations, it is better to adopt a more 
– model-based approach. There are also similar locational issues that are 
bound to impact the interventions. The project proposal rests on the premise 
that climate-resilient model building and scaling with collaborations with state 
and non-state actors is the best way forward. And will address the mistrust 
with some of the authorities. The pandemic has resulted in the state and 
administration retracting a lot – with respect to the budgets and attention to 
the urban poor and worker needs. It is expected that the welfare state and 
policy provisions are bound to shrink in the coming years. Thereby recognizing 
that policy-level engagements become further complicated. The silver lining 
though is that the concept of climate resilience for informal workers may be 
the most suited to this urban poverty team and its interventions for informal 
workers at this stage of the intervention. As the issue is of prime importance 
to the state and authorities and will be more receptive to ideas and suggestions 
for improving the same.
Operational challenges: technical financial and partner-related risks.
•The change in the laws related to Foreign Contribution 
Regulation in India: The NGOs cannot use 20% of funds in 
administrative expenses, thereby putting further restrictions in the 
manner where collaborative and joint interventions will now be 
restricted or must be strategically reduced to adhere to the guidelines. 
These factors have been accounted for in the project design.
•The program design is based on network building and its 
challenges:  Due to the changed law, the project intervention has been 
Oak Application Form     24
now conceived wholly to be directly implemented by IGSSS. The 
erstwhile partners and networks of IGSSS in the form of CSOs, CBOs 
and networks will remain as joint actors for engagement and campaigns, 
and specific support will be extended to local CSOs who will be engaged 
with and if needed capacitated to address the issues of climate 
resilience. Thereby imagining partnerships from the earlier formal 
project-based collaborations to more organic issue-based non-financial 
collaborations to allow for the transfer of knowledge and domain 
knowledge of emerging challenges of urban through networking at 
levels and scales.  
•Stressing innovative approaches and income generation for 
COVID realities: post – COVID economic slowdown and lack of 
livelihoods are going to be a reality for the next five years. To kick-start 
the interventions and to ensure the project aims for sustainable 
practices innovative models have been dovetailed into the proposals. 
Like – Worker resource centres, will ensure more accessible locations 
for communities to get access to and resolve their livelihoods concerns. 
These centres will be run by trained community volunteers. To 
propagate climate resilience for informal workers practice models will 
be identified, documented, and scaled with support, and shared for 
wider implementation across CSO networks. Also, the COVID-19 
pandemic has brought a livelihood crisis that will be only ameliorated 
with income generation and community institution/ membership models 
that this intervention aims to support and nurture for the long term. 
The following actions/ strategies are thought to ensure the viability of 
the project: 
•People-led actions and change: The principle of a rights-based 
approach is at the core of all programming under the proposed initiative, 
where the focus is on capacitating the workers belonging to the 
marginalised sections of the urban to access their rights to identity, 
entitlements, and habitats and livelihoods. The focus on creating a 
capacitated community leadership and cadre to lead the interventions 
will also go a long way to ensure that the community efforts remain 
sustainable. Institution/ capacity building of worker collectives and 
structures to ensure that the community owns and invests in all 
development actions planned and implemented in their contexts. This 
would include worker collectives, CBOs, Self Help Groups, and City level 
federations that are formalized and transformed to people’s 
organizations and institutions. The networks and alliances created at the 
local, state, and national levels with diverse stakeholders and actors will 
lead to capacitated CSOs working on informal workers and climate 
resilience. Thereby far outliving the project duration. This will also 
popularize the informal workers and their climate resilience discourse 
amongst the many networks and in the development sector in India.   
•Convergence and collaborations with state and non-state actors: 
Convergence and collaboration with resources and entitlements from 
the government have been a central strategy underpinning the work 
with communities. This will be promoted in this project as well – through 
linkages with the already listed policy engagements, implementation of 
existing laws and acts, as well as with the line departments and ULBs of 
the urban areas. Expenses will be made on the least cost basis without 
Oak Application Form     25
compromising quality. Low-cost meetings, workshops, exposures, 
conventions, etc. will be arranged so that these can be continued even 
after the project period with minimal external financial support. 
•Low-cost and climate-conscious project actions: Exploring new 
ways of working together with minimal resources – for example, 
collaborations with alliances and networks, sharing of knowledge/know-
how with like-minded institutions, and building up a strong case for 
evidential engagement through joint research and action. The activated 
communities and networks will be hoped to continue the development 
work that they learned during the project time. Any support offered in 
the name of model building and initial grounding of climate resilience 
models and income generational activities will be left with the 
community itself. At an organizational level, it is further decided that all 
meetings and gatherings hosted by IGSSS will avoid the use of plastic. 
And travels between cities will be promoted through rail only. Only in 
case of large distances will air/flight will be considered.
•Phasing of project interventions: IGSSS has imagined and designed 
this phase of work with informal workers and climate resilience for the 
2023-26 phase. IGSSS's understanding of informal workers, and 
sustainable cities have further improved in the last five years, and we 
hope to continue with our sustainable – resilient cities framework that 
the urban team has devised for interventions. The proposed phase will 
have its evaluations carried out and the strategy for further actions and 
interventions will be decided in consultation with stakeholders and 
actors. It is expected that the program will be continued in at least one 
more phase of interventions in the same area with the constituent 
groups

Global Greengrants Fund’s mission is to mobilise resources for 
communities to protect our shared planet and work toward a more 
equitable world. Our work is rooted in a theory of change built around the 
power of social movements to leverage systemic changes. It posits that 
movements based in the grassroots are necessary for social and 
environmental change because: 1) they represent local agendas and are 
comprised of the people with the greatest knowledge, experience, and 
stake in protecting their environment; 2) they have greater moral 
authority to question and change systems that adversely affect them; and 
3) they serve as the roots from which larger movements for social change 
gain the motivation and inspiration to grow.
Global Greengrants Fund was established in 1992, and over nearly three 
decades has built a decentralised and participatory decision-making 
model, in which a network of 200 volunteer activist advisors sets our 
strategies and makes grant recommendations, in addition to 
accompanying grassroots partners in their work through mentoring and 
other non-financial support. These advisors, organised in 25 advisory 
boards, sister funds and strategic partner organisations, are responsible 
for identifying grassroots actors who are working to change the systemic 
causes of climate change, environmental destruction and social and 
economic injustice; and to strengthen these actors through flexible, 
responsive and strategic funding and accompaniment. This advisory 
network collectively represents our most powerful asset.
Since 1992, Global Greengrants Fund has supported over 15,000 
grassroots initiatives around the world, almost 1,000 of them since 2013 
through Global Greengrants Fund UK, the younger, independent sister 
charity and applicant. Globally, between the US and UK sister 
organisations, we now support 1,000 grassroots groups per year with 
small grants funding, advisor accompaniment and networking 
opportunities.

Global Greengrants Fund UK is an independent charity registered with the

The applicant, Global Greengrants Fund UK, currently has 5 FTE staff (this

 5b. Summarise the organisation’s history.  In addition, highlight 2-3 key

Global Greengrants Fund was established in 1993 to channel direct funding 
and support to grassroots civil society actors working for environmental and 
social justice across the world. We do this through a decentralised, 
participatory grant-making model in which our network of over 200 expert 
local advisors identify grassroots movements; channel small, flexible grants 
funding to them; and provide ongoing mentorship and accompaniment to 
them as they deliver their self-determined initiatives. In 2013, Global 
Greengrants Fund UK was registered as an independent charity in England 
& Wales, with the first staff member joining the organisation in 2016.
The global organisation has grown significantly in recent years, and 
currently funds over 1,000 initiatives per year (including 217 through the UK 
entity in 2020-21). The UK organisation has grown its revenue and staffing 
resources substantially, and is on track to exceed $5m income for the 
current fiscal year.
Global Greengrants Fund’s India Advisory Board was established in 2001 to 
support grassroots environmental protection and rights-based development 
work through small grants and advisor mentorship. The Board’s work covers 
a diverse set of issues, from forest rights to water and sanitation, but with a 
cross-cutting focus on the most marginalised groups, including Adivasi and 
Dalit communities; women; transgender people; and rural and remote 
populations. The Oak Foundation has been the Board’s longest-term and 
largest donor since its inception, supporting the Board since 2012. This 
support from the Foundation has been critical to the Board’s evolving 
strategy: as one of the Board’s only funders providing multi-year support, the 
Oak Foundation has enabled the Board to develop relationships, networks 
and more in-depth understanding of the specific challenges facing the group 
it supports.
While the growth of our support to grassroots movements is a major 
achievement of the past two years, the achievement we are most proud of is 
our advisory networks’ ability to continue strengthening grassroots 
movements within the extraordinarily challenging context of Covid-19; in 
India, with the support of the Oak Foundation, the Advisory Board was able 
to rapidly mobilise emergency grants to 11 local initiatives on the frontline of 
Covid response during the country’s deadly second wave, and continues to 
provide additional support to all its grantees affected by the pandemic as 
required.
Oak Application Form     7
5c. What is the problem you want to address and what is your approach? 
How will you use Oak's funding? How did you identify the problem and 
decide your approach? If you have undertaken a theory of change exercise, or if 
you are influenced by research, policy or your own organisation’s experience, please
