Context
Over twenty years on since the inception of the Global Greengrants Fund 
India Advisory Board, marginalised communities in India continue to face a 
complex, interconnected range of social, environmental, health and rights 
challenges, all of which have been exacerbated significantly by the 
immediate and longer-term impacts of the Covid-19 pandemic and of the 
climate crisis.
Rural women and marginalised communities, including Adivasis, Dalits and 
migrant workers, have been disproportionately affected by the immediate 
health risk from the virus and by the effects of lockdown measures, including 
loss of income, food insecurity and exposure to violence; an estimated 75 
million people in India were pushed into poverty during the first wave of the 
pandemic alone. The effects of the pandemic have been especially 
pronounced for the Adivasi communities supported by our Advisory Board; 
many of the casual labourers who returned to remote rural communities at 
the beginning of the pandemic have remained there, putting additional 
pressure on already highly stretched local resources. Logging, mining and 
other activities harmful to the environment – both officially sanctioned and 
illegal – have increased, representing a major challenge to communities 
reliant on natural resources for their livelihoods, food, shelter and medicine, 
despite the protections set out in the Forest Rights Act.
Simultaneously, climate-linked disasters such as Cyclone Tauktae in 2021, 
flooding and landslides across multiple states particularly including the 
north-east, and the major heatwave of spring 2022, are destroying the 
livelihoods of thousands of farming and fishing communities already facing 
extreme poverty and food insecurity as a result of the pandemic. As well as 
the immediate threat to lives and property from disasters of this kind, 
climate change is driving increased water scarcity, crop failure, soil erosion 
and the loss of biodiversity including fishing stocks.
Both before the pandemic and during it, local organisations and movements 
across India have been the frontline responders to the intersecting health, 
social and environmental crises they face: identifying local challenges, 
designing solutions and mobilizing communities to carry them out. Through 
its grant-making and accompaniment work with emerging civil society 
actors, the India Advisory Board aims to strengthen these locally-led 
initiatives, enabling them to become more effective in achieving their self-
determined goals while also promoting a rights-based, inclusive approach to 
social and environmental justice work that is rooted in local agency, 
autonomy and dignity.
This grant-making and accompaniment work is also how we have identified 
the specific challenges affecting marginalised groups in India: with the 
support of the Oak Foundation, our advisors have developed an analysis 
which is rooted in the perspectives and experiences of our grantee partners. 
Oak Application Form     8
The proposed work is informed by this analysis and by Global Greengrants’ 
overarching theory of change, which posits that movements based in the 
grassroots are necessary for social and environmental change because they 
represent local agendas and are comprised of the people with the greatest 
knowledge, experience, and stake in protecting their environment; because 
they have greater moral authority to question and change systems that 
adversely affect them; and because they serve as the roots from which larger 
movements for social change gain the motivation and inspiration to grow.
Our partnership with Oak Foundation and recent highlights
As mentioned above, the Oak Foundation has been supporting Global 
Greengrants Fund’s India Advisory Board since 2012, with over 200 
grassroots initiatives funded and accompanied by our advisors in total 
through this partnership.
In the most recent phase of our partnership – the 2018-22 grant to which this 
proposed work links directly – we set out the following objectives:
1) To support a total of 40-50 grassroots civil society initiatives in Jharkhand 
and West Bengal with small grants to enable action on environmental justice 
and climate change, aiming to strengthen their ability to effectively advocate 
for their rights and implement viable solutions to local challenges; and in the 
medium to long term, to strengthen their organisational capacity.
2) To foster stronger networks among local civil society organizations in 
Jharkhand and West Bengal, as well as across India, through a series of 
grantee workshops and through grant-making to network organisations, with 
the aim of grantees having increased resources including knowledge, skills 
and financial support to carry out their work.
3) To promote women’s rights, safety, well-being, and economic security 
through small grants to women-led and women-focused environmental 
justice activities (30% of all grant-making), as well as through advisors 
working with grantees to support the incorporation of a gender lens in their 
work, with the aim of securing an increased leadership role for women in 
environmental justice initiatives. Examples of the types of activity supported 
through this objective include women-led initiatives addressing forest rights 
and agriculture.
During this most recent phase, 55 grassroots initiatives were supported with 
small grants to implement solutions for environmental justice and in 
response to climate change. The majority of projects focused on raising 
awareness of the importance of natural resource conservation, especially for 
women and youth, and orienting the communities towards organic and 
sustainable agriculture to improve livelihood opportunities, food security, 
and health. Projects also focused on strengthening grassroots institutions 
and local governance, supporting minority groups in obtaining and 
implementing Community Forest Rights in the context of FRA2006, 
empowering Gram Sabha, and providing equal access to water and 
sanitation.
Key learnings from this most recent phase of work include:
•Thirty-one percent of grantees who have reported have been able to 
access additional funding as a result of the grant provided through the 
Oak Foundation support. This includes funding from international 
foundations such as Keystone Foundation, Foundation for Ecological 
Oak Application Form     9
Security, 350.org, Action Aid and AJWS, but also national government 
administration (e.g. Forest Department of Jhrakhand, NABARD 
(National Agriculture Bank And Rural Development), Krishi Vigyan 
Kendra (Agriculture Research Centre), and other national NGOs and 
international NGOs including MOCICC (Movimiento Ciudadano frente 
a Cambio Climático, a Peruvian NGO). In addition, forty-two percent of 
grantees have told us that thanks to GGF’s support, they have been 
able to benefit from new networking opportunities, increased 
recognition and trust from the wider community, and general support. 
In some cases, it was observed that the visibility gained is a gateway to 
additional funding opportunities.
•Overall, groups observed a general inclination toward learning from - 
and helping - each other; forums and district-level meetings were 
organised to exchange lessons learned, experiences, and best practice. 
Some organisations have started to hold interactions with district-level 
NGOs, have been given opportunities to take part in stronger networks 
with other grassroots groups, and have been invited to join 
international conferences.
•Several of the grants made also went to network organisations; for 
example, one network organisation based in Karnakata is organising a 
series of twelve national and regional level meetings to develop and 
present an action plan regarding forest rights to policymakers. Access 
to these types of networks is critical for many of the grassroots 
organisations we support, who are often unable to access other 
sources of information and advice, and are able to share resources and 
strategies as a result.
•57% of grants made have been to women-led organisations or to 
initiatives focused on women’s rights, wellbeing, and economic 
security. Women are more prominently represented in the leadership 
of their organisation and have been able to develop their leadership 
skills through the seminars or workshops offered by the projects. In 
some projects, women's participation grew so much that they now 
represent one-third of the forest rights committee at the Gram Sabha 
level, where they often assume prestigious roles (secretariat, 
presidency, vice-presidency). In some cases, women are taking a 
crucial role in decision-making and lead the negotiations with local 
authorities.
•Eighty percent of the grantees who have reported have said that 
thanks to the Oak Foundation’s support they have been able to improve 
environmental conditions at the local level. Organisations could 
measure an overall increase in the awareness and responsibility of 
local communities towards improving environmental conditions and 
safeguarding natural resources, for example, through the set-up of 
Forest Rights Committees, Village Forest Management Committees, or 
through campaigning. Benefits reported by the grantees include: 
increased wildlife protection; restoration of water channels; farmers 
shifting to organic agriculture/ agroecology and no longer using 
chemical fertilisers and pesticides; regeneration of wastelands, and the 
return of birds, animals, and plant species.
Themes in our grant-making to date, and emerging priorities
Oak Application Form     10
While the Board’s strategy focuses on the most marginalised groups, a 
number of cross-cutting themes have emerged across its work with these 
groups across the different geographies within India where it works. The 
proposed work aims to leverage the Board’s existing networks and expertise, 
and with the support of the Foundation to also develop new approaches, 
resources and capacity which can make it more effective in addressing these 
specific themes and challenges. These themes include:
•Food systems and sustainable agriculture. Food security has 
become an even more urgent challenge for poor rural communities in 
the context of both Covid and rising temperatures driven by the 
climate crisis, with the continuing dominance of industrial agriculture 
threatening the economic independence of family farmers as well as 
impacting local biodiversity and soil conservation and acting as a major 
contributor to carbon emissions. Three of our advisors are specialists 
in this area, with one living as part of a collective farm run by Adivasi 
community members. For the proposed work, we anticipate that this 
theme will continue to be an important one across all of the 
geographies in India where the Board operates.
•Access to forest rights, especially for Adivasi communities. The 
Board has supported multiple Indigenous groups across India to 
exercise their right to protect, make decisions, and make a living from 
their traditional forests in the face of extractive interests. Several 
groups have been supported for a number of years in this work, such 
as one organisation in Jharkhand (funded by Oak since 2016) working 
to secure forest rights, survey forest produce and trees, and promote 
women’s involvement in the Gram Sabha. Two of our advisors have 
strong links to Adivasi community movements and this theme will 
continue to be prominent in the proposed work.  
•Addressing the impacts of climate change and industrial 
pollution on small-scale fishing communities. Fishing 
communities, like farmers, have been deeply impacted by climate 
change in India as cyclones hit coastal areas with increasing intensity 
and frequency and sea level rise changes coastal ecosystems. One 
group supported by Oak Foundation via Greengrants in West Bengal 
has been working to restore and protect mangroves in three villages 
affected by Cyclone Yaas, for example; others are especially focused on 
building the leadership, organisation, and economic independence of 
women in fishing communities.
•Waste and sanitation issues, especially in relation to Dalit 
women and youth and to transgender people. Waste picking and 
manual scavenging (cleaning human waste) generally falls on the most 
marginalised people in India, especially Dalit women and youth who 
are frequently unpaid and often suffer severe health impacts and 
abuse; this work is an increasingly prominent theme in the Board’s 
grant-making, and recent grants have supported the organising, 
education on rights and health, and registration of manual scavengers 
in informal settlements of Bangalore; another grant has funded work 
with transgender waste pickers in Kolkata to improve health conditions 
and connect them to broader environmental justice movements.
Oak Application Form     11
In the context of the pandemic, the Board has adapted its approach to ensure 
maximum flexibility and support to groups on the Covid frontlines, including 
with the support of the Oak Foundation. Our grantee partners have shown 
enormous resourcefulness and resilience throughout this crisis, whether by 
adapting existing activities to ensure the safety of community members, or 
by developing new lines of work such as Covid prevention and awareness 
activities, providing PPE or addressing the food security implications of the 
pandemic.
The next phase of our partnership with the Oak Foundation
As India begins to move into the post-pandemic recovery phase, the Board is 
looking ahead to the next phase of its existence and aims to continue scaling 
up its support to marginalised communities across India, building on the 
Board’s experience to date and also on the findings of the evaluation 
conducted on the previous phase of our partnership (attached 
separately).  The strategy for this proposed next phase of our partnership 
includes, firstly, exploring opportunities to support groups which the Board 
has had less engagement with to date – whether in new geographies, or 
those affected by additional dimensions of disadvantage such as trans or 
intersex identities. With one of the newest Board members from a Dalit 
background, the Board also aims to deepen its engagement with Dalit and 
other marginalised communities in the next few years, including by ensuring 
its own composition reflects that of its grantee partners in terms of gender, 
age, caste status, religion and geographical background. This need for 
enhanced focus on Dalit and other marginalised groups is one of the key 
recommendations of the evaluation of the previous phase of our partnership 
(see 4.1.3, paragraph 101 and 4.3 in the evaluation).
Secondly, the Board aims to strengthen its support to existing partners, 
recognising there is scope in its work to support emerging civil society to 
become more established organisations with enhanced capacity to address 
social and rights challenges and to be more resilient and sustainable in their 
work. In particular, this includes two changes to the Board’s grant-making 
approach: increasing the size of the average grant made from $7,000 
to $10,000; and moving towards providing multi-year funding 
commitments to trusted partner organisations. This longer-term 
approach to funding will also strengthen our grantees’ accompaniment work, 
enabling advisors to develop their relationships with grantee partners and to 
support them in becoming more sustainable and effective organisations over 
time; it follows the recommendation of the evaluation that the Board 
consider extending the size and duration of grants made (paragraph 4.1.1). 
These changes will also be complemented and strengthened by the Board’s 
participation in Global Greengrants Fund’s emerging global learning 
strategy, which aims to connect the different parts of our global grant-
making network more effectively to foster improved learning and 
communication; in part this also responds to the recommendation in the 
evaluation that the access of our grantees to expert advice be supported 
(4.2.1).
Finally, whilst individual Advisory Board members usually identify and 
support grantee partners in a specific state or cluster of states, an important 
aspect of the Board’s strategy for fostering a stronger civil society network 
in India is to develop and share expertise on these cross-cutting themes 
across different geographies within India. This is reflected in the grant-
Oak Application Form     12
making budget lines of the proposed work, which include a split of 60% 
grant-making for local initiatives in West Bengal, and the remainder for work 
in other states. We recognise that the Foundation’s strategy for India is 
strongly focused on West Bengal, which is a critical state for our advisors’ 
work; by requesting some support to be earmarked to other states, our 
objective is to ensure that grantees participating in grantee workshops and 
other engagement activities have the maximum opportunities to benefit from 
the work of allied and aligned civil society organisations across all of India. 
For example, as mentioned above, in the current phase of our partnership 
several network organisations based outside of West Bengal have been 
supported, enabling grantees within West Bengal and outside the state to 
benefit from resources, strategies and information through this peer support; 
examples of these organisations include DISHA (the National Fish-workers' 
Forum); the Save Our Rice Campaign (through PPUS); the Asia Pacific 
Transgender Network; and the North Bengal Forum of Forest People and 
Forest Workers (through Bajkul). Our objective is to continue 
strengthening this wider ecosystem of grassroots peer support with 
the Foundation’s support. This approach also follows a key 
recommendation from the evaluation conducted on the previous phase of our 
partnership, that supporting strategic networking will be key for improving 
environmental conditions (see 4.1.2 and 4.2.2 in the evaluation attached 
separately).
Funding context
The proposed renewal funding from Oak Foundation would represent a 
major contribution to the India Advisory Board’s evolving approach to 
supporting grassroots civil society in India over the next three to four years. 
The Advisory Board has continued to be successful in growing its 
engagement with other funders, including new multi-year commitments from 
several foundation sources in the UK, Europe and North America; through 
Global Greengrants Fund UK this includes renewed contributions from 
Stichting SED Fund and the Human Capability Foundation, as well as 
portions of larger grant commitments secured in the past six months from 
three large foundation donors. Cumulatively, the India Advisory Board’s

9. MONITORING, EVALUATION & LEARNING 
This section is twofold. Please tell us:
a) Monitoring and evaluation. How will you know if you are achieving your objectives? Please 
describe briefly how you will know if you are making progress and if what you are doing is working. 
If you have a formal monitoring and evaluation system and if you plan to collect indicator data or 
conduct an external evaluation, please provide details here.
b) Learning. Please tell us if there anything in particular that you are hoping to learn more about or 
test through this grant.
(300 words):
The proposed work’s approach to M&E is guided by an organisational 
learning and evaluation framework designed on the basis of our theory of 
change and our understanding of how environmental justice movements 
create and leverage social change. This incorporates tools including reports 
from grantees and advisors; grant-tracking systems; grantee surveys; 
learning exchanges; participatory action research; grant strategy reviews; 
network mapping; and in-depth regional case studies, to gather information 
about the impacts of our funding on individual grantee organisations, 
Oak Application Form     21
broader movements, and environmental and social conditions, and evidence 
of change. In-depth and longitudinal studies help us to map what long-term 
accompaniment and strengthening of a movement looks like.
Each community group in receipt of a small grant and advisor support is 
asked to report on the progress of the project one year after receipt of the 
funding. The reporting form asks for assessments and learning related to 
eight indicators which align with Global Greengrants Fund’s evaluation 
framework and help us assess impact:
1. Any evidence of improved environmental conditions since receiving 
funding
2. Strengthened organisational capacity
3. Increased community awareness or involvement
4. Increased involvement of women, youth, and indigenous leaders in the 
work of the initiative
5. Impacts on policy or policy implementation
6. Increased media interest in the grantees’ work, if this is something that 
the grantee seeks
7. Increased access to spaces for decision-making and advocacy and 
networks
8. Increased access to additional funding from sources other than 
Greengrants, or other forms of support (for example, expertise).
In addition, the report asks for a description of what the partner assesses to 
be the most significant change, any changes in the external environment, and 
any lessons learned from the work. The reporting process invites our 
community partners to reflect on their work and draw lessons. Reports also 
help advisors to analyse trends, inform the strategy-setting, and collate 
stories of success and learning; this data is collected by the Advisory Board’s 
Administrator with the support of the Coordinator, and analysis is conducted 
jointly by the entire Advisory Board.
The framework set out above is designed to be as flexible and appropriate as 
possible for Greengrants’ portfolio of grassroots, emerging civil society 
groups who are highly likely to lack capacity to conduct monitoring and 
evaluation activities, and whose aims and approaches vary significantly 
depending on the local context. Recognising this, Greengrants does not 
currently provide a more detailed framework for grantee partners to define, 
for example, parameters for improved environmental conditions; the 
framework seeks instead to place grantee partners’ own perceptions, rather 
than externally imposed definitions, at the core of Greengrants’ evaluation 
and learning work.
Findings will be reviewed by Global Greengrants Fund staff and discussed 
with advisors on a regular basis, including during virtual and (where 
possible) in person meetings, focusing on the impacts of individual and 
aggregated grants, the challenges our partners face, and wider trends.
All advisory boards receive disaggregated data relevant to their 
grantmaking, to help influence their future strategy-setting and decision-
making, and improve the quality of support Global Greengrants Fund 
provides. For the proposed work, we additionally plan to commission an 
Oak Application Form     22
evaluation in the final 5 months of the grant which will assess progress 
against the objectives outlined above, particularly including the degree to 
which the board has been able to incorporate an intersectional approach to 
its work, and any learnings from this which can be used to strengthen the 
board’s future grantmaking and accompaniment work. We will welcome the 
input and feedback of the Oak Foundation in developing the terms of 
reference for this evaluation to ensure that it meets the Foundation’s 
expectations, particularly in terms of including grantee partners’ 
perspectives.
The proposed work also links to Global Greengrants’ evolving learning 
strategy. This emerging piece of work, which will also intersect with the 
organisation’s ongoing Strategic Journey, aspires to decentralise learning 
across the Greengrants network and facilitate shared learning between 
advisors and grantees across disparate geographies and themes. This will 
also include evaluating the existing monitoring and evaluation framework to 
identify opportunities for strengthening our approach and developing 
additional insight that can strengthen our advisors’ and grantees’ work; this 
could potentially include working with our grantees to strengthen their 
monitoring and evaluation capacity.
GAF_A_Global_Greengrants_Fund_UK_SuppoGr.10. RISKS AND CHALLENGES:
10.  RISKS AND CHALLENGES
What are the risks or barriers that might prevent you from achieving your 
outcomes and how will you address these?  What are your opportunities?
We understand that achieving long-lasting and meaningful change is hard and we 
expect that the work you want to do will mean taking risks.  We encourage you to be 
open to telling us these, as well as how you will address these risks.  If some of your 
outcomes are risky, are there any incremental achievements that you could identify? 
(300 words):
External high-impact risks identified for the proposed work include the 
ongoing effects of the Covid-19 pandemic on communities with which we 
work, and on the ability of our advisors to continue their grantmaking and 
mentoring support. The pandemic has had an enormous impact on our 
grantees in India: lockdowns and travel restrictions represent a major 
barrier to frontline community actors’ ability to campaign, coordinate and 
build successful coalitions. To mitigate against these challenges, Global 
Greengrants has carried out several scenario planning exercises throughout 
2020-21 to help us navigate the impacts of the pandemic on our partners, 
and through our advisors we continue to apply maximum flexibility in our 
support to the activists and communities we work with.
Another external risk to highlight is the increasing frequency and severity of 
threats to environmental defenders across the world. Global Greengrants is 
managing this risk by providing rapid, flexible and discreet emergency 
funding to environmental defenders at risk identified by our advisory boards 
in Africa. We also house the Environmental Defenders Collaborative (EDC), a 
pooled fund of 14 funders, which supports environmental activists by 
Oak Application Form     23
increasing access to funding and strategic resources. We further work with 
other actors in the environmental space to increase understanding and 
implementation of prevention and protection strategies, including in 
partnership with the Funders Initiative for Civil Society. Within India, we will 
continue to ensure that all the work supported complies with the 
requirements of the FCRA and all other relevant laws and regulations.
Internally, one risk with potentially major consequences is the risk of 
advisors lacking capacity to deliver their work and / or facing burnout 
through stress, especially given the highly challenging external context and 
the impact this is likely to have on advisors. To mitigate this, Greengrants is 
investing in an organisation-wide Organisational Care Initiative (OCI), 
currently being led by independent consultant Ishita Chaudhry, and which 
will be coordinated by our new Director for People & Culture (starting 
September 2022). The OCI aims to minimise the risk of staff burnout but also 
to actively promote a culture of care across the wider network, including 
among our advisors. The work of our Learning Consultant, Mateo Martinez 
Abarca, who is responsible for delivering our learning strategy and ensuring 
our advisors are connected with learnings and insights from across our 
advisor network, will also be key in mitigating this risk.
Global Greengrants Fund UK also maintains a risk register which has 
identified key governance, compliance, financial, external and operational 
risks as well as mitigation measures. The charity’s trustees regularly identify 
and review the major risks to which the organisation is exposed. Both 
manual and automated checks are regular invoked, particularly those 
relating to the operations and finance of the charity, including through a 
finance sub-committee of the Board, chaired by the Treasurer, which is 
responsible for financial governance and risk management.
In addition to managing these internal and external threats, Global 
Greengrants Fund UK has in place a safeguarding policy, and jointly with our 
network-wide Diversity, Equity and Inclusion working group has developed 
an internal code of conduct which aims to enable individuals engaged with 
Global Greengrants to uphold and safeguard the dignity, freedom and liberty 
of all people, in line with our commitment to developing and strengthening 
an enabling environment, and a culture of communication, trust and 
empathy, where the health, safety and the dignity of all persons associated 
with our organisation, directly or indirectly, is given primacy.

4g. Summarise the project’s ultimate goal(s) (maximum 200 words):
( NOT REQUIRED FOR CORE SUPPORT GRANTS)
The project’s ultimate goal is to improve the sexual and reproductive health (SRH) 
outcomes of young women and adolescent girls of Jharkhand and West Bengal by 
creating a sustainable model of community empowerment and youth responsive 
SRH services in the public health system. Ipas Development Foundation (IDF) will 
be Ipas’s lead partner in implementing the project.
 
The project addresses multiple components of a sustainable abortion ecosystem 
taking a comprehensive approach to reduce barriers and improve health and lives 
of the most vulnerable and marginalized populations. Our approach utilizes a range 
of efforts with an eye on innovations and sustainability—awareness building among 
individuals, sensitization of families and communities, health system strengthening, 
local advocacy for action and support, state-level engagement for ownership, and 
national-level initiatives for policy and legislation. All our current strategies are 
adapted within the context of the COVID-19 pandemic so that they are both 
feasible to implement and designed to meet community needs.
 
Leveraging IDF’s strong partnership with the state governments, the project will 
strengthen the availability, quality, and utilization of SRH services by young 
women and girls. The complementary health system strengthening efforts, 
including in Sundarbans, will be supported by IDF’s core funds.

6. Context (The context section should not exceed two pages.)
6a. Describe the organisation (include information on leadership, 
governance, structure and staff) and expected changes. (maximum 300 
words):
Founded in 1973, Ipas is a pioneering global health and rights organization 
focused on amplifying, defending, and advancing access to safe abortion and 
contraception. We work in 29 countries across Africa, Asia, and Latin America to 
shape the sustainable abortion ecosystem—the context around an individual 
who seeks to terminate an unwanted pregnancy. Ipas is governed by an 18-
Grant Application Form, July 1 20135
member international Board of Directors of international professionals, medical 
providers, and academics in the fields of health, SRH, and finances. The board 
includes an Executive Committee, Finance and Investment Committee, Audit and 
Risk Committee, and other committees that set policies and review and approve 
Ipas’s long-term plans and annual organizational budgets. Board officers 
are Sandeep Prasad (Chair and former Executive Director of Action Canada for 
Sexual and Reproductive Health and Rights), Monica Oguttu (Vice Chair and 
Executive Director, Kisumu Medical and Education Trust), Trish Karlin (Treasurer 
and Executive Vice-President of Elizabeth Glaser Pediatric AIDS Foundation), 
and Carlos Plazas (Secretary and Chief Operating Officer of Planned Parenthood of 
Maryland). Senior leadership provides strategic and management leadership to 
Ipas staff. Directors and Managers of Ipas’s regional and country 
programs design, implement and monitor programs, and Directors of technical and 
operational departments support technical innovation, development, and 
administrative functions.  
 
Ipas is defining and implementing a system of shared leadership that shifts more 
power and some central functions to our country teams. The Ipas Country 
Directors are leading on planning and implementing an Ipas Road Map to start 
using the shared leadership approach. An example of this shift is the lead staff for 
our Quality-of-Care work across the world, is based in Kenya. This organizational 
shift is part of Ipas’s commitment to break down harmful power structures, 
particularly the neo-colonialism present in so many INGOs and global health 
organizations headquartered in the global north. 
6b. Describe the financial situation (include information on annual 
operating costs, fundraising strategy, reserves and debts) and expected 
changes. (maximum 300 words):
Ipas’s FY22 organizational budget anticipates annual operating costs of USD 
42,240,000. We have confirmed support from European governments (including 
from Finland, the Netherlands, Sweden, and the United Kingdom), the Canadian 
government, and many private US foundations. The structure of funding varies by 
grant award or contract, with many multi-year grants, some one-year grants, and 
contracts with partners to perform scopes of work or collaborate on projects. 
Ipas’s foundation and government grants are a combination of core and restricted 
funding, with approximately 30% for core funding. In addition, Ipas has an 
individual and major gifts program that exceeded its annual goals since 2020. We 
have estimate reserves totalling USD 49,031,000 and no debt.
 
The largest change in Ipas’s financial situation is due to changes in strategy of our 
large anonymous donor (LAD) that began in 2020 that negatively impacted Ipas’s 
budget as well as those of other INGOs dedicated to sexual and reproductive 
health and right (SRHR)—support from LAD changed from $29.9 million in FY20 to 
$13.2 million in FY21 and has resulted in an organization restructure of our US 
office, including a staff reduction (41 positions). Leadership worked to streamline 
operations, combining some departments and subcontracting out some 
Grant Application Form, July 1 20136
information technology functions. This has required scaling down and re-planning 
programming, and we are being mindful to carefully navigate these shifts to 
preserve critical safe abortion programming, as we also improve collaboration 
with partners. We have been moderately successful at increasing funding from 
some of our existing donors and identifying new sources of funding.
 
IDF was one of the recipients of a multi-country grant from LAD—withdrawal of 
support from LAD negatively impacted IDF’s operating budget by 40%. Like Ipas, 
IDF also mitigated this through strategic resizing and program changes and has 
now successfully secured additional funds to overcome the impact of this and 
continue efforts to improve the abortion ecosystem in its program states and at the 
national level.  
6c. Describe the history and past achievements of the organisation. 
(maximum 300 words):
Ipas has worked for nearly 50 years to ensure that women and girls have improved 
access to safe abortion and contraceptive care, which we consider crucial for 
improved reproductive rights, health, and gender equality. Our efforts on four 
continents have improved SRHR for women living within a range of restrictive 
abortion settings. Areas of expertise include implementing evidence-based 
initiatives to improve safe abortion access with governments, health providers, and 
community organizations, expanding health workers’ capacity and commitment to 
provide abortion care, and conducting action-oriented research to advance 
reproductive rights, with a focus on centering the perspectives and needs of those 
seeking abortion care. Guided by a commitment to human rights, innovation, and 
sustainability, we are skilled at building relationships with diverse stakeholders at 
every level of society, including within governments, institutions, and 
communities.
 
Ipas Development Foundation (IDF) is Ipas’s implementing partner is India. IDF 
began work in India in 2001 to address the SRH needs of Indian women and girls, 
specifically to reduce the incidence of unsafe abortion which continues to be the 
third major cause of maternal mortality. IDF’s presence in 10 states and women-
centered approach ensures that women and girls have improved knowledge, 
agency, and access to SRH care, including abortion and contraception. 
Partnerships with governments to achieve sustainability has resulted in: 
sustainable allocation of resources to support abortion care; consistent availability 
of essential equipment and supplies; increased numbers of trained providers to 
provide high quality care; and strengthened national policies and technical 
standards and guidelines to support a strong national abortion care program. As a 
result of IDF’s interventions, training, and advocacy, over 2,000,000 women and 
girls have accessed services from over 5,000 public health care facilities (with over 
84% of these at the primary level).
 
IDF’s interventions in Jharkhand and West Bengal in previous projects supported 
by the Foundation have resulted in positive outcomes—particularly in improving 
SRH knowledge among young women and girls, increasing service utilization and 
greater recognition of SRH as an important health issue (please see Annexure 1). 
Grant Application Form, July 1 20137
In Jharkhand, the endline evaluation shows statistically significant improvement in 
overall SRH indicators for knowledge, attitude, practices as well as stigma 
reduction, with the range of variation higher in the intervention group than in the 
comparison area – the findings are supported by an upward trend in SRH service 
uptake in public health facilities. In West Bengal, qualitative assessment of our 
intervention reveals an overall positive impact in improving SRH of adolescent 
girls (10-14 years) and young women (15-24 years)—adolescent girls and young 
women reported increased confidence and ability to discuss SRH issues and 
facility records show increase in utilization of SRH services in intervention 
facilities. While the results are encouraging, there is a continued need for 
nurturing an overall enabling environment for adolescent and youth SRH in the 
two states—some specific gap areas are mentioned in 6e.
6d. Describe the current strategy of the organisation. (maximum 300 
words):
Ipas’s programmatic strategy is based on the Ipas Strategic Framework which was 
rolled out in FY20. Ipas’s Strategic Framework offers a vision and strategy for 
progress on abortion access and rights that lead to programs that are fully 
grounded in the local contexts of the countries in which we work. Ipas’s Strategic 
Framework is based on our model for a sustainable abortion ecosystem. Ipas 
defines the sustainable abortion ecosystem as “a dynamic condition in which 
resilient local stakeholders and systems are actively accountable and committed to 
abortion rights and responsive to everyone’s abortion needs.” Ipas’s Sustainable 
Abortion Ecosystem model recognizes that a single approach (legal reform, health 
system strengthening, community education and engagement) will not alone 
create real access for women and girls—the full ecosystem needs to be addressed. 
Using a human-centered approach with women at the center, our approach 
acknowledges that sustainable abortion care requires flexibility and prioritization 
on how to collaborate with partners to achieve goals, and how to strike a delicate 
balance across many factors. Our ecosystem model and strategic framework 
recognize that sustainable abortion care must be driven by local stakeholders and 
address multiple programming components to meet women’s abortion needs. The 
Sustainability Framework identifies eight programming components that must be 
understood for each local context to accurately assess needs, develop and 
implement strategies, and monitor effective interventions. Underpinning the 
Strategic Framework is a continued commitment to a human rights and gender 
equality. Ipas articulates our work within a human rights analysis, and we partner 
across movements to advance the bodily integrity of all people.
6e. What problems are you addressing? What are the opportunities and 
challenges in addressing these problems? (maximum 600 words):
Young Indian women and girls face tremendous challenges and stigma in meeting 
their SRH needs and the COVID-19 pandemic has made accessing information, 
counselling and support, and services even more difficult. Young girls who marry 
Grant Application Form, July 1 20138
early are more likely to experience extreme social pressure of proving fertility and 
bear their first child before their body is ready for childbearing. As per latest NFHS-
5 (2019-20), 42% of young women in West Bengal aged 20-24 years got married 
before the legal minimum age of 18 years, while among men around 20% aged 25-
29 years got married before the legal minimum age of 21 years (IIPS 2020).  A 
similar trend is observed in the intervention district of 24 Parganas (South)—42% 
got married before 18 years (IIPS 2020). The situation is somewhat similar in 
Jharkhand. As per NFHS-4 (2015-16), 38% of women aged 20-24 years got married 
before the legal minimum age of 18 years, while among men around 31% men aged 
25-29 years got married before the legal minimum age of 21 years. Early marriage 
further leads to high teenage pregnancy—in West Bengal 16% of women ages 15-19 
years were already mothers or pregnant at the time of survey, this was 13% in 24 
Parganas (South). Given these, young women constitute 30% of total maternal 
mortality in the country. The highest maternal deaths (34%) in India are also 
recorded for young women ages 20-24 years (RGI 2019).
 
More than 33% of the disease burden and almost 60% of premature deaths among 
adults can be associated with behaviour or conditions that began or occurred during 
adolescence (GoI 2014).
 
Ipas’s partner in India, IDF, implements community-focused interventions in 
Jharkhand and West Bengal to address this, while also addressing specific gaps that 
were revealed during the evaluation of the previous grant.
 
Jharkhand
IDF’s work under previous grants from the Foundation has yielded positive 
outcomes (please see Annexure 1); however, some key gap areas from the previous 
grant include:  
1) Women’s agency around SRH-related decision making, negotiation skills with 
family members, and personal mobility is limited
2) Socio-cultural barriers including gender norms that impede women’s self-
efficacy for SRH
3) Men’ involvement—IDF’s work through male youth leaders has improved men’s 
attitudes towards women’s SRH needs and interspousal communication, but more 
work is needed to improve their acceptance of contraceptives and strengthen their 
ability to support their spouses in negotiating SRH discussions within 
families/communities
4) Need to decentralize SRH services for improved access
 
Opportunities:
•Strong foundation for a favourable SRH ecosystem established in the 
community
•Community-based evidence to guide strategies on addressing continuing 
SRH gaps and evolving needs of young women
•health system interventions for holistic impact (through separate IDF funds)
 
Challenges:
Grant Application Form, July 1 20139
•Potential government COVID-19 restrictions
•Resistance from the community due to fear of the pandemic
 
West Bengal (WB)– existing intervention areas
The often-overlooked SRH needs of adolescents and young women – particularly 
young adolescents (10-14 years) – are unique and critical, as early intervention 
lays the foundation for positive SRH outcomes. IDF’s targeted, age-appropriate 
SRH community outreach has led to encouraging results; (please see Annexure 1) 
while also revealing some gaps:
1) Support for SRH and improved communication within family – especially men 
(spouses), mothers of adolescent girls and mothers-in-law of married young women
2) Need to foster community-level support systems for sustaining a positive SRH 
ecosystem
3) Need to sensitize and strengthen the public health system for continued 
provision of adolescent/ youth-friendly services, especially to unmarried young 
girls, and for provision of services closer to the communities at lower-level 
facilities.
 
Opportunities:
•IDF’s ongoing memorandums of understanding with the government of WB 
for increasing access to comprehensive abortion and contraceptive services
•Initiation of contraceptive services at Health and Wellness Centres (HWCs)
•Established rapport with the community, health facilities and Anwesha 
counsellors
 
Challenges:
•COVID-19 restrictions and government regulations may hamper the pace of 
proposed work
•Legal barriers to providing SRH services for adolescents
•School shutdowns hampering outreach to adolescents
 
West Bengal – Sundarbans (proposed new intervention areas)
The Sundarbans region is characterized by poverty, chronic deprivation and acute 
suffering from climatic adversities. Communities are hard to access and 
economically vulnerable and ensuring access to basic healthcare services is 
challenging. Access to SRH – especially for adolescents – is not a priority and 
existing SRH services are insufficient. This project intends to build awareness on 
fundamental SRH topics among young women, sensitize communities on the 
importance of SRH, expand service availability, and strengthen linkages to enable 
access and improve care-seeking pathways.
 
Opportunities:
•IDF’s ongoing interventions in selected health facilities and good rapport 
with relevant officials
Grant Application Form, July 1 201310
•Huge need and scope for improving SRH awareness and service availability 
for young women and adolescent girls
 
Challenges:
•The project may require approvals from several departments, including 
health, Integrated Child Development Services (ICDS) etc.
•Unavailability of health workers/counsellors/doctors for training
•Lack of acceptance from the community due to low priority to SRH 
compared to more essential needs, including livelihood/employment

8. Cooperation
Describe the level of cooperation with other organisations and networks 
and explain how this cooperation helps achieve your goals (maximum 300 
words):
As Ipas's lead partner in India, IDF will implement the project with state-based 
NGOs, contributing to sustained capacity building and community-level ownership 
for SRH. In two other states – Bihar and Uttar Pradesh – IDF mentors a voluntary 
network of state-based CSOs to drive local advocacy and action and strengthen the 
grassroot SRHR movement. These partnerships have been crucial for IDF’s 
learning – they have revealed how mentoring local NGOs can generate impactful 
community-based evidence and lead to successful advocacy with local authorities. 
This complements IDF’s work of health system strengthening, community outreach 
and evidence-based policy making.
 
At the national level, IDF is part of various networks, like the Pratigya Campaign 
and closely works with a range of partners, and academic and professional 
organizations on SRH issues. These partnerships allow a two-way exchange of 
experiences and learnings to improve SRH in the country. IDF also benefits from 
close international associations that expose the organization to global learnings 
that we leverage for our on-the-ground efforts.
 
In the proposed project, IDF will explore learning partnerships with relevant 
organizations on social aspects, including the proposed collaboration for creating 
sustainable supply of low-cost sanitary napkins. Ipas will contribute expertise and 
global resources to develop IDF’s capacities especially around emerging concepts 
and methodologies related to agency-building and changing social norms in 
communities. IDF will also explore collaboration with partners, like CREA, for 
sharing of resources and internal skill building. In West Bengal, IDF will explore 
networking and alignment with other Oak Foundation grantees, particularly FPAI 
to ensure synergies and complementarity.    
 
As mentioned in Objective 3, the project aims to expand IDF’s work in the 
Sunderbans region. IDF will gain enhanced understanding about the challenges 
and needs of the region – including through secondary research – and explore 
learning collaborations with other relevant grantees of the Foundation.

9. Impact
What is the change you want to achieve from the overall project? (maximum 
300 words):
The project’s anticipated impact is improved agency of adolescent girls and young 
women to make their own reproductive health decisions and access services they 
need for better reproductive health outcomes. Specifically:
 
In Jharkhand, the project aims to establish sustainable, youth-friendly SRH 
services and a supportive environment for young women’s SRH. The following 
changes are envisioned:
•Agency of young women improved, particularly decision making, self-
efficacy and communication skills
•Men’s role strengthened as beneficiaries (as contraceptive acceptors) and 
allies facilitating young women’s SRH
•Social capital built to sustain enabling environment for young people’s SRH
•Digital SRH pathways seeded for continued access to information and 
counselling
•Youth-responsive, SRH service availability expanded, with emphasis on 
decentralization
 
In existing intervention regions of West Bengal, the project will consolidate gains, 
build on previous learnings, and focus on building sustainability by nurturing an 
enabling environment for adolescent and youth. The following will be achieved:
•Empowered adolescent girls and young women who are equipped to make 
their SRH decisions, and have interface with community structures to raise 
their concerns/SRH issues
•Improved support for adolescent girls’ SRH facilitating improved access to 
information and services
•Enhanced social capital in the communities to sustain a favorable 
environment for young women’s SRH
•Strengthened availability of adolescent/ youth friendly SRH services  
 
In coastal blocks in Sundarbans, the project will adapt and implement a youth-SRH 
model. With a phased expansion, the objective is to establish a strong foundation 
for future community-level interventions and achieve the following:
•Improved understanding of specific gaps in knowledge and services and 
needs of the community.
•Customized community outreach strategies (for adolescents and young 
women and men) co-created with young people of the area.
•Strengthened health facilities to initiate provision of adolescent and youth-
Grant Application Form, July 1 201322
friendly SRH services.
•Improved enabling environment in the communities for young people’s SRH.
10. Evaluation
How will progress be monitored and evaluated? (maximum 300 words):
Ipas will monitor the progress and efficacy of facility-based interventions through 
routine data collection from all intervention health facilities, including HWCs, in 
both Jharkhand and West Bengal. Monitoring data will be collected and analyzed 
to review: trends of utilization of SRH services; age-disaggregated data of young 
women and girls receiving services, including abortion; referral support provided, 
and quality of services offered. Results will be shared with providers, community 
intermediaries, and youth leaders for continued improvement in quality of 
information and service provision to young women. We will also conduct joint 
analysis sessions with service providers to transfer data-related skills of data 
disaggregation and analysis.
 
Field-level monitoring of community outreach work will be led by the state-based 
Program team in close collaboration with the youth leaders and their supervisors – 
the teams will conduct quarterly meetings to review data on community meetings 
and outreach activities, assess progress, and modify strategies as required.
 
In existing intervention areas, pre- and post-exit interviews with young women 
accessing SRH services at intervention facilities will reveal the perception of 
quality of services by adolescents and young women and attributes of accessing 
SRH services at public health facilities. Community-based endline assessments will 
demonstrate the impact of our community outreach in improving the overall 
ecosystem for SRHR (scope and methodology to be decided by the end of Year 
One).
 
In new intervention areas in West Bengal, community-level evaluations will 
examine the initial effectiveness of our interventions. Using a quasi-experimental 
design baseline research will assess knowledge, attitudes, and practices towards 
SRHR issues, as well as agency and gender equity-related aspects among young 
women. Partners of young married women will also be surveyed to assess their 
role. In addition to setting benchmarks for selected output indicators, the baseline 
study will help identify barriers and facilitating factors to SRH services. In 
contrast, the end-of-grant research will assess initial effectiveness of the 
intervention for refining future strategies.

11. Future Plans
How will the grant influence the organisation and future plans? (maximum 
300 words):
Learnings from the project will significantly contribute to Ipas’s and IDF’s 
organizational knowledge and influence future strategies, including organization 
strategic planning to be initiated in early 2022.
 
More specifically, this grant will greatly influence IDF’s technical priorities and 
future fundraising capacity. Work under the previous grants from the Foundation 
has significantly expanded IDF’s technical expertise and resources for community 
outreach for young women – adolescent and young women’s SRH is now one of 
IDF’s key thematic areas of work. The proposed grant will further augment IDF’s 
organizational learning and generate evidence on additional concepts – especially 
enhancing agency of women, facilitating gender-equitable norms and nurturing a 
supportive environment for young women’s and adolescent SRH. The proposed 
community-based work in the Sunderbans closely aligns with IDF’s priorities 
around reaching the most marginalized populations and will lay the foundation for 
future work in the region.
 
Along with support from the Oak Foundation, IDF continues to benefit from 
diverse donor support, including from Ipas Inc., Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation,

critical for IDF’s fund-raising plans – we believe that work on this key component 
will have maximum traction with donors in India and will therefore be in the

The Fund was founded in 2002, initially with a registered office in the US and 
then in the UK in 2013. Until late 2020 the Fund was led by its founding CEO, 
Regan Ralph, who stepped down after 20 years of inspirational leadership. In 
May 2023 the Fund’s new CEO, Gabriela Bucher, joined. During this 
leadership transition the Fund’s Deputy CEO, Brandee Butler, has been Acting 
CEO. The Fund’s leadership team is currently five members who collectively 
provide leadership and guidance to over 60 full-time Fund staff based all over 
the world.  Our Program staff are based in the regions where we have a 
program presence. In addition, each regional program has a part-time or full-

5c. What is the problem you want to address and what is your approach? 
How will you use Oak's funding? How did you identify the problem and 
decide your approach? If you have undertaken a theory of change exercise, or if 
you are influenced by research, policy or your own organisation’s experience, please 
tell us about this.  Have you consulted with relevant stakeholders, including your

Problem Analysis
The consequences of climate change in India - including eroding coastlines, 
destroyed ecosystems, catastrophic weather events and poorly designed 
climate mitigation and development projects - are deepening existing 
inequalities. Climate change is a threat multiplier, and populations in India 
that already are vulnerable because of factors such as geography, poverty, 
gender, indigenous or minority status, national or social origin, birth or other 
status, and disability, continue to face its harshest effects. The nexus of the 
climate crisis and socioeconomic and political inequalities is at the root of 
various types of climate injustices in India, and this is particularly pertinent in 
the state of West Bengal.
West Bengal is a very unique state in India that is still grappling with the 
effects of its contested history under British rule, and the post-independence 
political and economic stagnation that followed after years of being one of the 
richest regions in the world. Today, West Bengal has a fragile economy and is 
one of the poorest regions in India, attributed, in part, to years of communist 
rule that shunned industrialization and modernization, and the growing effects 
of extreme weather – such as flooding – that together are leaving many families 
destitute and are driving people to migrate to other states. Yet at the same 
time, West Bengal is home to some of the richest biodiversity and natural 
resources in India, including pristine forests with diverse fora and fauna, much 
of which have been carefully preserved and protected by tribal communities 
and other forest-dwelling communities who have lived there for centuries and 
are highly dependent on the forest for their livelihoods and food sovereignty.
However, West Bengal’s ecology and pristine forests, as well as the lands, 
livelihoods, culture and identity or the many indigenous communities that 
reside in them are increasingly under serious threat from a growing turn 
Oak Application Form     8
towards major investments in development, natural resource extraction and 
highly urbanized practices. One of the recent examples is the proposed 
Deocha-Panchami- open cast coal mining project of West Bengal State which 
supports the eviction of many communities.
 
Furthermore, whilst there are solid laws in India to protect the community 
rights of indigenous groups, as well as the land they inhabit – such as the 
Forest Rights Act (FRA) – implementation of these laws remains poor, and 
recent amendments in laws related to forests and the environment at both 
state and central government level have been contradictory and difficult for 
communities and civil society to predict and respond to. Majoritarian 
governance is also eroding constitutional democracy and the rule of law, and 
disempowering communities. Recent policies and actions have supported 
corporate mining and other interests, such as in 2021, India’s Ministry of 
Environment issued an order to help some mining projects avoid public 
environment clearance hearings which are a critical tool for good governance 
and an important process for mining-affected communities, who may be 
suffering from non-compliance of mandatory environmental safeguards in 
mining projects. India’s Wildlife Protection Act has also been responsible for 
the large-scale relocation of tribal communities, and an increased 
criminalization of forest communities, as documented in this recent report by 
Centre for Police Accountability.
This deeply concerning trend is intensifying and happening within a broader 
context of civic space and activism being severely curtailed across India as the 
state seeks to silence all dissent; today, India is one of the most dangerous 
places in the world to be a human rights defender (HRD), especially for those 
advocating around environmental issues who are easily labelled as threats to 
national security.
 
The Fund’s Response & Learning
The Fund’s work related to environmental issues in India is currently focused 
in Gujarat, Tamil Nadu, and West Bengal and more recently expanded to 
Chhattishargh and Jharkhand. However, the Fund has deepened its strategic 
focus and investment in West Bengal in recent years considering the needs on 
the ground and the critical window of opportunity the current moment 
presents in this state as it is on the cusp of major development and greater 
demands on its land and natural resources. The Fund knows that in the face 
of these growing threats it is imperative that local communities, particularly 
indigenous and forest-dwelling communities, be supported now to elevate 
their voices and power to demand their constitutional rights to land and access 
to natural resources, before private sector interests and deforestation take 
hold.
Over the last few years, thanks to Oak’s support, the Fund supported a number 
of community-led efforts in West Bengal to promote and protect the rights of 
indigenous and forest-dwellers affected by environmental issues, large 
development projects, land displacement, and forced evictions. We have 
gathered important learning about the most effective strategies to help 
counter and navigate the growing threats outlined above, which have informed 
our strategic priorities in the years ahead and for which we are seeking Oak’s 
continued support and partnership.
Oak Application Form     9
As many climate solutions are inextricably linked to social and economic 
justice in India, the Fund has supported advocacy and lobbying efforts with 
the government to ensure indigenous communities’ identities and culture are 
protected, as well as on promoting food sovereignty and sustainable 
agricultural practices.
From our experience we have learnt that climate change can be mitigated, and 
environmental justice facilitated when communities are economically resilient, 
women have equal and equitable access to resources and to power, younger 
people feel stronger community connectedness, and citizens are collectivized 
and have the knowledge of laws and policies that impact them and their 
environment.
The Fund is pleased to report that through Oak’s current grant for work in 
Jhargram, West Bengal, local groups and activists have made significant in 
their work over the last few years, and the results of this are extremely 
encouraging, and on which we are seeking to build. Over the last few years:
•Targeted communities in Jhargram, Purulia and Bankura have 
demonstrated increased capacity to self-organize and claim their 
community/individual forest rights.
•Perhaps most notably, at the time of writing this, up to now communities 
have been supported to form 15 Gram Sabhas - 9 in Nayagram Block and 
6 in Binpur II Block - and so far 8 are in the process of claiming 
community forest rights, with others are in the process of preparing 
their claims for submission. These 8 claims in process represent the 
rights of a total of 584 families and land 1,597 hectares in size, which 
demonstrates the huge reach and potential impact of community-level 
institutions like Gram Sabhas and their collective action.
•Another inspiring outcome has also been that some leaders of Gram 
Sabhas took initiative to form a platform/network of local Gram Sabhas 
- Banadhikar Gram Sabhas Mocha – which has since held two annual 
convenings of local Gram Sabhas, involving local leaders and forest 
rights activists from a number of villages. The last convening, held 
earlier in 2023, was attended by 200 people which demonstrates the 
appetite for such platforms and spaces. The convening included rich 
discussions. Banadhikar Gram Sabhas Mocha has also been able to 
successfully liaise with and advocate with the District Magistrate and 
other District officials in instances where Gram Sabhas claims are not 
being responded to, helping to amplify communities’ voices and 
concerns. Another positive development is that the organizers of this 
Mocha are now engaging themselves in discussing livelihood issues. The 
potential of this platform is extremely promising.
•One of the most important achievements noted by our grantees has been 
the change in attitude of government departments towards the forest 
rights campaign and work in Jhargram. When they started the work and 
helped Gram Sabhas to submit claims after meticulous preparation, 
none of the government departments showed any interest, rather they 
were actively discouraged from filing submissions. After two years of 
hard work and regular engagement with District officials, they are now 
publishing a booklet about the FRA, Gram Sabha and forest rights 
claims, publishing and circulating claim forms. The District Magistrate 
is now also promising to look into claims submitted and giving 
Oak Application Form     10
instructions to his subordinate officers on the same and most 
importantly, the Forest Department is acknowledging the process and 
sending Forest Officers to talk about FRA claims in a gathering 
organized by the very same community, with whom they share a 
contentious relationship. This is a major shift and step forward for State 
recognition and action in relation to community forest rights.
 
Key learnings from our work in West Bengal so far have shown that:
- the most important and effective way to engage and mobilize indigenous 
communities to claim their rights to land is to equip them with greater 
understanding of the connection between their cultural identity, traditional 
practices and customary laws, to the protection of and access to land. We have 
seen through our grantees’ work that focusing on this intersection – helping 
people to see that land is not just a resource but part of indigenous cultural 
identity – is the most powerful and successful way to empower and mobilize 
communities for action.
-equipping communities with a greater understanding of their constitutional 
rights and legal provisions is critical
- supporting efforts to strengthen the forest governance structure through 
people centric conservation practices through constitutional remedies such as 
the PESA, FRA etc. allows communities to demonstrate the meaning of 
conservation and protection of their natural resources
- supporting communities to mobilize, form Gram Sabhas and process 
collective claims takes considerable time, accompaniment and trust-building, 
but is an essential process in empowering communities and ensuring the 
realization of their rights
- communities need sound legal aid in order to claim their rights and respond 
to emerging threats, including criminalization by the state.
 
Support from Oak
The Fund seeks a new 4-year partnership with Oak and a grant of $575,000 to 
help bring the resources and actions needed in this critical moment for 
grassroots level organizing on land and resource rights issues in West Bengal. 
With Oak’s support the Fund would build on the success and learning from 
previous work and support a cohort of 4 local groups working on their 
communities’ management of and rights to natural resources in West Bengal, 
likely focused in Jhargram, Purulia, Paschin Bardhaman, Bankura, Alipurduar 
and Cooch Behar Districts. The Fund would continue to support 2 existing 
grantees and seek to expand support to 2 new grantees. With Oak’s support 
grantees will receive the resources and support to build on their work, 
progress and learning so far, with a deepened focus on building community 
awareness of the power in their cultural identity and heritage, its connection 
to land, and in pursuing their constitutional rights to land ownership and 
access. Grantees will be able to continue supporting communities to claim land 
titles, to scale up their outreach and mobilization efforts into new areas, and 
to advocate for West Bengal’s Forest governance structure to be 
strengthened, ensuring communities have the power and voice in the process 
through building grassroot mobilization of community-based organisations 
Oak Application Form     11
such as Banadhikargram sabha morcha and Uttar Banga Vanjan Shramajeevi 
Manch.
As far as our grantees liaising with the government departments, this will 
happen to some extent, especially with district administration, forest 
department, and nodal agencies such as the Department of Backward class 
welfare who is primarily responsible for the implementation of Forest Rights. 
However, grantees likely will not lobby or advocate directly with these 
departments since the Gram Sabha Morcha – an important people’s 
network/forum- will take the lead in having direct dialogue with government 
departments on behalf of its communities. Similarly, North Bengal groups will 
engage with such departments since they are already working on forest rights 
although it is not directly supported by our funds.
Our proposed work would align strongly with the Fund’s strategic priorities 
to shift more resources to grassroots environmental activists and solutions in 
India, to build indigenous communities’ resilience and power on 
environmental issues and their rights, to support intersectional approaches 
to activism, and to help nurture a grassroots climate justice movement that 
has indigenous communities, women and youth at its heart and helm.

9. MONITORING, EVALUATION & LEARNING 
This section is twofold. Please tell us:
a) Monitoring and evaluation. How will you know if you are achieving your objectives? Please 
describe briefly how you will know if you are making progress and if what you are doing is working. 
If you have a formal monitoring and evaluation system and if you plan to collect indicator data or 
conduct an external evaluation, please provide details here.
b) Learning. Please tell us if there anything in particular that you are hoping to learn more about or 
test through this grant.
(300 words):
a. Monitoring and evaluation:
The Fund has developed a strategic framework for each country that guides 
the Fund’s allocation of its resources and provides a means for evaluating its 
grant-making over time. Each grantee will be required to submit a proposal 
every year outlining their proposed work and goals for the year ahead and 
proposed qualitative and quantitative indicators to track developments and 
progress. The Fund’s program staff in India will then speak with each grantee 
to jointly set indicators – aligned to what we have outlined in this proposal - 
that they will use to determine whether their efforts are moving in the desired 
direction.
The assessment of these indicators is done typically through six monthly 
narrative reports.  Alongside these grantee reports, the Fund’s program staff 
in India will maintain regular communication with grantees – likely every 
quarter - as an important part of building strong relationships rooted in trust, 
and to help maintain open discussions on progress and challenges on their 
work and strategies. Fund staff will also visit grantees regularly to accompany 
them in their work, to deepen discussions around strategies, and to encourage 
ongoing reflection and learning.
The Fund recognizes that no work happens in isolation; it can have planned 
and unplanned impact, just as the emerging social, cultural and political 
context can impact the work in foreseen and unforeseen ways. During its 
discussions with grantees, the Fund’s major role is as a thought partner who 
Oak Application Form     15
can help the grantee understand the role and impact of their organization not 
just in its own silo, but also in the context of the broader eco-system of 
organizations. The Fund also provides guidance, and where possible additional 
support and resources, to also support grantees to build their capacity, 
leadership and ensure their sustainability. In India, the Fund does this with a 
particular focus on promoting the development of second line leadership 
within its grantees and ensuring the younger generation of activists are 
elevated.
b. Learning:
The Fund is increasingly nurturing a learning culture and sees learning as an 
ongoing and self-reinforcing process. Through the ongoing monitoring and 
evaluation efforts mentioned above, the Fund would seek to deepen its 
learning on the most effective strategies to build communities’ resilience and 
power to claim their rights related to access and management of land and 
natural resources in West Bengal, as well as on the intersection with 
protecting indigenous cultural identity. We would then use this reflection and 
learning to apply a sharper focus to our grantees’ and our own programming 
strategies going forward.

5a. Tell us about your governance and leadership structures, as well as 
staff and volunteer base. Highlight any significant recent or expected future

Durbar Mahila Samanwaya Committee (DMSC) is a collective of sex workers 
(male, female and transgender) based in West Bengal, India. It has been 
active since 1995 to remove different socio-cultural and structural barriers in 
the lives of the sex workers and other marginalized communities. Since last 
27 years, Durbar is continuously fighting for the protection and promotion of 
the fundamental rights to the sex workers and other marginalized 
communities. It has an Executive Committee of 9 persons who are elected 
from the General Body every three years. The Executive Committee is 
Oak Application Form     5
responsible for all decisions on policy, staff matters, fund raising, budgeting 
etc.
DMSC will be receiving these funds on behalf of the Right to Food and Work 
Campaign West Bengal (RTF&W Campaign WB). The RTF&W Campaign WB 
is a network of about 75-80 NGOs, people’s organisations and individuals, of 
which about 22 are fairly active. They have come together to address the 
issue of food security and rural employment in West Bengal. A Secretariat 
facilitates communication between partner NGOs to keep them informed 
about State and National level activities. Presently, the Steering Group, 
consisting of four partner organisations, Durbar Mahila Samanwaya 
Committee, Udayani Social Action Forum, SEWA Bharat and Paschim Banga 
Khet Majoor Samity, which has only one full time staff member and a part 
time legal consultant. Everyone else works for the Campaign on a voluntary 
basis.
During the coming year, the Secretariat will expand to include some more 
staff members to undertake various other activities as mentioned later. On a 
need-based basis, it may also take on other consultants.   The Steering group 
will also be expanded to include other interested partner organisations.
The Campaign has attempted to establish a North Bengal based network in 
the last few years which is partially functioning. This still needs nurturing in 
the next few years before it can function effectively.

A vertical HIV intervention program was launched in 1992 following a base 
line study conducted by All India Institute of Hygiene & Public Health 
(AAIH&PH), a Central Govt. institute. The objective was to initiate STD and 
HIV prevention program in Sonagachi, a red light zone in Kolkata, India. The 
intervention programme started with three principal components: provision 
of health services including STD treatment; information, education and 
communication (IEC); and condom programming. It was in the year 1995 out 
of felt need by the community members followed by several discussions and 
consultations, a unique body of the ‘fallen women’ was formed;  Durbar 
Mahila Samanwaya Committee (DMSC) came into existence. This is a forum 
exclusively set up and managed by sex workers and their children with the 
objective of creating solidarity and collective strength among the sex worker 
community and other marginalized groups.
1. The success of DMSC run HIV intervention program is known as 
‘Sonagachi model’ being the most successful intervention among sex 
workers globally. This has helped National Govt. to articulate a 
strategy called Targeted Interventions for the high risk communities 
like sex workers, Transgender, MSM population. Based on the ‘Lesson 
Learnt’ from Sonagachi Project, NACO (National AIDS Control

Organization) articulated the concept of ‘Creating Enabling 
Environment’ and ‘Community organizing and Ownership 
building’ what became the budgeted and integral component of HIV 
intervention program. The principles of Sonagachi model was taken to 
build the foundation of .Bill and Melinda Gates supported HIV 
intervention program in India spending $350 Million. Both these 
strategies were also accepted by all UN agencies including big donors 
like the Global fund DFID etc. in their programmatic approach.
2. Durbar is a founder member of All India Network of Sex Workers 
which at present represent 85 community based organizations of sex 
workers and TG spread across 18 states in India.
3. Durbar is part of numbers of National networks and campaign

others.

The Right to Food and Work Campaign West Bengal that has been in 
existence since 2001. In the last seven to eight years with the financial 
assistance from the OAK foundation it has made the following major 
contributions to the issue of food security: -
•It has been able to strengthen its network and spreads its network in 
20 districts in the state.
•In number of cases unpaid wages under the MGNREGA has been paid 
by the government due to strong intervention of the Campaign. In the 
year 2017 – 18 due to intervention of the campaign about 881 persons 
were paid their due wages and the approximate amount is 
Rs.17919540/-
•Several times, teams on behalf of the Campaign conducted studies in 
the tea gardens in North Bengal. Through the studies and fact findings, 
the campaign prepared a number of reports and calculated dues of the 
workers from the management. From time to time these reports were 
submitted to the both the central and state government as well before 
the Hon’ble Supreme Court of India. And finally on 4th April, 2018 
Hon’ble Supreme Court in a contempt proceeding of a case filed by 
Paschim Banga Khet Majoor Samity and other unions directed the 
government of West Bengal to pay Rs. 15 Cr. to the workers as an 
interim relief.
•The campaign organized  training programs for the tea garden workers 
regarding the procedure of filling claim forms also members of the 
campaign are consistently monitoring the proper implementation of the 
order passed by Hon’ble Court on 4th April, 2018 and to find out the 
problems of the workers to fill the forms.
•The Supreme Court in 2020 constituted a one-member committee 
headed by retired Supreme Court judge A.M. Sapre to inspect and 
verify the claims of workers. The hearing by Justice Sapre's Committee 
was delayed due to Covid-19 and subsequent lockdowns. However, on 
15.09.2021, the Committee passed an order stating that all the 
workers of these 29 gardens would have to submit their claim forms 
and which is an ongoing process till date.
