RTF&W Campaign WB is addressing the problem of food security, focusing 
especially on hunger deaths and malnutrition. It is working especially on the 
rights to food and work.  Its work is at various levels. For example, at the 
grass roots level, it works to ensure that people know about existing rights 
such as the Supreme Court orders on Right to Food, the NFSA and the 
MGNREGA. It also understands through the experience at the grass roots 
about lacunae in the implementation of these rights and mobilises and 
campaigns to deal with these lacunae at the administrative level. In addition, 
it also defines and lobbies and campaigns for an expansion of these rights at 
the State and National level. Civil society activists and local leaders are 
actively participating in the movement to add momentum and influence the 
policy makers to be pro poor in nature. The emergent leaders and the CBOs 
are taking up issues at the micro level and challenging the Panchayat, Block 
and District administration to be accountable and transparent in their 
execution of these rights.
The challenges facing the Campaign are as follows:-
The groups, individuals and the community leaders face difficulties related to 
pressure from local goons. Besides threats from the local leaders, the 
administration sometimes creates hindrances in effective implementation. 
Red tapism and too many bottlenecks related to documents and evidential 
proof takes more time in actual initiation of the actions to be taken.
Organisations are at various levels of understanding of issues and in 
capacities to deal with such issues. A big challenge is that there are large 
stretches of blocks and districts where our work has had no impact so far 
and where we do not have any partners.
A big challenge is to maintain communication and co-ordination amongst 
member organisations of the campaign. The North-South divide in the state 
in terms of distances as well as issues and even language means that the 
Campaign will have to have parallel activities for different areas.
Similarly, another challenge is to convince member organisations to move 
out of the project mode (where food security issues are taken up only when 
there are funds for a project) to the movement mode where these issues 
become part of their work on a long term basis.
This in fact would be the main focus of the project i.e. building capacities 
and understanding to go from viewing right to food as only a three year 
project to a view that it is an essential part of each partner’s work in the long 
term and that work continues even when the project ends. For this, we will 
focus on trainings to build capacity, but also give partners practical 
experience in doing studies, in campaigning and in lobbying. A preclude to 
such activity will be to actually do an assessment of where the partner is in 
terms of capacities and understanding of issues.
Oak Application Form     10
An important focus is also the use of instruments like litigation, studies and 
publications to bring about public focus on the rights to food and decent 
employment.
The network is learning from its past experiences and incorporating the 
learnings to the future strategies as and whenever required. For instance, 
the network is focusing on capacity building of the young generation of the 
target communities and building them asset to the communities. Also, 
inclusion of partners and community members in conducting studies helps 
the network to understand the depth of issue and to collect evidences of 
negligence/loopholes at the implementation of the social schemes. These 
documentations support the campaign to file strong litigation to the court. 
The network is going to emphasize on capacity building and inclusion of 
communities in these processes. The network will also emphasize on modular 
group formation as per capacity of the grassroot emerging leaders & existing 
partner organisations and link such groups on the existing groups at village 
level, at panchayat level, at Block level, at district level and to state level.

a keen interest in philanthropy, who will objectively make decisions on grant awards

Srivastava and Ms. Rajul Kadakia.

their own startups, equipped provide entrepreneurial expertise, technological 
inputs, corporate strategy and investor relations experience.

of the sector.

marketing & asset management. They are a valuable addition in providing critical 
and valuable feedback/suggestions in the Foundation’s operations, strategy and 
financials.
With regard to the expected changes - As AFEF grows further, the aim is to continue 
on the path of diversity, building a team and partners who can bring in a blend of 
thoughts and experiences to enable cross learning, and strengthen the organisation 
from within.

6b. Describe the financial situation (include information on annual 
operating costs, fundraising strategy, reserves and debts) and expected

AFEF looks to support credible small to mid-sized organisations in India doing 
impactful work with a focus on three critical segments of society; children, women 
and vulnerable communities. AFEF will be the anchor funder for all foreign grants 
to the grantee partners in India, will review grant applications and determine 
whether the requested grants will be made towards these reputable charitable 
organisations in India within the meaning of Section 501(c)(3) of the Internal 
Revenue Code of 1986. Governed by its funding eligibility criteria, AFEF may accept 
or refuse to grant award to the applying organisations.
Annual operating costs, which include staff salaries, fixed costs, service charge etc., 
will be proportionately accounted for through donor grants as ‘management cost’ 
by mutual agreement with the donor.
AFEF intends to connect with potential foundations, corporations and individuals by 
networking through peer engagement, events and research  to enhance outreach, 
build credibility and appeal to the larger Philanthropic ecosystem towards 
supporting credible organisations in India.
For the next 2-3 years, AFEF has visibility of a few funders who are anticipated to 
contribute medium to high volume of funds; estimated to be approx 5-6 million USD 
who are looking to support organisations in India inclusive of GROW.
6c. Describe the history and past achievements of the organisation. 
(maximum 300 words):
AFEF was incorporated in June 1, 2020 and has recently started operations. 
Currently AFEF is managing grants of ~USD 3.5 mn supporting programs in COVID 
19 aid, migrant and disaster relief, education and women empowerment grassroots 
initiatives in India.
These funds have been directly provided to the identified implementing partners 
working in India such as Goonj and Jan Sahas who are catering to communities pan-
India, Samaritan Help Mission, Sanjog,and SOVA in West Bengal and Orissa , etc.
AFEF’s primary activities includes identifying and creating relationships with 
reputable charitable organizations operating in India that provide services and 
programs consistent with the charitable purposes of the Foundation. AFEF as an 
anchor funder to the implementing partners in India, has currently identified 
EdelGive Foundation as an advisor and grants manager in India.
AFEF plans to act as a gateway for individuals and various institutions/organizations 
who are looking to provide grants to credible organizations operating in India.
EdelGive Foundation who is the reference partner, advisor and grants manager of 
AFEF, will be responsible for the overall implementation, management and 
monitoring of grants in India.
EdelGive has over the decade committed and influenced close to INR 3.3 billion into 
Grant Application Form, July 1 20136
social development, partnered with more than 150 Non-Government Organisations 
(NGOs) across 14 districts in India, impacted more than 1.7 million lives, and 
provided pro bono support of over 40,000 hours of skilled volunteering. EdelGive is 
currently part of 6 big collaboratives in diverse domains; in critical capacities.
6d. Describe the current strategy of the organisation. (maximum 300 
words):
India is home to 1.4 billion people from diverse communities with each community 
having its own distinct challenges.  Despite Government intervention and policies 
over the years, there have been gaps in addressing community needs, leaving 
some unaddressed and unheard.
Grassroot organisation’s role hence is fundamental to addressing social needs from 
a microscopic lens. Although, India receives the highest foreign aid from across the 
world, philanthropic efforts are unreachable/inequitably distributed towards the 
rural marginalized sections or urban poverty pockets within cities.
Hence, AFEF’s mission was born out of this realization to support small and mid-
sized organisations in India who understand the dynamic development dilemmas of 
the communities, their immediate needs and provide sustainable solutions. AFEF 
aims to fulfil this by focusing on:
•Education – With a belief that every child has the right to attend school and 
learn in school, AFEF seek to address the systemic gaps that impact children’s 
access to quality education.
•Women Empowerment – Adopt a rights-based approach to support women 
in society, free them from violence and discrimination, build awareness and 
accessibility to their rights and entitlements, make them economically 
independent and build grassroots leaders.
•Livelihoods – Work with vulnerable communities affected by unemployment, 
failing agriculture and natural calamities through interventions targeted 
towards building the resilience of the rural and tribal populations.
AFEF will scope/invite proposals from organisations implementing critical 
initiatives in India, and through a thorough due diligence process will award 
grantees with AFEF’s multi-year grants approach. AFEF has also partnered with 
EdelGive, to assist with the scoping process, monitoring and fund management in 
India.
AFEF with EdelGive joined its first collaborative, to support the GROW Fund as an 
anchor funder to help sustain 100 organisations for 2 years whose operations have 
been impacted owing to the pandemic.
6e. What problems are you addressing? What are the opportunities and 
challenges in addressing these problems? (maximum 600 words):
Grant Application Form, July 1 20137
Context
The rapid spread of COVID-19 has resulted in devastating consequences for 
economies, businesses, and communities across the globe. In India particularly, 
lockdowns have more deeply affected migrant and vulnerable communities who are 
grappling with loss of income, livelihood, food, healthcare and resultant uncertainty 
and helplessness.
Grassroot organisations have been at the forefront of addressing these problems but 
have also become casualties themselves owing to extreme financial distress that is 
likely to leave a lasting, negative impact outliving their capacities to mitigate them. 
Studies done during the COVID-19 period have reported that NGOs are facing lack 
of access to basic technology, salary cuts, lay-offs, inability to pay rent or source 
basic supplies for daily sustenance are already prevailing issues.
Of the 388 NGOs that responded to a Bridgespan survey on “Building Strong, 
Resilient NGOs in India: Time for New Funding Practices”:
•54% had less than 3 months of reserves in Sep’20, 50% NGOs never had an 
operating surplus
•61% NGOs based in non-metro areas are worse off than in metros others 
with less than 3 months of reserves
•60% NGOs led by leaders from historically disadvantaged communities 
(DBA-Dalit, Bahujan Adivasi communities) have lower financial resilience 
with less than 3 months of reserves, against 53% of non-DBA led NGOs.
The Impact of Covid-19 on India's Nonprofit Organisations report by CSIP based 
on survey responses from close to 300 NGOs and 52 interviews reported the 
following insights on challenges being faced:
•Operating in accordance with social distancing norms (61%)
•Dealing with financial insecurity (55%)
•Managing staff including remote work and ensuring staff well-being and 
safety (70%).
•Burnout and exhaustion given that many NPOs worked at capacity and 
beyond with limited staff strength
•Suspension of programs owing to discontinued funding and limited or 
absent resource mobilisation capacity.
Given the above realities and facts, the possibility of breakdown of this cadre of 
organisations whom Foundations like AFEF rely on to deliver last-mile relief to 
communities, is worrisome.
Opportunities:
As funders and grantmakers, AFEF and EdelGive deem it our responsibility to 
ensure the grassroots sector sustains through:
•Recognition of grassroots work and of the risks that will be encountered if it 
were to cease
•Acknowledgment of challenges that threaten to derail this work
•Readiness to arrive at urgent, practical and longer term solutions to address 
these challenges
As proponents of collaborative rather than siloed approaches having experience of 
anchoring multiple Coalitions, we were among the first partners to join 
Bridgespan’s Pay What it Takes initiative which is committed to building stronger, 
Grant Application Form, July 1 20138
more financially resilient NGOs. We have conceived the GROW Fund as part of our 
mission to strengthen small and medium NGOs to emerge stronger and stay sturdy 
to overcome crises like COVID-19.
The GROW Fund brings together like-minded Indian and international funders in a 
collaborative model (in line with PWIT tenets) to collectively address the 
challenges facing grassroots NGO in India. The Fund will demonstrate a new 
future of funding model that will ensure two-year support 100 vetted 
organisations, cover their core cost, provide capacity building (CB) support and 
organisational development support for future readiness (FR).
The GROW Fund has currently received commitments covering ~50% of its total 
budget and is in the process of initiating the call for proposals by August end.
The success of the GROW Fund 2021-2024 is anticipated to pave way for similar 
initiatives/subsequent rounds of GROW to shape the narrative of philanthropy in 
and for India.
Challenges:
We anticipate certain natural occurrences, which may hamper the project’s 
timelines/focus such as recurring relapse of COVID-19 that may lead to nationwide 
lockdowns and threat to lives.
The challenges to organizational resilience are multi-fold and we will adopt a multi-
dimensional approach to address them through common as well as customized 
alternatives for grantees

4g. Summarise the project’s ultimate goal(s) (maximum 200 words):
( NOT REQUIRED FOR CORE SUPPORT GRANTS)
The project’s ultimate goal is the realization of sexual and reproductive health and 
rights of poor, young and vulnerable people, especially women, girls and key 
populations, in a gender-just world, free from stigma or discrimination.
 In an endeavour towards this goal, FPA India proposes a four-year intervention for 
the disempowered populations in selected high-need areas of West Bengal to 
expand access to sexual and reproductive health and empower individuals and 
communities to exercise their sexual and reproductive rights towards gender 
equality, economic empowerment and poverty alleviation.
Barriers to realizing sexual and reproductive health and rights are rooted in 
unequal gender power relations, stigma and entrenched social norms, with ripple 
effects at individual, household, community and policy levels. To achieve a 
sustainable, transformational change, a four-pronged, overlapping approach will 
be adopted – Increasing the demand and supply of comprehensive SRH information 
and services, fostering partnerships to promote SRHR, imparting life-skills training 
and alternative livelihood opportunities to the young and vulnerable populations 
with limited means.
All actions will contribute to the overall SDG goals of ensuring healthy lives and 
promoting the well-being for all at all ages SDG3) and achieving gender equality 
and empowerment of all women and girls (SDG5).

FPA India is a voluntary organization that works on a wide range of SRH issues 
encompassing family planning, comprehensive sexuality education, maternal 
health, child survival, adolescent care, HIV/AIDS, safe abortion, reproductive tract 
cancer screening and prevention and mitigation of gender-based violence (GBV).
Key strategies include ensuring access to high quality SRH information and 
services; capacity building of health care providers and community volunteers on 
SRHR issues; engaging with communities and individuals to change gender 
disparity and promote SRHR; and advocacy for policy change at the national and 
state level. Through its various programmes, FPA India reaches a population of

community based volunteers and more than 1000 staff.
FPA India is an accredited Member Association of the International Planned 
Parenthood Federation (IPPF) which has 152 member countries working in 172 
countries, across the globe With its HQs in Mumbai and 44 Branches/Projects 
across 18 states of the country Family Planning Association of India (FPA India) 
follows a functional organizational structure.
The Governing Board at the apex comprises of a group of Volunteers following a 
democratic process of elections which involves the two governing board 
representatives of the Branches. The representatives are a part of the Branch 
Executive Committee and are elected through Branch Level elections. The

the Branches. The board reviews the annual performance of the Association in 
relation to its strategic goals, Association’s Annual budget and approve it, oversee 
the implementation of policies adopted by All India Council etc. All Branches and 
the HQ adhere to the governing and management requirements as laid down by 
the Constitution for the Association.

three-year term following which a new governing board is elected to the office by 
representatives of the All India Council of FPA India. The present CEC has been

FPA India has grown since, with each decade marked by pioneering work to

women, young people, key populations, underserved, marginalized poor 
and vulnerable groups.

Strategic Plan envisions all people empowered to enjoy their sexual and

The unmet need for family planning and SRH services continues to be high. 
According to NFHS 4, the percentage of the Unmet Need for Family Planning 
(currently married women age 15–49 years) is found to be 12.9%. Of 37% of 
contraceptive demand among adolescents (15-19 years) in India, only 15% have

need for limiting (2.5%).[1]
Inequalities-gender & poverty continue to impact health and empowerment 
outcomes; Stigma and discrimination of age, marital status, class, gender, caste, 
sexuality other markers pose major challenges to the implementation of SRHR.
Availability of government schemes: a large number of schemes are currently 
being implemented by the government for young people, women, and vulnerable 
groups related to health, livelihood and rights. These pose as opportunities for a 
strong referral system and partnership building that can enable FPA India and its 
various associates including clients to avail the schemes thereby affecting long-

6e. What problems are you addressing? What are the opportunities and 
challenges in addressing these problems? (maximum 600 words):
The project attempts to address sexual and reproductive health and rights issues 
faced by individuals and communities due to gender, age, caste, and 
socioeconomic differentials.
Our ongoing work in the operational areas of Kalchini and Kolkata has 
demonstrated an increasing demand for comprehensive abortion care, family 
planning, cervical cancer screening and management, maternal and child health 
services, gender-based violence screening and continuum of care for survivors, 
comprehensive sexuality education for adolescents and for some FGDs with key 
stakeholders conducted in 2017, regarding their perspectives on family planning. 
Additionally, there is a report of an intervention in the Buxaduar area of 
Kalchini that underscores the high need for SRH services for the high-need 
satellite clinic intervention in Kalchini and Kolkata that needs to be sustained.
As per NFHS-4 data for India, the percentage of married women aged 15-49 years 
Grant Application Form, July 1 20139
who use any modern contraceptive method stands at 47.8%. Of these, women in 
the age group of 20-24 who were married before the age of 18 stand at 26.8%. 
Also, women in the age group of 15-19 who were already mothers/pregnant before 
18 years is significantly high in the state of West Bengal (16.4%).
Data also shows that adolescents and youth have limited awareness about sexual 
and reproductive health matters. For instance, only 15% of young men and women 
(15–24 years) reported receiving any family life or sex education.
Home to nearly 18% of the world’s population, India also has the largest number 
of people living below the international poverty line of USD 1.90 a day. The socio-
economic disparities in India increased further during the COVID-19 pandemic. 
Around 140,000,000 (14 crores) Indians lost employment during the lockdown. 
More than 45% of households across the nation reported an income drop as 
compared to the previous year.
Situated near Indo-Bhutan International Border, most people from the operational 
area of Kalchini are dependent on Tea Gardens. These tea garden workers are 
deprived of their daily wages as per the government protocol. The health-seeking 
behaviour among the Tea Garden workers is also found to be very low due to the 
lack of easily accessible health facilities in the villages of remote and forest areas.
 
The tea estates are located deep in the interiors with no Government or private 
health facilities available nearby. There is a lack of good means of transport and 
the roads leading up to the tea estates/gardens are in a bad condition. This makes 
it even more difficult for healthcare professionals to get there to render health 
services to the workers and families. An assessment of the needs of the tea garden 
community during an intervention led by FPA India in Darjeeling district showed a 
high need for SRH and general health services. 
The findings suggested a need for an integrated SRHR intervention for the health 
and well-being of tea garden workers and high demand from the community for 
continuation of the intervention, as they experience improved access to health 
care and an improvement in their health-seeking behaviour.
The second wave of covid-19 has further exposed the potholes in the healthcare 
systems. Given the restrictions on movement during the lockdown, people’s ability 
to access health care services was severely impacted. Sexual and Reproductive 
healthcare services, including maternal and child healthcare, safe abortion 
services & Gender-based violence services were among the most severely 
impacted, with the lack of access to ante-natal care & GBV care leading to a rise in 
preventable deaths. A surge in gender-based violence cases particularly domestic 
violence showed the gendered nature of the pandemic and the need for sustained 
intervention.
 
The COVID - 19 pandemic has given an opportunity to FPA India to expand the 
service coverage in Kalchni and Kolkata by engaging government and private 
players to utilize and explore the digital health solutions into practice & build 
infrastructure capacities to facilitate telemedicine & teleconsultation models to 
address the SRH needs of communities, without fragmenting the existing 
landscapes of service delivery of care.
 
FPA India Kalchini Branch covers a population of more than 10 lakhs across 
Kalchini and Madarihaat blocks and Madarihaat municipality. Besides serving a 
large population of tea garden workers and their families, the branch reaches out 
to the most vulnerable and marginalized groups that include female sex workers at

Jaigaon (Indo Bhutan Border) and Alipurduar, Persons Living with HIV AIDs 
(PLWHA) in Alipurduar. The Branch is also associated with 380 CBOs, SHGs and 
youth groups that can be mobilized for community-based interventions. In recent 
months, the Branch has also started conducting Rapid Antigen tests for COVID-19 
for all clients with symptoms/history of exposure who visit the clinic for non-
COVID essential SRH services. The local district authorities rely on the FPAI team 
in Kalchini to deliver last-mile contraceptive supplies and immunization services to 
needy populations in hilly terrains where there are no motorable roads or

FPA India Kolkata Branch covers (Urban, peri-urban, rural and slum-based

Thus FPAI has been continually responsive to the community needs as well as the 
requests from health authorities to bridge the gaps in the SRH services, leading to 
an organic evolution of the programme from a family planning intervention in the

With support from Oak, FPA India will be able to conduct capacity building and

What is the change you want to achieve from the overall project? (maximum 
300 words):
FPA India proposes to work in coordination with all partners to consolidate 
interventions in existing geographies and to invest in a need-based expansion to 
additional geographies in North and South Bengal over a period of four years.
The long-term outcome of this expansion plan is to contribute to a shift in the key 
indicators of health and empowerment for a larger cohort of vulnerable 
populations.
The proposed interventions are expected to energize the existing health system. 
Sub-optimally functional tea garden hospitals in the expanded intervention area 
(Kumargram block in Alipuduar District) identified during the baseline will be 
revived through a public-private partnership to deliver quality assured family 
planning and SRH services. Increased allocation and utilization of available 
resources from the district PIPs for family planning will expand the trained 
provider base and equipped facilities for delivering FP and SRH services in 
intervention blocks.
At the end of 4 years, the total population covered will increase by 50% from the 
baseline.
Short-term outcomes, measurable across the project span will be the number of 
persons by type of vulnerability availing critical SRH services such as 
comprehensive abortion care, institution-based safe deliveries, cervical cancer 
detection and treatment, and continuum of care for surviving gender-based 
violence.
Socio-behavioral change in the community will be measured by assessing the 
change in the proportion of men and boys accessing SRH services, including family 
planning and the proportion of youth groups actively involved in peer training and 
support to keep their neighborhoods safe from GBV.
Process documentation to capture successes and challenges in the course of 
implementation will guide replication of the project interventions in other 
geographies and serve as a tool for advocacy and resource mobilization for 
evidence-based programming.

The foundation of Environment Conservation Society (ECS) was laid in 2008 
with a 1500 km long cycle ride across the coal belt of India to take the words

of climate change to the youth. The initial years of ECS were invested in 
spreading climate consciousness across educational institutions. Between 
2010 and 2017, ECS spun off 3 social enterprises respectively to take 
decentralized energy solutions to the underserved, to address unsustainable 
agriculture through an alternative ecosystem around organic agriculture, and 
to incubate Green Entrepreneurs.
ECS’s current outreach is to over 5560 villages and urban agglomerations 
across nine states in India, ranging from Maharashtra in the west to Manipur 
in the east. One of the major projects in early days was on “Capacity Building 
for Sustainable Access to Clean Energy in Eastern India”. Since then, ECS has 
implemented 57 projects, with average duration of 18.75 months and average 
value of 7.8 million INR. This includes promotion of 60 FPOs within last few 
years. 50% of these FPOs are 15-26 months old, having average cumulative 
turnover of INR 19,64,786 and average annual turnover of INR 9,81,630 per

79% of Solar Pump beneficiaries enhanced their agricultural productions 
whereas 65% stopped using diesel pumps. In Chattisgarh, 65% beneficiaries 
enhanced their income through efficient irrigation systems.

in off-grid clean energy development, and ICC Social Impact Award in 2020 
in the area of Clean Energy. ECS is empanelled with MNRE for programs 
around energy access in rural India, empanelled and functioning as a 
training provider with PMKVY, Utkarsh Bangla-PBSSD, NISE etc. For

5c. What is the problem you want to address and what is your approach? 
How will you use Oak's funding? How did you identify the problem and 
decide your approach? If you have undertaken a theory of change exercise, or if 
you are influenced by research, policy or your own organisation’s experience, please

Evidence suggests that the tea garden districts of northern West Bengal are 
likely source and transit points along the migration and trafficking corridor. 
Alipurduar, Jalpaiguri and Darjeeling districts in particular, share porous 
borders with Nepal, Bhutan and Bangladesh, and with north-east India, 
making them likely hubs for trafficking and unsafe migration.
There are nearly 250 tea gardens across the three districts employing over 2.2 
lakh workers, around 10% of which have been declared sick or shut down. Tea 
garden workers have been systemically exploited, often denied the minimum 
Oak Application Form     7
wage or entitlements such as provident fund and gratuity. Debt is offered in 
advance and offset against wages, trapping them in a vicious cycle. Child 
labour is rampant with many children being employed at 50% of the minimum 
wage for adults in peak season. Poverty, illiteracy, school dropouts, 
unemployment, under-employment, exploitation of workers (low wages, 
unpaid wages and benefits) are issues that are commonly seen. Poor 
implementation of social protection schemes further marginalises and 
disenfranchises them. As a result, the region witnesses high rates of out-
migration, including that of young people to faraway destinations without the 
knowledge or support of their families, making them vulnerable to trafficking 
and exploitation. Between 1992 and 2015, over 2.5 lakh people migrated out 
of tea gardens.
Within the state, 21.43% of the population is multi-dimensionally poor. The 
COVID-19 pandemic has further exacerbated the crisis, with many families 
deprioritising health, nutrition, and education. The Annual State of 
Education Report for West Bengal 2021 estimates that 3.5% of children aged 
15 to 16 years have either dropped out of school or never been enrolled. The 
National Family Health Survey V also paints a sordid picture on the health 
and nutritional indicators for children, and points to a prevalence of early 
marriage and gender-based violence. From 2016-2020, 8,000 children were 
reported missing from the state every year, and children account for 75% of 
cases of victims trafficked and victims rescued in 2020. CHILDLINE data 
also points to a high number of trafficking cases – 23% of cases in 2019-20 
were reported from West Bengal. Due to the recent division of districts, child 
protection structures such as Child Welfare Committees, Anti-Human 
Trafficking Units, shelter homes etc. are inadequate. Grassroots structures 
such as Village-level Child Protection Committees are inactive as well. With 
tea gardens being privately managed and far from the district headquarters, 
it is also challenging for stakeholders to make inroads with the community 
for monitoring and vigilance. 
BAT in partnership with The Hummingbird Foundation has developed a 
Prevention of Trafficking Model that has demonstrated impact in mitigating 
trafficking in West Bengal. The premise is that collective action by key 
stakeholders–young people, parents, community-based institutions and local 
government–leads to transformative community action and ultimately 
'systems change’ to reduce the risk of trafficking. We believe that this model, 
with certain adaptations, can also serve to reduce the vulnerabilities that 
lead to unsafe migration.
We seek to roll out an integrated programme in Jalpaiguri, Alipurduar and 
Darjeeling districts (selected after gathering secondary data and inputs from 
organisations, researchers and government stakeholders working in the 
region), that draws together children (6 to 18 years), young people (18 to 24 
years), families, community-based institutions such as Self Help Groups, 
children and youth groups, School Management Communities, Tea Garden 
Associations, migrant workers and state actors; builds their capacity to take 
collective action; and bridges the gaps in convergence between stakeholders. 
We will engage with 3 lakh community members, including 1.2 lakh children 
across 8 blocks in 3 districts, and will leverage on their local knowledge and 
strengths to design interventions that are best suited to the local context. We 
will convene a safe migration and counter trafficking network of 
implementing partners and resource organisations who hold strong 
Oak Application Form     8
community linkages and knowledge at different levels (panchayat, block and 
district), collaboratively working towards a common goal of mitigating 
trafficking and unsafe migration. Key interventions that are planned include 
community mobilisation; awareness generation; collectivisation and 
strengthening of grassroots child protection structures; empowerment of 
children and young people; facilitating linkages to entitlements; vocational 
training; and capacity building, engagement and advocacy with ecosystem 
stakeholders and government systems.  
The recent notifications issued by the Ministry of Women and Child 
Development on the Mission Vatsalya Implementation Guidelines, and by the 
West Bengal Government on the Modified Guidelines for Child Protection 
Committees in West Bengal, also serve as proof that the conditions are 
favourable to work with grassroots structures. Additionally, one of the 
selected implementing partners, CINI, has been appointed by the West 
Bengal government as one of the nodal agencies responsible for 
implementing the modified guidelines.

The Problem: AIF along with BBC partners intends to address the problem 
of Low Female Labour Force Participation Rate (FLFPR) in Rural India: 
At a policy level, Ministries such as Women and Child Development have 
schemes like E-Haat, Rashtriya Mahila Kosh and Swayam Siddha Kosh project 
among others made a sincere effort to encourage women entrepreneurship. 
However, despite the positive conversations and concrete steps being taken 
around the issue, it has unfortunately not translated into a conducive 
entrepreneurship ecosystem for women. There are a multitude of barriers 
that are a hindrance to the social progress of women as entrepreneurs. These 
include but are not limited to the inherent bias against women’s business 
skills, conventional gender roles rooted in patriarchal mindsets, and lack of 
access to finance and networks, among others. Refer detailed research report 
in the attachment. Deeply embedded gender norms among other sociocultural 
issues deprive women of access to information, market knowledge, finance, 
and most importantly, paid employment.
According to a 2019 report by Google and Bain & Company, women were 
already worst hit by India’s unemployment crisis. While the overall Indian 
unemployment rate was at 7 percent before India’s March 2020 lockdown, it 
was already as high as 18 percent for women. Post the devastating impact of 
the COVID 19 on India’s economy and the widening job crises, the FLFPR of 
India dropped to a historic low of 16.1% during the July-September 2020 
quarter, the lowest among the major economies. In 2021, as the COVID 
pandemic hit jobs and the economy, less than 16.1% of Indian women were 
part of the country’s labour force (Reuters, 2021). This is among the lowest 
rates of women’s workforce participation in the world. Today, only Yemen, 
Iraq, Jordan, Syria, Algeria, Iran, and the West Bank and Gaza have lower 
FLFPR than India.
Rationale for Formative Phase: BBC partners entered into the formative 
phase with a hypothesis that the micro, small, medium enterprise (MSME) 
Oak Application Form     8
sector can play a significant role in accelerating rural women's 
entrepreneurship, such that they can leverage digital and climate-resilient 
technologies, access government schemes and provisions and lead inclusive 
value chains to demonstrate an increase in FLFPR. To do so, BBC partners’ 
main objective were to learn following broader aspects to design gender-
sensitive programs via addressing following informational gaps:
•Identification of key enabling factors for the ecosystem to address 
systemic challenges, BBC partners will identify opportunities through 
research findings and strengthen networks for accelerating growth of 
mid-high impact, mid-high potential RWE.
•Approaches to strengthen and identification of best models to scale-up 
for viable and potential RWE and micro-enterprises. We intended to 
learn how and where in the value chain we can transform the lives of 
women by offering technical wherewithal, finance/market support, and 
network connections besides building and assisting strong narrative 
support to amplify RWE voices in policy discourse.
•Landscape analysis to identify new/existing opportunities as entry points 
for RWE through continuous engagement to build their product, value 
proposition, network’s capacity, and building linkages for sustainable 
businesses.
Identification of Problems through Formative Phase (8 months): From 
June 2022 to January 2023, Start-Up!, New Delhi a private consultancy, and 
Indian Institute of Bank Management (IIBM), Guwahati a premier institute 
conducted a mixed method primary and secondary research study to ascertain 
barriers to entry for women entrepreneurs, gender norms, policy frameworks, 
motivations and efficacy of government interventions. Start Up! designed and 
conducted In-Depth Interviews (IDIs) with 25 sector experts and dialogue 
sessions with a total of 166 rural women entrepreneurs (RWE) comprising of 
96 RWE in Assam and 70 RWE in West Bengal. The RWE interviewed by Start 
Up! was largely in stages 0-3 (stage 0- seed stage, 1- self-employed or striving, 
2-start-up, 3 - stable or steadfast) of entrepreneurship. Less than 5% of RWE 
were in stage 4 of scale and sector-shaper entrepreneurship. Given the current 
scenario, it’s relevant for BBC to uplift RWE struggling in stage 0-3. Please 
refer to page 4 and from page number 24 - 33 of the research report of Start 
Up! to know more about the various stages of entrepreneurship. IIBM’s 
research (which is currently ongoing), includes both secondary and primary 
sources, across 5 districts in Assam (Kamrup Rural, Nalbari, Baksa, Goalpara 
and Sivsagar) and 3 districts in West Bengal (Coochbehar, Jalpaiguri and 
Darjeeling). There are 6 value chains that the research has focused on, namely, 
Mushroom, Piggery, Floriculture, Dairy, Handloom and Tea. IIBM has 
intensively engaged with a total of 300 Women Entrepreneurs (50 women 
entrepreneurs from each value chain) along with 20 stakeholder consultations 
which includes aggregators from Mushroom and Piggery value chain, Eri Silk 
producer company, Tea Board officials, company promoting floriculture, tea 
brokers, handloom designers and market aggregators, Micro Finance 
Institutions.
 
At RWE level, our key research and findings from pilot suggests:
•Stereotypical gender roles: In the Edelgive Foundation study, 70% of 
the 1,235 women entrepreneurs admitted that domestic workload was 
Oak Application Form     9
their primary responsibility. Most women felt that it was against their 
culture/values to let their husband/other family members partake in 
household chores.
•Top value chains for women: In the state of Assam and West Bengal 
there is a huge untapped potential for upward mobility of RWE in the 
following value chains : 
oIn Assam: Tea with a special focus on small tea growers (women) 
and handloom.
oIn Assam and West Bengal: Livestock (pig, goat, poultry).
oIn West Bengal: Dairy and agriculture.
oEco-tourism and cultural tourism were identified as areas of huge 
potential in Assam.
•Access to information through digital skills: RWE do not have 
access to appropriate information or guidance which is specific to their 
business. It needs to be mentioned that most of the RWE are so involved 
in the operationalisation of their business that their attempts to seek 
additional information are rather limited. 
oIn Assam (92%) and West Bengal (87%) RWE strongly feel that 
lack of digital skill is an obstacle in expanding their business.
•Business skills for running an enterprise: Women usually run their 
enterprise as an informal entity and are not able to implement their 
business management skills in formalising their entities owing to lack of 
skills, mentoring and coaching support. 
oIn Assam (67%) and West Bengal (60%) RWE admitted that lack of 
business knowledge and financial constraints contribute to 
stunted growth of their enterprise.
•Risk taking aptitude with respect to finance and business 
expansion:  RWE do not demonstrate risk taking aptitude while 
managing their businesses. The average investment in starting their 
enterprise is INR 18,705 and almost 20% did not invest anything 
(Edelgive Foundation study). Further from this study, it was revealed 
that only 9% of them took some loan. Women revealed that they do not 
want to take loans because of the fear of inability to repay the loan, 
which would negatively impact their family and family pride. Since 
women do not have assets in their name, a large majority (83%) also feel 
that they cannot mortgage assets to secure loans, if required. This 
majorly deters women from taking loans. Further, 1% of women have 
availed of any government scheme and this is primarily because just 
about 11% are aware of any schemes. Less than a third (29%) of those 
who applied, could avail the scheme.  Considering a large proportion of 
women did not consider applying to the schemes even if aware (79%), 
they were asked the reason behind this. Major reasons cited by these 
women were: non-availability of required documents (17%), thought the 
process is complex (15%), did not feel the need for any support (13%), 
and believed that such schemes are only to support the rich (7%). 
oThe lack of financing remains the chief concern - 90 percent of 
women entrepreneurs in the country rely on informal sources of 
financing.
Oak Application Form     10
oIn Assam (83%) and West Bengal (60%), RWE are not aware of any 
financial linkage opportunities and an abysmal percentage (10-
20%) in both states are aware of the government benefits for RWE 
(as per Start-Up study).
Our Proposed Approach: Based on the reports, research findings and our 
collaborative partner's experience in the sector, we know that women's 
entrepreneurship is a significant tool of empowerment for women, and 
through BBC we want to create an urge within the stakeholders across the 
board to support this and contribute to the cause. We intend to do this through 
ecosystem transformation by shifting the mindset (where 
entrepreneurship become aspirational), infusion of innovation, 
establishment of formal-informal RWE associations/hubs, and creation 
of new evidence based knowledge products for dissemination at two 
intervention levels:
•At the 3P (Policy-Players-Processes) Ecosystem Design Level: We 
want to align our focus on bankers, financial, social, technology 
institutions and regulators to design and develop new products and 
processes for including women entrepreneurs from diverse socio-
economic profiles in value chains.
•At an Operational Demonstration-Delivery Level: We seek 
investments for long-term training, coaching and mentorship of women 
entrepreneurs to build access to capital, markets, and technologies for 
women entrepreneurs to scale. This will help in the co-creation of 
multiplying social/ professional networks of grassroots business women 
and develop women entrepreneurs’ voices and capacity to influence 
economic and developmental agendas.
•At each level, as per the strength of respective BBC partner and 
collective effort, our findings confirmed that five thematic capitals 
most influence RWE on various stages of entrepreneurship lifecycle 
(seed, self-employed, start-up, stable and scale up) and are worth 
investing in:
1.Personhood Capital : Autonomy or self/personhood. Celebrate and 
recognize rural women entrepreneurs locally, at district-levels and 
across states through running media campaigns to share stories of the 
true contribution of RWE.
2.Knowledge Capital: Competencies or knowledge, skills. Non-
conventional business management, mentoring and business leadership 
programs – programs that are local and accessible, rooted in the RWE 
context, with faculty that comprises technical experts as well as role 
model RWE.
3.Financial Capital: Access and control over resources, or ownership of 
capital, assets tools and technology. Building narratives that build the 
confidence of bankers in RW as credit-worthy and sound investment 
opportunity.
4.Social Capital: Relationships or personal and professional social 
networks for collectivization to organize trade fairs, summits to amplify 
voice and act as pressure groups to negotiate with family, market, 
government etc.

5.Recognition Capital: Increase RWE’s reputation capital in their locus 
of control and influence through stories, films and awards.

10.  RISKS AND CHALLENGES
Oak Application Form     21
What are the risks or barriers that might prevent you from achieving your 
outcomes and how will you address these?  What are your opportunities?
We understand that achieving long-lasting and meaningful change is hard and we 
expect that the work you want to do will mean taking risks.  We encourage you to be 
open to telling us these, as well as how you will address these risks.  If some of your 
outcomes are risky, are there any incremental achievements that you could identify? 
(300 words):
1. Research suggests women who earn in rural areas are more prone to 
gender-based domestic violence as there is a constant power 
struggle as to who will own the money and spend it. The BBC program 
will have to allocate resources to enhance provision of social security 
services for existing and emerging RWE to minimize the impact of risk 
factors at the household level.
2. Entrepreneurship development is a long-term resource-intensive 
game, besides in a collaborative-based partnership disagreement on a 
mutual goal and objective can threaten the success of the program. 
Therefore, rather than focusing on short-term quantitative outputs, the 
grant program could focus on longer-term outcomes over a period of 5-
10 years since ecosystem players on the groundwork in fragmented 
ways.
3. Working with governments is imperative, yet hard. Organizations would 
need time and capacity building to focus on systems change and 
engage other stakeholders in congruent ways. Mainstream adoption of 
models will not move unless backed by data and evidence. This would 
require investment in research, business case development, and 
creating a new and strategic narrative for RWE.
4. At an operational level, forming and managing a collaborative can be a 
very time-consuming and bureaucratic process that can take away 
time from working directly on campaign issues and organization tasks. 
To mitigate this risk, AIF will encourage democratic decision-making 
and sustained action by managing power dynamics within the group 
through transparent communication and appreciative inquiry for best 
practices, strategic planning, and organizational culture to increase the 
momentum of initiatives.
5. At a socio-political level, a high turnover rate among government 
officials in the strategic positions of influence will hamper the advocacy 
agenda at the ecosystem level. This is beyond BBC partners' locus of 
control; however, efforts will be made to strengthen partnerships at 
multiple levels to sustain relationships.

about 400 volunteers. There is a Board of Directors with six members currently. 
All board members are long-time volunteers with ten to twenty years’ experience 
within AID. There is an elected Executive Board (EB) consisting of nine to ten 
members and elected for a term of two years, responsible for operation and 
coordination across chapters. There are two full time Development Coordinators 
based in the US, who spend a few months working with the partners in India as 
well. Another full time person works with our partners in eastern India and is 
based in Kolkata.
 
There are five Jeevansaathis who work full time on various issues and across India. 
They were long-time AID volunteers in the US who have gone back and started 
work at the grassroots decades ago.
 
AID works with close to 75 grassroots organizations across India on agriculture, 
health, education, gender and environmental justice.
 
Currently AID has a part time accountant based in India helping us. AID is looking 
to hire a part time person in the US as well within the next 2 months.
 
About 37% of the leadership is women. There is a conscious effort to increase 
diversity along the lines of faith, gender and caste.

6c. Describe the history and past achievements of the organisation. 
(maximum 300 words):
AID was started in 1991 as a volunteer-based organization at College Park, 
Maryland by students from India interested in community development and social 
justice. Over the years the idea behind AID appealed to many and interested 
people formed chapters in many cities in the US. Today there are 30 chapters with 
about 400 volunteers.
 
AID began by supporting grassroots NGOs working in under-served areas. As AID 
grew, so did its network at the grassroots in India. We understood the 
interconnected nature of the problems and the need to work with the most 
marginalized communities on health, education, agriculture, gender and the 
environment. Today, along with its partners, AID reaches out directly to several 
million people and strives to strengthen communities under their own leadership.
 
A few prominent efforts:
1. The Eureka educational program in Tamil Nadu was designed to improve 
the quality of education, particularly math, science and language, in 
marginalized communities. This program works with 80,000 children 
through 1,000 village educational centers throughout Tamil Nadu.
2. In 2009 Cyclone Aila inundated the islands the Sunderbans in W Bengal 
with saline water. During initial relief efforts, AID realized that reviving 
agriculture was critical to the community’s well-being. Starting with 25 
farmers in 2009 today AID has worked with 25,000 farmers and helped them 
adopt sustainable organic agriculture. It has also facilitated sales of the 
organic produce in Kolkata.
In 2018, AID initiated a community based program on watershed development in 4 
tribal districts of Jharkhand, bringing together grassroots groups and a resource 
organization. The project had a tremendous impact in its first year itself bringing 
water and greenery to some of the drought stricken villages and over the last two 
years. There has been a lot of demand from the neighboring villages but we are 
limited by funds. In these 2 years we have treated close to 3000 hectares of land

6d. Describe the current strategy of the organisation. (maximum 300 
words):
AID works with marginalized communities and groups across India to address 
issues they currently face. Through experience over the last two decades, AID has 
learnt that the issues are cross-cutting and its support should not be limited to 
single issues, but rather towards an overall dignified life for the communities.
 
Agriculture: The majority of India’s population still has livelihoods based on 
agriculture and yet, farmers have been in distress for over a decade. AID has been 
addressing the agrarian crisis in India by -
1. By providing relief to farmers in crisis: AID helps families of farmers who 
have committed suicide and those affected by natural disasters, by 
providing immediate support as well as logistical support to interface with 
the administration. AID has worked with farmers after several natural 
disasters helping them reclaim their land and restart agriculture. AID is 
working in Sunderbans as we speak to revive agriculture after Cyclone 
Amphan.
2. By promoting sustainable practices:  AID helps to train farmers to move 
away from chemical farming towards ecologically sustainable and 
economically viable techniques. AID also works with landless families and 
tribal communities to improve food security through the practice of nutrition 
gardens.
3. Advocating for farmer friendly policies:  AID works with advocacy groups to 
make governments implement farmer-friendly policies.
AID works with about 50,000 farmers mainly in West Bengal, Telangana, Andhra 
Pradesh, Maharashtra and Tamil Nadu.
 
Health: AID works with several partners across India to improve health equity and 
making quality and affordable healthcare accessible to all.
1. AID works with physicians and health workers in remote areas without 
access to healthcare - innovating in extremely low resource settings, 
training village health workers and developing appropriate technologies and 
understanding social determinants of health.
2. AID supports groups demanding access to affordable healthcare as a right 
by organizing people to hold the public health system accountable.
3. Along with its partners, AID understands that food insecurity is a major 
cause of illness and undernourished children face irreversible damage 
before the age of 3. AID supports nutritional programs for children under 3 
and works to improve the Government run Anganwadis.
AID works with healthcare partners in Chhattisgarh, Maharashtra, Odisha, Tamil 
Nadu, Madhya Pradesh and Karnataka reaching out to at least 120,000 people.

8. Cooperation
Describe the level of cooperation with other organisations and networks 
and explain how this cooperation helps achieve your goals (maximum 300 
words):
The tropical forests of sub-Himalayan Bengal in India contain rich biodiversity and 
anthropogenic wealth. Several indigenous communities, such as Rava, Mech, 
Dukpa, Garo and many Jharkhandi adivasi groups (Oraon, Kheria, Santhal, Munda, 
Baraik) live here. Lepcha, Limbu, Rai, Tamang, Sherpa and other ethnic groups 
now being generically termed as Gorkha  also live here. Many of these people were 
brought in from surrounding states and forced to stay in the ghettoized 
settlements of forest villages set up by British foresters as labor colonies in the 
late 19th and early 20th Century.
Colonial laws passed by the British Government made it unlawful for forest tribes 
to even live within the forest or source their daily needs. The British also 
converted forest land to monoculture commercial timber plantations destroying 
the forest ecosystem in the process.
After Independence the Indian Government too, created policies with similar goals. 
Even laws passed ostensibly for conservation targeted forest communities as 
“destructive” to the environment and evicted them. Illegal timber harvesting 
continued and contributed to heavy deforestation, often also victimizing forest 
communities. Today, the timber industry takes advantage of poverty among these 
communities and employs them to harvest timber from the forest thus adding to 
ongoing environmental degradation.
The Forest Rights Act (FRA), passed in 2006, gave joint ownership of forest areas 
to both the Government and indigenous forest-based communities. It empowered 
these communities to form governing institutions that would administer the forest 
together with the Forest Department. Currently, it suffers from inadequate 
implementation due to lack of awareness among the affected communities.
The main actors involved in the larger context of the work are the peoples’ social 
movement, an NGO, the forest communities and solidarity groups. Another 
stakeholder is the Forest Department.
People from the community are involved in every step of the process from site 
selection to forming the groups to participate in agriculture. The learning centers 
on the other hand will be open to all youth of 12-18 years in the community. Gram 
Sabhas will be the main agency involved in the filing of the CFR as well as 
mapping the community forest areas.

10. Evaluation
How will progress be monitored and evaluated? (maximum 300 words):
A monitoring team will be formed for each project site, consisting of community 
leaders and project coordinators. This team will meet the communities each month 
and hold review meetings every 2 months. Gram Sabhas will also be monitoring 
the work at their respective sites. At the inter site level, the existing secretariat of 
the group will do the monitoring on a monthly basis
Additionally, for the learning centers, the monitoring and evaluation team will 
include civil society members and solidarity groups who will support in developing 
the learning modules. There would be 2 evaluations in a year for the learning 
centers. The first year would be focussed on understanding the efficacy and 
acceptance of the learning modules. The feedback will be used for modifications 
and adjustments.
AID volunteers will also carry out an annual evaluation by being on site as they 
have for the past 5 years.
The evaluation questions for the livelihood part would be to see how the 
community is bonding and making decisions, if they have been able to 
operationalize and start agriculture and how many times they are meeting and 
interacting with their respective Gram Sabhas.
For the learning centers, the regularity of the centers and the attendance in them 
would indicate the acceptance of the learning modules. Further on in the program, 
interactions with the youth will give an idea about their understanding of the local 
environment and care for it. Beyond that, it would be important to eventually see 
the youth participating in the Gram Sabha meetings and playing an active role in 
it.
For the Forest Rights component, we will need to see how many resource maps 
are developed for the community forests, followed by how many CFRs are filed. 
Finally, it would be important to see if the community is using the community 
forest land in a way that is beneficial to them.
To understand the impact, we would look at the following:
•Number of people participating in agriculture, learning at each site
•Change in the production of vegetables over the years at each site
•Observing the increase/decrease in the participation of women and out 
migrants
•Change in the mortality rate of the plantations
•Forest area mapped and the number of Community Forest Rights 
application
•Number of learners in each center

4g. Summarise the project’s ultimate goal(s) (maximum 200 words):
( NOT REQUIRED FOR CORE SUPPORT GRANTS)
The MRC (Migrants Resilience Collaborative) is India’s largest grassroots-led 
initiative steered by our Indian organisation partner, Jan Sahas. Initially, the 
program has a period of three years and will span over 100 districts, of which 15-
20 have high apparel-based migration, to sustainably impact 10 million migrants 
over five years. We aim to enable systemic improvements that build socio-economic 
resilience for over 139 million migrants.
The MRC has a strong affinity with Oak’s commitment to address global, social and 
environmental issues, particularly among the disadvantaged. The MRC enables the 
Oak Foundation to advance these goals both systemically and at scale, whilst 
leveraging the commitment of large institutional funders such as Omidyar 
Network, Dell Foundation, H.T. Parekh Foundation, and Godrej Group, at a time of 
heightened need.
More than 95% of migrants that we support belong to Scheduled Castes, 
Scheduled Tribes, and other backward classes. We aim to address the inequalities 
within these communities.
In addition, several components of MRC’s strategy and approach are aligned, 
including but not limited to:  
1) Building agency of migrant families and safeguarding labour rights.
2) Working with migrants specifically engaged in the construction and textiles 
sector.
3) Working with industry including the textiles industry to build an inclusive 
economy.
4) Focusing on systemic improvements.

6c. Describe the history and past achievements of the organisation. 
(maximum 300 words):
Jan Sahas has been working with the most excluded communities for over two 
decades, providing support on issues such as prevention and response to gender-
based violence, forced labour, and caste-based manual scavenging. This includes: 
1) Uniquely blending our grassroots-led approach with a focus on scale, facilitating 
direct support in ~60 districts across nine states of India, serving~2,000,000 
women and girls across program areas, tracking >200,000 migrant workers, 
rescuing >4.2k bonded and child labourers, and delivering >128,000 entitlements 
to migrants. During the initial months of the COVID-19 pandemic, Jan Sahas 
worked with 42 non-profits across 19 states in India to address needs of >1 million 
migrant families through immediate relief support. There have been a few projects 
that have been instrumental in achieving this. These include: an Initiative to 
substantially reduce the practice of Forced and Child Labour (F&CL) in cotton 
production in Madhya Pradesh, India; Fighting Forced Labour with Adivasi and 
Dalit communities in South Asia; Nirmaan Mazdoor Sashaktikaran Karyakram 
(NMSK) and Bandhuaa Majdoor Mukti Abhiyan.
2) With support from CBOs (Community Based Organisations), Jan Sahas has 
influenced key legislation (The Landmark Prohibition of Employment as Manual 
Scavengers and their Rehabilitation Act, 2013), and participates on various 
government working commissions (for example, Government of Madhya Pradesh’s 
commission on migrant workers, NITI Aayog’s Working Group for Social Justice 
and Empowerment to support on migration).  Jan Sahas’ promoted CBO, Rashtriya 
Garima Abhiyan and has influenced several initiatives at departmental and state 
level on the issue of manual scavenging and gender justice. 
Jan Sahas aims to address the issues faced specifically by migrant families at an 
unprecedented scale and crucially it has quickly emerged into new geographical 
areas. Thus, Jan Sahas believes in a collaborative approach, partnering with CBOs 
with similar values across the country to facilitate direct support through its 
interventions.

focuses on quality and continues to ensure strong accountability to our 
communities. Based on our learnings from our projects in the space of migration,

Since October 2020, we have started working using our current operating model 
on the theme in 50 districts and supporting 40 additional civil society 
organizations to intervene in another 50 districts. We are also piloting innovations 
to work at greater scale and update our operating models over the next five years.

10 million workers along with their information based on which of the three 
services (social security, responsible recruitment, and worker protection) they opt

6e. What problems are you addressing? What are the opportunities and 
challenges in addressing these problems? (maximum 600 words):
There are an estimated 139 million internal migrant workers in India. Despite 
being large contributors to India’s GDP, migrant workers face systematic 
disenfranchisement due to power imbalance & high vulnerability. As a result, they 
face three principal challenges: Non-recognition by states, & lack of social security 
leading to debt and poverty.
Under the proposed project we intend to use the corridor approach (work at 
source & destination together). The proposed geographic focus is the West 
Bengal migration corridor. We have selected 4 high prevalence districts of 
migration in West Bengal (Murshidabad, Nadia, Bardhaman and Birbhum) 
as source districts & Mumbai-Suburban and Delhi-NCR region as 
destination areas.
According to Census 2011, West Bengal ranks fourth among states from where 
people migrate to for work and employment. Approximately 80% of work-migrants 
from the state migrate to Maharashtra (45.3%) and Delhi-NCT (34%). Research 
shows that much of the migrant population in the country belong to lower-income 
quintile groups and are likely to be deprived of social security. 
In 2004-05, approximately 35% of workers in rural West Bengal were out of social 
security coverage and this increased to 50% in 2011-12. Furthermore, according 
to a study on the access to flagship programme benefits and public services in 
West Bengal, it was found that access to benefits was critically low due to lack of 
awareness, procedural complexities, harassment, apathy of state officials and 
opportunity cost being higher than benefit. 
The access to benefits is critically limited due to a lack of awareness, delay, 
procedural complexities, harassment, insensitivity of implementing officials and 
elected representatives, adverse selection & opportunity cost being higher than 
benefit. Given the high rates of poverty, out-migration and poor access to 
entitlement, it is critical that concerted efforts are placed into improving the social 
security coverage in West Bengal.
We decided that launching the MRC now would have the most impact for the 
following reasons:
Unprecedented political will and demand for Jan Sahas’ support on 
migrants’ issue: Post-COVID, migrant welfare has become a major political issue:
1) Central and State governments have embarked on social security registration 
drives, several have set up migrant welfare commissions. The central government 
accepted $1 billion credit fund from the World Bank to create a social registry for 
Grant Application Form, July 1 20139
strengthening social security.
2) Jan Sahas has partnered with multiple governments (for example, Delhi, 
Madhya Pradesh, Telangana) and we are discussing partnerships with several 
others. Partnering with West Bengal and Maharashtra has been considered in the 
project plan.
Unprecedented industry willingness to support migrants, including Jan 
Sahas’s mission: Industry bodies such as CREDAI and FICCI have taken up the 
cause of social security as a trust-building measure and to improve the value 
proposition for workers. Four of the largest Indian construction companies (L&T, 
Godrej, Lodha, Mahindra & Mahindra) co-signed an open letter with Jan Sahas, 
advocating for governments to deliver on its policies including benefits for migrant 
workers and committing to partner with government and civil society.
Demonstrated interest from philanthropy and civil society to support 
migrant workers: Large funders such as Omidyar Network, Azim Premji 
Philanthropic Initiatives, Michael & Susan Dell Foundation, HT Parekh Foundation 
have recalibrated strategies to support migrant families. 
With both need and the potential for high impact, the MRC seeks to harness the 
opportunity to capitalize on opportunity and address systemic at scale. In the 6 
months of operations MRC has registered 1,036,626 migrant households of which 
424,400 were women led, filled 1,192,936 social security applications, ensured 
benefits received to 847,556 migrant individuals. While, the helpline received 2871 
and 753 cases were registered through different sources (helpline and field). 
We are fully cognisant of the threats facing the program and have established a 
plan to address them:
1) Current and future FCRA law amendments hinder sub-granting funds to 
partner CBOs.
2) Reduced bargaining power of migrants and the industry’s willingness to 
support reforms due to added vulnerability of migrants. Additionally, the impact 
of the pandemic has sparked a change in labour codes.

CPF was established in the backdrop of realising the goal of forest dependent

with 32 NGO partners. They were spread over 12 districts in the three regions 
of undivided Andhra Pradesh, representing 80,800 households and protecting 
over 1,00,000 (one lakh) hectares of forest.
CPF understood that forest-based livelihoods alone not sufficient for 
enhancing the incomes and conserving the natural resources. It was also 
realized that tribal communities were unable to access basic services and 
social security schemes because of remoteness and apathy of officials. This led 
CPF to work with communities and government on entitlements and 
sustainable NRM based livelihoods through community-based institutions.

5c. What is the problem you want to address and what is your approach? 
How will you use Oak's funding? How did you identify the problem and

Alienation of tribals from the forest has dwindled their livelihoods, food 
security and increased poverty. It reduced their involvement in sustainable 
forest management and harvesting practices of NTFP.  This led to adverse 
impact on conservation of forest eco-system. Lack of awareness and skills to 
have constructive and collaborative engagement with government reduced 
access to avail rights and entitlements.
Over two decades, CPF worked with indigenous and other resource poor 
communities in Andhra Pradesh, Telangana and Odisha. The organization 
facilitated the communities to access rights on forest resources and supported 
Oak Application Form     7
them in sustainable natural resource management through promoting 
community institutions. This enabled them to reap the collective advantages 
of sustainable extraction and value addition of NTFP, participatory natural 
resource management and access entitlements from government.
CPF undertakes works that aligns with its vision. Before planning any 
intervention, action research is undertaken to analyze and identify the change 
and roles to be played by CPF and other stakeholders. The intervention is 
planned in a collaborative approach with defined objectives and outcomes 
involving community in planning, implementing and monitoring, enabling 
them towards sustainability.
CPF strategically works with government to build rapport between 
communities and concerned departments for leveraging funds for community 
needs. It appraises them about its work for possible replication.
CPF strives to ensure equity and equality in its functioning with women 
playing equal role in all its interventions. It facilitates in building their 
capacities, gain access and ownership over resources and become decision-
makers.
A scoping study was conducted in West Bengal, while interacting with relevant 
stakeholders to comprehend the prevailing policies, programs and their 
implementation in proposed project locations.
Based on the observations from the scoping study, CPF proposes to work in 
Ranibandh block, Bankura district of West Bengal because of its dense forest 
and high tribal population (Savara-PVTG, Santhal, Munda, Singh Sardar etc) 
with 47.1 % (Census, 2011). The main source of livelihood is agriculture, 
livestock and NTFP and majority are small and marginal farmers depending 
on rain fed agriculture. Though the district receives around 1400 mm rainfall, 
yet cultivation of crop primarily depends on constricted period of erratic 
rainfall. Due to lack of proper water harvesting structures, water percolation 
to the ground is minimal and irrigation facility is low. The farmers are 
predominantly into mono crop cultivation i.e., paddy. The farming practices 
are inorganic leading to high input cost and negative environmental impacts.
The Sundarban estuary with mangrove forest is inhabited by the resource poor 
and vulnerable communities. Owing to historical reasons coupled with climatic 
extremities and natural calamities, it remains one of the extremely 
underdeveloped places with 34 % below poverty line. Livelihood depends on 
agriculture (24.37%), un-organized labour (36.35%), house hold industries 
(4.86%) and others (34.42%) including fishery, forest resource collection [1]. 
The inhabitants of the region are also extremely vulnerable in various physical 
and socio-economic indicators.
In Sunderban, CPF propose to work on enhancing access of entitlements to 
communities in Sandeshkhali-I Block of North 24 Parganas District due to the 
high social vulnerability of the region with 25.95% of the population belonging 
to ST and 30.90% belonging to SC communities.
CPF vision and past experience of working with tribal and resource poor 
communities and Oak foundation’s focus areas to support the indigenous 
communities in West Bengal will bring in synergy in advancing the rights, 
availing entitlements and livelihood development in the proposed area of 
intervention.
Oak Application Form     8
Oak Foundation funding will be used for facilitating the communities to 
adopt crop diversification through improved agriculture practices, enhance 
livelihoods and enable the communities to access their rights and 
entitlements.

This is the most important part of your application, as it is your opportunity to explain

ambitious but also achievable.  
Overall objective / Goal
Improving livelihoods of tribals, resource poor and other vulnerable 
communities through promoting sustainable natural resource management 
and enhancing access to entitlements by building linkages with the 
Government institutions in 25 forest fringe villages of Ranibandh block of 
Bankura district and 12 villages in Sandeshkhali-I block of North 24 Parganas.
Specific Objectives
1. Formation and strengthening the village level institutions/groups while 
ensuring women leadership in these institutions
2. Promoting agro-ecological practices, crop diversification and water 
resource development for food & nutritional security amongst male and 
female farmers
3. Enhancing access to alternative livelihoods among landless, resource 
poor and other forest dependent communities while keeping with special 
emphasis on women farmers
4. Enabling project communities to access and avail their constitutional 
rights and entitlements
Background and Context
Given the experience of working in watershed project locations, CPF propose 
to work in the watershed areas in Randibandh block of Bankura district 
Oak Application Form     9
covering 25 villages of Ranibandh, Barikul and Rautora Gram Panchayats. The 
Integrated Watershed Management Programme, West Bengal was 
implemented in the proposed project locations in the year 2011-12 covering a 
total geographical area of 8819 ha of which the total treatable area was 5398 
ha. It was observed that the benefits of creation of these watershed structures 
could not be sustain due to lack of emphasis on improved agriculture 
practices, creation and strengthening of farmers institutions and bringing in 
convergence of various government schemes for the benefit of tribal and other 
resource poor households.
The present project aims to address the above-mentioned gaps. And it would 
demonstrate how the watershed projects in the forest fringe villages could be 
taken to the next level to reap the benefits and also sustain the initiatives 
through community participation.
The Sundarban estuary with mangrove forest is inhabited by the resource poor 
and vulnerable communities, owing to historical reasons coupled with climatic 
extremities and natural calamities. The inhabitants of the region are also 
extremely vulnerable in various physical and socio-economic indicators 
including infrastructure, food security, healthcare, education, drinking water 
and sanitation. It was observed that, livelihoods based on natural resources 
alone will not effectively sustain the people of the region. CPF proposes to 
work on enhancing access to entitlements for communities covering 12 
villages of Boyermari-I, Boyermani-II and Hatgachi Gram Panchayats of 
Sandeshkhali-I Block of North 24 Parganas District.
Thus, the project has immense potential for scaling up and replication in other 
socio-economically vulnerable regions of West Bengal.
CPF’s Role
The organization works with community institutions and capacitates them in 
appropriate skills as well as federates them at different levels for reaping 
collective advantages with regard to accessing their rights on forest resources 
and supports them in sustainable natural resource management including 
forest resources. Sustainable extraction of Non timber forest produce, value 
addition at the community level, participatory resource monitoring, water 
resource development, facilitating agro ecological practices in their lands, and 
helping them to access entitlements and proper services from the government 
departments are some of the activities the organization undertakes, to address 
the problems of the communities.
While recognizing that women lack decision making and negotiation skills, 
mobility, identity and self -esteem and access to and control over resources 
and assets, CPF focuses on building their leadership through all its 
interventions.
Primary stakeholders are the tribal and resource poor communities who 
mostly belong to the small and marginal farmer category
Secondary stakeholders are the various government departments, traders and 
other service providers (who are engaged to provide certain services to the 
community).
1. Formation and strengthening the village level institutions/groups
a. Formation and strengthening of Tribal Farmers Service Centre 
(TFSC)
Oak Application Form     10
The Tribal Farmer’s Service Centres will be formed with two representatives 
from each small group as committee members. CPF ensures that 50 percent 
are women in these committees with leadership role in the committee. The

Knowledge services, information about government schemes, providing

b. Formation and strengthening of Village Coordination Groups (VCGs)
CPF initiated a concept called Village Coordination Groups (VCGs) during the 
year 2016. In the VCGs, two members from each of the existing CBOs (one 
female and one male) are grouped at the habitation level along with Sarpanch 
and one ward member. The purpose is to facilitate to access entitlements to 
all eligible individuals and also seek support for community needs. Awareness 
regarding various new government schemes, policies for tribals including 
Forest Rights Act also discussed in the VCGs. VCG meets once in a month and 
discusses about the follow-up to be done with regard to the access/petitions 
submitted. It not only supports the individual CBOs on issues identified but 
also discusses about the community level issues and requirements such as – 
repair to PHC centre, approach road, drinking water etc.
At each of the 37 project habitations VCGs will be formed. Women 
representatives from CBOs will become leaders in the VCGs formed. Thus, 
VCG will contribute in filling the gap between the communities, Panchayats 
and block officials.
The VCGs provide services to all eligible households (as per baseline) access 
different government schemes of West Bengal like Khadya Saathi Scheme 
(RKSY-1 & 2), Duara Sarkar (campaign on 18 schemes with delivery at door

Planning, Monitoring and Evaluation system of CPF are based on participatory
